headline: Excerpt: '3'
summary: The new CBS dating show begins on Thursday.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS WITH MARTINA McBRIDE Ms. McBride, above, hosts this annual concert dedicated to promoting adoption and telling uplifting stories about children who found families. Between musical performances from Mary J. Blige, Justin Bieber, Gavin DeGraw and others, families that have adopted discuss the experience. One story is from the Hendersons of Helena, Ala., who were inspired to adopt their daughter Brittney after watching a previous presentation of ''A Home for the Holidays.'' Denise Richards, who adopted her daughter Eloise, will also reflect on her decision. 4 P.M. (Showtime2) DORIAN GRAY (2009) Claiming his inheritance, Dorian Gray (Ben Barnes) moves into a home in Victorian London, where he meets the aristocrat and dissolute hedonist Lord Henry Wotton (Colin Firth), who corrupts the newcomer into joining his lifestyle of wild abandon. To keep the good times from stopping, Dorian wishes to preserve his youthful looks forever, so he makes a deal with the devil: for the price of his soul he will show no signs of aging, but a painted portrait of him will reflect the toll of time and a life of indulgence. The portrait becomes as grotesque as his excesses, and when Dorian falls in love with a woman, he must keep the painting a secret. The movie is based on a novel by Oscar Wilde.

headline: Twitter's 'Amazing Race' Assist
summary: Just how attuned are television producers these days to chatter about their shows on Twitter? So much so that they watched in awe, half a world away, as two Twitter users saved a team on ''The Amazing Race'' from being kicked off the CBS show. The 19th season of the race-around-the-world reality show had just started taping in June in Southern California when one of the contestants, Kaylani Paliotta, unknowingly left her passport at a gas station. The camera crew with Ms. Paliotta and her teammate, Lisa Tilley, noticed what had been left behind, but could not tell them. Instead, they sent word to producers at the next stop, Los Angeles International Airport, to expect a premature end to the team's race.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION The series travels to Fayette County, Iowa, to surprise Audrey Gibbs, who, seven months after the death of her husband, had a brain aneurysm that left her legally blind. Doctors cannot predict whether she will lose her sight completely. Unable to continue her work as a cosmetologist, she has become a massage therapist, which doesn't require sight, the better to support her six children. In this, the penultimate episode, Ty Pennington (above, foreground, with Ms. Gibbs) and his crew remodel the family's farmhouse, which has no working toilet and a caved-in ceiling. The musician Bret Michaels lends a hand. 7:15 A.M. (Sho2) THE LAST PLAY AT SHEA (2010) The histories of Shea Stadium, the Mets, Billy Joel (below) and New York City itself across four and a half decades intersect in this documentary from Paul Crowder, which focuses on Mr. Joel's concerts on July 16 and July 18, 2008 -- the last performances given in the stadium, which was torn down the next year. ''For the July 18 concert,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, Paul McCartney ''miraculously appeared, having been whisked through customs at Kennedy International Airport after a flight from London that had been allowed to land early. He was sped to the stadium by a motorcade in 11 minutes and driven onto the field in time to perform by Pete Flynn, the dedicated groundskeeper who had driven the Beatles to the same stage 43 years earlier.'' Mr. Holden added: '' 'If it weren't for the Beatles,' Mr. Joel declares, 'I wouldn't do what I do.' Call it perfect symmetry. The final number, 'Let It Be,' rings as a sweet valedictory to all the struggle, the teamwork and the glory captured in this wonderful film.'' In the film ''The Love We Make'' (2011), at 11 on Showtime, Albert Maysles, Bradley Kaplan and Ian Markiewicz capture Mr. McCartney's experiences in New York City after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and his performance the next month with Elton John, Mr. Joel and David Bowie in the ''Concert for New York City'' at Madison Square Garden. Mr. McCartney had been on the runway at Kennedy when the attacks occurred.

headline: RECORD RATINGS
summary: The Jets' 28-21 win over the New England Patriots averaged 43.5 million viewers, which CBS projected as the most ever to watch a divisional playoff game based on records going back to 1987. The peak viewership of 52.3 million occurred from 7:30 to 7:48 p.m. The second-most-viewed game of the weekend was Pittsburgh's 31-24 victory over Baltimore on Saturday, also on CBS, which attracted an average of 34 million viewers. RICHARD SANDOMIR

headline: Sheen Loses His Role In TV Show
summary: 8:51 p.m. | Updated Throughout his recent rants about CBS, Warner Brothers and his own drug use, Charlie Sheen insisted that he was ready to return to work on the hit sitcom ''Two and a Half Men.'' On Monday, Warner Brothers disagreed, firing Mr. Sheen from the show, claiming the actor's ''statements, conduct and condition prevented him from performing his essential duties.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) TONY BENNETT: DUETS II Soon after his 85th birthday on Aug. 3, Mr. Bennett released ''Duets II,'' the follow-up to his Grammy-winning album ''Duets: An American Classic,'' made in honor of his 80th. ''Duets II'' started atop the Billboard 200 chart, making Mr. Bennett the oldest artist to reach No. 1. This ''Great Performances'' presentation captures recording sessions in Los Angeles, London, New York, Nashville and at the home of Andrea Bocelli in Italy. It also features performances including ''Body and Soul,'' with Amy Winehouse, in what would be her last recorded track; ''The Lady Is a Tramp,'' with Lady Gaga (above, with Mr. Bennett); ''Speak Low,'' with Norah Jones; ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' with Faith Hill; ''It Had to Be You,'' with Carrie Underwood; and ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' with Willie Nelson. ''Duets II'' has been nominated for three Grammy Awards, including for best pop duo/group. 7:15 A.M. (IFC) LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE (2006) Abigail Breslin, right, received an Academy Award nomination for her portrayal of the unlikely preteen princess Olive Hoover in this comedy about a family of misfits determined to get a 7-year-old to a beauty pageant. Alan Arkin won an Oscar for best supporting actor as the heroin-snorting grandfather who helps put Olive's talent routine over the top. Greg Kinnear and Toni Collette play the parents driving the ravaged family and its equally dilapidated Volkswagen bus. Steve Carell portrays Olive's suicidal gay uncle, and Paul Dano is the Hoovers' teenage son, who has decided to keep his mouth shut about the situation. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''a tale about genuine faith and manufactured glory that unwinds in the American Southwest, but more rightly takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.''

headline: OFF THE AIR, AND ON | MAY 15-21
summary: THE NEWS After 45 years as the spirited host of his annual Labor Day telethon to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association, Jerry Lewis, 85, said the 2011 broadcast will be his last. BEHIND THE NEWS Starting on a single New York station in 1966, Mr. Lewis built the event into a high-wattage national charity juggernaut lasting 22 often maudlin hours and raising more than $1 billion over the years. But its hold on the spotlight has ebbed in recent decades as charity megaconcerts, pledge weeks and celebrity appeals have proliferated; the show is being shortened and reformatted.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) A SMILE AS BIG AS THE MOON (2012) John Corbett, above, stars as Mike, a high school football coach and special-education teacher who takes a class of disabled students to NASA's Space Camp, in this Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation, based on the memoir by Mike Kersjes. Mike's inspiration: Ben (Peter ten Brink), a boy with Down syndrome who dreams of becoming an astronaut. Jessy Schram plays Robynn McKinney, a fellow teacher who helps Mike buck the opposition of school administrators. And Cynthia Watros is Dr. Deborah Barnhart, the Space Camp official who is skeptical that Mike's class will be able to hold its own with some of the brightest science students from across the country. The cast includes young actors with Down syndrome, autism and learning disabilities. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. Rick Scott, the Republican governor of Florida, offers a preview of Tuesday's primary. Carlos Gutierrez, a former commerce secretary, and Antonio Villaraigosa, the mayor of Los Angeles, talk about the Latino vote. And Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, responds to the State of the Union address.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 A.M. (MoreMax) GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING (2003) This feature directorial debut from Peter Webber, based on the novel by Tracy Chevalier, imagines the life of Griet (Scarlett Johansson, right), a teenage maid in the Netherlands in the 1660s who becomes the muse for Johannes Vermeer (Colin Firth) and is immortalized in one of his most famous paintings. ''Ms. Johansson is photographed so that her skin is as opalescent as her earring, but the movie is opaque,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''It is an earnest, obvious melodrama with no soul, filled with the longing silences that come after a sigh.'' Yet, he added, the film is ''a dexterous and absorbing visual re-creation of the lighting and the look that Vermeer achieved in his work.'' The movie received Oscar nominations for art direction, set decoration, cinematography and costume design. 9:15 A.M. (HBO2) CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS (1989) When the mistress (Anjelica Huston) of Judah Rosenthal (Martin Landau, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a Manhattan ophthalmologist, threatens to go public with their affair and his unethical financial dealings, he hires his mobster brother (Jerry Orbach) to kill her in this movie from Woody Allen, who received best director and best screenplay nominations. Mr. Allen also plays Cliff Stern, a married documentarian infatuated by another woman (Mia Farrow). Sam Waterston is Judah's best friend, a rabbi; Alan Alda is a successful television producer and Cliff's brother-in-law. ''The wonder of 'Crimes and Misdemeanors' is the facility with which Mr. Allen deals with so many interlocking stories of so many differing tones and voices,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. ''The film cuts back and forth between parallel incidents and between present and past with the effortlessness of a hip, contemporary Aesop.''

headline: At News Corp., A Plan to Sever Publishing Arm
summary: After years of defending its financially underperforming newspapers, News Corporation is now in talks to break up the company and sever its publishing assets, like The Wall Street Journal, The Times of London and The New York Post, from its lucrative entertainment units. The spinoff proposal will be reviewed by the News Corporation board on Wednesday and a decision to split up the company could be made as early as Thursday.

headline: ''Two and a Half Men'' Goes on Hiatus
summary: 8:52 p.m. | Updated CBS and Warner Brothers Television said on Friday that their sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' would take a production hiatus, citing the decision of co-star Charlie Sheen to enter a rehabilitation facility. In a brief statement issued by the network and the studio, as well as Chuck Lorre, the comedy's creator and executive producer, they said, ''We are profoundly concerned for his health and well-being, and support his decision.''

headline: As Gay Marriage Gains Ground in Nation, New Hampshire May Revoke Its Law
summary: As same-sex marriage supporters celebrate victories in Washington and Maryland this month, they are keeping a wary eye on New Hampshire, where lawmakers may soon vote to repeal the state's two-year-old law allowing gay couples to wed. A repeal bill appears to have a good chance of passing in the State House and Senate, which are both controlled by Republicans. The bigger question is whether they can muster enough votes to overcome a promised veto from Gov. John Lynch, a Democrat.

headline: More Big Names Join Philharmonic's 'Company'
summary: After the month that Jon Cryer just lived through, you'd think he'd had his fill of toxic bachelors. Instead, Mr. Cryer will spend some time away from ''Two and a Half Men,'' the CBS comedy on which he stars (starred?) with Charlie Sheen, in a semistaged production of ''Company'' for the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Cryer will play the role of David, a pot-puffing chum of the perennially single protagonist, Robert, who will be portrayed by his CBS colleague Neil Patrick Harris, representatives for the Philharmonic said on Monday. Also joining these ''Company'' performances, which will run from April 7 through 9, are Christina Hendricks, an Emmy Award nominee for ''Mad Men,'' who will be trading in her role as a tough-as-nails office manager to play the airhead flight attendant, April; Katie Finneran, a Tony Award-winner for ''Promises, Promises,'' who will play the motor-mouthed bride-to-be, Amy; and Craig Bierko (''The Music Man'') as Peter, one of Robert's amorous married friends. The cast will be rounded out by Aaron Lazar as Paul; Jill Paice (''The 39 Steps'') as Susan; Jennifer Laura Thompson (''Lend Me a Tenor'') as Jenny; and Chryssie Whitehead (''A Chorus Line'') as Kathy.

headline: Analysis: Comebacks and Consequences on Signing Day
summary: National signing day has turned into a made-for-television affair, with recruits selecting their universities' caps before crowds of friends and family members and an audience at home. The 2012 version of this annual rite yielded a few additional themes. The strong recruiting classes signed by Ohio State and Miami on Wednesday showed that prospects are willing to overlook N.C.A.A. sanctions (or the threat of penalties, in Miami's case) if the coach can sell the program.

headline: GAMES TO WATCH
summary: NO. 3 OKLAHOMA VS. NO. 11 TEXAS IN DALLAS Noon Eastern, ABC

headline: Girlhood Memories of Another Ship Turned on Its Side
summary: First thing Saturday, Pierette Domenica Simpson's boyfriend called and said, ''Go online. You'll be interested.'' She checked the headlines. Something about an Italian ocean liner in trouble. The way the ship was listing, the report that it was taking on water, the light from the cabins reflecting in the water, the passengers' struggle to clamber into lifeboats - everything seemed so familiar. ''I thought, 'How can this be? It's 56 years later,' '' Ms. Simpson said.

headline: After a Short and Stormy Tenure as a Current TV Anchor, Olbermann Is Fired
summary: 10:06 p.m. | Updated For nearly a year now, Al Gore and Joel Hyatt have been building their liberal cable news channel, Current TV, with the mercurial television anchorman Keith Olbermann at its center. This week, the center collapsed.

headline: A Foreign Correspondent in Nazi Germany Who Interpreted It for the World
summary: THE LONG NIGHT William L. Shirer and 'The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich'

headline: Romney Assures Evangelicals That Their Values Are His, Too
summary: LYNCHBURG, Va. -- Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life. At a graduation speech at the college, founded by the evangelical leader Jerry Falwell, Mr. Romney made the case that he is bound theologically and politically to the same belief and value system as Christian conservatives, though he never explicitly mentioned his Mormon faith.

headline: For Tennis Channel, Lost Viewers
summary: Cablevision and Verizon FiOS customers abruptly lost their access to Tennis Channel on Sunday midway through the United States Open. The dispute revolves around a new contract between Tennis Channel and the National Cable Television Cooperative, a consortium of cable operators that Cablevision and Verizon belong to. The deal, which went into effect after midnight, requires its members to place Tennis Channel on a broad digital basic level - or not at all.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) WORK IT Lee Standish (Ben Koldyke), a family guy, and his friend Angel Ortiz (Amaury Nolasco), a ladies' man, lose their jobs at Pontiac when the company folds in this new series. But then Lee discovers that a drug company is seeking female sales representatives, so he attends an interview in heels, a skirt and makeup. When he lands a job, he takes Angel, also in drag, to this workplace of women, where their colleagues seem to accept them. Everyone, that is, but Grace (Rebecca Mader), a manager, who knows something isn't right. It doesn't help when Angel falls for his boss, Vanessa (Rochelle Aytes). Or that Lee can't disclose his feminine subterfuge to his wife, Connie (Beth Lacke), or their daughter, Kat (Hannah Sullivan). But they sure do like this newfangled Mr. Sensitivity. (Above, from left, Mr. Koldyke, Mr. Nolasco, Kate Reinders, Ms. Mader and Kirstin Eggers.) In the premiere of ''Celebrity Wife Swap,'' at 9, Steffanie Sampson, engaged to the drug- and anger-addled actor Gary Busey, trades lives for 10 days with Gayle Haggard, married to the Rev. Ted Haggard, who in 2006 resigned as senior pastor from his New Life Church and as president of the National Association of Evangelicals after admitting to using crystal meth and having sex with a masseur. And in the winter premiere of ''Body of Proof,'' at 10, Dr. Megan Hunt (Dana Delany) scrutinizes the details in the case of a bride who plummeted to her death on her wedding day. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER In this Season 13 premiere, 10 pairs of contestants show up at the ranch and discover that not only will they be split from their loved ones, but they must also compete against them. Bob Harper and Dolvett Quince return as the trainers, guiding the competitors toward a $250,000 grand prize. Alison Sweeney hosts.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (BBC America) MISTRESSES This soap opera about four women in Bristol, England, balancing friendship and extramarital intrigue, left American viewers dangling when Season 2 wrapped in May 2009. Now it returns for a four-episode finale. When last we saw the girlfriends, Katie (Sarah Parish), the doctor who helped her terminally ill married lover commit suicide in Season 1 (and then went on to have an affair with his son and then with an old, also-married flame), was about to find out if her latest beau would sweep her off to Australia in an act of forgiveness. Trudi (Sharon Small), who thought her husband had died in the terror attacks of Sept. 11 and discovered that he was in fact still alive, had gotten married to a man who also wasn't what he seemed. Jessica (Shelley Conn, above), a pregnant event planner in an open marriage, learned that her spouse had decided to be monogamous. Or so he said. And Siobhan (Orla Brady) was relegated to single-mother status after struggling with infertility in her marriage, then getting pregnant by a colleague -- which sent her husband packing. In this Season 3 premiere the women are summoned to Katie's house, where their icy demeanor suggests that they are friends no more. Joanna Lumley joins the cast as Vivienne, Katie's imperious mother. 1 P.M. (HBO Signature) SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE (2003) In this double bill from the director Nancy Meyers, a music executive in his 60s (Jack Nicholson) with a fondness for young women finds the rug pulled out from under him when he falls for the mother (Diane Keaton, above) of a woman he's dating (Amanda Peet). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Mr. Nicholson and Ms. Keaton sparred ''with the freedom of professionals with nothing left to prove, and Mr. Nicholson has the gentlemanly grace to step aside and let Ms. Keaton claim the movie.'' He added, ''She in turn brings out the best in everyone around her.'' At 3:15, in ''It's Complicated,'' Meryl Streep plays Jane Adler, a successful California restaurateur who is about to settle into life as an empty nester when she is blindsided by advances from her ex-husband (Alec Baldwin), who had left her a decade earlier for a pretty young thing (Lake Bell). Steve Martin is thrown into the mix as the architect overseeing the renovation of Jane's house, and he is not without his own charms. The truth, Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times, is ''that everyone needs a little coddling, which could be the key to Ms. Meyers's peculiar talent: She pampers her audience shamelessly.''

headline: Parcells Returns to a Familiar Role
summary: Bill Parcells was hired by ESPN as an N.F.L. studio analyst on Wednesday. Again. Parcells's roster of coaching and TV jobs is nearly as long as the list of game shows hosted by Wink Martindale. The ex-Giants, ex-Patriots, ex-Jets, ex-Cowboys coach and former executive vice president of the Dolphins has slotted network jobs into his coaching hiatuses since leaving the Giants in 1991.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE 34TH ANNUAL KENNEDY CENTER HONORS Neil Diamond, Meryl Streep, Yo-Yo Ma (above, from left), Barbara Cook and Sonny Rollins are celebrated for their contributions to American culture by President Obama, the first lady and a roster of the honorees' peers at this program taped on Dec. 4 in Washington. Emily Blunt, Matthew Broderick, Glenn Close, Ravi Coltrane, Bill Cosby, Robert De Niro, Benny Golson, Herbie Hancock, Anne Hathaway, Kevin Kline, John Lithgow, Patti LuPone, Audra McDonald, Sarah Jessica Parker, James Taylor and Stanley Tucci offer tributes. 4:20 P.M. (Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose world-class aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson is Matty, the professional pitcher whose spell she falls under and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date, then as a friend whose father-cum-boss, Charles (Jack Nicholson), isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.''

headline: CHIRKINIAN DIES AT 84
summary: Frank Chirkinian, the longtime golf producer for CBS who helped turn the Masters into one of the most watched events in sports television, died Friday at age 84. Chirkinian died at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla., after a long bout with lung cancer, his son said.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (ABC) BARBARA WALTERS PRESENTS THE 10 MOST FASCINATING PEOPLE OF 2011 This 90-minute program features interviews with those who made headlines in 2011, including Donald Trump, who has inserted himself into the Republican presidential nomination contest, and Derek Jeter of the Yankees, who reached 3,000 career hits in July. Ms. Walters, above with Herman Cain, also interviews Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Eric Stonestreet, who play a gay couple on the sitcom ''Modern Family,'' and Simon Cowell of ''The X Factor.'' 11:20 A.M. (Sundance) BLUE BLOOD (2006) For more than a century, the Oxford and Cambridge varsity boxing match has embodied a university rivalry at its most visceral. This documentary, directed by Stevan Riley, follows novice fighters who donned the Oxford blue in 2005.

headline: Alan Mulally Brings E.V. To 'Letterman'
summary: Alan Mulally, the Ford Motor Company president and chief executive, took his pitch for the electric car to late-night television just after midnight on Thursday, with an appearance on ''The Late Show With David Letterman'' on CBS. Introduced by his uncharacteristically effusive host as a ''hero'' and the man ''responsible for rescuing the Ford Motor Company from the brink of bankruptcy,'' Mr. Mulally took his seat with a smile and a wave to the audience and, beyond it, the country Mr. Mulally hoped to sell on the Focus Electric, a purely electric compact car due in showrooms in 2012.

headline: Pakistan Is Razing House Where Bin Laden Lived
summary: ISLAMABAD -- The Pakistani authorities moved on Saturday to demolish the house where Osama bin Laden died at the hands of Navy SEALs last May, erasing a three-story building that had acquired a painful symbolism for Pakistan's powerful military, which was badly embarrassed by the American raid. Working by floodlight, heavy machinery operators broke through the tall perimeter wall of the 3,000 square-meter compound in Abbottabad, 35 miles north of Islamabad, after dark on Saturday. Hours later, they started to knock down the main house where Bin Laden had lived with his family and three smaller buildings.

headline: Corrections
summary: A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about the Nielsen estimates of viewers of various television programs on Sunday night described the episode of ''60 Minutes'' on CBS incorrectly. It was a rerun, not a new edition.

headline: Original Songs Help 'Glee' With Young Viewers
summary: The singers of ''Glee'' performed original songs for the first time on Tuesday as that hit musical-comedy on Fox topped the ratings on the night with the highest results among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although Fox led the night over all in that age group, the 10.8 million total viewers for ''Glee'' at 8 p.m. was fewer than the 12.5 million who watched reruns of CBS's procedurals ''NCIS'' and ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' at 8 and 9.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (OWN) SEASON 25: OPRAH BEHIND THE SCENES Fans of Oprah Winfrey's long-running talk show already know how it ends, but now they can watch how Ms. Winfrey tried to spoil the surprises that the producers had planned for the show's last few episodes. At 9, Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, goes on a 26-mile journey through northern Canada in ''Finding Sarah.'' And at 10, in ''Ryan and Tatum: The O'Neals'' (both are above), Tatum O' Neal goes with her father to a screening of ''Paper Moon'' at the Palm Springs Film Festival and remembers her mother, Joanna Moore, who died in 1997. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Representatives Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, and Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, who is the majority whip, will discuss the negotiations over the national debt ceiling. Rick Santorum, a Republican presidential candidate and a former senator from Pennsylvania, will speak about the economy. James Garvin, chief scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, will talk about the future of space exploration.

headline: If Disney Owns It, Comcast Will Soon Be Streaming It
summary: 1/5/12 | Updated In a deal that represents billions of dollars in revenue for the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant and Comcast said Wednesday that they had reached a decade-long distribution agreement covering all of Disney's television content, including streaming for iPads and other devices. The unusually long-term agreement provides a window into the future of television viewing and how its content will be consumed. Comcast, the nation's largest cable provider, will gain the rights to provide the Disney Channel, ESPN, Disney XD, ABC Family and the ABC broadcast network, among other Disney-owned services, to subscribers wherever they want to watch.

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary last Sunday about Frank Chirkinian, the executive producer for CBS's coverage of the Masters golf tournament for 38 years, referred incorrectly to his survivors. He was divorced at the time of his death. He was not married to Mary Jane Chirkinian, who was the second of his three wives. And his son, Frank Jr., was from his first marriage, not from his marriage to Mary Jane.

headline: Maddow Extends Contract, And MSNBC Keeps Its Star
summary: 4:57 p.m. | Updated | LOS ANGELES-- MSNBC said Tuesday that it had signed its top star, Rachel Maddow, to a new multi-year contract, cementing her position at the cable news channel for several years. The new contract comes a little more than six months after Keith Olbermann hastily departed MSNBC, shaking up the channel's prime time lineup. Mr. Olbermann, the 8 p.m. host, had been the top draw for viewers; now the top draw is Ms. Maddow, the 9 p.m. host, a protege of Mr. Olbermann who started hosting her show two months before the presidential election in 2008.

headline: Poll Finds Lack of Passion for '12 Republican Field
summary: With less than a year to go before the Iowa caucuses, Republican voters have yet to form strong opinions about most of their potential candidates for president in 2012, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Only those possible contenders who regularly appear on television -- or have run before -- are well known enough to elicit significant views from their fellow Republicans. And of that group, only former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas and former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska are viewed favorably by more than half of the Republican electorate.

headline: For Lease
summary: $42/SQUARE FOOT $1.08 million approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) KANGAROO MOB In the last 50 years, the population of eastern gray kangaroos around Canberra, the capital of Australia, has multiplied from a few hundred to tens of thousands. Forced to search for food beyond the city's drought-stricken hills, the hungry creatures have moved into urban territory, dining on parkland and lawns -- and dying by the thousands in run-ins with cars. That has led the government to reduce herds through extermination, prompting an emotional backlash. This ''Nature'' episode follows a gang of street-wise kangaroos to reveal how they survive in the city. Among them are Black Spot, above, at more than 6 feet tall the mob's dominant male and the father of most of the joeys in his group, and Madge, who teaches her son Sonny about survival among humans while carrying a nursing joey named Alice in her pouch. The program also ponders the prospect of relocating kangaroo herds or controlling their numbers through forced contraception. 11 A.M. (MoreMax) OUT OF AFRICA (1985) Meryl Streep earned her sixth best-actress Oscar nomination as the Danish writer Karen Blixen, who later published under the name Isak Dinesen, in this sweeping drama about her life on a coffee plantation in British East Africa, now Kenya, for which Sydney Pollack won for best director; the film won best picture. Klaus Maria Brandauer was also nominated for his role as Baron Bror Blixen, her Swedish-born cousin and husband. Robert Redford plays Denys Finch Hatton, the love of her life.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (Animal Planet) PRAIRIE DOG CHATTER ''Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom'' chronicles the efforts of Con Slobodchikoff, a biologist, who, after 30 years of studying the calls of prairie dogs, believes that he has discovered a language second in complexity only to that of humans. He's hoping that his bold claim will lead to the conservation of these cousins of the squirrel, who for decades were seen merely as pests and subjected to large-scale eradication campaigns in North America. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY The candidates and potential candidates for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination make the rounds of the news shows. Here, Chris Wallace interviews Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who announced on Friday that he would run for the Republican nomination. Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina appears on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC. And Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker who also officially declared his candidacy last week, visits ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SOUTH RIDING Anna Maxwell Martin, right, plays Sarah Burton, a feisty teacher who returns to her hometown in 1930s Yorkshire, England, to shake up the local girls' high school and is drawn to Robert Carne (David Morrissey), a tradition-bound landowner and war veteran -- and just about the last fellow Sarah would normally find herself falling for. This ''Masterpiece Classic'' period drama, adapted by Andrew Davies from the novel by Winifred Holtby, might just be what viewers need on the heels of the royal wedding: ''a mild astringent for those suffering from an excess of pomp,'' Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And, he added, ''there's not one abominable Philip Treacy hat in sight.'' 4 A.M. (CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, Telemundo, Univision) THE BEATIFICATION OF POPE JOHN PAUL II Live reports from St. Peter's Square in Vatican City.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | JULY 3-JULY 9
summary: Pop Nate Chinen

headline: Op-Ed Contributor: For God So Loved The 1 Percent ...
summary: Princeton, N.J. IN recent weeks Mitt Romney has become the poster child for unchecked capitalism, a role he seems to embrace with relish. Concerns about economic equality, he told Matt Lauer of NBC, were really about class warfare.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BEAL, HON. IRA F.
summary: BEAL--Hon. Ira F.,age 79, beloved brother of Marjorie and fond brother-in-law of Enoch Silverstein, passed away on June 12, 2011. Ira was the adored uncle of Thomas (Leslie), Bill (Karyn) and Ted Silverstein and grand uncle of Ariel, Beth, Carly, Josh, Joey and Brian Silverstein. Ira, who started his career as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County, spent 17 years in the entertainment business working for NBC, CBS, and several large music companies. In the late 1970's he was named Executive Vice-President of M.P.L. Communications, Inc., Paul McCartney's company and then became President of the Music Publishing Division of the New York Times. In 1982 he was appointed to the Bench of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. Three years later he was promoted to the New York State Supreme Court, where he served until his retirement in 2002. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 14 at 10:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at E 81st St).

headline: Top of the Board
summary: 1 CAROLINA PANTHERS CAM NEWTON QB, Auburn Heisman Trophy winner has plenty of talent, and his share of baggage.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BEAL, IRA F.
summary: BEAL--Hon. Ira F., age 79, beloved brother of Marjorie and fond brother-in-law of Enoch Silverstein, passed away on June 12, 2011. Ira was the adored uncle of Thomas (Leslie), Bill (Karyn) and Ted Silverstein and grand uncle of Ariel, Beth, Carly, Josh, Joey and Brian Silverstein. Ira, who started his career as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County, spent 17 years in the entertainment business working for NBC, CBS, and several large music companies. In 1982 he was appointed to the Bench of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. Three years later he was promoted to the New York State Supreme Court, where he served until his retirement in 2002. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 14 at 10:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at E 81st St).

headline: ING to Sell Real Estate Units for $1 Billion to Repay State Aid
summary: 7:24 p.m. | Updated The ING Group said Tuesday that it would sell most of its real estate investment management business for more than $1 billion in two separate deals and use the proceeds to repay state aid it received during the financial crisis.

headline: What's On Today
summary: NOON (Sundance) THE POOL (2008) Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious home in which no one seems to swim. Eventually he approaches the property's owner (Nana Patekar, above right, with Mr. Chavan) and becomes his assistant; the rich man, in turn, promises to become Venkatesh's benefactor if he will move from Goa to Mumbai and go to school. ''At first 'The Pool' suggests an inspirational fable in which a selfless older man rescues a youth from the streets,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film by Chris Smith, adapted from a short story by Randy Russell. ''But just when you expect the film to turn into a predictable, rose-colored valentine to opportunity and hope, it goes to a deeper, more ambiguous place. Contemplating poverty from Venkatesh's perspective, it understands that his pursuit of upward mobility will require a terrifying leap of faith.'' The film was chosen as a New York Times Critics' Pick. In ''Summer Hours'' (2009), a movie from Olivier Assayas, at 1:45 p.m., Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche play Frédéric and Adrienne, siblings who must decide what to do with their mother's charming country house and cherished art collection after her death. Frédéric wants to keep everything the way it is for the enjoyment of the next generation. Adrienne and another brother (Jérémie Renier) want to sell the house and most of its contents, donating the best paintings and furnishings to the Musée d'Orsay. ''That, in a nutshell, is the dramatic arc of this extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. 10:55 A.M. (HBO2) SOMEWHERE (2010) In the first entry in a double bill from Sofia Coppola, Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff) is a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood. He finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves their 11-year-old daughter (Elle Fanning, right, with Mr. Dorff) in his care. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott described the movie as ''exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious.'' What happens, he added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies.'' ''Lost in Translation'' (2003), for which Ms. Coppola won an Oscar for best original screenplay, follows at 12:40 p.m.

headline: Games To Watch
summary: NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE AT NO. 2 ALABAMA 8 p.m. Eastern, CBS With both teams coming off byes, the hype leading up to this game feels more like Super Bowl Sunday than a Saturday in November. It is No. 1 vs. No. 2 in the regular season for the first time since Michigan and Ohio State played a classic in 2006. It matches division rivals, with the winner becoming the heavy favorite for the Southeastern Conference title and a berth in the national title game. It also matches two of the best defenses in the nation, squaring off in prime time in front of a packed house in Tuscaloosa, Ala., and two of the most successful coaches in college football in Nick Saban and Les Miles, vying for any advantage they can muster. There is a lot to look forward to.

headline: Romney Backs Israeli Position On Facing Iran
summary: JERUSALEM -- Mitt Romney said Sunday that preventing Iran from obtaining nuclear capability should be America's ''highest national security priority,'' stressing that ''no option should be excluded'' in the effort. ''We have a solemn duty and a moral imperative to deny Iran's leaders the means to follow through on their malevolent intentions,'' Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, told an audience of about 300, including a large contingent of American donors who flew here to accompany him. ''We must not delude ourselves into thinking that containment is an option.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (MTV) THE BREAK (2012) More than 1.5 million children are estimated to live on the streets, in shelters and on friends' couches in the United States. Many come from troubled families and have run away from abuse or have aged out of the foster care system. Their futures often involve prostitution, crime and illegal drug use, and one in three are likely to attempt suicide. This documentary follows Ava, Nancy and Rob, young people currently without homes and in desperate need of improving their lives. Anne Mahlum -- an advocate for the homeless whose organization, Back on My Feet, uses running as a way of building strength and self-esteem -- offers them the opportunities and tools to bring about change. The project was envisioned by the Edge, from the band U2. 7:30 A.M. (Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson is Matty, the major league pitcher whose spell she falls under, and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd, above with Ms. Witherspoon) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date and then as a friend whose father-cum-boss (Jack Nicholson) isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it, that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.''

headline: A Media Personality, Suffering a Blow to His Image, Ponders a Lesson
summary: When Lynda and Stewart Resnick, the Beverly Hills entrepreneurs who founded POM Wonderful, wanted to host a dinner at their Aspen home in 2006 to talk about the Iraq war, they assembled a list of 22 A-list guests, including Queen Noor of Jordan, George Soros, the financier, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.Leading the list of journalists was one of their favorite guests: Fareed Zakaria , the Indian-born Harvard Ph.D and foreign-policy specialist who had turned himself into an unlikely media star.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International AN IRANIAN LEADER WARNS

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) GCB It's payback time in this new prime-time soap opera, based on the novel ''Good Christian Bitches'' by Kim Gatlin and counting Robert Harling (''Steel Magnolias'') and Darren Star (''Sex and the City'') among its executive producers. Leslie Bibb stars as Amanda Vaughn, a onetime high school mean girl who is forced to return to Dallas in disgrace after her marriage ends in scandal. Annie Potts plays Gigi, her socialite mother who wants nothing more than to have her daughter back in the fold, the better to give her teenage grandchildren a proper Southern upbringing. Kristin Chenoweth, above, is Carlene Cockburn, a former ugly duckling who was tortured by Amanda as a girl but has made an ''assisted transformation'' into a picture-perfect life of luxury with a gorgeous husband -- if only she could let go of old grudges. Miriam Shor is Cricket Caruth-Reilly, whose boyfriend Amanda stole and later married. Jennifer Aspen is Sharon Peacham, whose chance at the Miss Teen Dallas crown was snatched away when Amanda started a malicious rumor. And Marisol Nichols is Heather Cruz, an outsider turned member of this clique of God-fearing women capable of instilling terror. ''The result is a network comedy that sends up sex, sin and Southern Baptists, or at least the pious parvenus of Dallas,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Newt Gingrich discusses whether he can again become a contender for the nomination as Super Tuesday approaches. He also appears on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Shrouded in Secrecy, Parkinson's Takes Greater Toll
summary: When Nancy Mulhearn learned she had Parkinson's disease seven years ago, she kept the diagnosis mostly to herself, hiding it from friends, colleagues - even, at first, her mother, sister and teenage children. After seven months, she decided she had to tell her family, and they settled into an unspoken agreement not to talk about the disease. She also realized her colleagues already suspected the truth: One asked why she had trouble applying her lipstick. She sometimes could not control her shaking hands.

headline: Forstmann Equity Firm To Name New Leader
summary: Julian H. Robertson Jr., the hedge fund manager, is expected to be named chairman of Forstmann Little, succeeding Theodore J. Forstmann, the co-founder of the private equity firm and prominent financier who died Sunday. Forstmann Little, which has largely wound down its operations, still has three investments in its portfolio: IMG, the sports, fashion and media company; 24 Hour Fitness, a health club chain; and ENK International, a fashion-industry trade-show business.

headline: Daytime Emmy Awards
summary: The medical talk show ''Dr. Oz'' was a first-time winner at the Daytime Emmy Awards, which were telecast by CBS on Sunday night. Dr. Mehmet Oz's show was recognized in the informative talk show category. The other winners were more familiar: ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show'' was named the best entertainment talk show for the second year in a row, the ''Cash Cab'' host Ben Bailey was named the best game show host for the second year, and the soap opera ''The Bold and the Beautiful'' was named best drama for the third year.

headline: Ralph McQuarrie, Artist Who Helped Bring 'Star Wars' to Life, Dies at 82
summary: Ralph McQuarrie, the artist who transformed George Lucas's rudimentary concepts and earliest scripts into lush, vivid images of intergalactic expanse and light-saber combat that became the visual core of the ''Star Wars'' saga, died on Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, said Stan Stice, a friend and co-author of the 2007 book ''The Art of Ralph McQuarrie.''

headline: 'Breaking Bad' Cooks Up Record Viewership
summary: Despite a 13-month absence after an excruciatingly tense Season 3 cliffhanger, ''Breaking Bad'' set a ratings record in its return to AMC on Sunday night. According to Nielsen, an estimated 2.6 million people tuned in to witness the further misadventures of the meth dealers Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and to learn whether Jesse actually killed a fellow meth cooker. That number was 32 percent greater than the viewership for last season's premiere, and was the highest total in the series' history. Elsewhere, CBS won the night for the broadcast networks, with a double bill of ''60 Minutes'' (8.5 million total viewers) and ''Big Brother'' (6.89 million) leading the way. On Friday night, the 90-minute series finale of ''Friday Night Lights'' on NBC played the underdog to the end, drawing a mere 3.48 million viewers. That episode, which ran earlier on DirecTV, last week earned an Emmy nomination for outstanding writing for a television drama, along with the three other nominations (for outstanding drama, actor and actress).

headline: For Prime Time, Sets and the City
summary: New York is a changeling, a different city to everyone who passes through. The premiere of the fall TV season will reflect that: Just last month, a record 23 prime-time shows filmed here, thanks in part to recent tax breaks. In sound stages from the Chelsea Piers to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, designers rebuilt the landscape to fit plot lines, making the city seem brighter and sadder, wealthier and grittier, older and newer.

headline: What's on Sunday
summary: 9/11 NATIONAL MEMORIAL CEREMONIES The networks offer coverage of events at ground zero (above), the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pa., as well as supplemental programming. Here is a selection:

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WERSHBA, JOSEPH
summary: WERSHBA--Joseph, died peacefully in his 91st year. Renowned print and Emmy winning television journalist (See it Now, The New York Post, CBS Reports Sixty Minutes), he was cherished by Shirley, his beloved wife of 63 years, children Randi (Bob) and Donald (Haven) and granddaughters Emily and Faith, all of whom he considered to be his finest achievements. He will be missed by all of those whose lives he touched.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International EUROPEAN OFFICIAL CALLS

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS, SERIES IV: OLD, UNHAPPY, FAR OFF THINGS A new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' stalwart begins as Inspector Lewis, the long-suffering detective played by Kevin Whately (above left), and his erudite sidekick, Detective Sgt. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox, right), investigate the death of Poppy Toynton, a passive-aggressive -- and stunningly average -- graduate of Lady Matilda's, Oxford's last surviving all-female college, whose ''golden set'' has congregated on campus to honor its beloved professor Diana Ellerby (Juliet Stevenson) and perhaps to mourn the fact that the college has recently voted to admit men. But whodunit? Could it be the confident chief executive of a lingerie company (Stephanie Street)? The provocative newspaper columnist (Zoe Telford)? Lewis can't help but be reminded of the attack on 15-year-old Chloe Brooks at the college 10 years earlier, whose case was interrupted by the death of his wife, which obsesses him now more than ever. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, talks about the qualities in a presidential candidate that would win his endorsement as well as what he hopes to see in President Obama's proposed jobs plan.

headline: CORRECTIONS
summary: A Correspondent's Notebook article last Sunday, about a CBS News journalist who was sexually abused while reporting from Cairo, referred incorrectly to Gaza, where the writer of the article, Sabrina Tavernise, once worked. Gaza is not ''in Israel.'' And an accompanying picture caption misspelled the given name of the CBS journalist. As the article correctly noted, she is Lara Logan, not Laura.

headline: Production of Sheen's Show Is Suspended After He Attacks Creator
summary: 11:33 p.m. | Updated CBS and the television production studio Warner Brothers have decided to shut down production of the hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men,'' the companies said Thursday, after the show's star, Charlie Sheen, attacked the creator of the show, Chuck Lorre, in two incendiary interviews. In a terse statement, CBS and Warner Brothers, which produces the show, said, ''Based on the totality of Charlie Sheen's statements, conduct and condition, CBS and Warner Brothers Television have decided to discontinue production of 'Two and a Half Men' for the remainder of the season.''

headline: Worry, Blame, Anger — and a Little Optimism
summary: How voters of all kinds are feeling before the midterm election, as shown in a New York Times/CBS poll.

headline: Francesco Quinn, 48, 'Platoon' Actor
summary: Francesco Quinn, a television and film actor who appeared in Oliver Stone's searing 1986 Vietnam War film, ''Platoon,'', died on Friday in Malibu, Calif. The son of the actor Anthony Quinn, he was 48. Mr. Quinn collapsed on a street near his home, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said. His agent, Arlene Thornton, said the cause was believed to be a heart attack.

headline: Could a Revamped 'Cinderella' Be Invited to a Broadway Ball?
summary: The first Broadway production of ''Rodgers and Hammerstein's Cinderella'' is in the works for the 2012-13 theater season, with a new libretto by Douglas Carter Beane (''Lysistrata Jones,'' ''Sister Act'') based on the 1957 television musical that starred Julie Andrews, the producer Robyn Goodman said on Thursday. Calling Mr. Beane's book ''somewhat revisionist,'' Ms. Goodman said that the biggest twist was having Cinderella ''rescue the prince by teaching him good values.'' She described the plot as blending political satire (to interest adult theater-goers) with slapstick humor and the familiar story of cruel stepsisters, a fairy godmother, and a magic pumpkin (to appeal to children and teenagers). Mr. Beane also sought inspiration from various literary adaptation of the tale.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (USA) NFL CHARACTERS UNITE Tony Gonzalez of the Atlanta Falcons, Jimmy Graham of the New Orleans Saints, Hines Ward of the Pittsburgh Steelers (above right, with Carlton Dennis, a student) and Tony Dungy, a former head coach for the Indianapolis Colts and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, discuss the hate and bigotry they overcame as children to find success in pro football. This documentary also follows the men as they work with teenagers mired in similar situations. 1 P.M. (BET) AMERICAN VIOLET (2009) Nicole Beharie is Dee Roberts, a young African-American mother of four who is charged with distributing narcotics in a school zone in her small Texas town and risks going to trial instead of accepting a plea bargain for a crime she insists she didn't commit. Xzibit plays the father of her two youngest children; his desire for custody may be at the root of Dee's predicament. Michael O'Keefe is the local district attorney who is sued for racial discrimination by an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer (Tim Blake Nelson) on Dee's behalf. And Alfre Woodard is her mother. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this film from Tim Disney, based on real events in 2000, is ''beautifully acted by Ms. Beharie, whose high-strung character is no angel.'' The film was selected as a New York Times Critics' Pick.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SERVODIDIO, PASQUALE
summary: SERVODIDIO--Pasquale, "Pat," former President of Multimedia Broadcasting Company and RKO General, passed away quietly on March 15, 2011 after a four year battle with lung cancer. He graduated from Fordham Prep, Fordham University, and Harvard University's Special Management Program. In the time-honored way, Pat rose from the mail room at CBS Television to the office of President of RKO TV and Radio, which included CBS, NBC and ABC. As President of RKO General, he managed billion-dollar broadcast facilities nationwide. Pat is survived by his children Christian and Alexa, and his life companion for more than forty years, Ulla Servodidio. He is survived by his brothers and sisters Mary, Loretta, Rose, Frank and Michael, their spouses, and many nieces and nephews. Visiting: Friday, March 18th 2-4pm and 7-9pm Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, March 19th at 10:30am at Assumption Church, Tuckahoe. Interment to follow at Holy Mount. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may contribute to the Thoracic Research Fund, c/o Memorial Sloan-Kettering H1016, 1275 York Avenue, Room 1016, New York, NY 10065. To send the family a condolence online, visit westchesterfuneralhome.com

headline: Quick Return for Sheen?
summary: The latest episode in the saga of Charlie Sheen is looking more like a repeat. As was the case last season, it looks like Mr. Sheen will complete rehabilitation and be back on his hit CBS comedy, ''Two and a Half Men,'' much sooner than originally expected.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SERVODIDIO, PASQUALE
summary: SERVODIDIO--Pasquale, "Pat," former President of Multimedia Broadcasting Company and RKO General, passed away quietly on March 15, 2011 after a four year battle with lung cancer. He graduated from Fordham Prep, Fordham University, and Harvard University's Special Management Program. In the time-honored way, Pat rose from the mail room at CBS Television to the office of President of RKO TV and Radio, which included CBS, NBC and ABC. As President of RKO General, he managed billion-dollar broadcast facilities nationwide. Pat is survived by his children Christian and Alexa, and his life companion for more than forty years, Ulla Servodidio. He is survived by his brothers and sisters Mary, Loretta, Rose, Frank and Michael, their spouses, and many nieces and nephews. Visiting: Friday, March 18th 2-4pm and 7-9pm Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, March 19th at 10:30am at Assumption Church, Tuckahoe. Interment to follow at Holy Mount. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may contribute to the Thoracic Research Fund, c/o Memorial Sloan-Kettering H1016, 1275 York Avenue, Room 1016, New York, NY 10065. To send the family a condolence online, visit westchesterfuneralhome.com

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 A.M. (Flix) THE PREACHER'S WIFE (1996) Denzel Washington, above, plays a trench-coat-and-fedora-clad angel who enters the lives of an urban minister (Courtney B. Vance) facing bankruptcy and the possible demolition of his church, and his neglected wife (Whitney Houston), who also directs the choir, in this update of the 1947 comedy ''The Bishop's Wife,'' starring Cary Grant, David Niven and Loretta Young. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said Ms. Houston, who died on Saturday, ''barely has to act to bring a gritty nobility to the title role of Penny Marshall's sweetly uplifting film.'' All she has to do, he added, ''is sing, and you begin to believe in angels, miracles, happily ever after and all the other corny items that this inspirational comedy spills across the holiday table.'' Among the movie's highlights are Ms. Houston singing gospel with the Georgia Mass Choir and her pop ballad ''I Believe in You and Me.'' Hans Zimmer earned an Oscar nomination for best musical score. 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL Blair (Leighton Meester) plays Cupid and shoots her arrow in the direction of Dan (Penn Badgley, below, with Ms. Meester) and Serena (Blake Lively). Nate (Chace Crawford) finds Lola (Ella Rae Peck) harder and harder to resist, but the feeling may not be mutual. And Georgina (Michelle Trachtenberg) crashes a Valentine's Day party. The band St. Vincent performs. In ''Hart of Dixie,'' at 9, Wade (Wilson Bethel) has Lemon (Jaime King) disguise herself. And George (Scott Porter) asks Zoe (Rachel Bilson) for her medical expertise.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
summary: NO. 8 NEBRASKA AT NO. 7 WISCONSIN 8 p.m. Eastern, ABC Nebraska's first Big Ten game is one of the most anticipated matchups of the season. This is the first meeting of top-10 teams in Madison since 1962. So far, Wisconsin, behind quarterback Russell Wilson, has overwhelmed opponents. Nebraska has also scored a lot of points, but its defense has been suspect, giving up 29 points to Fresno State and 38 against Washington. The Cornhuskers will need to be better defensively, but much also hinges on the play of quarterback Taylor Martinez. While Wilson looks to throw before scrambling, Martinez is second in the Big Ten with 421 yards rushing and has run for seven touchdowns. Nebraska is 10-0 when he rushes for more than 50 yards.

headline: A New Way To Stream Broadcast Television
summary: 11:40 a.m. | Updated Barry Diller, who created the Fox television network almost 30 years ago, now wants to free it and other networks from the chains of what he calls the ''closed cable-broadcast-satellite circle.''

headline: Teenagers Rule
summary: Teen drama, both real and fictional, continues to be a winning formula for MTV. The network's new scripted comedy series ''Awkward'' made its debut to strong ratings Tuesday night, following the hit show ''Teen Mom,'' a reality series whose title needs no explanation. Currently on its third season, ''Teen Mom'' drew 3.2 million viewers and was the most-watched cable show in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic for the night, a prize it has claimed each week since its season premiere on July 7, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers. ''Awkward,'' which focuses on the teenage life of one Jenna Hamilton (Ashley Rickards), who wants nothing more than to fit in at her high school, picked up slightly more than 1.7 million viewers. Meanwhile, Wednesday night's battle for ratings supremacy on the broadcast networks did not have a clear victor. CBS led with total viewers for the night as a new episode of ''Big Brother'' won the 8 p.m. hour with just over 7 million viewers. However, Fox claimed the top spot overall among the 18- to 49-year-old set, thanks to a two-hour edition of ''So You Think You Can Dance.'' Finally, NBC once again boasted the highest-rated program of the night, with a results show edition of ''America's Got Talent'' at slightly less than 9.9 million viewers.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | FEB. 13-FEB. 19
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: College Games To Watch
summary: NO. 4 WISCONSIN AT NO. 15 MICHIGAN STATE 8 p.m. Eastern, ESPN With Russell Wilson leading the way, the Badgers are No. 1 in the nation in scoring and are firmly in the national championship conversation. They will be tested by a stingy Michigan State defense that has allowed more than 14 points only once. This is Wisconsin's first true road game and it has lost its last three games in East Lansing, including its only defeat last year. Michigan State displayed its speed and aggressiveness last week when it punished Denard Robinson and defeated Michigan, 28-14. The Spartans may have been a little too aggressive. Defensive end William Gholston has been suspended for this game after throwing a punch against the Wolverines.

headline: Optimism About Viewership
summary: Optimism About Viewership Bob Arum, the chairman of Top Rank boxing, said that based on early projections, the pay-per-view buys from Manny Pacquiao's defense of his welterweight title fight against Shane Mosley last Saturday would match or exceed the roughly 1.2 million buys for Pacquiao's previous fight, against Antonio Margarito. The numbers are significant because the fight, distributed by Showtime Pay- Per-View, was promoted heavily by CBS, in what Arum viewed as the first step toward returning boxing to broadcast television. More at nytimes.com/sports. GREG BISHOP

headline: What's On Today
summary: 6:45 A.M. (HBO) BOBBY FISCHER AGAINST THE WORLD (2011) Liz Garbus (''The Farm: Angola, U.S.A.'') profiles Fischer (1943-2008), above, the prickly individualist from Brooklyn who became a chess grandmaster and in 1972 turned his match with Boris Spassky, his Soviet counterpart, into a global media event. She also documents Fischer's inner turmoil, which in later years prompted him to live in exile in Japan and Iceland and to give voice to a worldview rife with conspiracy theories and anti-Semitism, despite his Jewish background. ''What happened?'' A. O. Scott asked in The New York Times. The film, he wrote, ''tactfully but strongly posits a connection between the genius he brought to an infinitely complex game and the madness that defined his relationship to just about everything else.'' And yet, Mr. Scott added, ''if he had been spared fame, the world would have been denied a share of sublimity, and the kingdom of chess would never have found its wayward, dazzling, tragic prince.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS When a Navy reservist with high-level security clearance is found dead, Gibbs (Mark Harmon) clashes with Dr. Samantha Ryan (Jamie Lee Curtis) of the PsyOps Division as he tries to uncover the truth about the reservist's apparent suicide. In ''NCIS: Los Angeles,'' at 9, the team is shocked to discover that all evidence points to the guilt of Special Agent Kensi Blye (Daniela Ruah) in the murder of a former colleague of her dead father's.

headline: Games To Watch
summary: NO. 12 GEORGIA VS. NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE Southeastern Conference championship, Atlanta 4 p.m. Eastern, CBS L.S.U., which appears to be headed to the Bowl Championship Series title game win or lose, has one of the most formidable defenses in the nation and will be a big favorite. Cornerback Tyrann Mathieu, right, is in the center of the storm. Georgia has won 10 in a row, but only three of those victories came against teams with winning records. L.S.U. has eight victories over top-25 teams.

headline: A Narrower Lead, but Big Changes Probably Aren't the Cause
summary: We are beginning to see more national surveys now, including this week's New York Times/CBS News poll, which show Mitt Romney with a slight lead over President Obama in the general election matchup. To be sure, there are also a number of polls that put Mr. Obama slightly ahead. But his lead does seem to have narrowed - from about three or four points in an average of national polls a month or two ago to more like a point or so in surveys today. Has something fundamental changed in the race?

headline: Not Exactly 'Idol': 'X-Factor' Comes Up Short
summary: In what turned out to be a bad case of over expectations, the Fox network and its biggest star, Simon Cowell, posted disappointing ratings for the premiere of the widely-anticipated singing competition, ''The X-Factor,'' Wednesday night. The show, which had network competitors fearing that Fox could have on its hands another blockbuster the size of ''American Idol,'' performed well in an objective sense, attracting about 12.5 million viewers and scoring a much-better-than-average 4.2 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old audience that Fox primarily sells to advertisers.

headline: Lionsgate Announces Sitcom Deal With Sheen
summary: Charlie Sheen has made a deal that will - possibly - bring him back to television in a new situation comedy. Mr. Sheen, whose turbulent departure from the hit CBS sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' was among the most widely covered television stories of the year, has agreed to star in a show based on the movie ''Anger Management'' to be produced by the successful independent production company Lionsgate (''Mad Men,'' ''Nurse Jackie,'' ''Weeds'').

headline: 'America's Got Talent' Bests America's Pastime
summary: Broadcast at the same time as Major League Baseball's All-Star Game on Fox, ''America's Got Talent'' still managed to deliver Tuesday night's most viewers, as 13.8 million tuned in to the show's latest two-hour installment, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although off by some 2 million viewers compared with last week's episode, the NBC talent competition was still up considerably compared with its showing a year ago (11.6 a million) on the same night as the All-Star Game. Final audience figures for Fox's coverage were not immediately available on Wednesday, but preliminary overnight estimates for the broadcast were the lowest ever for the All-Star Game and down 13 percent compared with last year, when it attracted 12.1 million viewers.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $50/SQUARE FOOT $1.16 million approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 84TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The tried-and-true Billy Crystal returns for his ninth stint as host of this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles (above, setting the scene). George Clooney is up for best actor for ''The Descendants,'' but oddsmakers are predicting that Jean Dujardin will take home the Oscar for his role as a silent-movie star in ''The Artist,'' the black-and-white tribute to a golden age in Hollywood. That film is expected to win best picture as well, while its director, Michel Hazanavicius, is favored for the directing award. Viola Davis is the top best-actress contender for her turn as a courageous maid in ''The Help,'' though Meryl Streep, as Margaret Thatcher in ''The Iron Lady,'' could make it a close race. And in the best-supporting category, Christopher Plummer is expected to win as a father who comes out of the closet near the end of his life in ''Beginners,'' as is Octavia Spencer, who portrayed another determined maid in ''The Help.'' ''A Separation,'' the domestic drama set in Iran, is favored to win for best foreign film. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 4 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Tim Gunn, Robin Roberts, Jess Cagle, Nina Garcia and Louise Roe interview celebrities on the red carpet at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! 7 A.M. (Sho2) THE KING'S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, below, in the role for which he won the best-actor Oscar last year, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps him conquer his debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Bertie's wife and staunch support system, who can't quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie's older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. ''It isn't exactly 'Pygmalion,' not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie's biggest draws,'' Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 nominations and earned Mr. Hooper an Oscar as best director. ''Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, 'The King's Speech' wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.'' The film also won Academy Awards for best picture and original screenplay (David Seidler).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BEAL, HON. IRA F.
summary: BEAL--Hon. Ira F.,age 79, beloved brother of Marjorie and fond brother-in-law of Enoch Silverstein, passed away on June 12, 2011. Ira was the adored uncle of Thomas (Leslie), Bill (Karyn) and Ted Silverstein and grand uncle of Ariel, Beth, Carly, Josh, Joey and Brian Silverstein. Ira, who started his career as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County, spent 17 years in the entertainment business working for NBC, CBS, and several large music companies. In the late 1970's he was named Executive Vice-President of M.P.L. Communications, Inc., Paul McCartney's company and then became President of the Music Publishing Division of the New York Times. In 1982 he was appointed to the Bench of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. Three years later he was promoted to the New York State Supreme Court, where he served until his retirement in 2002. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 14 at 10:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at E 81st St).

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International TALIBAN FREES HUNDREDS FROM PAKISTANI PRISON

headline: Ratings Rise, Often Briefly
summary: Presidents have traditionally seen sharp increases in their approval ratings during international crises, diplomatic events and military operations. In the next few days, as public opinion polls are released, how Osama bin Laden's death affected Americans' views of President Obama's job performance will be apparent. After the Sept. 11 attacks, there was an unprecedented increase in President George W. Bush's approval rating, from 50 percent in a CBS News poll before the attack to 90 percent soon afterward.

headline: ABC Will End 2 Long-Running Serials
summary: The demise of one of broadcasting's oldest institutions, the daytime soap opera, crept closer Thursday as ABC announced it would end two of its long-running daily serial dramas, ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live.'' The decision will leave ABC will just one soap on its schedule, ''General Hospital.'' CBS has eliminated two of its venerable soaps, ''Guiding Light,'' which was dropped in 2009, and ''As the World Turns'' which was canceled last year.

headline: Gameday Guide: Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups.
summary: 6 L.S.U. at 5 AUBURN 3:30 p.m., CBS The last two unbeaten teams in the SEC square off in the must-watch game of the weekend. 10 WISCONSIN at 13 IOWA 3:30 p.m., ABC Wisconsin is coming off a big victory, but this week faces an Iowa team that is hitting its stride.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) HUGH LAURIE: LET THEM TALK -- A CELEBRATION OF NEW ORLEANS BLUES Mr. Laurie (''House''), right, who was first introduced to the blues as a teenager when he heard Professor Longhair's ''Tipitina,'' tours New Orleans and sings along with some of its legends, like Allen Toussaint and Irma Thomas, while accompanying himself on the piano and guitar. He also gets a little vocal backup from his fellow Briton Tom Jones. Concert sequences in this ''Great Performances'' presentation were filmed at Latrobe's on Royal in the French Quarter; the songlist, comprised of standards and neglected gems, includes ''Swanee River,'' ''You Don't Know My Mind,'' ''Copperhead Road,'' ''John Henry,'' ''St. James Infirmary,'' ''Buddy Bolden's Blues'' and ''Baby Please Make a Change.'' Mr. Laurie appears on ''The Tonight Show With Jay Leno,'' at 11:35 on NBC. 10 A.M. (Fox Business Network) VARNEY & CO. Liz Claman interviews Warren Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, right, about President Obama's proposed Buffett Rule, which stipulates that people who make more than $1 million a year should pay at least the same percentage of their earnings in taxes as middle-class Americans; his recent stock repurchase; and a possible European bailout. At 11 p.m., Mr. Buffett appears on ''Charlie Rose'' on Channel 13.

headline: Coolly Shattered A Space Ceiling
summary: Sally Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, died on Monday at her home in San Diego. She was 61. The cause was pancreatic cancer, her company, Sally Ride Science, announced on its Web site.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) BLACK SWAN (2010) Natalie Portman, above, in the role that earned her an Academy Award, stars as Nina, a ballerina teetering on the brink of insanity as she tries to break out of the corps and into the dual lead of ''Swan Lake'': the Swan Queen and her villainous black swan twin. Mila Kunis is Lily, the sultry newcomer who is everything the increasingly tormented Nina is not, as their company's artistic director, Thomas (Vincent Cassel), insists on pointing out. And Barbara Hershey is Nina's mother, a former dancer who desperately wants her daughter to achieve everything she never could. The result is ''a witchy brew of madness and cunning,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film from Darren Aronofsky (''The Wrestler''), which also earned Oscar nominations for best director and picture. ''One of the pleasures of 'Black Swan' is its lack of reverence toward the rarefied world of ballet, which to outsiders can look as lively as a crypt,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''Mr. Aronofsky makes this world (or his version of it) exciting partly by pulling back the velvet curtains and showing you the sacrifices and crushingly hard work that go into creating beautiful dances.'' She added, ''Much like the new version of 'Swan Lake' that Thomas creates, 'Black Swan' is visceral and real even while it's one delirious, phantasmagoric freakout.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Robert Darnton, the director of the Harvard University Library, discusses his crusade for the creation of an international digital public library based on Thomas Jefferson's belief that ''the field of knowledge is the common property of mankind.''

headline: Fighting Antipiracy Measure, Hackers Click on Media Chiefs
summary: The online activist group known as Anonymous, which has targeted opponents of the Occupy Wall Street movement and businesses that stopped providing services to WikiLeaks, has set its sights on a new adversary: media executives. In protest of antipiracy legislation currently being considered by Congress, the group has posted online documents that reveal personal information about Jeffrey L. Bewkes, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, and Sumner M. Redstone, who controls Viacom and the CBS Corporation. Those companies, like almost every major company in the media and entertainment industry, have championed the Stop Online Piracy Act, the House of Representatives bill, known as SOPA, and its related Senate bill, called Protect I.P.

headline: Jim Parsons Joins Cast Of 'Normal Heart'
summary: Proving that it is possible for the star of a CBS comedy to take a break from his series without mortifying the network or his co-stars or burning all of his bridges in the entertainment industry, Jim Parsons, the ''Big Bang Theory'' star, will join the cast of the coming Broadway production of ''The Normal Heart,'' the play's press representatives said Monday. Mr. Parsons, who in recent months has won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his portrayal of the physicist Sheldon Cooper, will make his Broadway debut in ''The Normal Heart,'' playing Tommy Boatwright, a Southerner in a nascent group of HIV/AIDS activists in the early 1980s. Also joining the cast is Lee Pace, a star of the late, lamented ABC series ''Pushing Daisies,'' who will be making his Broadway debut in the role of Bruce Niles, a closeted fellow activist. This latest production of ''The Normal Heart,'' Larry Kramer's semi-autobiographical work about AIDS, friendship and love in 1980s-era New York, will be directed by Joel Grey (with some help from George C. Wolfe), and is to begin previews at the Golden Theater on April 19 with an opening night planned for April 27. Previously announced cast members include Joe Mantello as the protagonist, Ned Weeks; Ellen Barkin as Dr. Emma Brookner; and John Benjamin Hickey as Weeks's lover, Felix Turner.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $39/SQUARE FOOT $518,700 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 1:15 P.M. (IFC) CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER (2006) A cruel emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) and his secretive wife (Gong Li, above with Mr. Chow) plot each other's annihilation: he, by destroying her sanity with a rare fungus; she, by planning a bloody coup during a festival and persuading one of her three sons (Jay Chou) to join her revolt. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that this martial arts drama from the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, set in A.D. 928, ''achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.'' She added: ''Since his debut in 1987 with 'Red Sorghum' Mr. Zhang has made more controlled films but never one that's more fun. With 'Curse of the Golden Flower' he aims for Shakespeare and winds up with Jacqueline Susann. And a good thing too.'' 6 A.M. (Oxygen) A WALK ON THE MOON (1999) Diane Lane plays Pearl Kantrowitz, a housewife who each summer totes her ironing board, children and mother-in-law to a camp in the Catskills while her husband, Marty (Liev Schreiber), stays in New York City, repairing television sets. Viggo Mortensen is the hippie salesman who turns her life upside down in 1969, as the moon walk and Woodstock loom. Writing in The Times about this romance from Tony Goldwyn, Janet Maslin said, ''Even when it turns turbulent, the film sustains its warm summer glow, and makes itself a conversation piece about the moral issues it means to raise.''

headline: Stieg Larsson's Last Novel
