summary: Remember that mysterious, unpublished, unconfirmed manuscript of the fourth book in Stieg Larsson's best-selling ''Millennium'' series? It's actually the fifth book. So said Mr. Larsson's brother, Joakim, in an interview on CBS that was broadcast on Sunday.

headline: Marketa Kimbrell, 82, Actress and Producer
summary: Marketa Kimbrell, an actress and co-founder of a theater company that brought stage productions to audiences for whom they were rarely available, among them prison inmates, died on July 6 in Sykesville, Md. She was 82. The cause was Alzheimer's disease, her son Andrew said.

headline: Kennedy Center Honors for Streep And Four Disparate Musicians
summary: WASHINGTON -When the actress Meryl Streep learned that she would be among the five performers to receive this year's John F. Kennedy Center Honors, the moment was bittersweet. ''I am deeply honored by this news, and wish my mother and father were alive to hear it!'' she said in a statement Tuesday sent from Connecticut, where she is filming the romantic comedy ''Great Hope Springs.'' ''All that education, allowance, tuition, voice lessons, summer jobs, scholarship application deadlines and loving care and discipline - all that they gave me, bore fruit in a way they never dreamed. I am so grateful!''

headline: 'Metropolis II'
summary: A look at Chris Burden's kinetic sculpture in progress, filmed in 2009 at the artist's studio in Topanga, Calif. (Video courtesy of CB Studio)

headline: Corrections
summary: The Media Equation column on Monday, about the shake-up of hosts for the ''Early Show'' on CBS, erroneously included one of the early members of the ''60 Minutes'' team as being among those who remain on the show. While Morley Safer still appears, Mike Wallace does not. (He retired in 2006.)

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) PEARL JAM TWENTY In this ''American Masters'' documentary, part of the PBS Arts Fall Festival, the director and music journalist Cameron Crowe culls material -- from more than 1,200 hours of rarely seen film footage and an additional 24 hours of recently shot concert and interview video -- to profile the Seattle-based rock band. Mr. Crowe begins with the period leading up to the group's formation (it is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year), the chaos the resulted not long after its rise to stardom and its step back from center stage. Among those interviewed are the band members (above, from left) Mike McCready, Matt Cameron, Eddie Vedder, Jeff Ament and Stone Gossard, as well as the Soundgarden singer and guitarist Chris Cornell. Mother Love Bone, Temple of the Dog, Kurt Cobain and Neil Young are seen in archival clips. Taylor Hackford narrates. 7:35 A.M. (Sundance) FLIGHT OF THE RED BALLOON (2008) The Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien creates a love letter to Paris -- and to Albert Lamorisse's 1956 classic, ''The Red Balloon'' -- in this tale about Suzanne (Juliette Binoche), above, a puppeteer; her lonely, 7-year-old son, Simon (Simon Iteanu); and Song (Song Fang), a Chinese film student hired to be his nanny. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said: ''In the end what elevates Mr. Hou's films to the sublime -- and this one comes close at times -- are not the stories but their telling. In 'Flight of the Red Balloon' Mr. Hou plays with light and space on the small canvas that is Simon and Suzanne's apartment, moving the camera around as gracefully as if it were a brush (or a balloon).''

headline: CNBC's Burnett Is Said Ready to Jump to CNN
summary: The CNBC anchor Erin Burnett is poised to sign a long-term contract with CNN, according to three people with knowledge of her plans. The signing will represent a shift to general news anchoring for Ms. Burnett, who has shown interest in branching out beyond business news, CNBC's specialty. It is unclear what time slot she will occupy at CNN.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Crime dramas like ''NCIS'' and ''Rizzoli & Isles'' are among the top series, along with football, football and football. The 16-week season mostly plays out on Sundays on NBC, Mondays on ESPN and Thursdays on the N.F.L. Network, in games like the 49ers-Chargers matchup on Dec. 16, above. (Games can also be seen on CBS and Fox.) ''Dancing With the Stars,'' the top series, had the added drama -- or melodrama -- of a season with Mike Sorrentino, a k a the Situation, David Hasselhoff and Bristol Palin. Jennifer Grey won the title. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (HBO) TREME The reconstruction of New Orleans in the wake of Hurricane Katrina continues, and so does the city's jazz, as this series created by David Simon and Eric Overmyer, of ''The Wire'' fame, begins a second season, with the music and its makers venturing north to the clubs and restaurants of New York City. But first the story resumes in New Orleans as the trombonist Antoine (Wendell Pierce, above, with Phyllis Montana-Leblanc) contemplates a move, while his ex, LaDonna (Khandi Alexander), resists one; the D. J. Davis (Steve Zahn) expands in new directions personally and professionally, with the help of the violinist Annie Tee (Lucia Micarelli); the Indian chief Albert (Clarke Peters) is forced out of his temporary residence; and the lawyer Toni (Melissa Leo), a recent widow, worries about the emotional distance of her daughter, Sofia (India Ennenga), after her father's suicide. Meanwhile, in New York, Albert's son, the trumpeter Delmond (Rob Brown), has just released his new album. And the chef Janette (Kim Dickens), in a story line given a jolt of reality by Anthony Bourdain, who has joined the show's writing staff this season, lands a job in the kitchen of a culinary tyrant whose antics might make even Gordon Ramsay tremble. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Mr. Wallace interviews Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, an independent, about President Obama, the federal budget crisis, immigration reform and his own political future.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (MSNBC) 17 DAYS BURIED ALIVE On Aug. 5, 2010, 33 miners were trapped nearly a half-mile underground after a rockslide in the San José Mine near Copiapó, Chile. The men, above, survived there for 69 days, and after a riveting rescue mission they vowed not to reveal what had taken place during the first 17 days -- what they called ''the dark days'' -- when they didn't know if help would come. In this documentary from Ed Schultz, six of the miners break their silence to discuss their fears of never again seeing the light of day and their temptations to do things they never thought they would. The film will be shown at 2 p.m. on Saturday on Telemundo, hosted by Omar Germenos. 11:25 A.M. (Showtime 2) BIG FAN (2009) Patton Oswalt plays Paul Aufiero, a rabid New York Giants fan and radio talk-show caller whose brush with his favorite player, Quantrell Bishop (Jonathan Hamm), takes a dark turn. Reviewing this drama from Robert Siegel (who wrote the screenplay for ''The Wrestler'') in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote that the screenplay ''avoids sentimentality without abandoning sentiment.'' She added, ''Paul might make you squirm, but Mr. Siegel refuses to sell him out so you can feel more comfortable with his eccentricities, no small thing in contemporary independent cinema.''

headline: Organizing Now, Democrats Expect Tough Bid in 2012
summary: WASHINGTON - Republicans, with justification, shouted ''hypocrisy'' last week after former White House aides opened a campaign organization using the sort of anonymous donors condemned by President Obama. But they also understood it as a compliment. That's because, in another springtime full of political disappointment, Democratic strategists have begun concluding that Mr. Obama faces a tougher-than-anticipated re-election fight.

headline: TimesCast | October 28 2010
summary: Illinois Senate barbs; the latest New York Times/CBS poll and award-worthy political ads in New York region.

headline: With Season Under Way, Some Shows Decline
summary: ''NCIS'' on CBS delivered Tuesday night's largest audience with 19.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, but other new and returning series had losses as the fall season continues to unfold. ''No Ordinary Family'' (8.9 million), the new ABC science-fiction series, was down by nearly 2 million viewers from its premiere, and the network's new cop drama, ''Detroit 1-8-7'' (8.3 million), was also down. On Fox, a religion-theme episode of ''Glee'' (11 million) was off about 2 million viewers from last week's Britney Spears extravaganza. CBS won the night over all with a lineup that also included ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (16.2 million) and ''The Good Wife'' (12.7 million). ABC was second as ''Dancing With the Stars'' (16.4 million) bade farewell to the comedian Margaret Cho.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (13) PLÁCIDO DOMINGO: MY FAVORITE ROLES Mr. Domingo, left, the beloved tenor and the director of the Los Angeles and Washington National Operas, recounts his roots in Spain while looking back at some of the most famous of his 130 roles in works like ''Carmen,'' ''La Gioconda,'' ''Ernani,'' ''Luisa Miller,'' ''Tosca,'' ''Simon Boccanegra,'' ''Le Contes d'Hoffmann,'' ''Samson et Dalilah'' and ''Otello.'' This ''Great Performances'' presentation also includes scenes of Mr. Domingo with female colleagues including Shirley Verrett, Ileana Cotrubas, Kiri Te Kanawa, Renata Scotto, Teresa Stratas, Carol Neblett, Elena Obraztsova, Adrianne Pieczonka and Agnes Baltsa. 9 A.M. (Cinemax) LOVE HAPPENS (2009) Aaron Eckhart plays a widowed self-help guru who won't face his grief after the death of his wife. Jennifer Aniston, above with Mr. Eckhart, is the florist who forces him to confront the emotions he has neatly packed away.

headline: Instant Ratings: Just Add Cash
summary: Before the subjects of headlining news stories agree to a television interview these days, some have one question: how much money can I make? ABC and NBC, embroiled in a fight for viewers in the mornings, are increasingly in the news for their willingness to pay thousands of dollars to gain exclusive access to news subjects.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GLOVER, ERIKA DOMENICA LEOPOLDINA
summary: GLOVER--Erika Domenica Leopoldina, age 79, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, died on November 16, 2010, of heart failure and kidney failure at Nevis. Erika Glover was along with her late husband William a Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which they founded in 1964. She was born in the former Yugoslavia in 1931, left for Germany in 1954, and came to the United States, to Kentucky, in 1957. She settled in New York, where she worked for CBS and The New Yorker, marrying William Glover in 1962. She was a woman of courage, enthusiasm, and joy, a bonne vivante who loved her family very much. She is survived by daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu; a brother Luka, sister-in-law Vera, nephew Boris in Croatia; and cousins Marijan and Gregory in Toronto. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, www.doctorswithout borders.org

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (E!) KEEPING UP WITH THE KARDASHIANS The family heads to Bora Bora to celebrate Bruce and Kris Jenner's 20th wedding anniversary. Kim, above left, brings along her new boyfriend, the New Jersey Nets forward Kris Humphries, right, who stirs up a few problems by pushing her too far, or so her parents and siblings think. In real time, he and Ms. Kardashian were scheduled to be married on Saturday. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Karl Rove, a former senior adviser to President George W. Bush, and Bill Burton, a former deputy press secretary for President Obama, discuss the 2012 presidential campaigns. The Republican candidate Rick Santorum will be interviewed.

headline: If You're Going
summary: WHEN IS THE TOURNAMENT? Now through Sunday, Sept. 12. WHERE IS IT? At the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Current TV) BAR KARMA An interactive feature on the Web site for this show offers viewers a chance to help shape the stories they will watch -- with a chance to win a six-month gig at the network. Here is what the audience has helped create (so far): The billionaire Doug Jones (Matthew Humphreys) has won a bet and become the owner of a special bar where he ends up working with a 20,000-year-old bartender named James Anon (William Sanderson, above) and a waitress, Dayna Rollins (Cassie Howarth). Every episode brings in one customer who is at a crossroads in his or her life. And like the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future the employees help the patron come to a realization. In this episode, Charlie O'Connell (''The Bachelor'') is a football player from the 1960s who is torn between two women. 5:30 P.M. (CNBC) MONEY IN MOTION CURRENCY TRADING Melissa Lee hosts this series premiere about currency trading from the Nasdaq MarketSite in Times Square.

headline: Sarkis G. Soghanalian, an Arms Dealer Who Aided U.S. Intelligence, Dies at 82
summary: Sarkis G. Soghanalian, a larger-than-life arms dealer who provided weapons to Saddam Hussein and many other dictators and rebels, worked closely with American intelligence and later told his story on television, died early Wednesday in Hialeah, Fla. He was 82. The cause was heart failure suffered at Hialeah Hospital, his son, Garo Soghanalian, said. He lived in Miami.

headline: More Shows On Demand At Comcast
summary: Comcast said Wednesday that it had become the first cable or satellite provider to have TV shows from each of the four major networks on its video-on-demand service. While the selection is still incomplete - hit shows like ''Modern Family'' and ''The Big Bang Theory'' are missing - the deals represent progress for the television industry. Both network owners and cable providers know that they have to provide more shows on demand to keep consumers happy. Making more programming available on the cable platform could be perceived as an alternative to online streaming and digital video recording.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) FRAMED The eccentric residents of an offbeat Welsh village discover that the National Gallery in London is storing its art collection, including priceless Leonardos, Raphaels and Donatellos, in a nearby mine while the museum is renovated, leading to some strange encounters between a local schoolteacher (Eve Myles) and a forlorn curator (Trevor Eve). He thinks of art in terms of composition, genre and genius; she believes that art is nothing without people to appreciate it -- and perhaps have their lives changed in the process. David Tennant hosts this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' production based on the children's novel about art, life and Ninja Turtles by Frank Cottrell Boyce. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURIn a tribute to members of the United States military and their families, Bob Woodruff looks at the growing number of veterans who find themselves homeless after returning from Iraq and Afghanistan. Ms. Amanpour interviews Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, the vice chief of staff of the Army, about the longterm consequences of repeated deployments. And David Rohde, a reporter for The New York Times, and his wife, Kristen Mulvihill, discuss their new book, ''A Rope and a Prayer,'' which traces the couple's ordeal after Mr. Rohde was kidnapped in November 2008 by members of the Taliban in Afghanistan and held hostage for seven months before escaping.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $43/SQUARE FOOT $220,418 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) LEAVING (2010) A gunshot is heard in the opening scene of this turbulent French drama from Catherine Corsini, which finds Suzanne (Kristin Scott Thomas, right), a British expatriate and physiotherapist, living in apparent comfort in the South of France with her husband, Samuel (Yvan Attal), a doctor, and her teenage children (Alexandre Vidal and Daisy Broom). That is, until she meets Ivan (Sergi López), a Spanish day laborer hired to help renovate a stone shed where her new office will be. Soon enough, Suzanne is abandoning almost everything for love, with Samuel threatening to take away the rest if she doesn't stop this foolishness. ''Here, a contemporary French white woman who yearns for liberté, égalité and fraternité is as much a prisoner of her circumstances as women were once upon a time and still are in some cultures,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, ''though truly it's all the clichés in this film that make her a captive.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT The host Nick Cannon reveals the winner of the $1 million prize and a Las Vegas show.

headline: Josef Suk, 81, Violinist of Czech Musical Dynasty
summary: Josef Suk, a Czech violinist who was known for his warm-toned interpretations of works by Mozart, Beethoven, Debussy and Janacek as well as for his lineage -- he was a great-grandson of Dvorak and a grandson of the turn-of-the-century violinist and composer also named Josef Suk -- died on July 6 in Prague. He was 81 and a lifelong Prague resident. The cause was prostate cancer, said Antonin Matzner, a program adviser at the Prague Spring International Music Festival, of which Mr. Suk was honorary president.

headline: 'Defenders' Tops New Shows
summary: Old favorites led the ratings on Wednesday night, but some new shows put up promising numbers. According to Nielsen's estimates, the new CBS legal drama ''The Defenders'' (12.1 million viewers) delivered the largest audience of any new show on the night, trouncing ABC's rival series ''The Whole Truth'' (4.9 million) and the second half of NBC's ''Law & Order: SVU'' (which averaged 10 million viewers in a two-hour premiere). Earlier on NBC, ''Undercovers'' (8.6 million), a new espionage thriller created by J. J. Abrams, made a solid if more modest debut. CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (14.1 million) earned the night's largest audience, while ABC's Emmy-winning comedy ''Modern Family''(12.6 million) finished close behind for the premiere of its second season.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) GREENBERG (2010) In what A. O. Scott called Noah Baumbach's ''funniest and saddest movie'' so far, ''and also the riskiest,'' Ben Stiller, above, plays Roger Greenberg, a 40-year-old former musician who, after a mental breakdown, house-sits in the large Los Angeles home of his vacationing brother. Greta Gerwig portrays Florence Marr, Roger's brother's 25-year-old assistant and Roger's on-again, off-again love interest in his quest to recapture his youth. ''Mr. Stiller, suppressing his well-honed sketch comedian's urge to wink at the audience, turns Roger into a walking challenge to the Hollywood axiom that a movie's protagonist must be likable,'' Mr. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times. ''But Mr. Baumbach, relishing his antihero's obstinate difficulty -- which is less an inability to connect with other people than a stubborn refusal, on hazy grounds of principle, to try -- treats Roger with compassion, even tenderness.'' Only at the end does Mr. Baumbach reveal that the film has been ''a romantic comedy all along,'' Mr. Scott said. ''And suddenly a movie about a man who is defiantly difficult to like becomes very hard not to love.'' 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The topic is the new Congress. Representatives Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota; Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York; Darrell Issa, Republican of California; and Mike Kelly, Republican representative-elect of Pennsylvania, discuss.

headline: Donald S. Kellermann, 83, Varied Journalist
summary: Donald S. Kellermann, who gained wide attention as a young newspaper reporter by committing a crime so that he could report on life in jail, then went on to help start an influential public opinion research organization, the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 83. The cause was liver cancer, his family said.

headline: 'American Idol' Ratings Drop
summary: The second installment of Fox's new season of ''American Idol'' delivered 22.9 million viewers on Thursday, down more than three million from the premiere on Wednesday but far ahead of any other programming on the night, according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox led the night over all, garnering 10.9 million viewers for ''Bones'' at 9 p.m., after ''Idol.'' CBS ranked second, benefiting from ''CSI'' (14.3 million) and ''The Mentalist'' (14.7 million) from 9 to 11 while earning strong ratings for its sitcoms in the 8 p.m. hour, ''The Big Bang Theory'' (13.6 million) and ''$#*! My Dad Says'' (10.3 million). NBC and ABC tied for third with NBC broadcasting new episodes of its comedy lineup, including ''The Office'' (8.3 million) and ''30 Rock'' (5.3 million) and premieres of ''Perfect Couples'' (4.2 million) and ''Parks and Recreation'' (6.2 million). ABC garnered solid results for ''Wipeout'' at 8 (8.3 million) but meager ratings for reruns the rest of the night.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (VH1) PLANET ROCK: THE STORY OF HIP HOP AND THE CRACK GENERATION Snoop Dogg, right; B-Real of Cypress Hill; RZA and Raekwon of the Wu Tang Clan; and other hip-hop artists tell the story of crack cocaine's effect on their culture -- from the Fair Sentencing Act and the drug policies of the Reagan and Bush administrations to the origins of gangsta rap and the murders of Biggie Smalls and Tupac Shakur. Ice-T narrates. ''40 Most Shocking Hip-Hop Moments,'' a two-hour countdown of behavior both ridiculous and scandalous, leads in at 8. 8 A.M. (IFC) THE STATION AGENT (2003). When his only friend dies, an antisocial dwarf moves to rural New Jersey and into a train station. But living in solitary confinement isn't easy when people refuse to leave you alone. Peter Dinklage, Bobby Cannavale and Patricia Clarkson star.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) NEW GIRL She's ''adorkable'': Zooey Deschanel, above, stars as Jess Day, a nerdy loser who, after discovering that her boyfriend is cheating on her, moves into a loft apartment with three male roommates: the bartender Nick (Jake Johnson), the womanizer Schmidt (Max Greenfield) and the personal trainer Coach (Damon Wayans Jr.). Their mission is to help Jess turn off the ''Dirty Dancing'' reruns, pack away the Kleenex box and re-enter the dating scene. Hannah Simone is Cece, Jess's childhood best friend. '' 'New Girl' is charming and quite funny,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, adding that ''it seems quite old-school: an appealing, clueless heroine who bewitches male protectors -- like Barbara Eden on 'I Dream of Jeannie' or Daryl Hannah in 'Splash.' The only difference is that in those older comedies the women have supernatural powers; Jess stands out because she seems so natural.'' 5:30 P.M. (AMC) NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN (2007) Before last year's remake of ''True Grit,'' there was this more modern western from Joel and Ethan Coen, adapted from the Cormac McCarthy novel. Tommy Lee Jones plays Ed Tom Bell, a world-weary sheriff along the Texas border in 1980; Josh Brolin is Llewelyn Moss, a welder who finds $2 million at the scene of a drug deal gone bad; and Javier Bardem, above, is Anton Chigurh, a psychopath charged with retrieving the cash. The film earned Oscars for best director, best picture and best adapted screenplay, as well as a best supporting actor award for Mr. Bardem.

headline: The Caucus: Obama Coalition Is Fraying
summary: Results from a New York Times/CBS News poll show that critical parts of the coalition that delivered President Obama to the White House are now switching their allegiance to the Republicans.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT The series begins its 13th season with a thinly veiled account of the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case, as Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) is called to the scene when a hotel maid (Anika Noni Rose) accuses a powerful Italian diplomat (Franco Nero, above right, with Ron Rifkin) of rape. The bureau chief, Cutter (Linus Roache), and Assistant District Attorney Cabot (Stephanie March) eventually find their prosecution growing more complicated when the maid's credibility is questioned. Back at the precinct, Detective Amanda Rollins (Kelli Giddish) steps into the shoes of Detective Stabler (Christopher Meloni, who has left the series). 11:45 A.M. (MoreMax) CRAZY HEART (2009) Jeff Bridges, in his Oscar-winning role, stars as Bad Blake, an aging country singer with a wayward streak, and Maggie Gyllenhaal is Jean Craddock, the small-town reporter who inspires Bad in this tale of second chances, written and directed by Scott Cooper and based on the novel by Thomas Cobb. ''Some of Mr. Bridges's peers may have burned more intensely in their prime, but very few American actors over the past 35 years have flickered and smoldered with such craft and resilience,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''There can never be too many songs about drinking, loving and feeling bad, and there is always room for another version of that old song about the guy who messed it all up and kept on going,'' he added. ''Especially when that guy can play the tune as truly and as well as Mr. Bridges.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) VEGAS, BABY A celebration of Sin City kicks off with ''Ocean's Eleven'' (1960), the classic Rat Pack caper starring Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr., Peter Lawford and Joey Bishop as friends who plot a heist at a Las Vegas casino. The tribute continues at 10:15 with ''Viva Las Vegas'' (1964), featuring Elvis Presley and Ann-Margret, above, as a race car driver and the swimming instructor who wants him to slow down his career; ''The Las Vegas Story'' (1952), starring Jane Russell as a newlywed whose shady past resurfaces when her husband (Vincent Price) insists they visit her hometown, at midnight; ''Painting the Clouds With Sunshine'' (1951), about three chorus girls (Virginia Mayo, Lucille Norman and Virginia Gibson) who hit the Strip in search of rich husbands, at 1:45 a.m.; and ''Meet Me in Las Vegas'' (1956), with Cyd Charisse as a ballerina who becomes the lucky charm of a gambler (Dan Dailey), at 3:30. 7 P.M. (Mnet) BEATS PER MNET Paul Kim and Yvonne Lu host this new daily series focusing on the latest in Asian pop culture, from music and fashion to toys, film and food. In this premiere, the Internet sensation Kaila Yu stops by the Los Angeles studio with her band, Nylon Pink.

headline: CORRECTIONS
summary: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about Mike Hale's choices for the best television shows of 2010 misspelled the given name of the actress who plays the title character in the CBS legal drama ''The Good Wife.'' She is Julianna Margulies, not Juliana.

headline: #TRENDING N.Y.C.
summary: WHEN Derek Jeter sent his 3,000th hit into the stands on Saturday, he also sent #Jeter and #3000 soaring up the weekend Twitter charts, as New Yorkers scrambled to commemorate their favorite Yankee's achievement as well. ''Big shout-out to Derek Jeter for dating Adriana Lima, Jessica Alba & Minka Kelly. Also for #3000 hits in baseball or whatever,'' wrote @funnyordie. (Verdict: funny.) And even Mets fans, those almost genetically inclined to dislike the Yankees, offered their best wishes, like @LucCarl, who wrote: ''This day will not be soon forgotten. What you have accomplished is super-human. #3000. That being said ... Go Mets.'' Sunday and Monday brought two premieres: the Season 8 debut of ''Curb Your Enthusiasm,'' in which Larry David returns to New York, and the United States premiere of the final Harry Potter movie, held at Lincoln Center. Tweets came from Potterheads who had camped out there for hours hoping for a glimpse of the movie's stars, and from confused commuters wondering just what spectacle they were witnessing. Some, like @beccasara, fell somewhere in the middle.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) CLASSIC HORROR Turner Classic Movies celebrates Halloween this month with a 32-film festival, which picks up here with the long-overlooked ''Carnival of Souls'' (1962), starring Candace Hilligoss as Mary Henry, a free thinker who survives a car crash and goes on the run to save her life from the Man (Herk Harvey, who directed the film) and a conservative society intent on keeping women in their place. The evening continues with Francis Ford Coppola's ''Dementia 13'' (1963), about an Irish clan whose members are killed off by one of its own intent on inheriting the family fortune, at 10:30; William Castle's ''Strait-Jacket'' (1964), with Joan Crawford as an ax murderer trailed by carnage after returning home to her daughter (Diane Baker) from her stint in a mental hospital, at midnight; and a double bill directed by Roger Corman and starring Vincent Price, above, in ''The Pit and the Pendulum'' (1961), at 1:45 a.m., and ''The Masque of the Red Death'' (1964), at 3:15. ''The Devil's Bride'' (1968), Terence Fisher's tale about small-town Satanists who entice a pair of siblings into their coven, closes the lineup, at 5. 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL The Waldorf family's Yom Kippur observance spirals into chaos. Serena (Blake Lively) finds her new job threatening her friendship with Dan (Penn Badgley), and Diana (Elizabeth Hurley) looks for some heroism from Nate (Chace Crawford) as her latest publication becomes mired in problems. In ''Hart of Dixie,'' at 9, Zoe (Rachel Bilson) exposes a scandal involving a minister (Peter MacKenzie) and his wife (Kerry O'Malley), and Lemon (Jaime King) tries to raise money to restore a bridge destroyed by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) AFI'S MASTER CLASS -- THE ART OF COLLABORATION Turner Classic Movies and the American Film Institute examine the 40-year friendship and working partnership between the director Steven Spielberg and the composer John Williams. The program begins with a look at ''The Sugarland Express'' (1974), Mr. Spielberg's first theatrical film, for which he hired Mr. Williams to write the music. It then moves on to blockbusters like ''Jaws'' (1975), above, which earned Mr. Williams the first of three Oscars he would win from scoring Mr. Spielberg's films; ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' (1977); ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' (1982), Mr. Williams's second Oscar; and ''Schindler's List'' (1993), his third. ''Saving Private Ryan'' (1998), starring Tom Hanks as a squad leader sent to find a soldier (Matt Damon) whose brothers have died in combat, and which Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, called ''soberly magnificent,'' follows at 9. Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Williams's work can be seen in the coming ''Adventures of Tintin'' and ''War Horse,'' both in theaters at Christmas, and in their 26th film together, ''Lincoln,'' slated for release in December 2012. 9:15 A.M. (Sundance) OF TIME AND THE CITY (2009) In his first documentary Terence Davies uses archival footage, musical excerpts and recollections to construct a poetic essay about the Liverpool, England, of his childhood. He revisits the pain and pleasure of growing up gay and Roman Catholic in postwar Britain. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''a deeply personal piece of art that never descends into the confessional or the therapeutic, and a work of social and literary criticism that never lectures or hectors, but rather, with melancholy, tenderness and wit, manages to sing.'' In ''Fermat's Room,'' Luis Piedrahita and Rodrigo Sopeña's thriller, at 12:15 p.m., four mathematicians are trapped inside a shrinking chamber and must solve a series of puzzles to survive.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $48/SQUARE FOOT $579,984 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) BONES Season 7 opens as the team investigates the death of a woman with a history of amnesia, disappearances and head trauma whose body was found in a shallow grave. Booth (David Boreanaz) and Brennan (Emily Deschanel, above with Mr. Boreanaz) discuss how they'll live after their baby is born. 7 A.M. (Oxygen) SHOPGIRL (2005) In this film adaptation of a novella by Steve Martin, who also stars in and wrote the screenplay, a down-on-his-luck stencil artist (Jason Schwartzman) and an older millionaire (Mr. Martin) compete for the attention of a lonely glove saleswoman at Saks. Claire Danes plays the object of the men's ardor.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) JESSE STONE: INNOCENTS LOST (2011) Tom Selleck, above, fresh off the first season of the recently renewed police drama ''Blue Bloods,'' reprises his role as Chief Stone, the novelist Robert B. Parker's beleaguered detective in the fictional Paradise, Mass., whose battles with alcohol and his ex-wife have made his life anything but bliss. In this seventh installment, a newly reinstated Stone is jolted by the death of a teenage girl he tried to help go straight, prompting him to investigate the situation while acting as a consultant in the case of a murder convict who may be innocent. Kathy Baker (as Deputy Rose Gammon), Kohl Sudduth (Deputy Luther Simpson), Stephen McHattie (State Homicide Commander Healy) and William Devane (Stone's psychiatrist, Dr. Dix) fill out the cast. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews King Abdullah II of Jordan, who on Tuesday met with President Obama.

headline: ZERO HOUR
summary: CBS usually waits until after the nets have been cut down following the national championship game to show its annual N.C.A.A. tournament highlight reel, ''One Shining Moment.'' The network could have shown it Thursday if it wanted to. There was certainly enough material. Some of the moments will live for years. It was hard to watch Morehead State's Kenneth Faried blocking a last-second attempt by Louisville without leaving his feet and not think back to 1993 when Santa Clara sealed an upset against second-seeded Arizona and introduced the country to a stringy-haired guard named Steve Nash. For Princeton, seeing its season end in the final seconds against mighty Kentucky must have felt uncomfortably close to when the 1989 Tigers, seeded 16th, came so close to felling No. 1 Georgetown, a team led by Alonzo Mourning.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) 2011 AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS Fans have voted, and the winners will be revealed at this 39th-annual ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater L.A. Adele leads the pack with four nominations; Katy Perry, Lady Gaga, Lil Wayne, Rihanna, Taylor Swift and the Band Perry follow with three each. Nicki Minaj and the D.J. David Guetta, both above, will open the show; Maroon 5 and Christina Aguilera will pair up on ''Moves Like Jagger''; and Drake will perform his hit ''Headlines.'' Other collaborations include Ludacris with Enrique Iglesias; Pitbull with Marc Anthony and Lil Jon; Gym Class Heroes and Adam Levine; and Will.i.am and Jennifer Lopez. Mary J. Blige, Kelly Clarkson, Chris Brown, LMFAO, Daughtry and OneRepublic fill out the roster. Vanessa Lachey and Chris Harrison will host ''Countdown to the American Music Awards,'' a red-carpet special at 7. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Rahm Emanuel, the Chicago mayor and former White House chief of staff, makes a case for the re-election of President Obama; Senators Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, and Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, discuss the Agree Act, which puts together jobs proposals favored by both Democrats and Republicans.

headline: New York Is Ready For Its Close-Up
summary: New York has played many roles on television recently. On ''Blue Bloods,'' the CBS drama about several generations of a crime-fighting family, the city's landmarks have been showcased, with the Brooklyn Bridge and Washington Square Park proving to be particularly popular repositories for killers disposing of bodies.

headline: For Sale
summary: $18 MILLION Chelsea Star Hotel

headline: So Did Nadal
summary: To the Sports Editor: Re ''Open and CBS Ponder Their Losses During Interminable Wait for Winner,'' Sept. 14: Rafael Nadal, garnering a career Grand Slam at 24 with his victory at the United States Open on Monday night, deserved a great deal more respect from CBS and ESPN2 than he received during the broadcast of his delayed final against Novak Djokovic.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Google and its YouTube division strongly outpaced all other video content properties in January. Top properties include Vevo, a music site, and Viacom, which has shows like ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' on Nickelodeon and ''The Game,'' with Tia Mowry and Pooch Hall, above, a BET sitcom. Turner Digital has teamed up with Sports Illustrated to present Nascar, P.G.A. and N.B.A. content, along with episodes from its TNT portfolio. CBS Interactive has a similar reach with sports, TV shows and news, and Break Media offers entertainment aimed at men. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Los Angeles County Officials Restart '81 Inquiry in Actress's Death
summary: MONTEREY PARK, Calif. - The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said on Friday that it had reopened its investigation into the actress Natalie Wood's death 30 years ago because of new information from multiple sources. ''Recently, we received information which we felt was substantial enough'' to reopen the case, Lt. John Corina of the Sheriff's Department said at a morning news conference here.

headline: Tough Return for Paul Reiser
summary: Twelve years after ''Mad About You,'' Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBC's comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of ''The Paul Reiser Show'' at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBC's similarly ratings-starved sitcom ''Community'' (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by ''American Idol'' on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for ''The Office'' (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of ''Idol'' and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for ''Bones.'' CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of ''Wipeout'' at 8 (6.2 million). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: GAMES TO WATCH
summary: NO. 1 OKLAHOMA AT NO. 5 FLORIDA STATE 8 p.m., ABC

headline: A Women's Team Wins 'The Amazing Race'
summary: For the first time in its 17 seasons of globe-trotting ''The Amazing Race'' has been won by an all-woman team. Viewers saw Nat Strand and Kat Chang reach the finish line first on CBS on Sunday night, beating another female duo, Claire Champlin and Brook Roberts. Several men-women pairs have won the competition's $1 million prize but television critics have wondered when two women would do so. Women have won other reality shows, like ''Survivor'' on CBS. The ''Amazing Race'' finale drew almost 12 million viewers on Sunday. When the series returns in February it will be broadcast for the first time in high definition. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Paul Leka, 68; Wrote Hit That Became Arena Taunt
summary: Paul Leka, a songwriter and producer who worked with many recording stars but who was best known for writing the chanting chorus of ''Na Na Hey Hey (Kiss Him Goodbye),'' a No. 1 hit in 1969 that was reborn in the 1970s as a sports arena anthem, died on Oct. 12 in a hospice near his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 68. The cause was lung cancer, said his brother, George.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8:30 P.M. (Fox) BOB'S BURGERS In this animated series, above, Louise (the voice of Kristen Schaal) feels left out when Bob (H. Jon Benjamin) and Gene (Eugene Mirman) bond over spaghetti westerns. Gene even gets pointers from the films on how to deal with a school rival. At 9 p.m., on ''Family Guy,'' Peter (the voice of Seth MacFarlane) persuades Lois (Alex Borstein) to take up boxing. And at 9:30 p.m., on ''American Dad!'' Steve (the voice of Scott Grimes) challenges his father, Stan (Seth MacFarlane), who does everything in his power to show that he is still the leader of the pack. And Hayley (Rachel MacFarlane) and Jeff (Jeff Fischer) are off to marriage counseling after their short honeymoon phase. 7 A.M. (ABC) TODAY The actor James Marsden is a guest, Sheryl Crow performs and the chef Chuck White demonstrates.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
summary: NO. 11 FLORIDA STATE AT NO. 21 CLEMSON 3:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (TV Land) AFI LIFE ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO MORGAN FREEMAN One of the top-grossing actors of all time -- his films have earned more than $3 billion in ticket sales -- Mr. Freeman, right, is known for work infused with a quiet dignity. In this ceremony held on June 9 in Los Angeles, Mr. Freeman's cultural contributions were honored by the American Film Institute and friends and peers, including Betty White, who stepped out of a limousine in a spoof of ''Driving Miss Daisy''; Rita Moreno, who recited a love poem; Helen Mirren, who presented a poem on aging; Don Cheadle, who introduced film clips from ''Glory''; and Forest Whitaker and Tim Robbins, who discussed ''The Shawshank Redemption.'' Clint Eastwood, who directed Mr. Freeman in ''Unforgiven,'' ''Invictus'' and ''Million Dollar Baby,'' for which Mr. Freeman won an Oscar for best supporting actor, presented the award. ''I'm glad I'm an actor,'' Mr. Freeman said at the end of the evening, ''but for this one night you've made me feel like a star.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews the outgoing Secretary of Defense, Robert M. Gates, and Jon Stewart of ''The Daily Show.''

headline: Express to the Web
summary: CECIL BEATON produced a torrent of work, not unlike Andy Warhol and Takashi Murakami, who collaborated with Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton. In a new book, ''Cecil Beaton: The New York Years,'' Donald Albrecht suggests that his methods of working in a variety of media, his blurring of the lines between art and commerce, and his promotional skills made him ''remarkably prescient.'' Certainly Beaton was able to move from one medium to another: fashion photography, portraiture, illustration, costume and set design. I'm sure many designers today wish they could be liberated from their studio bunkers; the demands of work keep them pinned down like enemy fire. A few have time to express themselves in other media (and I don't mean HSN), but most have to do their dreaming with pins and fabric and mood boards. It's not so bad.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DRIBBEN, ELIZABETH L.
summary: DRIBBEN--Elizabeth L.,New York City, passed away on January 20, 2011 after a long illness. Elizabeth was born in Buffalo, NY on August 20, 1937 and was the daughter of the late Louis Dribben and Clara Franklin. A graduate of Lafayette High School (Buffalo) and University of Buffalo, "Liz" enjoyed a four-decade career encompassing almost every aspect of broadcast news from writing to producing to on-air reporting, both locally on Buffalo's WKBW-TV and nationally for CBS News, in both radio and television. A pioneer among women in her field, Dribben continued to mentor younger reporters in her capacity as a member of the Adjunct Faculty of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University. At CBS from 197293, Dribben was principal writerproducer for Mike Wallace and Dan Rather, and produced her own program, One on One, eventually racking up some 2000 in-depth interviews with newsmakers in politics and the arts, from jurist Robert Bork to actress Helen Hayes. Her passion for theatre was legendary. She created and managed the network's (and the world's) first satellite radio unit. Ms. Dribben was a 2001 inductee of the Buffalo Broadcasting Hall of Fame, and a 2008 inductee to the Lafayette High School Hall of Fame. While she leaves no immediate family, she is survived by cousins in Albany, New York City and Israel, with her "family of friends" intertwined world-wide throughout the broadcasting and performance arts world. Elizabeth's generosity extends beyond her life, with the donation of her body to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Contributions in her memory may be made to the University at Buffalo (Attn: Cindy Johannes E. Dribben Archives, P.O. Box 730, Buffalo, NY) or the Buffalo Broadcasters (Buffalo Broadcasters Association, 5672 Main Street, Williamsville, NY 14221) to help with the archiving of over 2,000 items from Elizabeth's vast portfolio from personal correspondence to reel to reel tape interviews. Memorial services in Buffalo and New York City will be planned over the next few months. Toot-a-loo, Elizabeth - and spin that prayer wheel for us!

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CRANBERG, LAWRENCE M.
summary: CRANBERG--Lawrence M.,PhD. Lawrence Cranberg, 94, passed away on November 21, 2011 surrounded by his loving family. Cancer was the cause of death. Lawrence, a true patriot, was born on the 4th of July in 1917 in Bronx, New York, the eldest child of Fanny Rubenstein and Hyman Cranberg Polish and Russian immigrants. Lawrence married Charlotte Mount on October 31, 1953 in New Mexico at the Old Santa Fe Courthouse. A nuclear physicist, inventor and entrepreneur, Dr. Cranberg's career spanned seven decades, but the wonder and beauty of science was always on his mind. After graduating from Townsend Harris High School at age 16, he matriculated from the City College of New York, Harvard University, and The University of Pennsylvania. His career in science began in 1940 at the Signal Corps. Engineering Labs where he was a Senior Physicist. Dr. Cranberg developed systems of target detection and location-based use of infra-red radiation, a precursor technology to today's autofocus cameras. He later joined the Los Alamos National Laboratory where he became a fellow of the Atomic Energy Commission. At Los Alamos, he was a protege of Hans Bethe, and conducted groundbreaking research on high energy neutrons. Dr. Cranberg was appointed to the US delegation to the First International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy at Geneva in 1955 where he reported on his work. Among his many widely-cited publications were papers in The Scientific American and Physics Today. Dr. Cranberg also generously shared his intuitive insights with colleagues; one such insight directly led to the discovery of the neutrino. Dr. Cranberg was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1958 his nomination made by 1995 Nobelist and neutrino pioneer Frederick Reines and J.M.B. Kellogg. Once introduced as "Mr. Nanosecond" by Sir Denys Wilkinson to a London physics conference, Dr. Cranberg developed the means to measure a billionth of second before "nanotechnology" was a word; his "time-of-flight" method of measuring neutron spectra became the foundation for neutron spectrometry. Following a Guggenheim fellowship in 1962, Dr. Cranberg was instrumental in securing a large federal grant to the University of Virginia to build and to become founding director of its Physics Accelerator Laboratory. He was a devoted scientist and teacher. Thirty years later, one of his grateful graduate students would endow a scholarship and faculty research in his name at George Mason University, remarking that Dr. Cranberg inspired him by exemplifying the work ethic of American scientists. Dr. Cranberg didn't hesitate to fight for justice whether it be the case of his own academic freedom, or his involvement in the lawsuit that eventually forced UVA to accept women into its formerly all-male undergraduate school. In 1971, after winning an AAUP hearing that declared his academic freedom had been invaded, Dr. Cranberg moved to Austin where he joined a small high-tech company, eventually starting his own firm to develop fast-neutron techniques for the treatment of cancer. He was always grateful for the welcome arms of the private sector and of Texas, calling it "The Land of Milk and Honey". In 1975, Dr. Cranberg applied the laws of physics to fire-building and invented the Texas Fireframe grate. Later dubbed "The Physicist's Fire" by Time magazine, his invention was featured in news stories on CBS and BBC. His company is now run by his daughter. An advocate for social causes throughout his life, Dr. Cranberg fought for racial equality in Virginia (he also recruited the first black graduate physics student at UVA), for the freedom of Russian physicist Andrei Sakharov and for scientists and inventors not properly credited for their work. He wrote incisively about topics from the ethical problems of scientists to the pseudoscientific basis of Marxism. Dr. Cranberg's candidacy for the U.S. Senate from Texas was inspired by his desire for science to better inform decisions in and of the law. Dr. Cranberg's capacity for indignation at injustice was matched only by his optimistic belief in his ability to fight for change and to make a difference. Dr. Cranberg was a loving, devoted husband, father and grandfather: his last words were "I'm the richest man in the world." His enthusiasm, generosity, sense of humor and his quest for knowledge, truth, and justice are just a few of the qualities that his family, friends and colleagues will always remember him for. Dr. Cranberg is survived by Charlotte, wife of 58 years; son Alex of Austin, Texas; daughter Nicole and husband Giff Crosby of Cos Cob, Connecticut; and grandchildren Jacob, Hannah and Clare. Other surviving family members include brother, Gilbert Cranberg of Sarasota, Florida and sister, Sylvia Troy of Beverly Shores, Indiana. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial donations be made to the Niels Bohr Physics Library Center for History of Physics: https://donate.aip.org/ Please type "In Honor of Lawrence Cranberg" in the comments box. A memorial service will be held by the family at a later date. To share memories, please visit http://texasfireframe.com/ fireplace-grate-blog/ 2011/11/24/remembering-lawrence-cranberg/

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: PLAYING THE PONIES Turner Classic Movies presents five for horse lovers, starting with ''National Velvet'' (1944), starring Mickey Rooney as a young drifter who tames the Pie, the wild steed of a 12-year-old British girl (Elizabeth Taylor, above, with Mr. Rooney), training the horse for the Grand National steeplechase. The lineup continues with ''International Velvet'' (1978), at 10:15, a sequel in which an orphaned American girl (Tatum O'Neal) is sent to England, where she rides the Pie's last foal for the British Olympic team under the guidance of a stern trainer (Anthony Hopkins). In ''Black Beauty'' (1946), at 12:30 a.m., a motherless girl (Mona Freeman) searches for the horse she raised; in ''Snowfire'' (1958), at 2, a rancher's daughter (Molly McGowan) forges a bond with a wild stallion. And in ''Casey's Shadow'' (1978), at 3:30, the sons of an irascible and broke horse trainer (Walter Matthau) try to turn their family pet into a champion. 5 P.M. (MSNBC) HARDBALL WITH CHRIS MATTHEWS As part of NBC News's Education Nation On-the-Road tour, Bill Maher and Michael Powell, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and the son of Gen. Colin L. Powell, discuss the educational challenges facing the country.

headline: What's on Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 53RD ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDSBob Dylan, a 10-time Grammy winner and recipient of a lifetime achievement award from the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which presents the Grammys, will perform during the live ceremonies at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Mr. Dylan, above, and Mumford & Sons and the Avett Brothers will salute acoustic music at the event honoring excellence in the recording industry. Dr. Dre, a six-time winner, will give his first live television performance in more than a decade alongside Adam Levine, the Maroon 5 front man, and Eminem, who leads the nominations this year with 10. (Bruno Mars follows with 7; and Jay-Z, Lady Antebellum and Lady Gaga with 6 each.) Other scheduled performers include Mick Jagger, who will take the Grammy stage for the first time, accompanied by Raphael Saadiq and his band, as part of the telecast's In Memoriam segment; Barbra Streisand, the 2011 MusiCares Person of the Year; and Cee Lo Green, joined by Gwyneth Paltrow and the Jim Henson Company Puppets. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour will interview Israel's defense minister, Ehud Barak, about the uprising in Egypt and what it means for the Middle East.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) WILL FERRELL: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Mr. Ferrell, above, the 14th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony taped on Oct. 23. Among those cheering Mr. Ferrell -- whose career has traversed the Groundlings improv group, ''Saturday Night Live'' and films like ''Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby,'' ''Blades of Glory,'' and ''Everything Must Go'' -- are colleagues and friends like Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day, Ed Asner, Jack Black, Matthew Broderick, Gwen Ifill, Adam McKay, Tim Meadows, Conan O'Brien, John C. Reilly, Paul Rudd, Andy Samberg, Molly Shannon and Ben Stiller. ''Before Will a man in his boxers was considered funny,'' Mr. O'Brien said, explaining Mr. Ferrell's appeal. ''But sometime in the '90s Will raised the bar and appeared in tight, unflattering briefs. It was a paradigm shift, a cosmic break, and comedy has never been the same.'' 1 A.M. (TV Land) ROSEANNE'S WICKED HALLOWEEN BASH Five hours of some of the spookiest episodes of ''Roseanne,'' including a spoof of ''Rosemary's Baby'' that starred Marlo Thomas, Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LANGLEY, SUSAN
summary: LANGLEY--Susan, age 63 passed away peacefully on January 31, 2011, after a long illness. She is preceded in death by her parents, John and Dorothy of Brighton-Sussex UK and her beloved companion, Dominic Annechiarico. Susan leaves behind many devoted friends who will mourn the loss of her unique charm, wit and love of life. She arrived on these shores in 1968 and began her long distinguished career at CBS and Sony Music from which she retired as Director Of Human Relations. Susan will be honored at a Memorial service 11am on February 12, 2011 at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church 106 East 86 In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Park Avenue United Methodist Women.

headline: CORRECTIONS
summary: A correction in this space last Sunday for a picture caption on Dec. 19, with a listing of Mike Hale's choices for the best television shows of 2010 referred incorrectly to Julianna Margulies, whose given name had been misspelled as Juliana. Ms. Margulies is the actress who plays the title character in the CBS legal drama ''The Good Wife.'' ''Julianna Margulies'' is not the name of the title character. (Alicia Florrick is the character's name.)

headline: The Election on TV and Online
summary: Two old media outlets, ABC and CBS, have new media partners for Tuesday's midterm elections. ABC is live-streaming its election night special reports on Facebook; CBS is collaborating with Google to mine search results and YouTube video viewing trends.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LANGLEY, SUSAN
summary: LANGLEY--Susan, age 63 passed away peacefully on January 31, 2011, after a long illness. She is preceded in death by her parents, John and Dorothy of Brighton-Sussex UK and her beloved companion, Dominic Annechiarico. Susan leaves behind many devoted friends who will mourn the loss of her unique charm, wit and love of life. She arrived on these shores in 1968 and began her long distinguished career at CBS and Sony Music from which she retired as Director Of Human Relations.
