headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CMT) SWEET HOME ALABAMA Tribble Reese, above, the former college quarterback and self-defined ''bartender extraordinaire'' from Birmingham, Ala., who was the runner-up in the first season of this series, continues his quest for love as 22 women move in together and compete for his affections. ''Sweet Home Alabama: Outtakes & Updates,'' featuring extra footage from the inaugural season, leads in at 8. The sixth round of ''Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders: Making the Team,'' at 10, begins by following hundreds of candidates as they audition for a handful of positions on the squad. 2:30 P.M. (HBO2) CATFISH (2010) In this festival favorite from Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman, Nev Schulman (Ariel's brother), right, a 24-year-old New York City photographer, becomes entangled in an Internet relationship with a Michigan family that includes an 8-year-old art prodigy and her beautiful older sister -- with whom Nev supposedly falls in love. Reviewing the film in The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote: '' 'Catfish' flops down into this paradoxical reality and proceeds to generate some complications of its own. Judged by the usual standards it is a wretched documentary: visually and narratively sloppy; coy about its motives; slipshod in its adherence to basic ethical norms.'' He added: ''But at the same time -- precisely because of these lapses -- 'Catfish' is a fascinating document, at once glib, untrustworthy and strangely authentic. I say this with a heavy sigh: this is, by far, one of the most intriguing movies of the year.''

headline: To Beat 'Today,' Look To Tomorrow
summary: When a sports team loses long enough, fans get restless and soon enough, the coach ends up getting the gate. After all, you can't fire the whole team, right? Unless you work in television. Last week, every single member of the perennially last place ''Early Show'' on CBS was shown the door. Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez are out. Even the weatherman, Dave Price, was let go. (Why blame the weatherman for something besides the weather? Did he forget to convert from Celsius?)

headline: With a Crash, Entering Theater Used By Letterman
summary: Updated 3:11 p.m. | Most visitors to the Ed Sullivan Theater enter by way of a ticket to David Letterman's ''Late Show.'' But about 7 a.m. on Sunday, a 22-year-old man broke in through the glass doors to the theater, on Broadway between 53rd and 54th Streets, the police said. The police have not offered any explanation for why the suspect chose the building, beyond noting that the man, an aspiring actor, appeared intoxicated.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 3 A.M. (BBC America, MSNBC, WE, 13, 49); 3:30 A.M. (TLC); 4 A.M. (ABC, CBS, CNN, E!, Fox News, NBC, Univision); 5 A.M. (Fox, Reelz); 6 A.M. (HLN) THE WEDDING OF PRINCE WILLIAM AND KATE MIDDLETON Royals watchers will need to rise and shine extra early to catch the nuptials of William and Kate at Westminster Abbey, above, scheduled for 11 a.m. local time (6 a.m. in New York), after celebrities like David and Victoria Beckham and foreign royalty including the sultans of Oman and Brunei have filed into the pews. The service will be led by the Rev. Dr. John Hall, the dean of Westminster; the couple will be married by the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury. The Right Rev. Richard Chartres, the bishop of London, will present the address; music will be provided by the Chapel Royal Choir and the Choir of Westminster Abbey, the London Chamber Orchestra and the fanfare trumpets from the Central Band of the Royal Air Force, in honor of William's service as a pilot. After the ceremony the newlyweds will travel to Buckingham Palace for the traditional kiss on the balcony in the 1902 State Landau coach (rain gear: the Glass Coach), accompanied by nine gray horses. ROYAL WEDDING PRIME-TIME ROUNDUP Let the analysis and the backbiting begin! Joan Collins, Lisa Rinna, Lisa Vanderpump, Nate Berkus, Jay Manuel and Colin Quinn dish on the details in ''Joy Behar's Royal Wedding After Party,'' at 7 p.m. on HLN. London is the setting for ''The Fox Report With Shepard Smith'' at 7 and''The Royal Wedding,'' a recap of the day's high points at 9, both on Fox News Channel. Perez Hilton and NeNe Leakes let the snark flow with highlights from the wedding in ''Will + Kate Forever,'' at 7 on the Wedding Channel and at 9 on WE. Katie Couric examines the significance of the wedding and the future of the British monarchy in ''The Royal Wedding: Modern Majesty'' at 8 on CBS. You can be sure that no stone will be left unturned, and possibly unflung, in ''Kathy Griffin's Insightful and Hilarious Take on the Royal Wedding,'' at 8 on TV Guide. Ann Curry ventures backstage to find out what happens after the pomp and circumstance in a two-hour version of ''Dateline NBC'' at 9. Barbara Walters reminisces about the events of the day, and no doubt evokes a tear or two, in ''A Special Edition of 20/20: A Modern Fairytale'' at 9 on ABC. And on E! Ryan Seacrest traces the footsteps of the bride and groom in ''Will and Kate: Road to the Altar'' at 9, while Joan Rivers, Kelly Osbourne, George Kotsiopoulos, Giuliana Rancic and Tori Spelling dissect the guests' attire, the headpieces and the gown to end all gowns in a special edition of ''Fashion Police Royal Wedding'' at 10.

headline: A Rich Year, and More to Come
summary: AFTER falling for two years in the wake of the financial crisis and the recession, executive pay is soaring again. The median salary for C.E.O.'s at about 200 big American companies rose 12 percent last year, while the average was up 20 percent, according to data compiled by Equilar. By comparison, average pay for American workers in the private sector rose 2.1 percent in 2010, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Many large corporations have not yet publicly disclosed compensation, so paydays for other executives could surpass those of the 30 C.E.O.'s listed below. For instance, Leslie Moonves of the CBS Corporation made $43 million in 2009, which would have easily earned him one of the top spots that year. But the company had not disclosed his pay in time for publication.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Black Girls Rock!, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the healthy emotional development of young black women, joins forces with BET to pay tribute to role models who have made outstanding contributions to society through their careers and public service. Tracee Ellis Ross and Regina King host this special, taped at the Paradise Theater in the Bronx, which honors women in business, politics, entertainment, sports and community service, including Angela Davis, Shirley Caesar, Taraji P. Henson (above), Laurel J. Richie, Imani Walker, Malika Saada Saar and Tatyana Ali. Performers include Mary J. Blige, Erykah Badu, Jill Scott, Melanie Fiona, Mary Mary and Elle Varner. Nia Long, KeKe Palmer, Anita Baker, Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight and Ruby Bridges, who in 1960 was one of six children chosen to desegregate the New Orleans schools, offer messages of inspiration. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR House Speaker John A. Boehner weighs in on reducing the deficit, job creation and the Republican presidential contenders.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE BACKSTAGE Behind-the-scenes glimpses, like a set sketch, above, chronicle the history of ''Saturday Night Live,'' including how the show began in 1975. Interviews feature some of the stars, writers, hosts and musical guests -- among them, Alec Baldwin, Drew Barrymore, Jeff Bridges, Albert Brooks, James Franco, Buck Henry, Sarah Palin, Joe Piscopo, Taylor Swift, Justin Timberlake and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, discuss President Obama's proposed 2012 budget and potential bipartisan solutions to the nation's fiscal problems. There's more on that subject with Senators Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, and Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; with Representatives Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, and Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and with Senators Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Flix) ANTONIA'S LINE (1995) Part fable, part pastoral fantasy, this winner of the Oscar for best foreign film, written and directed by Marleen Gorris, follows the magically feminist bloodline of a Dutch matriarch (Willeke van Ammelrooy, above, with Jan Decleir) as she reflects, over the course of a single day, on her life after World War II. Els Dottermans portrays Danielle, Antonia's daughter, an introvert who isn't too shy to stab the village rapist with a pitchfork. Carolien Spoor, Esther Vriesendorp and Veerle van Overloop play Danielle's intellectually precocious daughter, Therese, at various points in her life. And Elsie de Brauw is Lara, Therese's tutor, with whom Danielle falls in love as she imagines her to be a living version of Botticelli's Venus. ''While the film rejects and even mocks ideas of organized religion, it has a solid faith in nature and destiny, as well as in the fundamental goodness of its women,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. ''It expresses that faith with serene confidence in the cycles of birth, death and replenishment that play out during the story.'' 3 P.M. (Cinemax) HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG (2003) Massoud Behrani (Ben Kingsley, left, in an Oscar-nominated role), an exiled Iranian military officer reduced to menial labor in his adopted homeland, and Kathy Nicolo (Jennifer Connelly), a house cleaner recovering from years of addiction and the breakup of her marriage, spar -- with tragic consequences -- over a modest piece of coastal California real estate to which both seem to have an equally legitimate claim in this directorial debut from Vadim Perelman, based on the novel by Andre Dubus III. Shohreh Aghdashloo is Nadi, the wife over whom Behrani exercises a brutal tyranny; Ron Eldard is Lester Burdon, the sheriff's deputy who evicted Kathy from her house and now wants to help her get it back. None of the central characters ''are particularly likable, but they all seem worthy of sympathy, in part because they remain capable of showing it,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Even as the conflict over the house escalates, Behrani, Lester and Kathy all hold on to compassion and decency, and even show signs of a willingness to relent. They seem to agree that no house is worth a human life, which makes the heavily foreshadowed final cataclysm especially painful and powerful.''

headline: StarGreetz Has Star Backers
summary: LOS ANGELES - Many young companies are trying to seize on the intersection of social media, personalization and celebrity, but StarGreetz.com has something most do not: a pack of prominent Hollywood backers. StarGreetz, which is only a few months old, has two primary businesses. The simple one is a line of personalized video e-cards, invitations, ringtones and greetings priced at 99 cents to $2.99. Animated characters (Cinderella), athletes (Joe Namath) and other celebrities (Reba McEntire) speak directly to the recipient by name. Sample: ''Michael, hey this is Reba!''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) SYRIA UNDERCOVER As the death toll from the revolution in Syria nears 3,000, Ramita Navai, above, a reporter for ''Frontline,'' travels incognito to meet with members of the opposition movement and experiences life as a fugitive when she is trapped in a safe house with three coordinators on the government's most-wanted list. Also, Anthony Shadid, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times, talks about how President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has managed to hold on amid the Arab unrest. In ''Women, War & Peace,'' at 10 on Channels 13 and 49, modern warfare and the unprecedented uses of women as primary targets is discussed by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and her predecessors Condoleezza Rice and Madeleine K. Albright; Leymah Gbowee, the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize winner; Fadila Memisevic, the Bosnian war crimes investigator; and Zainab Salbi, founder of Women for Women International, which helps female war survivors rebuild their lives. Geena Davis narrates. 11:35 A.M. (Cinemax) AVATAR (2009) This ''trippy joy ride about the end of life -- our moviegoing life included,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times, took decades of dreaming and four years of making (with a $230 million production budget) by the director James Cameron. Sam Worthington plays a paraplegic former Marine who is transported from a wheelchair into a 10-foot, blue-skinned, part-alien and part-human body, the better to infiltrate a distant moon that harbors a valuable substance called unobtainium. Alas, he falls in love with both this lush dreamscape and one of its slinky inhabitants (Zoë Saldana). ''If the story of a paradise found and potentially lost feels resonant, it's because 'Avatar' is as much about our Earth as the universe that Mr. Cameron has invented,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''But the movie's truer meaning is in the audacity of its filmmaking.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:15 A.M. (Showtime) THE ART OF THE STEAL (2009) Don Argott chronicles the contentious history of the Barnes Foundation, a private art collection established in suburban Philadelphia by Albert C. Barnes (1872-1951), above, a chemist who made a fortune by developing an antiseptic drug. Barnes stipulated that the European masterworks, African sculptures, Asian prints and American Indian ceramics valued at more than $25 billion that he amassed should remain in their original locale, far from the urban elite he despised. ''Money, power, race, a mansion stuffed with treasure, a city plagued by scandal -- about all that's missing from 'The Art of the Steal,' a hard-hitting documentary about a high-cultural brawl, is a hot woman with a warm gun,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: ''At times the fight comes across as a smackdown between art snobs who want to preserve Barnes's right to exhibit his masterworks however he wanted because, well, he paid for them (a curiously underexamined refrain), and vulgarians who want to turn his patrimony into tourist bait along with the Liberty Bell and an actor in a Ben Franklin getup. What remains unanswered, finally, is the larger question of whether deep pockets ensure custodial rights forever.'' After a 2004 ruling that allowed the foundation to bypass its charter, the collection is expected to move into a new building in downtown Philadelphia early in 2012.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CRANBERG, LAWRENCE M.
summary: CRANBERG--Lawrence M., PhD. Lawrence Cranberg, 94, passed away on November 21, 2011 surrounded by his loving family. Cancer was the cause of death. Lawrence, a true patriot, was born on the 4th of July in 1917 in Bronx, New York, the eldest child of Fanny Rubenstein and Hyman Cranberg - Polish and Russian immigrants. Lawrence married Charlotte Mount on October 31, 1953 in New Mexico at the Old Santa Fe Courthouse. A nuclear physicist, inventor and entrepreneur, Dr. Cranberg's career spanned seven decades, but the wonder and beauty of science was always on his mind. After graduating from Townsend Harris High School at age 16, he matriculated from the City College of New York, Harvard University, and The University of Pennsylvania. His career in science began in 1940 at the Signal Corps. Engineering Labs where he was a Senior Physicist. Dr. Cranberg developed systems of target detection and location-based use of infra-red radiation, a precursor technology to today's autofocus cameras. He later joined the Los Alamos National Laboratory where he became a fellow of the Atomic Energy Commission. At Los Alamos, he was a protege of Hans Bethe, and conducted groundbreaking research on high energy neutrons. Dr. Cranberg was appointed to the US delegation to the First International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy at Geneva in 1955 where he reported on his work. Among his many widely-cited publications were papers in The Scientific American and Physics Today. Dr. Cranberg also generously shared his intuitive insights with colleagues; one such insight directly led to the discovery of the neutrino. Dr. Cranberg was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1958 - his nomination made by 1995 Nobelist and neutrino pioneer Frederick Reines and J.M.B. Kellogg. Once introduced as "Mr. Nanosecond" by Sir Denys Wilkinson to a London physics conference, Dr. Cranberg developed the means to measure a billionth of second before "nanotechnology" was a word; his "time-of-flight" method of measuring neutron spectra became the foundation for neutron spectrometry. Following a Guggenheim fellowship in 1962, Dr. Cranberg was instrumental in securing a large federal grant to the University of Virginia to build and to become founding director of its Physics Accelerator Laboratory. He was a devoted scientist and teacher. Thirty years later, one of his grateful graduate students would endow a scholarship and faculty research in his name at George Mason University, remarking that Dr. Cranberg inspired him by exemplifying the work ethic of American scientists. Dr. Cranberg didn't hesitate to fight for justice whether it be the case of his own academic freedom, or his involvement in the lawsuit that eventually forced UVA to accept women into its formerly all-male undergraduate school. In 1971, after winning an AAUP hearing that declared his academic freedom had been invaded, Dr. Cranberg moved to Austin where he joined a small high-tech company, eventually starting his own firm to develop fast-neutron techniques for the treatment of cancer. He was always grateful for the welcome arms of the private sector and of Texas, calling it "The Land of Milk and Honey". In 1975, Dr. Cranberg applied the laws of physics to fire-building and invented the Texas Fireframe grate. Later dubbed "The Physicist's Fire" by Time magazine, his invention was featured in news stories on CBS and BBC. His company is now run by his daughter. An advocate for social causes throughout his life, Dr. Cranberg fought for racial equality in Virginia (he also recruited the first black graduate physics student at UVA), for the freedom of Russian physicist Andrei Sakharov and for scientists and inventors not properly credited for their work. He wrote incisively about topics from the ethical problems of scientists to the pseudoscientific basis of Marxism. Dr. Cranberg's candidacy for the U.S. Senate from Texas was inspired by his desire for science to better inform decisions in and of the law. Dr. Cranberg's capacity for indignation at injustice was matched only by his optimistic belief in his ability to fight for change and to make a difference. Dr. Cranberg was a loving, devoted husband, father and grandfather: his last words were "I'm the richest man in the world." His enthusiasm, generosity, sense of humor and his quest for knowledge, truth, and justice are just a few of the qualities that his family, friends and colleagues will always remember him for. Dr. Cranberg is survived by Charlotte, wife of 58 years; son Alex of Austin, Texas; daughter Nicole and husband Giff Crosby of Cos Cob, Connecticut; and grandchildren Jacob, Hannah and Clare. Other surviving family members include brother, Gilbert Cranberg of Sarasota, Florida and sister, Sylvia Troy of Beverly Shores, Indiana. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial donations be made to the Niels Bohr Physics Library Center for History of Physics: https://donate.aip.org/ Please type "In Honor of Lawrence Cranberg" in the comments box. A memorial service will be held by the family at a later date. To share memories, please visit http://texasfireframe.com/ fireplace-grate-blog/ 2011/11/24/remembering-lawrence-cranberg/

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Three weeks into the young season, and three new broadcast series have fallen: ''Outlaw'' (NBC), ''Lone Star'' (Fox) and ''My Generation'' (ABC). No new arrivals are in the top 10 shows. Crime dramas continue to be very popular. These include NCIS (CBS), at No. 3 overall, ''Blue Bloods,'' above starring Tom Selleck, and ''Criminal Minds'' (CBS), at No. 8 in its sixth season.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSEL At this point in the awards season you'd have to be living under a rock not to know that George VI -- portrayed by Colin Firth, the best actor Oscar favorite for ''The King's Speech'' -- stuttered. But did you know that John Stossel was also a stutterer? In this edition Mr. Stossel, above, describes how he overcame it. He also looks at the happily-ever-after messages projected by Hollywood movies in general and asks how realistic they are. His guests include Glenn Garvin, the television critic for The Miami Herald; Suzanne Somers, the actress and author of ''Sexy Forever''; Lisa Kennedy Montgomery, a former MTV host; Dr. Paul Offit, chief of the infectious diseases division at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia; and Michael Medved, the radio host and film critic. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA A report on Kate Middleton, the future bride of Prince William.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) LA LA'S FULL COURT LIFE In this Season 2 opener, La La Anthony (above, with her son, Kiyan), the wife of the basketball player Carmelo Anthony, adjusts to life in New York after her husband is traded to the Knicks. But her friends' talk about infidelity soon forces her to confront issues in her own marriage. In the premiere of ''Styled by June,'' at 9:30, June Ambrose, a fashion stylist for Jay-Z, Mariah Carey, Mary J. Blige and Jamie Foxx, helps some faded stars rebrand themselves. Ms. Ambrose's first client is the actress Mischa Barton, who says that her soul has been sucked dry by attention from the paparazzi. 7:05 P.M. (Sundance) PABLO'S HIPPOS (2010) Antonio Von Hildebrand chronicles the rise to power of the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar through the eyes of a pet hippopotamus.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (BET); 8 P.M. (Centric) A BET NEWS EXCLUSIVE: THE PRESIDENT ANSWERS BLACK AMERICA In the first of a series of specials created by BET Networks to bring an African-American perspective to the 2012 presidential campaign, President Obama speaks with the journalist Emmett Miller at the White House about the economic crisis, the American Jobs Act and other topics of concern to black voters. Viewers can submit questions at #AskObama on Twitter, on Facebook or at bet.com. 8 P.M. (CBS) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER Ted (Josh Radnor) struggles to make amends with an old girlfriend he cheated on, and Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) makes a bet that could result in his wearing of the ducky tie that Marshall (Jason Segel) owns. In ''2 Broke Girls,'' at 8:30, Caroline (Beth Behrs) interferes with the breakup of Max (Kat Dennings) and Robbie (Noah Mills). On ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Judy Greer makes her debut as Bridget, the ex-wife of the Internet billionaire Walden (Ashton Kutcher). And Mike (Billy Gardell) and Molly (Melissa McCarthy) adjust to their engagement -- she, by planning their wedding; he, by going fishing with the guys -- on the Season 2 premiere of ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CLARK, BARBARA M
summary: CLARK--Barbara M. ("Babs"). Passed away July 24, 2011, in New York City. Born July 19, 1938, only child of George P. Clark and Evelyn McCann Clark. After graduation from Marymount College, Arlington, VA, Barbara enjoyed a lengthy, successful career at CBS Television Network. She was selected as the first female network sales executive and earlier worked in the New York Yankees organization, then a division of CBS. "Babs" had a zest for life which uplifted those around her. Our dear cousin, godmother and friend of many, "Babs" will be missed by all who knew her. Mass of Christian Burial was held July 30 at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church, Forest Hills. Donations in her name to the Make-A-Wish Foundation will be appreciated. Make-A-Wish Foundation of America, Gift Processing Center, P.O. Box 749596 Los Angeles, CA 90074-9596 www.wish.org. Services entrusted to Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (Showtime) THE HELP (2011) Skeeter (Emma Stone), an aspiring writer from a prominent family in early 1960s Mississippi, causes an uproar in her community when she interviews black female servants in this adaptation of the Kathryn Stockett novel, directed and written by Tate Taylor. Viola Davis earned a best actress Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Aibileen, a maid who has raised several of the town's white babies. Octavia Spencer (above right, with Ms. Davis) won for best supporting actress as Aibileen's best friend, Minny, who endures soul-killing work for Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard), a housewife who believes in white superiority. And Cicely Tyson is Constantine, the woman who raised Skeeter -- and who inspires her former charge's journey of discovery. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this best picture nominee a ''big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum.'' The movie's ''vision of a divided America that while consistently insulting and sometimes even terrifying, is rarely grotesque, despite Hilly's best (worst) segregationist efforts,'' she added. ''Inside all these different homes, black and white women tend to the urgent matters of everyday life, like the care and feeding of children. And while every so often the roar of the outside world steals in like thunder, Mr. Taylor makes sure it doesn't rattle the china or your soul.'' 8 P.M. (HBO) SOMETHING BORROWED (2011) Ginnifer Goodwin stars as Rachel, a New York lawyer who imagines herself a wallflower until, on her 30th birthday, she finally ends up in bed with her longtime crush, Dex (Colin Egglesfield). Kate Hudson is Darcy, a brassy blond bombshell and Rachel's lifelong best friend -- and the woman Dex happens to be engaged to. ''The contrast between Darcy and Rachel is a bit overdrawn, but it should have given the conflict between them at least a hint of comic snap,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times about this film, adapted by Luke Greenfield from the novel by Emily Giffin. ''And the premise should have been a surefire recipe for farce, especially when everyone piles into a summer share in the Hamptons.'' Why this film ''should be so cautious and tepid,'' Mr. Scott said, ''is a puzzle.''

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Monday about fees paid by television networks for exclusive access to news subjects, misstated the title of Jeff Fager, a CBS executive. He is the chairman of CBS News, not its president.

headline: Best Sellers: Hardcover Nonfiction: Sunday, July 1st 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the July 1, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 16, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (USA) POLITICAL ANIMALS Sigourney Weaver (above, with James Wolk, left, and Brent Jennings), in a role based on Hillary Rodham Clinton, portrays Elaine Barrish Hammond, a former first lady who ran for president and became secretary of state in this new mini-series. She's married to a philandering former president, Bud Hammond (Ciaran Hinds), but in this make-believe version, Elaine doesn't stand by her man -- she divorces him. Carla Gugino is Susan Berg, a journalist who won a Pulitzer Prize for writing about Bud's infidelities, and who has exclusive access to Elaine in exchange for keeping the news about the Hammonds' troubled son, T. J. (Sebastian Stan), quiet. (His twin, Douglas, played by Mr. Wolk, is Elaine's chief of staff.) And Adrian Pasdar is President Paul Garcetti, the charismatic candidate who beat Elaine for the Democratic nomination. ''It may be too soon to assess her place in history, but it is already clear that Mrs. Clinton has a huge hold on the public imagination: a woman so well known, and yet so unknowable, that writers and filmmakers keep turning to fiction to try to solve her mystery,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. She added: ''Mrs. Clinton's life, with all its political triumphs and private torments, turned out to be juicier than any script a movie or television studio could conjure. And the writers, at least, don't want that to end. 'Can you keep a secret?' Elaine asks a Secret Service agent at her side. 'I'm going to run for president again, and this time I'm going to win.' '' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, a former White House chief of staff for President Obama, and Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, discuss the presidential election.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY ''Masterpiece Classic'' inaugurates a new chapter in this soap opera, created by Julian Fellowes, about masters and servants at the twilight of the British Empire. Hugh Bonneville returns as Lord Grantham, who, with three daughters and no direct male heir, is being forced to hand down his beloved ancestral home to a middle-class third cousin, Matthew Crawley (Dan Stevens), along with the fortune of his American-born heiress wife (Elizabeth McGovern, above). Maggie Smith is his imperious mother, and Siobhan Finneran is Miss O'Brien, Lady Grantham's Machiavellian maid. The story reopens in 1916 at the Battle of the Somme, where Matthew -- his romance with Lord Grantham's eldest daughter, Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery), derailed -- is now an officer trying to keep his troops alive. ''As the dowager countess, Ms. Smith has many of the best lines and usually the last word,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. ''When her middle granddaughter, Lady Edith, frets that she will end up a spinster, Lady Violet says briskly, 'Don't be defeatist, Dear, it's very middle class.' There is nothing middle class about 'Downton Abbey.' Even a world war can't sever the bond between aristocrats and the servants who love them.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY In a broadcast from New Hampshire, Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Jon Huntsman, as well as Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) BOARDWALK EMPIRE Nucky Thompson (Steve Buscemi, above center), whose fortunes have soared in the wake of Prohibition legislation, finds himself investigated for voter fraud after rigging a mayoral election and faces not only jail time but also the insurrection of his closest allies in this second-season premiere. (The series just earned an Emmy for Martin Scorsese, who won for outstanding directing of the pilot episode of a drama series.) Meanwhile, Chalky (Michael Kenneth Williams) is threatened by a Ku Klux Klan attack; Margaret (Kelly Macdonald) struggles with the disciplinary problems of her son (portrayed by two actors, Rory and Declan McTigue); and Angela (Aleksa Palladino) and Gillian (Gretchen Mol) compete for the affections of Jimmy (Michael Pitt). A preshow program begins at 8:30. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, about Mr. Obama's jobs act and deficit-reduction plan. (Mr. Plouffe will also appear on ''State of the Union With Candy Crowley,'' at 9 on CNN, and on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC.)

headline: Afghanistan: A Massacre, Then Questions
summary: The case of an American soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians has roiled political support in Congress for the military campaign in Afghanistan, with a prominent Republican senator accusing his party's candidates for president of undermining the nation's military commanders. ''When Republican candidates for president, when Republican politicians talk about being for early withdrawal, it makes it harder for the general to do his job,'' said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and a senior member of the Armed Services Committee. ''I want to be in a Republican Party that understands the strategic consequences of winning and losing in Afghanistan and will back up a general who deserves to be backed up.''

She was selected as the first female network sales executive and earlier worked in the New York Yankees organization, then a division of CBS. "Babs" had a zest for life which uplifted those around her. Our dear cousin, godmother and friend of many, "Babs" will be missed by all who knew her. Make-A-Wish Foundation of America, Gift Processing Center, P.O. Box 749596 Los Angeles, CA 90074-9596 www.wish.org. Services entrusted to Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY

headline: Lady Gaga Special No Turkey for ABC
summary: Based on the early Nielsen ratings Lady Gaga may not become a Thanksgiving mainstay like Charlie Brown, but ''A Very Gaga Thanksgiving'' still posted solid numbers on Thursday night for ABC with a total audience of 5.7 million viewers. The 90-minute special, where Gaga performed a handful of songs and showed off some curious wardrobe choices, was ABC's highest-rated show in that time period - 9:30 p.m. to 11 - in four years. CBS finished first in prime time over all and a repeat of ''The Big Bang Theory'' was the No. 1 program of the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and in total viewers, with 11.2 million. Earlier in the day the audience for NBC's broadcast of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade was down - according to Nielsen's preliminary overnight estimates - by about 3 percent compared to last year, when 22.1 million viewers tuned in. Final audience figures were not available on Friday.

headline: Corrections
summary: And a television listing for ''Children of 9/11,'' at 10 p.m. on Monday, misidentified the network. It is on NBC, not CBS.

headline: Campaigns Turning Focus to Borders
summary: If you're focused on the presidential campaign, get ready for the politics of immigration. President Obama set the stage on Friday by announcing that he would unilaterally stop enforcing deportations against many illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children. But immigration was already set to be the topic of the week on the campaign trail.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL VIII Some of the cutest bruisers around, rescued from shelters across the country, go in for tackles, fumbles and ''Fido first downs'' (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy) at Animal Planet Stadium. Dan Schachner calls plays and penalties in his new role as the Ref; Jill Rappaport provides analysis and commentary. A piglet pep squad cheers from the sidelines, while Meep the Bird tweets the action online. Aerial coverage of the pups is provided by the Ice Breakers blimp and its hamster crew. Sloppier ground-level angles are offered by the ever-popular water-bowl camera; the puppy cam, to watch the action from the players' perspective; and the kiss cam. Not to be missed: the Kitty Halftime Show. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Gov. Martin O'Malley of Maryland, the chairman of the Democratic Governors Association, and Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia, the chairman of the Republican Governors Association, discuss the presidential election. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana and Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts speculate on the Super Bowl.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS, SERIES V: FEARFUL SYMMETRY A new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' stalwart continues as Inspector Lewis, the long-suffering detective played by Kevin Whately, and his erudite sidekick, Detective Sgt. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox, above left with Mr. Whately), are drawn into the underbelly of Oxford while investigating the murder of Jessica Lake (Abigail Hardingham), a substitute baby sitter who was found bound by her wrists to the bed of her employers, Honey and Nick Addams (Georgia Taylor and Ciaran McMenamin). But when this unusual death pose exposes Jessica's secret life as a model for Marion Hammond (Lucy Cohu), a fetish photographer exploring the nature of passion, the men find themselves searching for answers in a residence for abandoned children, a primate lab and the home of a venture capitalist (Gary Kemp), who just happens to be Nick's boss, adorned with Marion's photographs. 8:30 A.M. (IFC) CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER (2006) A cruel emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) and his secretive wife (Gong Li) plot each other's annihilation: he by destroying her sanity with a rare fungus; she by planning a bloody coup during a festival. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that this martial-arts drama from the director Zhang Yimou, set in A.D. 928, ''achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 1:35 P.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen (above, a diver under the ice) at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature. 9 A.M. (Sundance) LE DIVORCE (2003) Kate Hudson plays Isabel Walker, an American in Paris to visit her pregnant half-sister (Naomi Watts), whose marriage to a French artist (Melvil Poupaud) is in shambles. And after a style and sensibility makeover, lust and romance ensue. Writing in The Times about this Merchant-Ivory adaptation of Diane Johnson's novel, A. O. Scott said that despite very fine actors -- among them Stephen Fry, Sam Waterston, Stockard Channing, Glenn Close (above right, with Ms. Hudson), Leslie Caron and Thierry Lhermitte -- the film ''is pretty weak tea, a thin and unsatisfying concoction that somehow manages to make one of the richest and most durable sources of culture-clash comedy into an occasion for dullness.'' He added, ''What's French for annulment?''

headline: 'Fear Factor' and Clinton Give NBC a Ratings Bump
summary: After a five-year hiatus, NBC's gross-out competition ''Fear Factor'' delivered strong numbers for over a two-hour period with an average of 8.6 million total viewers. It also matched the highest 8 p.m. rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a non-sports program on NBC since February 2008. At 10 p.m., also on NBC, Chelsea Clinton's debut as a news correspondent gave ''Rock Center with Brian Williams'' a slight ratings bump, with four million viewers tuning in. But CBS was still the No. 1 network over all for the night in both ratings categories, led by ''Two and a Half Men'' (14.7 million total viewers) and ''2 Broke Girls'' (12.5 million).

headline: Singers and Dancers Face Off on Television
summary: The fight between two branches of performing arts - voice and dance - tipped decidedly to the singers Monday night in the area that counts most in television, younger adult viewers. But ''The Voice'' on NBC and ''Dancing With the Stars'' on ABC are doing enough damage to each other to ensure that Fox's ''American Idol'' will regain its status as the top-rated weekly show with its Wednesday edition.

headline: The Caucus | Cooperation Remains Elusive
summary: In Washington, developments this week tempered some of the hope for bipartisan cooperation. Meanwhile, a new Times/CBS News poll shows Congressional disapproval at record levels.

headline: For 'Community,' A Solid Return
summary: Maybe absence really does lead to fondness: The return of NBC's cult-favorite ''Community'' on Thursday night generated the show's best ratings for this season by far, and the best entertainment numbers for NBC in that time period in 14 months. And in one stunning statistic, ''Community'' beat ''American Idol'' in the youngest of the important advertising age groups, viewers between the ages of 18 and 34.

headline: Excerpt: 'Undercover Boss'
summary: The reality show has been an unexpected hit for CBS.

headline: Another Armstrong Rides to Victory
summary: HAMPTON COURT, England -- For a brief time, Kristin Armstrong thought her competitive cycling days were over. She had a gold medal from the Beijing Olympics and a beautiful little boy named Lucas, and since it felt right, she retired. Six weeks after giving birth, she went for a bike ride. Twenty-two months after that, on Wednesday she found herself at a start line, defending the women's time-trial gold medal she captured in 2008. That she won again could have been expected. That she won by more than 15 seconds, after the birth and the retirement and a broken collarbone, surprised even Armstrong.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Katy Perry and Kenny Chesney, both at right, headline this 36th annual spectacle, in which 40,000 shells -- about 1,500 a minute -- are scheduled to explode from six barges on the Hudson River. Regis Philbin hosts this fireworks display, the largest in the nation. The theme this year is ''Ignite the Night.'' The ''Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular,'' at 10 on CBS, will feature Jennifer Hudson and the Boston Pops Orchestra, under the direction of Keith Lockhart, on the banks of the Charles River. Michael Chiklis hosts. 7 A.M. (TMC) GREY GARDENS (1975) Before the Broadway musical and the HBO film there was this portrait of Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Little Edie, directed by David and Albert Maysles. An aunt and a first cousin of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, the two lived as recluses in a deteriorating mansion in East Hampton, N.Y. ''There is no doubt about the artistry and devotion that the Maysles have used in recording the life in 'Grey Gardens,' '' said a review in The New York Times. ''There is no reason to doubt them when they say they love and admire the Beales. But the moviegoer will still feel like an exploiter. To watch 'Grey Gardens' is to take part in a kind of carnival of attention with two willing but vulnerable people who had established themselves, for better or worse, in the habit of not being looked at. And what happens when the carnival moves on?''

headline: Matchup
summary: Jets (7-5) vs. Chiefs (5-7), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Mark Sanchez vs. Himself

headline: 'X Factor' Lifts Fox As 'Angels' Descends
summary: '' The X Factor'' once again carried Fox to a Thursday-night victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, despite dropping 12 percent from last week's premiere. The talent show averaged just under 12 million total viewers over a two-hour period. CBS was the most-watched network over all, with ''Big Bang Theory'' beating all competition in the 18-to-49 set and reaching 14.5 million viewers. ''Charlie's Angels'' on ABC had the largest second-week drop among Thursday programming in the 18-to-49 category, falling 29 percent and averaging 7.2 million total viewers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LONDON, CHARLOTTE
summary: LONDON--Charlotte Lord. Jacqueline and David mourn the loss of our devoted mother Charlotte on September 2, 2011 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Jack London. A woman before her time, she was a renowned radio commentator, mostly for the ABC and CBS radio networks, music producer and programmer, financial advisor, and driver in the Mobil Economy Run. She is survived by her two children and four grandchildren, Sarah, Rachel, Jack and Jackson. She will be missed by her loyal friends and family.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LONDON, CHARLOTTE LORD
summary: LONDON--Charlotte Lord. Jacqueline and David mourn the loss of our devoted mother Charlotte on September 2, 2011 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Jack London. A woman before her time, she was a renowned radio commentator, mostly for the ABC and CBS radio networks, music producer and programmer, financial advisor, and driver in the Mobil Economy Run. She is survived by her two children and four grandchildren, Sarah, Rachel, Jack and Jackson. She will be missed by her loyal friends and family.

headline: Romney's Former Rivals Speak Out on Bain Attacks
summary: Republicans have been assailing President Obama and his re-election team for days for pointedly - and they say unfairly -- questioning the private equity experience of Mitt Romney. But on Sunday, three prominent Republicans were called to answer for their own past criticisms of the former Massachusetts governor. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor and a rival of Mr. Romney's in the 2008 Republican presidential primary, had painted a dim picture during that campaign of the former governor's economic policies and the health care program he put in place in Massachusetts.

headline: Fond Memories at That 'Deluxe Apartment in the Sky'
summary: Officially, the high-rise at 185 East 85th Street has a name: Park Lane Towers. ''But nobody calls it that,'' said Rod Behren, who has lived there for more than a decade. ''The de facto name of the building is 'the Jeffersons' building.' You meet people. They say, 'Where do you live?' You say, '85th and Third.' They say, 'Oh, the Jeffersons' building.' ''

headline: David Simon and What He Thinks About the 'Wire' Fandom, Late Adopters or Early
summary: It seemed like a good idea to check in with David Simon. As a reporter whose book was the basis of the NBC series ''Homicide: Life on the Street'' and as the creator of the HBO series ''The Wire,'' he might have some pertinent things to say about his friend Richard Price's new show, ''NYC 22'' on CBS. Mr. Simon had hired Mr. Price, the author of ''Clockers'' and other novels, to write for ''The Wire,'' and we thought Mr. Simon would understand the differences involved in writing a cop show for cable and one for broadcast. But when the conversation wound back to ''The Wire,'' four years after that endlessly exalted show went off the air, a controversy was born. In the interview, for ArtsBeat, we mentioned that Mr. Price had said that though many people praise ''The Wire'' now, at the time the show was broadcast it didn't draw many viewers and almost couldn't get a Season 4, much less a Season 5.

headline: Correction
summary: An article last Thursday about the fitness trainer Jillian Michaels referred imprecisely to the daytime television shows ''The Doctors,'' whose cast Ms. Michaels will join in the fall, and ''Dr. Phil,'' on which she will be a special correspondent. They are syndicated by CBS Television Distribution and can be seen on local affiliates of various major networks, not just those of CBS. The article also misspelled the Pennsylvania community of Cynthia Eyler, who used Ms. Michaels's weight-loss Web site as she lost 93 pounds. It is West Chester, not Westchester.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER In this alcohol-fueled episode, above, which starts the Monday night comedy lineup's winter premiere, Marshall (Jason Segel) visits his father's grave to carry on their tailgating tradition. Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) and Ted (Josh Radnor) open a bar called Puzzles, and Robin (Cobie Smulders) must go on the air for an inebriated news anchor. In ''2 Broke Girls,'' at 8:30, Caroline (Beth Behrs) becomes addicted to extreme couponing and stumbles upon the secret ingredient in the cupcakes made by Max (Kat Dennings). In ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) works to enlist Alan (Jon Cryer) as an ally when his ex-wife (Judy Greer) and mother (Mimi Rogers) try to take over his company. And in ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30, Carl (Reno Wilson) confronts his fear of commitment when Christina (Holly Robinson Peete) wants to get more serious. 1 P.M. (HGTV) HGTV DREAM HOME 2012 Monica Pedersen tours this year's giveaway home, a rustic contemporary ranch house near Park City, Utah, featuring a stone-clad great room with vaulted ceiling; a kitchen overlooking the Provo River and the mountains beyond; a master bedroom with sitting room, porch and spalike bathroom; and a hot-tub deck. The prize package also includes a sport-utility vehicle, $500,000 and every furnishing in the house. Viewers can register to win at HGTV.com and FrontDoor.com.

headline: Jets (6-5) at Redskins (4-7)
summary: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Wayne Hunter and D'Brickashaw Ferguson vs. Brian Orakpo and Ryan Kerrigan

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '12 The Rev. Al Sharpton will be honored for his humanitarianism, and the band Maze, featuring Frankie Beverly, for lifetime achievement at this 12th-annual ceremony honoring excellence by African-Americans and other minorities in entertainment and sports. Samuel L. Jackson, right, hosts this event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Marsha Ambrosius, Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige, Melanie Fiona and Rihanna are nominated for best female R&B artist; Chris Brown, Bruno Mars, Miguel, Trey Songz and Usher for best male R&B artist; Big Sean, Drake, J. Cole, Lil Wayne, Rick Ross and Young Jeezy for best male hip-hop artist; Diamond, Nicki Minaj, Brianna Perry and Trina for best female hip-hop artist; and ASAP Rocky, Big Sean, Diggy, Future and Meek Mill for best new artist. Reporting from the red carpet starts at 6; an after-party follows at 11:30. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews Jacob J. Lew, the White House chief of staff, about the Supreme Court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act. Mr. Lew also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' alongside Victoria Kennedy, the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and Representative Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, at 10 on ABC, and on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10, where Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, will discuss his party's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Wednesday about a poll that found broad dissatisfaction among New Yorkers over the quality of the city's public schools credited the poll incorrectly in some editions. It was conducted by The New York Times; it was not a New York Times/CBS News poll. And the article misstated the middle initial of a political consultant who said education may not turn out to be as strong a legacy as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had hoped to leave. The consultant is Bruce N. Gyory, not Bruce M.

headline: Best Sellers: Combined Print & E-Book Nonfiction: Sunday, June 17th 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.
