summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: Matchup
summary: Jets (8-5) at Eagles (5-8), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Brodney Pool and Eric Smith vs. Philadelphia's offense Into the void created by Jim Leonhard's season-ending knee injury slides Pool, whose first test teaming with Smith at safety - as it was last season - is a doozy. The Eagles are loaded with big-play threats at every skill position, and that includes tight end, the Jets' bugaboo. How Pool and Smith handle the increased responsibilities - making in-game adjustments and calls in the secondary - will play a major role in deciding whether the Jets' defense flourishes.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHELLING, WILLIAM F.
summary: SCHELLING--William F., August 3, 2011, of Allendale, NJ, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, cherished father of Patricia Schelling Cellary and her husband Christoper, of Allendale, NJ, devoted grandfather to Brian Christopher and Kevin William Cellary, dearest brother of Lucy Schelling Averill and her husband Professor Dr. Anton W Zimmermann of Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of the late Martha Louise Turner Schelling and cherished father to the late William F Schelling, Jr. Head of the CBS TV Lighting department in New York City, was at CBS for 40 years, a member of Local 1 IATSE (International Alliance Theatrical Stage Employees) for 63 years. He had the opportunity to travel the world. Bill was responsible for the lighting for political conventions, beauty pageants, sporting events, soap operas and many other significant events. He was a pioneer and innovator in the design of the television lighting industry. A WWII veteran, graduating from RCA Engineering School, a member of Archer United Methodist Church and a member of the Knickerbocker Country Club in Tenafly, NJ for 20 years. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 10th at the United Methodist Church, 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Archer United Methodist Endowment Fund 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 or the ASPCA.

headline: Mixed Message Helps Cain Video Go Viral
summary: Has the first viral video of the campaign season come from the Herman Cain camp? Emerging on YouTube a few days ago but spreading like a drought-struck prairie fire by last night, the video was certainly jarring. It features Mark Block, the chief of staff of Mr. Cain's presidential campaign, extolling the virtues of his candidate while standing outside an office building, smoking.

headline: New Lineup at E!
summary: The E! network announced an ambitious lineup of original programming Monday, including a new singing competition from one of the producers of ''American Idol,'' a relationship show with a Jonas brother (and his wife), and a weekly talk show with the comedian Whitney Cummings, which could raise questions about the future of her NBC sitcom. The channel also signaled that it intends to enter the arena of scripted series for the first time, announcing a list of shows in development for 2013, including several from top creative names, like producers John Wells and Phillip Noyce, and the actor Kevin Spacey.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHELLING, WILLIAM F.
summary: SCHELLING--William F.,August 3, 2011, of Allendale, NJ, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, cherished father of Patricia Schelling Cellary and her husband Christoper, of Allendale, NJ, devoted grandfather to Brian Christopher and Kevin William Cellary, dearest brother of Lucy Schelling Averill and her husband Professor Dr. Anton W Zimmermann of Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of the late Martha Louise Turner Schelling and cherished father to the late William F Schelling, Jr. Head of the CBS TV Lighting department in New York City, was at CBS for 40 years, a member of Local 1 IATSE (International Alliance Theatrical Stage Employees) for 63 years. He had the opportunity to travel the world. Bill was responsible for the lighting for political conventions, beauty pageants, sporting events, soap operas and many other significant events. He was a pioneer and innovator in the design of the television lighting industry. A WWII veteran, graduating from RCA Engineering School, a member of Archer United Methodist Church and a member of the Knickerbocker Country Club in Tenafly, NJ for 20 years. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 10th at the United Methodist Church, 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Archer United Methodist Endowment Fund 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 or the ASPCA.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS CLOSING CEREMONY The Games come to an end with this celebration at Olympic Stadium, titled ''A Symphony of British Music'' and directed by Kim Gavin, where the caldron will be extinguished and the Olympic flag passed to Mayor Eduardo Paes of Rio de Janeiro, the home of the 2016 Summer Games. The details are being kept under wraps, but those expected to perform include the Spice Girls, Adele, the Who, Ray Davies, Muse, Ed Sheeran and members of Pink Floyd.10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses the negative ads in the presidential campaign and the speculation around Mitt Romney's vice presidential pick. Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, talks about the campaign trail.

headline: Mort Lindsey, 89, Pianist And Versatile Bandleader
summary: Mort Lindsey, who led Merv Griffin's television orchestra, accompanied Barbra Streisand on the piano in Central Park and played with Judy Garland in her celebrated comeback concert at Carnegie Hall, died on May 4 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89. The cause was complications of a broken hip, his son Steve said.

headline: 9 Nods for Chesney
summary: The country music singer Kenny Chesney now has nine more reasons to tip that ever-present cowboy hat of his. He led all artists with nominations in nine categories, entertainer of the year and best song among them, when the Academy of Country Music announced its slate of contenders for its 47th annual honors on Thursday. Jason Aldean, another connoisseur of cowboy hats, was next, with six nominations, and Brad Paisley had four. Among groups, Lady Antebellum led the tally with five nominations, and the list of female performers was headed by Taylor Swift, who received three nominations.

headline: Country Is Music to ABC's Ears
summary: Some 16.3 million viewers tuned in to the 45th Annual Country Music Association Awards on ABC on Wednesday night, as Taylor Swift was named Entertainer of the Year. The show dominated all of prime time in all ratings categories. The numbers were very similar to last year, when the broadcast averaged 16.5 million viewers. The other big Wednesday shows performed poorly in the face of the increased competition: ''The X Factor'' on Fox was down to an average of 10.1 million viewers, while ''Survivor: South Pacific'' on CBS fell to 10.6 million.

headline: Stress of Holiday Spending
summary: -Holiday spending is a source of concern and stress for many Americans, even as they plan to spend less money, according to recent CBS News polls. A third say they feel more stress than usual about the amount they plan to spend on gifts, and half are concerned they will not be able to afford the gifts on their list this season. And with these anxieties, few anticipate spending any more this year than last year. -Not surprisingly, household income plays a role in how people consider their holiday budgets. Those who are less affluent are more likely to spend less money on gifts this year, are more concerned about not being able to afford what they want to buy, and express more anxiety about the spending money on gifts this year. The poll was taken Nov. 18-21 with 951 adults.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The Arizona and Michigan exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters on Tuesday as they left primary election locations throughout the two states.

headline: 'Downton Abbey' Sets Itself Apart
summary: The Season 2 premiere of ''Downton Abbey'' on PBS on Sunday drew an average of 4.2 million total viewers, a number that would impress even the most cold-hearted dowager. That performance doubled the average prime-time rating for PBS, according to Nielsen data, and the show experienced an 18 percent jump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with the typical rating from the first season. It was a quiet night on Monday among the broadcast networks as CBS and Fox ran repeats to avoid direct competition with the title game of the college football Bowl Championship Series on cable. ABC won the night over all, but a new episode of ''The Bachelor'' hit a series low in the 18-to-49 demographic and dropped slightly in total viewers, to 7.2 million from the 7.7 million who watched last week's premiere episode.

headline: Dolphins (0-6) at Giants (4-2)
summary: Dolphins (0-6) at Giants (4-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Giants CB Corey Webster vs. Dolphins WR Brandon Marshall Marshall has made plenty of headlines this season for things he has said (predicting he would be ejected for fighting against the Jets; guaranteeing a victory against the Giants). But he is an undeniable talent, and Webster will be chasing him. Two weeks ago, the Giants' secondary gave up early big plays to the Buffalo Bills but excelled late in a dramatic victory. Can Webster lead a more complete effort against Marshall and the winless Dolphins?

headline: Corrections
summary: An article last Wednesday about second-quarter earnings at CBS referred imprecisely to the network's involvement with the television series ''Star Trek'' and ''Cheers.'' While CBS has the rights to the shows through its ownership of the original production companies, ''Star Trek'' and ''Cheers'' are not considered ''old CBS shows.'' Both were broadcast on NBC.

headline: NBC Renews 'Smash' ...
summary: Undoubtedly with some sense of relief and satisfaction, NBC announced Thursday it would bring back ''Smash'' for a second season. The Broadway-based drama, on which the network lavished attention and promotion, has performed reasonably well in its 10 p.m. Monday slot - and far better than anything NBC has tried in that time period in many years. It is by far the top-rated drama now on NBC.

headline: Sometimes You Can Tell Who'll Make It
summary: Five of the 25 new shows on network television couldn't cut it: viewers didn't take to angels or agents, and couldn't find viewing time for bunnies or so-called gentlemen. ''Charlie's Angels'' on ABC, ''Free Agents'' and ''The Playboy Club'' on NBC, ''How to Be a Gentleman'' on CBS and CW's ''H8R'' were all canceled; none made it more than four episodes. The shows that have found the largest audiences appear to be going strong, and they're led by two young women who, to borrow from the title of their show, don't have much else going for them. The CBS sitcom ''2 Broke Girls'' leads all new shows that have had at least three episodes in average viewers and ratings in the pivotal demographic of 18-to- 49-year-olds. That show, staring Kat Dennings and Beth Behrs, has garnered an average of 12.7 million total viewers through six episodes.

headline: After Throat Surgery, Adele to Sing at Grammys
summary: Adele will perform at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 12, making her first appearance since undergoing throat surgery last fall, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday. ''It's an absolute honor to be included in such a night, and for it to be my first performance in months is very exciting and of course nerve-racking,'' the British singer and songwriter said in a statement.

headline: Craig Ferguson Discusses Anthrax Scare on His Show
summary: 12:00 p.m. | Updated The comedian Craig Ferguson seemed to be in good spirits on Tuesday evening when he wrote on his Twitter account: ''Ack! Someone mailed my show white powder & claimed it was anthrax. I'm not a big fan of that sort of thing.''

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Thursday about Mitt Romney's more aggressive strategy against Newt Gingrich described incorrectly polling data from a New York Times/CBS News poll of those likely to vote in the Iowa caucuses. Thirty-four percent of those voters said they would support Mr. Romney enthusiastically if he were the nominee in November; the poll did not say ''of those who said they planned to vote for Mr. Romney only 34 percent said they supported him 'enthusiastically.' ''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (AMC) MAD MEN At the close of the fourth season, Don Draper (Jon Hamm, above with Elisabeth Moss) made a surprise proposal to his secretary, Megan (Jessica Paré), and the advertising agency Sterling Cooper Draper Price was reeling from the loss of its biggest account. After a 17-month break, this award-winning series from Matthew Weiner returns with a two-hour premiere. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, discusses the budget and the 2012 election campaign. Gov. Rick Scott of Florida talks about the Trayvon Martin case, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, answers questions about Afghanistan.

headline: The TV Watch: Larry King Returns To Talk, But Online
summary: Larry King has told viewers that he wants to be frozen after his death. And that's fitting because the talk show host's new Web endeavor on Hulu, ''Larry King Now,'' is almost exactly that - his persona is cryopreserved on the Internet, in suspenders, if not suspension, in fine fettle and ready for television resuscitation sometime in the future. ''Larry King Now,'' which Mr. King created in partnership with a new digital video network, Ora TV, is an example of how the Internet accommodates old age as easily as youth. Justin Bieber and Lena Dunham got their D.I.Y. start on the Internet. Older stars who have retired from television but still have an itch to be on camera can keep their careers going online. It's probably an even better alternative than cable, because most people don't surf their remotes as far as AXS TV, the cable network formerly known as HDNet, where Dan Rather went after he left CBS News.

headline: Augusta Wouldn't Bend for President
summary: Custom and ritual have ruled Augusta National Golf Club for 80 years, and chief among those traditions has been an iron-willed chairman with almost complete authority, an obsessive desire for secrecy and eccentric determination to be different.The most powerful forces on earth have not been able to dissuade Augusta National's leadership at times. In 1956, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, a club member, rose to address a meeting of Augusta National's board of governors.

headline: 'Twilight' Gets Scarier: Can It Cause Seizures?
summary: Setting foot into a screening of ''The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1,'' the latest installment in the hit film series about the romance between a mortal girl and a sparkly vampire boy, may induced an unexpected kind of overstimulation: a few viewers say they have experienced epileptic seizures that, The Guardian reports, could be a result of rapidly changing colors in the film's climactic childbirth scene. Brandon Gephart of Roseville, Calif., who attended a showing of ''Breaking Dawn'' with his girlfriend, Kelly Bauman, was taken to a hospital following the scene in which the newlywed Bella (played by Kristen Stewart) delivers the daughter of her vampire husband, Edward (Robert Pattinson), as red, white and black strobes flash on the screen. ''He was convulsing, snorting, trying to breathe,'' Ms. Bauman told the Sacramento affiliate of CBS News.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: The BrandIndex scores for cable and broadcast networks measure people's overall impressions, satisfaction and perceptions of value and quality. Among the top 25, the highest-scoring broadcast network is Fox at No. 12. ABC and CBS are Nos. 20 and 21, respectively, and NBC is No. 25, with a score of 15.9. Discovery Channel has found success with shows like ''Dirty Jobs'' with Mike Rowe, above, and ''American Chopper,'' and the History Channel has had series like ''American Pickers'' and ''Pawn Stars'' consistently make the top 15 shows in weekly cable TV ratings (box, top right). SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: 2011 Emmy Winners
summary: Comedy Series: ''Modern Family'' (ABC)

headline: Showtime, HBO and CNN Among Peabody Leaders
summary: The Showtime counterterrorism drama ''Homeland,'' the Comedy Central satire ''The Colbert Report'' and the cable news channels CNN and Al Jazeera English were among the recipients of George Foster Peabody Awards on Wednesday. The awards, presented by the University of Georgia's Grady College of journalism and mass communication, are considered to be the most prestigious of their kind in electronic media. HBO picked up three: one each for ''Game of Thrones,'' ''Treme'' and a documentary it showed about Rwanda, ''Earth Made of Glass.'' Its rival Showtime picked up two, one for ''Homeland'' and another for a documentary it ran about survivors of 9/11 called ''Rebirth.'' CNN also won three awards, for its worldwide coverage of the Arab Spring, commentary by the weekend host Fareed Zakaria, and its annual awards telecast, ''CNN Heroes.''

headline: A Resurrection Is Planned at the Tonys
summary: The producers and investors in the Broadway musical ''Leap of Faith'' lost more than $14 million when the show closed on May 13 after receiving terrible reviews from critics. Usually the only thing left would be the tax write-offs. But even as the biggest flop of the season, ''Leap of Faith'' had an unusual asterisk - its single Tony Award nomination, a major one, for best musical. And so the producers had a decision to make: Whether to leave ''Leap of Faith'' dead and buried, or capitalize on the nomination and pay to stage a musical number on the Tony Awards telecast on CBS on June 10? The producers opted to go for it, and have raised roughly $150,000 to secure a spot for the number at the Tonys ceremony, according to two Broadway industry executives familiar with the plans; they divulged the information on condition of anonymity to preserve their relationships with the ''Leap'' producers, who declined to comment. But a spokeswoman for the producers said that they had raised enough money to stage the number, though she declined to confirm the amount.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in some editions on Friday about the PGA Tour's new television contracts with CBS Sports and the NBC Sports Group misidentified the network that broadcasts the P.G.A. Championship. It is CBS, not NBC.

headline: Americans Divided Over Tax Policy
summary: It may come as no surprise, but Americans are deeply split along party lines when it comes to federal tax policy. A New York Times/CBS News poll released Tuesday found that a majority of Republicans approve of the current tax policy, while most Democrats and independents disapprove of taxing income from capital gains at a lower rate than earned income.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) WHAT'S ON TONIGHT: EXOTIC PETS This Virginia McKenna-Bill Travers double bill begins with ''Born Free'' (1966), James Hill's drama, based on the 1960 autobiographic best seller by Joy Adamson, in which the married actors, above, play a game warden in Kenya and his wife who face a heartrending decision after Elsa, the orphaned lion club they have raised, becomes too big to keep. The composer John Barry won the Oscar for best original score and, with Don Black, for best original song for ''Born Free.'' Vincent Canby, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''a poignant but happy reminder of the beauty and mystery of the life cycle.'' In ''Ring of Bright Water'' (1969), at 10, Mr. Travers portrays a London civil service clerk whose life is changed when he decides to move Mij, his rambunctious pet-shop otter, to a village along the west Scottish coast. Ms. McKenna plays the doctor who, with her spaniel, captures the pair's attention. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Rick Santorum discusses his campaign for the Republican nomination. Mr. Santorum also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC.

headline: An 'A' for Effort on Emmy Night
summary: Emmy Awards don't factor in the degree of difficulty, but they should. It's at least one way to choose between equally good performances. So in the spirit of rewarding the effort behind excellence, here are one critic's picks for what should win when the Emmys are handed out on Sunday night.

headline: Jets (8-7) vs. Dolphins (5-10)
summary: Jets (8-7) at Dolphins (5-10), 1 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, CBS Matchup to Watch: Jets vs. the Percentages

headline: 'American Idol' Premiere Suffers Drop in in Viewers
summary: 5:16 p.m. | Updated Is this the year that television's powerhouse will start to lose its mojo? Fox's ''American Idol'' took a tumble in the ratings for the premiere of its new season on Wednesday, down more than 25 percent from last year. The falloff was apparent in both the total number of viewers and in the audience that ad buyers most care about - viewers between the ages of 18 and 49.

headline: How Entrance Poll Was Conducted
summary: The Iowa caucus poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters on Tuesday evening as they entered party caucus locations throughout the state. The poll was conducted by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J., for the National Election Pool, a consortium of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.

headline: A Change in Leadership At ABC's 'World News'
summary: Jon Banner, who managed ABC's nightly newscast ''World News'' through nearly a decade of turbulence and through four periods of anchors, is moving off the program and into a special projects position at the news division. Mr. Banner, the longest-serving of any of the evening news executive producers, is being succeeded by Michael Corn, a longtime producer of ABC's morning program ''Good Morning America,'' called ''GMA'' for short.

headline: ABC Wins Ratings
summary: With the other networks taking a holiday from their regular prime-time schedules, ABC emerged as No. 1 in all ratings categories on Wednesday thanks to its usual comedy lineup. A new episode of ''Modern Family'' led the way, with 12.6 million total viewers, followed by ''The Middle,'' at 9.1 million, according to Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, a special Wednesday live results episode of ''The X Factor'' drew 8.5 million total viewers and put Fox in second place for the night in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS was in third place with a slate of repeats and a recap episode of ''Survivor: South Pacific.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Critic's Notebook: Playing a Role, Even as Himself
summary: When Richard Dawson first turned up as host of ''Family Feud'' in 1976, some people might well have done a double-take. ''What is this?'' they might have asked. ''An actor disguised as a game show host?'' That's because before ''Family Feud,'' there was ''Hogan's Heroes,'' a popular sitcom about captives in a German prisoner-of-war camp in World War II. Mr. Dawson, who died on Saturday at 79, played one of the prisoners, Cpl. Peter Newkirk, and along with a cast that included Bob Crane, Ivan Dixon, Robert Clary, John Banner and Werner Klemperer helped to prove that Nazi Germany could be funny. Mel Brooks's film version of ''The Producers'' was still three years in the future when the series made its debut on CBS in September 1965.

headline: The Money Race: A Milestone for Obama
summary: When President Obama boards Air Force One and departs New York City on Thursday night, he will have hit a notable milestone: He will have held more than 100 fund-raising events for his re-election effort in less than a year. That is more than President George W. Bush held during the entire 2004 cycle, according to unofficial tallies kept by the CBS reporter Mark Knoller, suggesting the intense pace of Mr. Obama's fund-raising as he prepares to battle Republicans and the independent groups likely to spend tens of millions of dollars to defeat him.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:50 A.M. (HBO Signature) THE AMERICAN (2010) Before ''The Descendants'' and ''The Ides of March'' brought him Oscar nominations in this latest awards season, George Clooney, above, played a gun-toting expatriate who arrives in a small Italian town after a mishap on his previous job and takes an assignment to build a custom weapon for a sexy assassin (Thekla Reuten). ''I'm out,'' he says at one point, intent on making the kind of human connection that his taciturn temperament and job -- as a hit man, perhaps -- have denied him until now. Soon he has made friends with a priest (Paolo Bonacelli) and a prostitute (Violante Placido), who is so enamored of his prowess in bed that she stops charging him. The film, directed by Anton Corbijn from a script by Rowan Joffe, by ''filtering out any mention of the character's history and suppressing all but the tiniest indications of emotion, tries to strip the man to his essence,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But there is not quite enough there: the still waters run very cool but not terribly deep, and 'The American' falls back into a view of its protagonist that is ultimately more sentimental than unsettling or intriguing.'' 9 A.M. (Cinemax) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) In this sequel to Oliver Stone's 1987 drama, ''Wall Street,'' Michael Douglas, right, returns as the reptilian Gekko, the ruthless corporate raider who, after serving an eight-year prison sentence, has landed in the public spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf is the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko's fans and the live-in love of Gekko's estranged daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume.

headline: 'General Hospital' Blessed With a 50th Season by ABC
summary: Maybe it was Farah Fath, a former soap opera star, who said it best on Wednesday when ABC confirmed that it had renewed ''General Hospital'' for a landmark 50th season. Congratulating the cast and crew in a Twitter message, she wrote, ''A soap renewal in 2012 is nothing short of victorious.''

headline: BET Show Will Offer News and Commentary
summary: Add BET to the list of channels who will be competing in late-night television. Sometime this fall the channel will start ''Don't Sleep With T.J. Holmes,'' a Monday-through-Friday series that will compete with the likes of ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central, ''Chelsea Lately'' on E! and ''Conan'' on TBS.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The South Carolina exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters on Saturday as they left primary election locations across the state. The poll was conducted by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J., for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, and NBC News.

headline: Viewers Flock To 'Big Brother' House
summary: ''Big Brother'' on CBS claimed the top spot among the broadcast networks on Thursday night in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million people tuning in, according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows' long-in-the-tooth format. Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted houseguest, and the person with the most votes will get a chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, as the network averaged around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers, thanks to its reality competitions, ''Wipeout'' (6.6 million viewers) and ''Expedition Impossible'' (4.8 million).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) TEACHERS ROCK PRESENTED BY WALMART AND 'WON'T BACK DOWN' -- A CONCERT AND CHARITY EVENT BENEFITING TEACHERS AND EDUCATION Garth Brooks, Carrie Underwood, Josh Groban (above) and others perform in honor of American educators at this event taped on Tuesday at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. A number of stars -- including Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, Usher, Adam Levine and James Valentine of Maroon 5, Meryl Streep, L L Cool J, Jack Black and Morgan Freeman -- talk about teachers who influenced their lives. The program also features clips from the forthcoming movie ''Won't Back Down,'' starring Viola Davis and Maggie Gyllenhaal, about two mothers determined to transform a failing urban school.8 P.M. (HGTV) HGTV GREEN HOME 2012 GIVEAWAY Monica Pedersen randomly draws the winner of an environmentally friendly, 2,300-square-foot farmhouse in the Atlanta area with three bedrooms, two-and-a-half baths and an open floor plan in a 900-acre community connected by walking paths.

headline: Ted Danson to Star in 'C.S.I.'
summary: CBS has landed a very familiar name, Ted Danson, to lead its most familiar drama, as the network tries to keep alive the one-time top show in television, ''C.S.I.'' CBS announced Tuesday night that Mr. Danson, who has been among the most popular stars in television since his days leading the NBC comedy hit ''Cheers,'' will take over in the fall as the chief investigator of the Las Vegas Crime Scene Investigation team, the job first held by William Petersen and most recently by Laurence Fishburne. CBS has moved ''C.S.I.'' out of its longtime home on Thursday night to Wednesdays in the fall. Ratings for the series began to fall off sharply toward the end of last season, the show's 11th on the air. There had been some question about whether CBS would try to keep the crime drama alive, facing the challenges of having to replace a star for the second time. But CBS often retains shows longer than other networks, calculating that new shows are always a bigger risk And ''C.S.I.'' remains a significant financial asset for the company, which has an ownership stake in the series. The drama still sells to many international broadcasters and its repeats are still purchased for a high price by the cable channel Spike. Mr. Danson has expanded his acting repertoire in recent years, playing a villain on the FX series ''Damages'' -- and gaining an Emmy nomination - and a reprobate publisher on the HBO comedy ''Bored to Death.'' According to CBS's announcement Mr. Danson will continue in that role. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: 'Today' Show Streak at Top Is Halted by 'GMA'
summary: Update, 1:55 p.m.| ABC's ''Good Morning America'' appears to have prevailed over NBC's ''Today'' show in weekly viewership for the first time in over 16 years. Preliminary Nielsen ratings show that ''GMA'' had an average of 5,147,000 total viewers for the week of April 9 -- 13,000 more than the ''Today'' show, which averaged 5,134,000.

headline: 'The Lorax' Rules the Box Office Again
summary: A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixar's top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, ''Dr. Seuss' The Lorax'' (Universal Pictures) -- featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito -- was North America's No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. Finishing a distant second with about $30.6 million in ticket sales was Disney's ''John Carter,'' a space epic directed by Andrew Stanton of ''Finding Nemo'' and ''Wall-E'' fame for Pixar. Analysts say Disney faces a $100 million to $165 million loss because of the film's poor opening-weekend results. Disney noted that ''John Carter'' took in an additional $70.6 million overseas and said the film received a B-plus score from audiences in exit polls. ''Project X'' (Warner Brothers) was third, taking in about $11.6 million for a two-week total of $40.1 million. ''Silent House,'' an inexpensive horror movie from Open Road Films, placed fourth, with about $7.01 million, while ''Act of Valor'' (Relativity Media) was fifth, taking in $7 million for a three-week total of $56.1 million.

headline: 'Big Brother' Tops Race
summary: Thursday night will once again be safe for nonfootball programs, now that National Football League preseason is coming to an end. Pre-emptions and repeats were plentiful on the broadcast networks Thursday because of various N.F.L. games. Of the nonfootball players, ''Big Brother'' on CBS (one of two network programs not in repeats) was the night's victor, according to Nielsen estimates. CBS finished the night in first place in overall audience and won the 18- to 49-year-old category most coveted by advertisers. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Political Ad Database Will Move To the Web
summary: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a proposal to have local broadcasters publish information about political advertising sales on the Web in a government database. Supporters of the proposal said it would give the public more information about the millions of dollars that are spent on ads to influence elections. It had been expected to pass despite deep opposition by the owners of some television and radio stations.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters on Tuesday as they left primary election locations in Georgia, Massachusetts, Ohio and Tennessee. The polls were conducted by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J., for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.

headline: Armstrong Recording to Be Released
summary: Just five months before he died, Louis Armstrong gave a performance at the National Press Club in Washington, singing and playing the trumpet for nearly a half-hour at a party for the club's newly elected president. That concert was recorded by CBS newsmen who attended the event, and the press club later pressed about 300 vinyl copies and distributed them to journalists who had attended. It was never released as a commercial album, even though it was one of the last times the jazz trumpeter performed before his death in July 1971. Now Smithsonian Folkways Recordings has gotten permission from the Armstrong estate to release the recordings on a new album, ''Satchmo at the National Press Club: Red Beans and Rice-ly Yours,'' which will come out April 24 as part of the Smithsonian's annual Jazz Appreciation Month, the label and the press club announced on Thursday.

headline: Damien Bona, 56, Oscar Buff Who Became Oscar Scholar
summary: Flip to just about any page in ''Inside Oscar: The Unofficial History of the Academy Awards'' and something fascinating is bound to pop up. In 1997, when ''Breathing Lessons,'' about a man who spent most of his life in an iron lung, won the award for best short documentary, the director, Jessica Yu, stepped to the mike and said, ''You know you've entered new territory when you realize your outfit cost more than your film.''

headline: Museum Plans Program On Kovacs and Adams
summary: The poet Percy Dovetonsils, disc jockey Wolfgang von Sauerbraten, magician Matzoh Hepplewhite and storyteller Auntie Gruesome are getting a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image - and so, too, are Ernie Kovacs, who portrayed these characters, and Edie Adams, his wife and frequent co-star, who appeared with him in several pioneering television series of the 1950s and 60s. The museum said on Wednesday that it will host a month-long program, running from April 27 through May 27, honoring Kovacs and Adams, whose innovative character skits and comedy pieces influenced any number of self-aware, self-referential performers and shows, including David Letterman, ''Sesame Street'' and Pee-wee Herman.

headline: Tune In To Tennis
summary: American Express, one of the event's corporate sponsors, offers card-carrying members a free radio headset for live commentary from CBS, Tennis Channel or ESPN. The gadget, available at the company's booths and called American Express Radio Live at the Open, has become a mainstay since it was introduced seven years ago. The company estimates it will hand out more than 140,000 headsets during the tournament this year. American Express has its own private radio station with a production team that pulls the broadcast feeds.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BEING ELMO: A PUPPETEER'S JOURNEY (2011) As a teenager in Baltimore in the 1970s Kevin Clash had a singular wish: to be a puppeteer on the team of Jim Henson, the creative force behind ''Sesame Street'' and the Muppets. Mr. Clash's dream eventually came true when he attracted the attention of the Muppet designer Kermit Love. And then one day the veteran puppeteer Richard Hunt tossed a furry red monster at him in a fit of frustration, unable to find the character's voice. Mr. Clash eventually did, and Elmo (above, with Mr. Clash), one of the world's most beloved characters, was born. ''Independent Lens'' presents this documentary, directed by Constance Marks and narrated by Whoopi Goldberg, which Neil Genzlinger, writing in The New York Times, called ''a winning tale of the persistence and creativity behind one of the most famous and fuzziest faces in the world.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER Ted (Josh Radnor), Marshall (Jason Segel) and Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) watch the original ''Star Wars'' trilogy and imagine what their lives will be like in three years. In ''2 Broke Girls,'' at 8:30, Max (Kat Dennings) persuades Caroline (Beth Behrs) to take part in a clinical drug trial to raise money for her father. In ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) tells Zoey (Sophie Winkleman) that he's going into business with his ex-wife (Judy Greer). And in ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30, the outspokenness of Molly (Melissa McCarthy) costs her and Mike (Billy Gardell) a wedding chapel.

headline: Games To Watch
summary: OHIO STATE AT NO. 17 MICHIGAN Noon, ABC

headline: Allan Jefferys, 88, Drama Critic
summary: Allan Jefferys, the drama critic and entertainment editor for WABC-TV in New York in the 1960s, died on Sept. 29 in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 88 and lived in Pinehurst. His death was confirmed by his son, Doug.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ENRIONE, ROBERT U.
summary: ENRIONE--Robert Ugo â€œBobâ€. February 5, 1947 - June 28, 2011. Robert Ugo â€œBobâ€ Enrione, a veteran of the United States Navy, an Emmy award-winning video journalist, and a longtime resident of Tarrytown, NY, died suddenly on June 28, 2011, while he and his wife were visiting family in Virginia. He was 64 years old. Born on February 5, 1947, in Astoria, Queens, Mr. Enrione was the son of the late Hugo and Ermina Enrione. A 1964 graduate of Bryant High School, Mr. Enrione earned a Bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from City College in 1974. During the Vietnam War, Mr. Enrione served in the United States Navy as a Petty Officer -- Machinist's Mate. Stationed in Vietnam, he was awarded the Silver Star, as well as numerous other decorations. Bob worked for ABC News and CBS News as a videotape editor from the mid 70's through his retirement in 2010. Most notably, Bob worked for the CBS Evening News and 60 Minutes and sports. He was also a frequent commentator on political, social, and economic topics on blogs and online journals. In the mid-1990's Bob shared responsibilities with his wife, Jackie, on their local newspaper, West Side Beat. They covered neighborhood politics up through the Washington Beltway. A gourmet cook, Bob is immortalized in his Chef Hugo column providing unique, easy-to-cook recipes for Manhattanites in their traditional closet-size kitchens. The couple was married October 26, 1996. Mayor Giulilani performed the nuptials. Mr. Enrione was an amateur naval historian of enormous skill and considerable reputation. A contributor to Sea Classics and Naval History magazines, Bob's encyclopedic knowledge of naval warfare ranged from the operational intricacies of sloops and brigs-of-war, to the strategic and tactical nuances of the great naval battles of the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic wars, and the War of 1812. At the time of his passing, Bob was working on a monumental historical novel concerning life at sea during the Nelsonian period. He was also a long-time member of the U.S. Naval Institute, and an informal researcher for the renowned novelist, Dewey Lambdin. Bob was also a very talented visual artist, and his sketches of schooners, sloops, brigs, and ship-of-the-line from the great age of sail enlivened several publications and serve as special keepsakes for his family and friends. He leaves his loving wife of 15 years, Jacqueline Wolf-Enrione, as well as numerous close cousins and friends. Bob had many good friends from all walks of life from medical lab technicians to media moguls and five star generals. Those of us whose lives he touched are richer for having known him. Enrione's HMS Indefatigable 251947 shines on. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that a donation be made in Bob's name to the Naval Institute, 291 Wood Rd, Annapolis, MD 21402, attn: Carol Parkinson. A memorial service will be announced.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Science) TED TALKS In this collection of the best TED conference talks, the producer and director J. J. Abrams tells of a ''mystery box'' he received as a child that he never opened, explaining that his fascination with the unknown drives his work. Bonnie Bassler, above, a molecular biologist, discusses a chemical language that allows bacteria to communicate. Robin Ince, a comedian, riffs on the relationship between science and wonder. And the inventor Skylar Tibbits speaks about the future of building and the nascent science of self-assembly. 8 P.M. (CBS) UNDERCOVER BOSS The chief executive of Yankee Candle learns how his company works at the store level when he dons a disguise (a curly wig and a soul patch) and pretends to be a new hire. But his go-getter attitude raises eyebrows when he expends considerable effort on customer service, and he almost blows his cover when he speaks up testily about a store's sloppy appearance.

headline: Unleash the Crowd, Gingrich Says
summary: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.comNewt Gingrich insists his fans will not be silenced. Mr. Gingrich, a former House speaker, on Tuesday morning threatened not participate in any future debates with audiences that have been instructed to be silent. That was the case on Monday, when Brian Williams of NBC News asked the audience of about 500 people who assembled for a debate in Tampa to hold their applause until the commercial breaks.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) MIDNIGHT IN PARIS (2011) In Paris with his fiancée and her parents, Gil (Owen Wilson, above with Marion Cotillard), an aspiring novelist with a nostalgic bent, goes for long walks each night and is magically transported to the 1920s. Though he wakes up each morning in the present, he spends his nights consorting with Picasso (Marcial Di Fonzo Bo), F. Scott Fitzgerald (Tom Hiddleston), Salvador Dalí (Adrien Brody) and other notables, delighting in the glamour of the Paris described as a ''Moveable Feast'' by Hemingway (Corey Stoll). A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the film ''is marvelously romantic, even though -- or precisely because -- it acknowledges the disappointment that shadows every genuine expression of romanticism.'' Woody Allen, who wrote and directed the movie, won an Academy Award for best original screenplay. Noon (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MINDDavid Segal, a reporter for The Times, discusses the quality of education at law schools in the United States and why graduates are not necessarily prepared to practice law.

headline: Teenagers Watch Fox
summary: The Teen Choice Awards on Fox on Sunday night managed to ensnare its elusive target demographic thanks to squeal-inducing appearances by Taylor Swift, Robert Pattinson and Justin Bieber. The ceremony was the highest rated telecast of the summer for Fox among teenagers. Adults didn't quite follow suit, flocking to somewhat older fare on CBS. ''60 Minutes'' garnered 8.7 million total viewers and ''Big Brother'' had 7.8 million, giving the station another Sunday win in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old segment. On cable, the season finale of the post-apocalyptic drama ''Falling Skies'' on TNT finished with its best numbers since the series premiere on June 19. The show, which was picked up for a second season last month and will return next summer, had 5.6 million total viewers on Sunday.

headline: Amanpour to Return to CNN, Leaving 'This Week' on ABC
summary: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Christiane Amanpour is leaving the anchor chair of ABC's ''This Week'' and returning to her old network home, CNN, as the anchor of an evening newscast on CNN International. The changes, confirmed Tuesday, come a year and a half after Ms. Amanpour surprised her colleagues at CNN by leaving the network to anchor ''This Week,'' the Sunday morning public affairs program on ABC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) MARGARET MITCHELL: AMERICAN REBEL Mitchell, above, the author of ''Gone With the Wind,'' won a Pulitzer Prize for her novel and used royalties from it to pay for the education of some the first black doctors in the South. She was also among the first female newspaper reporters in Georgia. This profile, part of the ''American Masters'' series, includes re-enactments of her life based on her correspondence. 11:40 A.M. (IFC) THE TAVERN (2000) A bartender hears the knock of opportunity when offered the chance to own a tavern, only to learn that he is unprepared for the pressure and responsibility of running a small business. Ronnie (Cameron Dye), the man with the plan, doesn't have enough money, so he borrows some from his family and joins with his friend Dave (Kevin Geer), who ponies up the rest. But the competition in Manhattan is tough, and the bar's former owner opens a new establishment that attracts the old customers.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: ONE WORLD The old saying ''no pain, no gain'' will be tested this week as the competition for $1 million continues. (Above, Greg Smith, left, and Jay Byars during an immunity challenge.) With both tribes living on the same site, drama runs high as the tribal council makes an unexpected decision. 1:30 P.M. (Sundance) GRIZZLY MAN (2005) Timothy Treadwell, who spent many of his summers living with and filming grizzly bears in the Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska, below, was killed in a bear attack in 2003, along with his girlfriend, Amie Huguenard. The director Werner Herzog combed through their footage to create this documentary, which casts an unsentimental eye on Treadwell's mission to protect the grizzlies and questions his preparation for life in the wilderness. Interviews with family members and friends shed light on Treadwell's past as an actor who struggled with addiction. And those who last saw him, including the medical examiner who performed his autopsy, depict him as a man who failed to appreciate the power and danger of nature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Treadwell's adventures with grizzlies amounted to ''a kind of performance, built on lies and truth and played out on the stage of celebrity.'' She added, ''Even though his choices were dangerous and finally fatal, he traveled a familiar American path shaped by boundless optimism and an almost religious belief in the self.''

headline: 'Two and a Half Men' Offers Its Own Roast
summary: The Charlie Sheen roast on Comedy Central was a cake walk compared with the season premiere of ''Two and a Half Men'' on CBS on Monday. That wasn't a sitcom romp, it was more like watching Iraqis tear down statues of Saddam Hussein in the early days of the American-led invasion. Real anger seemed to seep through punch lines in a funeral service that was supposed to finesse the loss of Mr. Sheen and set the stage for his replacement, Ashton Kutcher. Perhaps to coax the audience to focus on him, and not the past, Mr. Kutcher appeared naked in a few scenes, his private parts blurred for the camera.

headline: A Scorecard Filled with Scholarships
summary: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. - Wesley Bauguess still chokes up every time she tells the story of how her husband, Army Maj. Larry Bauguess, died at 36 during efforts to settle a border dispute. It was May 14, 2007, and her husband was participating in a peace meeting involving United States, Afghanistan and Pakistan forces in a tribal region of Pakistan. By all accounts, the meeting was successful. The participants shook hands, posed for photographs and exchanged coins. But as Bauguess and his men prepared to leave, a uniformed Pakistani soldier reportedly opened fire at close range. Bauguess was at the point of attack and shielded others, which allowed his team time to react. Several men were wounded, but he was the only one killed, leaving behind two young daughters, Ryann and Ellie.

headline: Jets (2-0) at Raiders (1-1)
summary: 4:05 p.m., CBS Matchup to Watch

headline: Best Sellers: E-Book Nonfiction: Sunday, June 17th 2012
summary: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the June 17, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending June 2, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline: McCarver Wins Frick Award
summary: Tim McCarver was thinking about his broadcast partners at the Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday when he won the National Baseball Hall of Fame's Ford C. Frick Award. McCarver was a broadcasting rookie in 1980, working with Harry Kalas, Chris Wheeler, Andy Musser and Richie Ashburn after 21 seasons as a catcher, largely for the Cardinals and Phillies.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 2:30 P.M. (HBO2) SEPARATE LIES (2005) In this directorial debut from Julian Fellowes (''Downton Abbey''), who adapted the screenplay from Nigel Balchin's novel ''A Way Through the Wood,'' Tom Wilkinson portrays James Manning, a London lawyer who spares no one his imperious authority, not even his wife, Anne (Emily Watson, above with Mr. Wilkinson). When the husband of their cleaning woman is killed in a hit-and-run accident, James suspects that Bill Bule (Rupert Everett), a family acquaintance who attended a party at the Mannings' home that evening, was driving the car. Then Anne confesses that she and Bill are having an affair -- and that she was behind the wheel. But instead of allowing her to go to the police, James constructs an alibi. ''This powerful performance, equal in stature to Mr. Wilkinson's grieving father in 'In the Bedroom,' pushes 'Separate Lies' halfway toward the rarefied class of that 2001 film,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But that's not nearly far enough to begin to lift this intriguing but chilly moral puzzle to anything close to greatness.'' 9 A.M. (CUNY) REVISITING THE GREAT SOCIETY: THE ROLE OF GOVERNMENT FROM F.D.R. AND L.B.J. TO TODAY The roots and legacy of President Lyndon B. Johnson are explored by Robert A. Caro, his Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer; former Vice Present Walter F. Mondale; former Senator George S. McGovern; and the journalist Bill Moyers in this two-hour report, culled from a symposium presented last month by the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College. Highlights include a panel discussion moderated by Bob Schieffer of CBS News as well as archival photographs and audio recordings of Johnson in conversation with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and presenting a speech in 1965 before a joint session of Congress. The program will be repeated a 3 and 9 p.m.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) FINDING YOUR ROOTS WITH HENRY LOUIS GATES JR. The married actors Kevin Bacon and Kyra Sedgwick, above, are both descended from prominent American families that have been in this country since its inception. But this episode reveals other similarities, including ancestors who were early abolitionists. Mr. Bacon's Quaker clan repudiated slavery in 1780. And in 1781 Theodore Sedgwick argued the case of Elizabeth Freeman, known as Mumbet, which helped end slavery in Massachusetts. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS In a special Easter broadcast with Jake Tapper filling in for Mr. Stephanopoulos, Pastor Rick Warren of the Saddleback Church in Lake Forest, Calif., talks about the spiritual climate of the nation, culture wars, the intersection of church and state, and keeping faith in difficult times. Mr. Tapper also speaks with Mr. Warren's wife, Kay Warren, about her new book, ''Choose Joy: Because Happiness Isn't Enough.''

headline: Postcard From Alabama: Playing for the Stones, Rooting for the Tide
summary: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. - Chuck Leavell has traveled the world with the Rolling Stones, but he still calls Tuscaloosa home. And he still counts himself as a die-hard fan of Alabama football. ''You can't be from Tuscaloosa and not be a Crimson Tide fan,'' Leavell said in a telephone interview Friday.

headline: Neil Patrick Harris To Return as Tony Host
summary: In a year when offbeat experiments with the hosts of major award shows haven't always yielded satisfying results, it's understandable that the organizers of the Tony Awards would turn to someone with experience to serve as their master of ceremonies. Neil Patrick Harris, who hosted the 2009 Tony Awards program - not to mention the 2009 Emmy Awards and, for some reason, the 2010 Spike Video Game Awards -- will return as host of next month's Tonys show, the award program's press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Harris, a star of the CBS comedy ''How I Met Your Mother'' who starred in the New York Philharmonic revival of ''Company,'' said in a statement: ''I'm honored and stoked to have been asked to host the 2011 Tony Awards. It should be a great show -- we've got a fantastic mix of live performances, a few secret surprises, and since they're closed for retooling, we're using all the rigging equipment from 'Spider-Man.' What could possibly go wrong?''

headline: Youth Wins for Univision
summary: A relatively barren television landscape on Thursday night -- with the big four networks running either comedy repeats or reality shows -- allowed the Spanish-language Univision to score a ratings victory in the category advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds with its 8th Annual Youth Awards show, ''Premios Juventud.'' The three-hour ceremony, which featured performances from Ricky Martin and Pitbull, averaged 4.1 million total viewers. The winners were determined by online vote at univision.com. CBS had the most total viewers on the night thanks to a live eviction episode of ''Big Brother'' (6.7 million viewers). ''Love Bites,'' the sole NBC series not in repeats, fell to just under 1.8 million viewers for its (unplanned) final episode. The show was canceled earlier this week. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Judge Judy Signs Up for More Time in Court
summary: The nation's No. 1 television judge, Judy Sheindlin, has decided to continue settling disputes for at least the next four years. Ms. Sheindlin, who has headed up ''Judge Judy'' for the last 15 years, has signed a new contract that will keep her on the show through 2015, her distributor, CBS Television Distribution, said Monday. Ms. Sheindlin, who is one of the highest-paid stars on television, had suggested publicly that her prior contract, which has her on the show until 2013, could have been her last, The Associated Press reported. But she evidently decided to sign up for two more years.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International PHOTOS OF PROTESTER ON FIRE

headline: Games To Watch
summary: NO. 6 OREGON AT NO. 3 STANFORD 8 p.m., ABC Oregon brings its no-huddle, high-speed offense to Palo Alto, where Stanford will counter with Andrew Luck, the Heisman front-runner. Oregon relies on one of the most dangerous running backs in college football, LaMichael James, right, and the Ducks average just under 300 yards a game on the ground, good for fifth in the nation. Stanford's defense has been great against the run, allowing 79 yards per game, tied with Florida State for third nationally.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE LATINO LIST Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, the photographer and the director of three editions of ''The Black List'' on HBO, presents video portraits of Latinos who have contributed to contemporary society in music, science, journalism, theater, literature, business and government. Maria Hinojosa of NPR interviews the subjects, including the singer-songwriter Gloria Estefan and her husband, the producer Emilio Estefan; the actors America Ferrera, John Leguizamo and Eva Longoria; the writer Sandra Cisneros; José Moreno Hernández, a former NASA astronaut; Consuelo Castillo Kickbusch, who became the highest-ranking Hispanic woman in the combat support field of the United States Army; Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey; and the Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, above. NOON (FX) GHOST TOWN (2008) Ricky Gervais, near right, plays Bertram Pincus, a misanthropic Manhattan dentist who sees spirits after having a near-death experience during a colonoscopy. Greg Kinnear is Frank Herlihy, a two-timing yuppie who was hit by a bus while trying to avoid a falling air-conditioner. And Téa Leoni is Frank's widow, Gwen, whom he wants Bertram to befriend and prevent from remarrying. She hates Bertram at first, and then she doesn't.

headline: Guest Hosts for a PBS Show
summary: PBS's Friday newsmagazine ''Need to Know'' is turning to a rotating group of well-known guest hosts for the next several months, as it seeks a new permanent anchor in the wake of Alison Stewart's departure on Friday. First up is Scott Simon, the host of NPR's ''Weekend Edition Saturday,'' who will fill in this week. Others to follow are Maria Hinojosa, the former ''Now on PBS'' correspondent who reports occasionally for ''Need to Know,'' and Ray Suarez, a senior correspondent for ''The PBS NewsHour.''

headline: Postcard From L.S.U.: N.F.L. Bloodlines Infuse The Tigers With Talent
summary: BATON ROUGE, La. - While success on the field usually materializes because of work ethic and talent, a little boost from the gene pool never hurts. For top-ranked Louisiana State, family connections to the N.F.L. are plentiful.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (Showtime) HOMELAND Is he a Qaeda operative or not? Claire Danes, above, stars as Carrie Mathison, a psychologically tormented C.I.A. officer who suspects that Sgt. Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis), a Marine who is rescued in Afghanistan after spending eight years in captivity, may not be quite the hero he's cracked up to be in this new thriller inspired by an Israeli series, ''Hatufim'' (''Prisoners of War''). Morena Baccarin is Brody's beautiful wife, who has moved on with their children. And Mandy Patinkin is Carrie's boss and mentor, Saul Berenson, whom she deceives to mount a rogue surveillance operation. ''This series is not particularly high-tech, and it doesn't have a real-time ticking clock conceit, spectacular special effects or preposterous red herrings,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. ''Homeland' is '24' for grown-ups.'' The Season 6 premiere of ''Dexter,'' in which the forensics expert and serial killer (Michael C. Hall) shows up at his 20th high school reunion with a plan to go mano a mano with the prom king, leads in at 9. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Former Vice President Dick Cheney and his daughter Liz discuss the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born cleric who was a leading figure with Al Qaeda's Yemen affiliate, as well as the 2012 Republican presidential field, President Obama's jobs plans and his chances for re-election. In ''Fareed Zakaria GPS,'' at 10, Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discusses Pakistan, the killing of Osama bin Laden, leaving the Obama administration, the scheduled withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan and proposed Pentagon budget cuts.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY A new season of NBC's Thursday night comedy block begins as the study group members reunite after summer break and wonder if they'll see Pierce (Chevy Chase), who left in anger after last spring's paintball game. Jeff (Joel McHale) has a run-in with the new biology teacher, Professor Kane (Michael K. Williams), and is kicked out of class. And Dean Pelton (Jim Rash, above) finds a new nemesis in Vice Dean Laybourne (John Goodman) of the Air-Conditioning Repair Annex. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 8:30, Leslie (Amy Poehler) decides to break up with Ben (Adam Scott) or follow her dream of running for office. Ann (Rashida Jones) dispenses medical advice, and Ron (Nick Offerman) prepares for the return of his first ex-wife, Tammy (Patricia Clarkson). In ''The Office,'' at 9, the new regional manager of Dunder Mifflin is revealed amid a frenzy of speculation. James Spader joins the cast as the company's mysterious new chief executive. And in the premiere of ''Whitney,'' at 9:30, Whitney (Whitney Cummings), a whiny photographer, worries that she and her exceedingly patient longtime beau, Alex (Chris D'Elia), may have to rev up their relationship if it's going to survive. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR As part of its collaboration with The Economist Film Project, ''Last Train Home'' looks at the impact of China's mass migration from rural areas to cities by focusing on people's annual return to their home villages to celebrate the New Year.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Sports fans drifting toward summer after the Dallas Mavericks took the N.B.A. title, and after the N.H.L. Stanley Cup series, which went to a dramatic seventh-game finish and a win for Boston after 39 years, stumbled on a new name at the U.S. Open Golf Championship: Rory McIlroy, above. The 22-year-old golfer from Northern Ireland broke eight Open records on his way to winning his first major championship. Golf fans and those just learning about McIlroy turned to Wikipedia, the golfer's own site, and WTOC11, which is the CBS affiliate in Savannah, Ga. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DALE, CHALMERS
summary: DALE--Chalmers, born December 29, 1925, died peacefully June 12, 2011 at his home in South Nyack, NY. Survived by sons Anthony Chalmers and Henry Bell Dale, four grandchildren and Arnie Walton his companion for 53 years. Raised in Haverford, PA, Chum served in the US Navy during WWII, and worked for CBS Television 1951-1991 first in the mailroom and eventually becoming Emmy award winning producer/director/writer of cultural and religious programs. He published a memoir in 2003 called A Life Full of Days.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) CLASSIC HORROR Turner Classic Movies celebrates Halloween all month with a 32-film festival, introduced by ''A Night at the Movies: The Horrors of Stephen King,'' in which this master of the macabre discusses the films that influenced his writing. The lineup begins at 9 with ''Frankenstein'' (1931), James Whale's adaptation of the Mary Shelley novel. ''Freaks'' (1932), Tod Browning's tale about a dwarf (Harry Earles) who takes revenge on a beautiful but evil trapeze artist (Olga Baclanova), follows at 10:15; ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' (1932), starring Fredric March in the role that won him his first Oscar, at 12:30 a.m.; Browning's ''Mark of the Vampire'' (1935), with Lionel Barrymore and Bela Lugosi, at 2:15; Robert Wiene's ''Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'' (1919), generally acknowledged as the first German Expressionist film and featuring Werner Krauss as a mysterious mesmerist, at 3:30; and ''Nosferatu (1922), F. W. Murnau's unauthorized adaptation of Bram Stoker's ''Dracula,'' starring Max Schreck, above, as the vampire Count Orlok, at 4:45. 7 P.M. (MSNBC) THE GREAT DEMOCRATIC DEBATE Left, right or centrist? Chris Matthews moderates this special edition of ''Hardball,'' in which panelists debate President Obama's options for re-election. The roster includes the filmmaker Michael Moore; former Gov. Ed Rendell of Pennsylvania; the political strategist Mark Penn; the historian Douglas Brinkley; Joan Walsh, an editor at large for Salon.com; Clarence Page, a columnist for The Chicago Tribune; and Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHALMERS, DALE
summary: DALE--Chalmers, born December 29, 1925, died peacefully June 12, 2011 at his home in South Nyack, NY. Survived by sons Anthony Chalmers and Henry Bell Dale, four grandchildren and Arnie Walton his companion for 53 years. Raised in Haverford, PA, Chum served in the US Navy during WWII, and worked for CBS Television 1951-1991 first in the mailroom and eventually becoming Emmy award winning producer/director/writer of cultural and religious programs. He published a memoir in 2003 called A Life Full of Days.

headline: Musicians Plan to Sue Grammys
summary: The increasingly bitter dispute that first erupted early in April when the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced it was eliminating 31 categories from the Grammy Awards notched up yet another step on Thursday when a New York law firm announced plans to sue the Academy on behalf of musicians who play Latin jazz, one of the categories that is being dropped. At a news conference in Manhattan, the drummer Bobby Sanabria, one of the Latin jazz musicians who has been most vocal in criticizing the Academy's action and in leading efforts to restore all 31 categories, also called for a national boycott against CBS, which broadcasts the Grammy Awards program each February. Speaking in both English and Spanish, he urged viewers to refrain from watching programs on the network and to write letters of protest to corporations sponsoring shows on CBS.

headline: Pupi Campo, 91, Cuban Bandleader and 'the Rumba Maestro'
summary: Pupi Campo, a Cuban bandleader who brought rippling syncopation to Jack Paar's ''Morning Show'' on CBS television in the early 1950s and to his long career in nightclubs around the country, died on Dec. 12 at a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 91. His wife, Joette, confirmed the death.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARTSCH, JANE E.
summary: BARTSCH--Jane E, passed away on June 14, 2011 in Cortlandt Manor, NY. Jane was the VP and general manager of WJBR Radio in Wilmington DE., Jane worked locally in the New York area for CBS FM and KJOY in Long Island, as well as other radio stations throughout the country. She is survived by her husband Hans Mac Bain, brothers Paul and Donald Bartsch, and a sister Dale Bartsch. Contributions can be made in Jane's memory to the Lankanau Medical Center, 300 E Lancaster Ave, Wynewood, PA 19096 www.mainlinehealth.org/lhgiving. Services will be private.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WEDECK, DAVID OF TEANECK
summary: WEDECK--David of Teaneck, NJ passed away on July 21st at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife Diane, children Douglas and Andrew, grandchildren Moshe, Sheva, Naama, Benjamin, Eliyahu and daughters-in-law Yael and Mara. Another son Jonathan died in 1973. He was born in Brooklyn, NY. Following a long career as an executive at both NBC and CBS television, at the age of 70, Mr. Wedeck invented the patented technology for, the first screwless, eyeglass frame. Prior to his network positions, he was a VP at the ad agency Benton Bowles. He then co-founded the commercial production company Focus Presentations. Mr. Wedeck was a Jewish soldier stationed in Germany during World War II and then went on to Columbia University where he received an undergraduate degree in Business Management and then a Masters of Science of Business. He attended Townsend Harris High School. Mr. Wedeck was a generous, passionate, honest, funny and intelligent man who until he was ultimately felled by the ravages of Alzheimer's disease, was undaunted in the pursuit of his goals. His loss will be felt by many.

headline: First Lady Brushes Aside Book's Account of Friction
summary: Michelle Obama dismissed a new book's portrayal of her role as first lady, saying it played off an image of her as ''some angry black woman'' and insisting that she had played little role, at least directly, in the West Wing of the White House. ''I don't have conversations with my husband's staff,'' she told Gayle King of CBS News in an interview broadcast on Wednesday morning. ''I don't go to the meetings.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WEDECK, DAVID
summary: WEDECK--David of Teaneck, NJ passed away on July 21st at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife Diane, children Douglas and Andrew, grandchildren Moshe, Sheva, Naama, Benjamin, Eliyahu and daughters-in-law Yael and Mara. Another son Jonathan died in 1973.
