headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARTSCH, JANE E
summary: BARTSCH--Jane E, passed away on June 14, 2011 in Cortlandt Manor, NY. Jane was the VP and general manager of WJBR Radio in Wilmington DE., Jane worked locally in the New York area for CBS FM and KJOY in Long Island, as well as other radio stations throughout the country. She is survived by her husband Hans Mac Bain, brothers Paul and Donald Bartsch, and a sister Dale Bartsch. Contributions can be made in Jane's memory to the Lankanau Medical Center, 300 E Lancaster Ave, Wynewood, PA 19096 www.mainlinehealth.org/lhgiving. Services will be private.

headline: It's Time to Warm Up Your Flat-Screen Crystal Ball
summary: It's 2011 -- television is everywhere, and cable runs on a 24-hour news cycle. But the start of the fall season on broadcast television still captures the imagination of viewers and causes network executives to grip their armrests a little tighter. There are 25 new scripted shows -- sitcoms and dramas -- on ABC, CBS, FOX, NBC and CW. Which show will be the breakout hit of the year? Is ''Terra Nova,'' a family-focused action-adventure series on Fox that is set in both the future and the prehistoric past, this season's ''Lost?'' Will NBC's ''Prime Suspect,'' a remake of a British police procedural, find success on this side of the Atlantic, and is the CW show ''Ringer,'' starring Sarah Michelle Gellar, the second coming of ''Buffy?''

headline: Preseason Football Scores
summary: They may have only one playoff victory since the 1997 season, but the Dallas Cowboys still bill themselves as America's Team -- and they have the ratings to match. The Cowboys' preseason game against San Diego on NBC averaged 9.6 million total viewers over the course of prime time on Sunday, handily winning the night in overall viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic among the broadcast networks. (The Chargers won, 20-7.) CBS came in second for the night with a new episode of ''Big Brother'' (8.8 million viewers). According to initial overnight figures reported by BBC News, the first episode of ''The X Factor'' without its show creator, Simon Cowell, had a premiere with 10.5 million viewers on British channel ITV1. Mr. Cowell is developing an American version for Fox, which will have its debut on Sept. 21 and will try to unseat his former show, ''American Idol,'' as the highest-rated program on television.

headline: Bills (5-5) at Jets ( 5-5)
summary: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: --Jets Receivers --vs. Bills' secondary

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $42/SQUARE FOOT $213,696 approximate annual rent

headline: After 36 Marathons, One Radio Goes Silent
summary: For each of the 36 years that the New York City Marathon has existed as a five-borough race, Steve Mendelsohn could be found in the lead vehicle with the race director, cruising along with the lead male runner and relaying messages on his ham radio. But in November, Mr. Mendelsohn will not be there. He died Wednesday morning of pancreatic cancer at his home in Dumont, N.J., said his wife, Heidi. He was 67.

headline: Men's Ratings Are Highest Since 2005
summary: More people watched the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament through Saturday's Final Four than in any year since 2005, which makes sense. For the first time, four networks -- CBS, TNT, TBS and truTV -- have been carrying the tournament, instead of just CBS, as a result of a new CBS-Turner deal that goes through 2024. Through Saturday, an average 9.9 million viewers watched each game, up from 9 million last year and the best in six years. The Final Four averaged 15.4 million viewers, tying last year for the best since 2005, according to Nielsen. Connecticut's victory over Kentucky was seen by 16.7 million viewers.

headline: For Lease
summary: $175/SQUARE FOOT (blended rent)

headline: Sherman Hemsley, Star Of 'Jeffersons,' Dies at 74
summary: Sherman Hemsley, the bantamweight comic actor who portrayed the scrappy, nouveau riche George Jefferson on the hit CBS sitcom ''The Jeffersons,'' died on Tuesday at his home in El Paso. He was 74. His death was confirmed by his agent, Todd Frank. He did not specify a cause.

headline: Chargers (4-1) at Jets (3-3)
summary: 1 p.m., CBS Matchup to Watch

headline: Bills (4-1) at Giants (3-2)
summary: 1 p.m., CBS MATCHUP to watch

headline: In Sun Valley, Less Adulation of Tech Start-Ups
summary: As moguls descended on Sun Valley on Tuesday for Allen & Company's annual gathering, they were greeted by a giant plume of smoke. Fanned by wind, wildfires in southern Idaho had spawned a huge cloud, obscuring the area's verdant hills and creating a mess on the runways. Commercial and private jets were delayed. Many circled Friedman Memorial Airport, waiting for their turn to land. And about a dozen private jets were diverted to the airport in Twin Falls -- an hour and a half drive from the resort.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (CBS) 60 MINUTES Scott Pelley reports on a ripple effect of mortgage foreclosures: plummeting property values in neighborhoods with high home-vacancy rates. Anderson Cooper goes scuba diving in one of the Caribbean's imperiled coral reefs. Morley Safer meets with Meryl Streep, above, to discuss her portrayal of Margaret Thatcher in the biopic ''The Iron Lady.'' Ms. Streep also touches on topics like her preference for low-budget pictures and her opinion that the quality of acting has improved over time, even as the subjects of more and more films have become less intellectual. 9 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS David Gregory interviews Speaker of the House John Boehner about the payroll tax and asks Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, about the Iowa caucuses and her attempt to outshine Newt Gingrich. Nikki Haley, the governor of South Carolina, discusses her endorsement of Mitt Romney.

headline: Jets (4-3) at Bills (5-2)
summary: Jets (4-3) at Bills (5-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Shonn Greene vs. Buffalo defense The Bills have allowed 120 rushing yards a game this season. Under Rex Ryan, the Jets have averaged 279 yards on the ground in four meetings with Buffalo, which augurs well for a rejuvenated Greene. Behind a steady offensive line, Greene erupted for a season-high 112 yards on Oct. 23 against San Diego. He must contend with the superb rookie defensive tackle Marcell Dareus, a pass-rushing force who also clogs the middle.

headline: Kutcher to Replace Sheen on 'Two and a Half Men'
summary: Ashton Kutcher, one of the former stars of the sitcom ''That 70's Show,'' has been selected to replace Charlie Sheen on the hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men,'' Warner Brothers and CBS announced on Friday. The selection of Mr. Kutcher had been rumored since Thursday, when he signaled the news to his followers on Twitter with the cryptic message ''What's the square root of 6.25?'' (The answer: 2.5.)

headline: Jim Parsons May Meet A Giant Rabbit
summary: The Emmy Award-winning actor Jim Parsons (''The Big Bang Theory'') is in talks to return to Broadway this spring to play Elwood P. Dowd in the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy ''Harvey,'' about a man who claims to be friends with a 6-foot-tall rabbit no one else can see. Two theater executives close to the discussions, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to disclose the possible deal, said Mr. Parsons, above, was in negotiations with Roundabout Theater Company. Representatives for Mr. Parsons and for Roundabout declined to comment. The two executives said the production hinged on the schedule of Mr. Parsons, who stars as the socially awkward theoretical physicist Sheldon Cooper in ''The Big Bang Theory'' on CBS, for which he won the Emmy for best actor in a comedy in 2010 and again in September. Mr. Parsons made his Broadway debut last spring, to critical accolades, in the Tony Award-winning revival of ''The Normal Heart,'' playing the young gay activist Tommy Boatwright. ''Harvey,'' by Mary Chase, opened on Broadway in 1944 and ran for more than four years; the play was made into a movie in 1950 starring Jimmy Stewart as Elwood and Josephine Hull as his exasperated sister Veta, a performance that earned her an Academy Award for best supporting actress. The play has been revived once on Broadway, in 1970, starring Stewart and Helen Hayes (in her final Broadway production) as Veta.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SPENCER, EDSON WHITE
summary: SPENCER--Edson White, age 85, passed away peacefully at home in Wayzata, MN on March 25, 2012 after a valiant battle with PSP. He was surrounded by his wife of 62 years Harriet, and their four children, Linda Spencer Murchison, Edson W. Spencer Jr., Douglas Stuart Spencer and James McClure Spencer. Born June 4, 1926, and raised in Chicago, Illinois, Spencer served in the U.S. Navy and was honorably discharged in 1946. A graduate of Williams College, he went on to Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, earning an M.A. in 1950. He and Harriet McClure Stuart married in August 1950. He worked for Sears Roebuck in Sioux City, IA, La Crosse, WI, and in Venezuela before settling in Minneapolis in 1954. Ed began his 32 year career at Honeywell as an aeronautical engineer, then as Regional Manager for Honeywell Asia based in Tokyo, Japan from 1959 to 1964. He ultimately served as Chairman and CEO of Honeywell from 1973-1987. During that time he served on the boards of Norwest Corporation, CBS, and American Express Mutual Funds Group, and the international advisory boards of NEC, Chase Manhattan Bank, and Robert Bosch, Gmbh. Ed's personal interests were many and varied and he brought passion, insight and intellectual curiosity to everything he took on. He was most proud of his service on the boards of the Ford Foundation, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the Mayo Foundation and the Minneapolis Foundation. Throughout his career he pursued his interest in US Japan relations with membership on the U.S. Japan Business Council and the Trilateral Commission. Additionally, he served on Governor Perpich's Blue Ribbon Commission on the University of Minnesota, Governor Carlson's Roundtable on Higher Education, and the Board of Carleton College. Ed was actively engaged in the Humphrey Institute at the University of Minnesota and a dedicated advisor to the Center for Victims of Torture. Between many a trip to interesting places around the world you could find Ed (and Harriet) casting a line in the Clarks Fork of the Yellowstone in Northwestern Wyoming. Deeply committed to the national treasure that is Yellowstone National Park, he and Harriet were founders of the Yellowstone Park Foundation, and served on the Advisory Board of the National Parks and Conservation Association. Spencer was accomplished athlete who enjoyed competition throughout his life. He was an excellent college hockey and tennis player; later in life he enjoyed skiing, tennis, fly fishing and hiking. These many professional accomplishments never masked what was most important to him, which was spending time with family and friends. He is survived by his wife Harriet; children Linda (Reid) Murchison, Ed (Val) Spencer, Doug (Kathleen Parrish) Spencer and Jim (Polly) Spencer, and nine wonderful grandchildren, Sarah (Andy), Clare, Emily, Julia, Katie, Alison, Teddy, James, and Michael. The family would like to express special appreciation to Becky Fredericks and her team of nurses for their gracious and wonderful care, and to Allina Hospice Care. A memorial service will be held at the Wayzata Community Church on Tuesday, April 3rd at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made to Cure PSP, 30 E. Padonia Road, Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093; www.curepsp.org; The Center for Victims of Torture, 649 Dayton Avenue St. Paul, MN 55104; www.cvt.org; or The Mayo Foundation: www.mayoclinic.org.

headline: Football Wins Again
summary: Although final audience numbers were not yet available on Monday, the ''Sunday Night Football'' game (the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Indianapolis Colts 23-20) once again carried NBC to a ratings victory. Among scripted entertainment shows, the series premiere of ''Pan Am'' on ABC took off with 10.9 million total viewers, a higher total audience than its lead in, ''Desperate Housewives'' (9.8 million viewers). A new timeslot and an Emmy win for Julianna Margulies (not to mention a dynamite new haircut, with bangs) did not translate to a ratings increase for ''The Good Wife'' on CBS. That legal drama attracted 10.5 million viewers, down from 12.9 million for last season's premiere episode. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 11 P.M. (13) FLORENT: QUEEN OF THE MEAT MARKET (2011) David Sigal traces the trajectory of Restaurant Florent, a 24-hour diner-cum-bistro on Gansevoort Street in Manhattan's meatpacking district, from 1985, when it was the lone eatery in a shadowy industrial area, to 2008 when, after a successful run, it became a relic of a bohemian utopia in a quickly changing neighborhood. The film also chronicles the life of the restaurant's owner, Florent Morellet, above, a French expatriate, artist-cartographer and political activist who, after learning in 1987 that he was H.I.V. positive, disregarded the advice of friends and revealed his status, even keeping a running tabulation of his T-cell count on the restaurant's menu board. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called this film, which features appearances by Julianne Moore, Diane von Furstenberg, Isaac Mizrahi and Michael Musto, ''a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, about the administration's plan to turn around the economy. She also speaks with Rick Santorum, a former Republican presidential candidate, about the conservative agenda. Later in the morning, Mr. Plouffe appears on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC; and on ''Meet the Press,'' on NBC at 10:30.

headline: Obama 'Super PAC' Runs Anti-Romney Ad
summary: The ''super PAC'' supporting President Obama is out with its first commercial this year, being broadcast in Michigan, and it highlights Mitt Romney's opposition to the federal loan program that helped rescue General Motors and Chrysler. ''His message was clear,'' an announcer says as the ad cuts to a brief sound bite of Mr. Romney saying ''Let Detroit go bankrupt.'' The end of that sound bite - where Mr. Romney utters ''bankrupt'' - is repeated three separate times with the audio amplified to create an echo effect.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2012 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Russell Brand, above, hosts this show, broadcast live from the Gibson Theater in Universal City, Calif., which bestows the Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in ''best'' categories like kiss, villain, fight, jaw-dropping moment and breakout star. New ''bests'' include hero, on-screen transformation, gut-wrenching performance and on-screen dirtbag. Johnny Depp will be honored with the MTV Generation Award. Presenters include Adam Sandler, Emma Watson, Leighton Meester, Emma Stone, Andrew Garfield, Charlize Theron, Michael Fassbender and Matthew McConaughey. The director Christopher Nolan and the actors Christian Bale, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Gary Oldman will be on hand for a preview of their film ''The Dark Knight Rises.'' Performers include the Black Keys, in a rendition of their single ''Gold in the Ceiling''; Fun., in a tribute to the greatest party films of all time; and the rapper Wiz Khalifa. Martin Solveig will be the house D.J. Ashton Kutcher will punk Kim Kardashian and Drake in a preparty at 8. The Season 2 premiere of ''Teen Wolf'' follows at 11. 8:30 A.M. (BBC AMERICA); 9 A.M. (Fox News Channel); 11 A.M. (CNN) QUEEN ELIZABETH II'S DIAMOND JUBILEE Britain celebrates the 60-year reign of Queen Elizabeth -- only Victoria ruled longer -- as a flotilla of more than 1,000 boats adorned with streamers and Union Jacks sails down the Thames. On BBC America, a marathon of tell-alls, including ''William & Kate: The First Year,'' at 7 p.m., leads up to ''The Diamond Queen,'' at 8, in which Andrew Marr interviews royals and Prime Minster David Cameron to analyze the effect of the royal family on British trade and international relations. At 9, C-Span will broadcast the arrival of the queen, above, at Parliament, where the speakers of the House of Commons and the House of Lords will pay tribute to the occasion, and she will offer comments in return. And at 4:15 a.m. on Tuesday on BBC America, early risers can catch the queen and Prince Philip as they attend a service of thanksgiving at St. Paul's Cathedral, followed by a carriage procession.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 2 A.M. (TBS) A CHRISTMAS STORY (1983) ''You'll shoot your eye out.'' That's the oft-repeated refrain when Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsley, above) tells adults he wants a BB gun for Christmas, and it's just another putdown for the 9-year-old boy, who is browbeaten by his parents, teased by his schoolmates and suckered by the Ovaltine company. The film, which is being shown every two hours till 6 p.m., listens in as a grown-up Ralphie (Jean Shepherd, the narrator) remembers his childhood in 1940s Indiana with comic nostalgia. 9 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS This week's topic is the political climate of 2011 and the bearing it will have on the 2012 election. Sitting at the roundtable are Tom Brokaw of NBC; Kathleen Parker of The Washington Post; Thomas Friedman of The New York Times; and Marc H. Morial, former mayor of New Orleans. The program ends with a Christmas Day message from Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, archbishop emeritus of Washington.

headline: Political Memo: Social Issues Return to Dominant Role in National Debate
summary: Rick Santorum creates a stir by speaking out against prenatal testing. Virginia's governor and legislature get caught up in an emotional debate over requiring women seeking abortions to undergo an ultrasound. President Obama, under pressure, recalibrates his position on health-insurance coverage of contraception for employers with religious affiliations. Social issues are back with a vengeance, dominating the dialogue on the presidential campaign trail, in Congress and in state capitals.

headline: Charlie Sheen and Warner Brothers Settle Suit Over His Firing
summary: The protracted conflict betweenCharlie Sheen and Warner Brothers Television ended quietly on Monday when the two sides agreed to settle a lawsuit the actor filed after the studio fired him from the hit CBS sitcom, ''Two and a Half Men.'' Warner Brothers issued a statement saying that the settlement had been agreed ''to the parties' mutual satisfaction.'' Mr. Sheen had also sued the comedy's executive producer, Chuck Lorre, and that action was also settled by the agreement. No terms were disclosed and the statement said all the parties had ''agreed to maintain confidentiality over the terms.''

headline: Gus Johnson Joins Fox Sports
summary: Gus Johnson Joins Fox SportsGus Johnson, who left CBS Sports after16 years, joined Fox Sports to call gamesin college football and basketball and theN.F.L. Johnson is best known for an excitablestyle that was most in evidenceduring the N.C.A.A. men's basketballtournament on CBS, which he will nolonger call. More at nytimes.com/sports.RICHARD SANDOMIR

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (BET, Centric) CENTRIC PRESENTS: 2011 SOUL TRAIN AWARDS Gladys Knight and Earth, Wind & Fire (whose members include, above from left, Verdine White, Philip Bailey and Ralph Johnson) are honored as living legends by some of their peers at this event, taped on Nov. 17 at the Fox Theater in Atlanta and hosted by Cedric the Entertainer. Another tribute celebrates the life of Heavy D, the rapper who died on Nov. 8. Performers include Natalie Cole, Freddie Jackson, Cee Lo Green, Common, Chrisette Michele, Mary Mary, Marsha Ambrosius, Melanie Fiona, Miguel, Musiq Soulchild, Anthony Hamilton, Jill Scott, Robin Thicke, Lalah Hathaway and the Original 7ven, the group formerly known as the Time. Also onstage: the CNN host Wolf Blitzer, who teams up with Doug E. Fresh in a skit. The stroll down the purple carpet kicks off at 8, on BET. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews the Republican presidential candidate Jon Huntsman, a former governor of Utah and ambassador to China, about the state of his campaign and the race. Mr. Wallace also speaks with Senators Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, about the failure of the joint Congressional committee on deficit reduction to reach an agreement.

headline: 'Harvey' Sets Date For Broadway
summary: The Jimmy Stewart vehicle ''Harvey'' - and the Emmy Award winner Jim Parsons (''The Big Bang Theory'') - are coming back to Broadway this spring. Roundabout Theater Company confirmed plans on Tuesday to mount the first Broadway revival of ''Harvey'' since 1970, when Stewart reprised his performance as Elwood P. Dowd from the 1950 film (as well as from the 1940s Broadway production.) Mr. Parsons, who was previously reported to be in negotiations for the revival, will take on the role of Elwood, the genial eccentric who claims to see a six-foot-tall white rabbit named Harvey. He made a well-received Broadway debut last spring in a supporting role in ''The Normal Heart.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICA IN PRIMETIME Television as a lens on American society is the focus of this new four-part series, which looks at some character archetypes -- the man of the house, the misfit and the crusader -- that have remained a staple of shows for generations, and in the process have both mirrored and helped to shape the national character. First up: ''Independent Women,'' which reflects on the transformation of women from model housewives to complex and even proudly controversial characters. Among the actors and writers interviewed are Mary Tyler Moore and James L. Brooks (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show''); Candice Bergen (''Murphy Brown''); Liz Brixius and Linda Wallem (''Nurse Jackie''); Eva Longoria, above left (''Desperate Housewives''); Robert and Michelle King (''The Good Wife''); Shonda Rhimes, above center, and Sandra Oh (''Grey's Anatomy''); and Diablo Cody, above right (''United States of Tara.''). 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY David Axelrod, an Obama campaign adviser, discusses the strategy to get the president re-elected. Also, Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, talks about his presidential aspirations and his Republican rivals. On ''Fareed Zakaria GPS,'' at 10, the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy, who pushed President Nicolas Sarkozy of France to urge NATO intervention in Libya, discusses that country's revolution and whether the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was justified.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International AMID FLEDGLING CEASE-FIRE,

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) ONCE UPON A TIME Emma Swan (Jennifer Morrison), a 28-year-old bail bondswoman who has been on her own since she was abandoned as a baby, is reunited with Henry (Jared Gilmore), the son she gave up years ago -- and who now, at 10, is desperately in need of his mother's help. He believes that Emma actually comes from an alternate world and is the missing daughter of Snow White (Ginnifer Goodwin, above with Josh Dallas) and Prince Charming (Mr. Dallas), who sent her away to protect her from the curse of the Evil Queen (Lana Parrilla). In the process, all the fairy-tale characters were brought into modern reality. Unfortunately, in this new series, the queen is now Henry's foster mother. In ''Desperate Housewives,'' at 9, Susan (Teri Hatcher) tries to comply with the request of her art teacher (Miguel Ferrer) that his students take his class in the nude, the better to be able to create from a perspective of honesty. Elsewhere, Bree (Marcia Cross) aspires to serve homemade soup to the homeless but ends up feeding others instead; Gaby (Eva Longoria) alienates volunteers in her new job as president of the P.T.A.; and Lynette (Felicity Huffman) goes to a singles bar. And in ''Pan Am,'' at 10, the crew finds itself embroiled in sexual intrigue in Monte Carlo. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, left, and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discuss the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and the withdrawal of United States forces from Iraq by the end of the year, which President Obama announced on Friday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NORTH, SUZY
summary: NORTH--Suzy Hansen, daughter of Violet Colt Hansen and Philip H. Hansen died September 11, 2011. Suzy is survived by son, Christopher Colt North; grandchildren Matthew Colt North, Kathryn Clayton North, and Christopher Colt North II; and great-grandchild Ellasynne Ryder McCleskey. In her professional life Suzy was an editor of Harper's Bazaar and held positions in public relations at Allied Chemical and CBS in New York City. In Washington, DC she was with the Capital Association of Advertisers. She retired to Williamsburg, Virginia in 2003. Suzy's volunteer work included teaching teenaged girls in Harlem Gracious Living. In Washington she was a member of the American Newswomen's' Association, and The National Cathedral Literacy Program where she tutored first graders. She was also a volunteer at the Hospice House and Support Care of Williamsburg. Suzy traveled extensively and loved to dance, read, and converse. She especially enjoyed music, architecture, interior design, fashion and fine dining. Her friends will miss her wit, generosity, grace, class, and independence. Suzy's legacy will continue in her family and friends, especially the five ladies she lovingly referred to as her "Angels". In lieu of flowers, please donate to the American Cancer Society at www. cancer.org.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NORTH, SUZY HANSEN
summary: NORTH--Suzy Hansen, daughter of Violet Colt Hansen and Philip H. Hansen died September 11, 2011. Suzy is survived by son, Christopher Colt North; grandchildren Matthew Colt North, Kathryn Clayton North, and Christopher Colt North II; and great-grandchild Ellasynne Ryder McCleskey. In her professional life Suzy was an editor of Harper's Bazaar and held positions in public relations at Allied Chemical and CBS in New York City. In Washington, DC she was with the Capital Association of Advertisers. She retired to Williamsburg, Virginia in 2003. Suzy's volunteer work included teaching teenaged girls in Harlem Gracious Living. In Washington she was a member of the American Newswomen's' Association, and The National Cathedral Literacy Program where she tutored first graders. She was also a volunteer at the Hospice House and Support Care of Williamsburg. Suzy traveled extensively and loved to dance, read, and converse. She especially enjoyed music, architecture, interior design, fashion and fine dining. Her friends will miss her wit, generosity, grace, class, and independence. Suzy's legacy will continue in her family and friends, especially the five ladies she lovingly referred to as her "Angels". In lieu of flowers, please donate to the American Cancer Society at www. cancer.org.

headline: FX Channel Picks Up New Charlie Sheen Show
summary: Charlie Sheen will return to television next summer in an adaptation of the 2003 movie ''Anger Management,'' the FX cable channel announced Thursday. The project has been the subject of extensive speculation in the television business since Mr. Sheen signed on to star in it, after being fired from the CBS hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men.'' Adding to the interest was that the studio developing the comedy show, Revolution, hired the veteran comedy producer Bruce Helford (''The Drew Carey Show'') to run it.

headline: What's Next? A Top 10 on Art Shows?
summary: David Letterman would be the first to admit that his taste in art is pretty malleable, if he admits to having one at all. ''I like a few things; the rest of it is lost on me,'' he said. ''If somebody would say to me, 'This is great,' I would probably agree.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE VOYAGE OF THE DAWN TREADER (2010) Lucy Pevensie (Georgie Henley, above, with the lion Aslan) and her brother, Edmund (Skandar Keynes), joined by their chatterbox cousin Eustace Scrubb (Will Poulter), are lured back into Narnia by a maritime painting that turns into a Niagara Falls, sweeping the children out to sea in this franchise's third installment, directed by Michael Apted. Soon they've been rescued by their old comrade in arms, King Caspian (Ben Barnes), and brought aboard his ship, now armed with a crew of clean-cut men and talking beasts, including a mouse-kateer named Reepicheep (voiced by Simon Pegg). ''Though there are times when the movie turns into a congested mess, as in a climactic battle that washes the screen in gray, there are moments when you also see a quieter, less industrial production,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Such is the case after Eustace is turned into a grand, ungainly, unhappy dragon. When he lies forlornly on a beach, or as forlornly as dragons do, and a monstrous-size tear slides down his scaly face, you don't just see the wizardry magic, you also see the human touch behind it.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports from the United States Army Chaplain Center and School at Fort Jackson, S.C., where counseling is available to help members of the clergy.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (HBO) ONE DAY (2011) Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess (above) portray Emma and Dex -- she's bookish, serious and from a family of modest means; he's dashing, irresponsible and wealthy -- who meet, as drunken university graduates, on St. Swithin's Day in 1988 and proceed to reunite on that date, July 15, each year. Rafe Spall and Romola Garai play the characters who would seem to be Emma and Dex's perfect matches. Ken Stott and Patricia Clarkson are Dex's parents. Lone Scherfig, ''a veteran of the Danish Dogme 95 movement, whose previous English-language films are 'Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself' and 'An Education,' can be a wonderfully centrifugal director, wandering away from the center of a conventional narrative toward its scruffy margins, where the interesting stuff happens,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Her eccentric eye and offbeat rhythm sustain 'One Day' through its stretches of banality and mitigate some of its flaws. Among these are a superficial sense of history -- remember how girls used to wear their hair? remember nuclear disarmament? -- and, more seriously, a late, disastrous dive into the deep end of weepitude.'' 7:45 P.M. (Bravo) THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS (1991) Just in time for dinner -- fava beans and a nice Chianti, perhaps? -- the network offers back-to-back screenings of this Jonathan Demme thriller about Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster), an F.B.I. trainee who enlists the help of Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins, above), a sociopath with a taste for human flesh, in tracking a serial killer. The film won Oscars for best actor, best actress, best screenplay based on previously published material, best director and best picture.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (13) FAUST Des McAnuff, the artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, whose revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' is now on Broadway, makes his Metropolitan Opera debut with Gounod's ''Faust,'' updated to the 20th century. Jonas Kaufmann stars as a nuclear scientist, despairing of the effects of his life's work, who makes a contract with the Devil. Marina Poplavskaya, above with Mr. Kaufmann, is Marguerite, Faust's love interest and eventual victim, and René Pape reprises his role as Méphistophélès. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducted this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation, which was shown live in movie theaters on Dec. 10. ''It is better if a production does not look too deeply for elements of existential despair that are simply not in the piece, and that seems the problem with the new 'Faust,' '' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, adding that this co-production with the English National Opera, ''though rich with ideas and theatrically daring, is finally rather clinical and oppressive.'' 7:45 A.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut of Sarah Polley, who earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

headline: A Times Editor Is Promoted
summary: The New York Times said Tuesday that it was promoting its longtime design director, Tom Bodkin, to deputy managing editor, the latest change to the masthead since Jill Abramson took over as executive editor in September. Mr. Bodkin, who has been the paper's design director since 1987, had held the title of assistant managing editor. He will continue to oversee a team of 130 art directors, Web designers, graphic artists and others responsible for the look and feel of the paper and its Web site. The promotion is effective Jan. 1.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase of deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration among HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and a nationwide outreach to more than 40,000 community organizations. This first installment, ''Consequences'' (above, a scene from the film), explores the health effects of being overweight. Part 2, ''Choices,'' at 9:10, investigates the science of weight loss and offers diet and exercise tips that will help people find success. Parts 3 and 4 will be broadcast on Tuesday, starting at 8. 2 P.M. (AMC) CINDERELLA MAN (2005) In this biopic from Ron Howard, Russell Crowe, right, portrays James J. Braddock, the Depression-era heavyweight boxing champion with a 75-inch reach, who on June 13, 1935, fought the fight of his life against Max Baer (Craig Bierko), a k a the Livermore Larruper, whose reach was 81 inches. But it's the face-off between Braddock and his manager, Joe Gould (Paul Giamatti), that gives the film its bite. One of its satisfactions is that the story that unfolds inside the ring is not the same one the filmmakers seem keen to sell, Manohla Dargis said in The New York Times. ''Their Cinderella Man is the decent little guy who affirms what movie people call the triumph of the human spirit,'' she wrote. ''The story Mr. Crowe tells, with Mr. Giamatti as a gleeful Mephistopheles, is that of a man who, having sampled the blood of others, clearly enjoyed the taste.''

headline: GAMES TO WATCH
summary: NO. 17 NEBRASKA AT NO. 20 MICHIGAN Noon, ESPN

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.

headline: U.S. Open Could Add Rest Day By 2013
summary: MELBOURNE -- The Australian Open, once the weakest of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments, now has two stadiums with retractable roofs and a third one on the way. Player response continues to be positive. ''Of the four Grand Slams, it is the tournament that behaves better toward the players,'' Rafael Nadal said after losing in the men's final last Monday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KOLL, DONALD MILTON
summary: KOLL--Donald Milton, 78, of Newport Beach and Beverly Hills, California, passed away peacefully with his wife and family at his bedside on December 6, 2011. Don lived inspirationally for the last six years after suffering physical limitations from a stroke. Don was born in Santa Monica, California, to Milton and Edna Koll. He attended Harvard School in Los Angeles and became an Eagle Scout. In 2010, Don was awarded distinguished Eagle Scout buy the Boy Scouts of America. After earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in economics from Stanford University in 1955, Don joined the Air Force as a fighter pilot. Don started his real estate career building custom homes in Newport Beach and, in 1962, he founded The Koll Company. The Koll Company quickly grew into one of the leading real estate companies in southern California and has been responsible for the development of over 90 million square feet office, industrial and retail space in the last 50 years. He brought Jack Nicklaus championship golf courses to Los Cabos, Mexico, at his Palmilla and Cabo del Sol resort developments which was a major contribution to making Los Cabos a world class destination. He was an entrepreneur, a great family man and a mentor to literally dozens of people in commercial real estate throughout California and across the United States. He was Presidential appointee to the Board of Trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum and the American Red Cross, and has served on the boards of CB Richard Ellis, Wells Fargo Bank, the Irvine Company, and Fidelity National Title. Don was an avid supporter of the Boy Scouts of America, Stanford University and many local charities in Orange County and Los Cabos, Mexico. Don has always enjoyed traveling the world, especially to St. Tropez and Los Cabos. He is survived by his wife Kathi, his six children and their spouses, three step-children and their spouses, 21 grandchildren, and his brother Ed. A service in his memory was held at Our Lady Queen of Angels in New Port Beach, California on Decemeber 14, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please donate to: UCLA Neuro-Critical Care Research Fund; Attn: Dr. Paul Vespa, 757 Westwood Blvd., Rm. #

headline: Laurence Fishburne Leaving 'CSI'
summary: After two seasons, Laurence Fishburne is leaving the cast of ''CSI,'' one of the longest-running series on prime-time television. CBS declined to comment Wednesday on many news reports about his departure, but network executives, speaking on condition of anonymity because CBS has not commented, acknowledged that they expected him to depart after the 11th season of the show, which ended in May. The network expects a new character to replace Mr. Fishburne's Dr. Raymond Langston for the 12th season, which will start in the fall.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 A.M. (NBC) MACY'S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Matt Lauer, Ann Curry and Al Roker host this 85th installment of the parade, with appearances by the Big Apple Circus, Mary J. Blige, Neil Diamond, Michael Feinstein, Cee Lo Green, Avril Lavigne, Shelby Lynne, Mannheim Steamroller, the Rockettes, Scotty McCreery, the Muppets of ''Sesame Street,'' and the Broadway casts of ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert,'' ''Sister Act,'' ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' with Daniel Radcliffe. Soaring above it all: Tim Burton's ''B. Boy,'' a balloon boy obsessed with flight who has the scars to prove it. Mr. Lauer explores the components of this year's procession in ''The 85th Anniversary of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade,'' at 10 p.m. Above, a scene from last year's parade. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE ON CBS Kevin Frazier and Christina McLarty introduce excerpts from the Macy's parade and performances by John Fogerty and the Broadway casts of ''Anything Goes'' and ''Memphis.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE SONG OF LUNCH In this bittersweet dramatization of Christopher Reid's poem of the same title, Emma Thompson, above, and Alan Rickman, portray former lovers -- he is a copy editor and failed poet in London; she was his muse, now married to a successful novelist and living in Paris -- meeting for lunch at their favorite trattoria. The menu for this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' presentation features sex, temptation, guilt, revenge and not a little Chianti. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Members of a political roundtable, including the Democratic strategist Donna Brazile and the ABC News conservative commentator George Will, discuss the Republican presidential field and the sexual abuse scandal surrounding Penn State.

headline: Ferguson Is Taking His Show to Paris
summary: 12:46 p.m. | Updated The last time Craig Ferguson's ''Late Late Show'' went to Paris it was without the approval of the CBS late-night host or his producers: they discovered that their program was being - how do you say? - ripped off by a French copycat. But now he and his material will pay a proper visit to the City of Light: on Monday night's episode of ''Late Late Show'' Mr. Ferguson said he and a stripped-down version of the show would travel to Paris next week to shoot a series of episodes that will be broadcast later in the summer.

headline: 'Face the Nation' Will Run an Hour
summary: The half-hour Sunday public affairs program on CBS, ''Face the Nation,'' will become an hourlong program next spring, matching its rivals on other television networks. ''I cannot remember when I've been happier to break a story than I am to tell you this,'' the program's moderator, Bob Schieffer, said on Sunday as he told viewers about the expansion.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GLOVER, ERIKA
summary: GLOVER--Erika Domenica Leopoldina, age 79, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, died on November 16, 2010, of heart failure and kidney failure at Nevis. Erika Glover was along with her late husband William a Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which they founded in 1964. She was born in the former Yugoslavia in 1931, left for Germany in 1954, and came to the United States, to Kentucky, in 1957. She settled in New York, where she worked for CBS and The New Yorker, marrying William Glover in 1962. She was a woman of courage, enthusiasm, and joy, a bonne vivante who loved her family very much. She is survived by daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu; a brother Luka, sister-in-law Vera, nephew Boris in Croatia; and cousins Marijan and Gregory in Toronto. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, www.doctorswithout borders.org

headline: 'Dallas' to Return
summary: It's a dream come true for fans of ''Dallas,'' the vintage-1980s prime-time soap opera, and presumably one that doesn't end with Pam Barnes waking up to find Bobby Ewing in the shower and an entire season of the show wiped out. The pilot episode of a new ''Dallas'' series being prepared for the TNT cable network will feature Larry Hagman, Patrick Duffy and Linda Gray, reprising their roles from the original CBS series, TNT said on Tuesday night. Mr. Hagman is set to return as J. R. Ewing, the Texas oil magnate who became a one-name shorthand for '80s-era greed and ruthlessness. Ms. Gray will once again play Sue Ellen, J. R.'s wife, and Mr. Duffy his younger brother Bobby, who appeared to be hit by a car and killed in the original series, only to reappear, alive and well, in the shower the following year. (Mr. Duffy had intended to leave the series but decided to return.)

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS JR.John Lithgow hosts this summer edition of must-see films for young viewers, which ends for the season with a double bill starring the English actor John Mills. The tribute beings with Disney's ''Swiss Family Robinson'' (1960), based on the book by Johann Wyss, in which Mills portrays the patriarch of a family (above, from left, Tommy Kirk, Dorothy McGuire, Mills and James MacArthur) en route to New Guinea. The family members build a new life -- and an enormous treehouse -- after they're shipwrecked on a tropical island. At 10:15 in ''The Rocking Horse Winner'' (1949), adapted by Anthony Pelissier from the short story by D. H. Lawrence, Mills plays a former stable boy turned handyman to an upper-class London family in financial ruins. The family's 10-year-old (John Howard Davies) discovers that he can pick winning race horses by riding his hobby horse into a furious frenzy. Valerie Hobson is the boy's extravagant mother, who spends the money as fast as her son makes it. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) BEFORE THEY WERE FAMOUS ''20/20'' reminisces about the growing careers of some 2010 Academy Award nominees through film clips and interviews with people who knew them when their stars were just beginning to shine. The roster of friends, family and colleagues includes George Clooney's father, Nick; Sidney Hicks, the husband of Mo'Nique, right; Jeff Bridges's brother, Beau, and his ''Last Picture Show'' co-star Cybill Shepherd; Rita Moreno, who performed a ditty with Morgan Freeman on ''The Electric Company''; and Wesley Snipes, who threw around a few balls with Woody Harrelson in ''White Men Can't Jump.'' Deborah Roberts reports. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The top 10 female semifinalists perform.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 62ND ANNUAL PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDSJimmy Fallon takes over from Neil Patrick Harris as host of this ceremony honoring excellence in television, held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles and broadcast live from coast to coast for the first time in more than 30 years. Eight cameras positioned backstage -- the better to capture preparations by nominees and presenters, as well as the winners' reactions -- will stream a companion show online at NBC.com and Emmys.com. Billy Bush, Maria Menounos and Nate Berkus will report from the red carpet, starting at 7. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Education Secretary Arne Duncan; Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers; and Michelle Rhee, the Washington, D.C., schools chancellor, discuss education and school reform in the United States.

headline: HBO Teams Its 2 Dramas From the Bayou
summary: How this for a crossover act? A late-night star waving across the continent - and across networks - to another late-night star. That was the carefully crafted idea cooked up by two late-night shows - until the N.H.L. took over.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 82ND-ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Will ''The Hurt Locker'' beat out ''Avatar'' as best film? Will Sandra Bullock trump Meryl Streep as best actress? Will Jeff Bridges, after five nominations, finally take home a golden Oscar? The jokesters Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will hold court at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles, above, where these questions and plenty of others will be answered. In her final Oscar special, at 7, Barbara Walters will interview Ms. Bullock, who is nominated for best actress for ''The Blind Side,'' and Mo'Nique, who earned a best supporting actress nomination for ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire.'' Sherri Shepherd, Jess Cagle and Kathy Ireland will report from the red carpet starting at 8. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Tom DeLay, the former House Republican leader, talks about health care and broken government.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HGTV) ALL AMERICAN HANDYMAN Don't let the title fool you. Five women will join 15 men to compete in an assortment of fix-it challenges in this search for the country's best nonprofessional Jack (or Jill) of all trades. The grand prize: a $10,000 shopping spree at Sears and a development deal with HGTV. The contest begins as the 20 finalists (one, Matthew McGuire, is above) are winnowed to 10 after their ingenuity and construction skills are sized up by the show's judges, Mike Holmes and Scott McGillivray. The guest judge is Bill Kiss, the chief marketing officer for tools and hardware for Sears. After the first cut, the remaining competitors will undertake a challenge in which they must identify the elements of a botched construction job; a power-tool test to determine their accuracy at measuring and cutting; and a trivia quiz. Molly Culver hosts. And Part 1 of Mr. Holmes's new two-episode special, ''Lien on Me,'' in which he helps a couple whose contractor has walked off the job, leads in at 8. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURIn conjunction with the publication of his autobiography, ''A Journey: My Political Life,'' the former British prime minister Tony Blair reflects on taking his country to war in Iraq, the fight against extremism and his biggest fears. He also shares his thoughts on American leaders, including the former presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush and the former vice president Dick Cheney, as well as his impressions of Princess Diana and Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CMT) PETTY BLUE Think of Nascar, and chances are the name Petty is going to come to mind. This new documentary follows the family dynasty around the track, starting with its patriarch, Lee Petty (above, center, with his sons Maurice, left, and Richard), who raced under No. 42 and was the face of Nascar's earliest days in 1949. It continues with his son Richard (No. 43), the Hall of Famer and driver with the most wins in the sport's history -- and the only motor sports athlete to earn the Presidential Medal of Freedom -- and Richard's son, Kyle (No. 44), who has twice won one of Nascar's most prominent honors, the Myers Brothers Award. It also follows the family tragedy. In 2000 Kyle's son Adam (No. 45) was killed, more than 50 years after his great-grandfather's first race, when the throttle of his car stuck while he was practicing in New Hampshire -- sending him barreling into a wall. Kevin Costner narrates this film, whose title refers to the distinctive blue color of Richard's cars in the 1960s and '70s, the most famous of which was probably the Plymouth Superbird -- the character Richard played in the 2006 animated Pixar film ''Cars.'' In ''Invitation Only,'' at 10, Toby Keith performs songs from his new album, including the title track, ''Bullets in the Gun,'' as well as ''Somewhere Else'' and his latest single, ''Trailerhood.'' He backs them up with old favorites, among them ''Good as I Once Was'' and ''I Love This Bar,'' and answers audience questions. 8 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC Dennis Murphy reports on the capital-crimes conviction of Steven J. Hayes in the triple murder of Jennifer Hawke-Petit and her two daughters, Michaela and Hayley, on July 23, 2007, in Cheshire, Conn.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF D.C. At last, the moment Washington watchers have been waiting for. The inaugural season comes to a close amid a media frenzy as viewers hear, along with the rest of the incredulous housewives, about the presence at President Obama's first White House state dinner of Michaele and Tareq Salahi, above. They were accused of crashing it last November. The Salahis will join Andy Cohen on ''Watch What Happens: Live,'' at 10:15, to discuss their experiences and to answer viewer questions. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) investigate the remains of a young man who was last seen strutting his stuff at a nightclub near a New Jersey beach.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES The American ice-dancing teams of Meryl Davis and Charlie White, who placed third in the compulsory dance, and Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto, who placed fourth, try to close the gap with Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin, above, the top-ranked Russian pair, in the gold-medal final. Aerial freestyle skiing and ski jumping round out the prime-time coverage. The day's events include men's curling and women's hockey at noon on USA; men's and women's team sprints in the cross-country skiing final at 3 on NBC; the women's hockey semifinal and women's and men's curling at 5 on CNBC; award ceremonies at 12:35 a.m. on NBC; and men's curling (same-day tape) at 3 a.m. on MSNBC. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The show's experts discuss teenagers and sex.

headline: Carl Gordon, 78, a Late-Blooming Actor
summary: Carl Gordon, who four decades ago, nearing midlife and feeling trapped in a series of dispiriting jobs, heeded a surprising call and became a successful character actor on television and the stage, died on Tuesday at his home in Jetersville, Va. He was 78. The cause was non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, his family said.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ESPN) UNMATCHED The main thing Chris Evert, above right, remembers about Martina Navratilova, above left, when they first faced each other as teenagers on the tennis court in 1973 was that her competitor was fat and sullen. ''She was very emotional on the court, whining if she didn't feel she was playing well,'' Ms. Evert said. ''But I remember thinking, if she loses weight, we're all in trouble.'' Her only goal that day, Ms. Navratilova countered, was for Ms. Evert ''to remember my name.'' Eighty matches later, the women had become not only competitors but also true friends. In this latest entry in the ''30 for 30'' documentary series, Lisa Lax and Nancy Stern Winters interview these tennis superstars to tell the story of one of the sport's greatest rivalries and to get their opinions on the state of the game. 6 A.M. (MSG Network) BOOMER & CARTON Boomer Esiason, the former National Football League quarterback, and Craig Carton, a onetime host of ''Jersey Boys,'' an occasionally controversial talk show out of Trenton, bring their morning banter to television in a new program simulcast from their spiffed-up studio at WFAN (660 AM) headquarters in the South Village. ''Boomer & Carton,'' which replaced ''Imus in the Morning'' on WFAN, is now New York's top-rated morning show among men 25 to 54. ''Boomer & Carton in 60,'' a nightly hourlong program featuring the best of that morning's show, will be broadcast at 10.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | FEB. 7--FEB. 13
summary: Television This week brings assorted season finales and premieres (for instance, CBS rolls out ''Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains'' on Thursday), not to mention the Super Bowl and the start of the Winter Olympics. So PBS's ''Independent Lens'' offering (Tuesday night on many stations; check local listings) may have even more trouble than usual getting noticed. But it's a good one, and a different sort of film for this consistently rewarding series.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) 20/20 In 1985, Kathryn Eastburn, an Army wife, and two of her three daughters were found dead in their home near Fort Bragg, N.C. Timothy B. Hennis, above, a master sergeant who had visited the home days earlier when he answered an ad placed by the Eastburns, was found guilty in 1986 of raping and murdering Ms. Eastburn and killing her daughters. He was sentenced to death. But when defense lawyers argued in 1989 that photographs of the grisly crime scene had been projected on a screen over the defendant's head, an appeals court declared that the case should be retried, and Mr. Hennis was acquitted. DNA later linked Mr. Hennis to Ms. Eastburn's body, and the military took up the case in 2006. In April a military jury found Mr. Hennis guilty and sentenced him once again to death. Elizabeth Vargas reviews the case and interviews Jana Eastburn, the youngest of the daughters, who was left alive inside the house. Ms. Vargas also speaks with Gary Eastburn, Jana's father, and with the lawyer who represented Mr. Hennis in his first two trials. 8 P.M. (Cartoon Network) SYM-BIONIC TITAN Teenage aliens crash on Earth while trying to escape an evil general in the premiere of this animated series, left. Season 3 of ''Star Wars: The Clone Wars,'' at 9, finds five clone cadets trying to muster team spirit to complete their training. Anakin and Obi-Wan defend Kamino and its factories against the separatists.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HALLMARK) THE WOMEN WHO DRESS AMERICA As Fashion Week at Lincoln Center comes to a close, Martha Stewart, above right, has her first interview special with the designers Diane von Furstenberg (above left), Tory Burch, Jenna Lyons and Donna Karan. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran about his country's nuclear program and the status of the two American hikers who are still detained in Iran. Christine O'Donnell, the Republican Senate nominee in Delaware, and Karl Rove, a Republican strategist, talk with Chris Wallace on ''Fox News Sunday.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY School's back in session at Greendale Community College, and -- who else? -- Betty White, above, shows up in a guest role as an esteemed but batty anthropology professor in this Season 2 premiere. Meanwhile Señor Chang (Ken Jeong) decides to enroll as a student so he can join the study group. The fifth-season premiere of ''30 Rock,'' at 8:30, finds Jack (Alec Baldwin) determined to help Liz (Tina Fey) hold on to a man for once by meddling in her relationship with Carol (Matt Damon). Elsewhere, Tracy (Tracy Morgan) agonizes over the termination of Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) as a page. And Jenna (Jane Krakowski) becomes the newest TGS producer. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Steve Carell begins his seventh and final season as Michael, who incites outrage when he refuses to fire the surly new assistant (Evan Peters). Meanwhile, Andy (Ed Helms) acts as if he doesn't mind that Erin (Ellie Kemper) has expressed interest in another man. And Pam (Jenna Fischer) thinks she'll impress Jim (John Krasinski) with a prank of her own. She could be wrong. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Johnny Weir swaps his figure skates for a pair of stilettos to run in the men's division of the ''High Heel-a-thon,'' a 150-yard dash in Central Park held on Tuesday -- in heels three inches or more -- to support the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHENKEL, STEPHEN
summary: SCHENKEL--Stephen, 75, Emmy nominated television writer, producer and network executive died peacefully. Mr. Schenkel earned his reputation as a creative force and innovator by producing "All My Children," "Another World," and "Edge of Night." Co-Creator/Creative Consultant on "Ryan's Hope" and "ABC After School Specials." A Columbia University grad, Mr. Schenkel served as an executive at NBC, CBS, ABC and Benton & Bowles. He developed and produced a full spectrum of entertainment (variety, mini-series, game) programs and Discovery Channel documentaries. Stephen married his beloved Penny Bergman in 1990 after meeting her on the set of "All My Children." For both, it was a marriage made in soap opera heaven. Survivors include the families of Ellen and Cantor Tyrone Bauer, Bergman and Gottlieb in-laws. Donations: Parkinson's Disease Foundation or Trustees of Columbia Univ. c/o Dr. Leonard Stern/Chronic Kidney Disease Program.

Survivors include the families of Ellen and Cantor Tyrone Bauer, Bergman and Gottlieb in-laws. Donations: Parkinson's Disease Foundation or Trustees of Columbia Univ. c/o Dr. Leonard Stern/Chronic Kidney Disease Program.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSEL Forget, for a moment, received notions of civic responsibility. Should all Americans vote, regardless of their knowledge of the candidates and the issues at stake? John Stossel, above, presents the question to a panel that includes John Fund, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal Web site and the author of ''Stealing Elections: How Voter Fraud Threatens Our Democracy''; the political satirist P. J. O'Rourke; Andy Bernstein, a founder of HeadCount, an organization that encourages young people to vote; Roger Clegg, president of the Center for Equal Opportunity; Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana; and Michael C. Moynihan, a senior editor of Reason magazine. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan (Emily Deschanel) rethinks her relationship with Booth (David Boreanaz) when he arrives for a surprise visit with his girlfriend, a war correspondent (Katheryn Winnick). Meanwhile the team tries to identify a couple whose bodies were discovered in a cave in a national park. In ''Fringe,'' at 9, Olivia (Anna Torv) helps Peter (Joshua Jackson) and Walter (John Noble) investigate a strange box that seems to be sending people into trances from which they cannot emerge. Elsewhere, Walter attends a reading of William Bell's will.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (History) SAMURAI Mark Dacascos, above, an actor, martial-arts expert and the Chairman on Food Network's ''Iron Chef America,'' explores the life of Miyamoto Musashi, the most famous samurai in the history of Japan and the author of ''The Book of Five Rings,'' a 17th-century text on the elements of sword fighting and Zen philosophy. Mr. Dacascos also studies the weaponry and wisdom of the country's great warriors in this two-hour program. Animation brings ancient battles to life. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The Top 12 finalists perform.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Discovery) KING TUT UNWRAPPED Zahi Hawass, right, an Egyptologist who leads the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Cairo, oversees this two-part forensic investigation into the 19-year life of King Tutankhamen, revealing for the first time the identity of the boy pharaoh's parents and grandparents, his cause of death about 1324 B.C. and new details of his nine-year reign. Part 1 begins by following the extraction of DNA from Tut's mummy, which is described in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. Part 2, on Monday at 8, draws on new evidence to determine what caused Tut's death, and how his afflictions might have affected his military, religious and political leadership. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Republican of California, and Gov. Edward G. Rendell, Democrat of Pennsylvania, discuss how to break the partisan deadlock in Washington.

headline: Coach Gets Ultimate Accolade
summary: INDIANAPOLIS - Tom Konchalski, the editor and publisher of High School Basketball Illustrated, called St. Anthony High Coach Bob Hurley in his apartment Thursday to wish him a Happy Easter. Before speaking with Hurley, whom he has known for more than four decades, Konchalski reached his wife, Chris, who informed him that Bob would be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame on Aug. 13. ''What took them so long?'' Konchalski said.

headline: NBC's Slide From TV's Heights To Troubled Nightly Punch Line
summary: At its height, NBC was the very model of what a television network should be. With iconic programming, enviable ratings and spectacular business success, the peacock network delivered plenty of laughs along the way with ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Seinfeld'' and ''Friends.'' Nobody is laughing anymore.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) BIG LOVE Bill Henrickson (Bill Paxton) and his wives -- above, from left with Mr. Paxton, Barb (Jeanne Tripplehorn), Nicki (Chloë Sevigny) and Margene (Ginnifer Goodwin) -- further their entrepreneurial ambitions with the opening of their Mormon-friendly casino in this Season 4 premiere. But their American Indian partner (Robert Beltran) and his son (Adam Beach) are having some last-minute jitters, not least because the feds have come snooping around regarding some unfinished business with Roman Grant (Harry Dean Stanton). Elsewhere, Alby (Matt Ross) has a close encounter with Dale Tomasson (Ben Koldyke), the state-appointed trustee of Juniper Creek's assets, and Lois (Grace Zabriskie) offers Frank (Bruce Dern) an interest in her smuggling business. And at the compound, Adaleen (Mary Kay Place) reveals a shocking secret to her daughter. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, debate the war on terror. The discussion continues on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, with Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and Representative Peter Hoekstra, Republican of Michigan. Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, take a look at the 2010 midterm elections before moving to ''Meet the Press'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) THE AUDITION How do you get to the Met? Audition, audition, audition. Susan Froemke covers the week leading up to the finals of the Metropolitan Opera's 2007 National Council Auditions, where thousands of aspiring singers annually compete for a cash prize, the chance to perform onstage at the Met and a jumpstart to a major operatic career. At the heart of the film, presented by ''Great Performances at the Met,'' are three tenors: Alek Shrader, 25, whose movie-star looks may not be enough to help him hit nine high C's in Donizetti's ''Pour Mon Ame,'' the aria that made Pavarotti famous; Ryan Smith, 30, who dreams of stardom despite little formal training (Mr. Smith died of cancer in 2008); and Michael Fabiano, 22, who wrestles with some inner demons -- and who currently can be seen at the Met in Verdi's ''Stiffelio.'' Above, the 11 finalists. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL Auditions continue in Orlando, Fla.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC, BET, Bravo, CBS, Centric, CMT, CNN, Comedy Central, Current TV, CW, Discovery Health, E!, Epix, Fox, Fuse, G4, HBO, MLB Network, MTV, My Network TV, National Geographic, NBC, Oxygen, Palladia, Planet Green, Showtime, SoapNet, Style, TNT, TV One, VH1, 21, 49) HOPE FOR HAITI NOW: A GLOBAL BENEFIT FOR EARTHQUAKE RELIEF George Clooney signs on from Los Angeles as host of this all-star, multichannel, two-hour telethon, which he helped to organize with MTV Networks. Beyoncé, Jay-Z, Rihanna and Bono and the Edge of U2 join in from London; Anderson Cooper from New York; and Wyclef Jean, above, from Haiti. Performers also include Justin Timberlake, Bruce Springsteen, Taylor Swift, Mary J. Blige, Kid Rock, Coldplay, Alicia Keys, Madonna, Keith Urban, Jennifer Hudson, Sting, Christina Aguilera, Sheryl Crow, Shakira, Stevie Wonder, Dave Matthews and John Legend. Other participants will include former President Bill Clinton, Ben Stiller, Brad Pitt, Chris Rock, Clint Eastwood, Denzel Washington, Halle Berry, Jon Stewart, Julia Roberts, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Meryl Streep, Morgan Freeman, Nicole Kidman, Robert Pattinson, Samuel L. Jackson, Tom Hanks, Will Smith and Muhammad Ali. Donations will benefit Oxfam America, Partners in Health, the Red Cross, Unicef and Mr. Jean's Yéle Haiti Foundation as well as the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund and the United NationsWorld Food Program. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts look at what happens to a woman's organs after childbirth and what to expect from a post-partum body.

headline: David Gerber, Award-Winning Television Producer, Dies at 86
summary: David Gerber, an Emmy- and Peabody Award-winning television producer who brought forward-thinking series like ''Police Story'' and ''Police Woman'' to prime time in the 1970s and produced more than 50 television films and mini-series during a four-decade career, died on Jan. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 86 and lived in Los Angeles. The cause was heart failure, his publicist, Jeff Sanderson, said.

headline: Goodell Stresses A Culture of Safety
summary: One of the iconic images of football is of linemen preparing to square off, face mask to face mask, with one hand dug into the turf in a three-point stance, but Commissioner Roger Goodell said Sunday that it was conceivable such showdowns could be prohibited. Goodell told Bob Schieffer on CBS's ''Face the Nation'' that the league was continuing to assess ways to make the game safer, especially in reducing head injuries. In response to a question from Schieffer, Goodell said, ''You'll see a lot of players that never get down in the three-point stance, so it's possible that that would happen.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) CLASH OF THE CONTINENTS The scenario: an astronaut passes through a space-time warp that returns him to Earth after 250 million years, above. What would he see? This new series consults with experts about the past so as to better predict the future, including the natural forces that could put an end to human civilization and bring Earth full circle. The journey begins as scientists imagine a brave new world in the form of a supercontinent created by the planet's land masses moving into a new position. At 10, the scientists speculate on whether our species will evolve -- or self-destruct. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE The Rev. Jesse Jackson discusses the forced resignation of Shirley Sherrod from the Department of Agriculture and its effect on race relations in America. The debate continues at 10:30 on CBS and ''Face the Nation'' with Abigail Thernstrom, vice chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights; Michael Eric Dyson, the Georgetown University sociologist; and Cornel West, the Princeton University professor.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) BREAKFAST SPECIAL Rick Sebak samples buckwheat pancakes in rural New York State; Scotch eggs, above, in Portland, Ore.; and grits and gumbo on a Georgia sea island. He also makes a stop in Columbus, Ohio, to taste a breakfast risotto with apples and to tour a selection of neighborhood restaurants. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICALeonardo DiCaprio promotes his latest movie, ''Inception.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (AMC) RUBICON Set and shot in New York City, this new series is a thriller involving a team of intelligence analysts who sift through data in search of potential threats to the United States, while the wider plot hinges on a major conspiracy. In the premiere tonight, a two-episode installment, Will Travers (James Badge Dale, ''24,'') tries to go further into what he suspects is a vast web of intrigue, and a billionaire's wife (Miranda Richardson) becomes suspicious of her husband's suicide. Dallas Roberts, Christopher Evan Welch and Arliss Howard (above, right, with Jessica Collins and Mr. Dale) are also in the cast. At 10, ''Mad Men'' follows up last week's season opener with a Christmas-theme episode in which things go well at the new agency as it increases its staff and lands another account, but its holiday party might be ruined by a surprise visitor. 9 A.M. (CBS) SUNDAY MORNING Harry Smith interviews President Obama at an auto plant in Michigan. At 10:30 on ''Face the Nation,'' Adm. Michael Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona; Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations; and Thomas A. Saenz, president of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, discuss immigration and the war in Afghanistan. At 10:30 Admiral Mullen also appears on ''Meet the Press,'' on NBC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO2) THIS IS MY AFRICA This documentary from Zina Saro-Wiwa, below left, a daughter of the Nigerian activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, offers a glimpse into the heart and soul of Africa through first-person accounts on subjects including favorite foods and songs, the evolving cultural landscape and the importance of encouraging a vibrant and stable continent for future generations. Among those interviewed are the artists Yinka Shonibare and Mustafa Maluka; the actors Colin Firth, Chiwetel Ejiofor and Lupita Nyong'o; the filmmaker John Akomfrah; Jon Snow, the Channel 4 news anchor; the singers Mpho Skeef and Josephine Amankwah; the writers Biyi Bandele, Noo Saro-Wiwa (the filmmaker's sister), Dipo Agboluaje, Mazzi Binaisa and Nana O. Ayim; the fashion designer Bayo Oduwole; the D. J.'s Duncan Brooker and Tony Nwachukwu; the politician and lawyer Paul Boateng; the restaurateur Mourad Mazouz; and the magazine publishers and sisters Njide and Nneka Ugbomath. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDSRush Limbaugh chats with Gretchen Carlson about his health scare on Christmas and his recent stint judging the Miss America contest.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) IMPORTANT THINGS WITH DEMETRI MARTIN Mr. Martin, above with Sarah Silverman, blends stand-up comedy, sketches, animation and music to examine one ''important thing'' per episode. On the list in this Season 2 premiere: ability, strategy and attention. In the Season 3 opener of ''The Sarah Silverman Program,'' at 10:30, Ms. Silverman skewers a range of topics including pedophile vans, Holocaust memorial competitions and the rigging of mayoral elections. 8 P.M. (Fox News Channel) THE O'REILLY FACTOR In the conclusion of a two-part interview, Bill O'Reilly talks with Jon Stewart of ''The Daily Show'' about topics like President Obama, the political landscape and media bias.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LUND, THERESA M.
summary: LUND--Theresa M. Died at home in Jupiter, FL, on March 17, 2010 at the age of 69, after a seven year struggle with PSP (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy). During that time she was an inspiration to all who knew her or came in contact with her. Theresa, known to her children, grandchildren and friends as Tzippi, lived a full and fascinating life. She was married for nearly 50 years to Peter A. Lund, the former CEO of CBS. After meeting in the fifth grade and growing up together in Minneapolis, MN, the two of them, along with their sons, Mark and Tim, began an odyssey that included 13 moves and some wonderful adventures. Tzippi was eclectic in her interests and pursuits. As they moved about the country she was, at various times, a yoga instructor, travel agent, banker, hotel sales agent, photographer and small business entrepreneur. She was an avid hiker and with her good pals she trekked in Nepal, hiked portions of the Appalachian Trail, the mountains of Vermont and Colorado and at one point walked across England. In between trips she was a skier, golfer, tennis player, bridge player and still found time to read two or three books every week. But, clearly her greatest accomplishment was the way she handled the last seven years of her life. From the time she was diagnosed with PSP until she died, she never complained. Even during the past several years, when she couldn't talk or move anything except the fingers of her left hand, she would signal yes when asked if she was happy. A truly remarkable woman who was a gift to the wonderful group of friends who were part of her life until the very end. Theresa is survived by her husband, Peter; her two sons, Mark of NBC in New York and Tim of Arnold Advertising in Boston; and her seven grandchildren, Connor, Kelly, Jack, Maxwell, Olivia, Nathan and Charlotte; and her two sisters, Kathy and Patti. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Celebrated 10am, Monday, March 29, 2010 at St. Patrick Catholic Church in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Memorial contributions may be made in Theresa's name to, CurePSP, Foundation for PSP/CBD and related brain diseases, Executive Plaza III, 11350 McCormick Road, Suite 906, Hunt Valley, MD 21031.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Logo) THE ROBERT VERDI SHOW STARRING ROBERT VERDI An ice cream flavor named in his honor? A shopping mall? His own television channel? No dream is too great for Mr. Verdi, above, the style expert, as he aspires to take over the pop culture world by expanding the Robert Verdi brand. In this series premiere he decides to become an internationally beloved children's cartoon character and sets off for a toy store with a ''focus group'' consisting of his four nieces; later he consults the cartoonist and author Marisa Acocella Marchetto about his character. Meanwhile, Mr. Verdi's assistant oversees a baby shower for Ana Ortiz of ''Ugly Betty.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Lady Gaga and Cyndi Lauper discuss the Viva Glam lipsticks named for them as part of ''From Our Lips,'' the newest campaign of the M.A.C. AIDS Fund, here and on ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 on ABC.
