headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) FILMED IN MONUMENT VALLEY A night of movies from out West, all directed by John Ford, begins with ''My Darling Clementine'' (1946), which stars Henry Fonda (above with Cathy Downs) in a retelling of Wyatt Earp's feud with the Clantons after they steal his cattle and kill his brother. In the courtroom drama ''Sergeant Rutledge'' (1960), at 10, a black sergeant (Woody Strode) is accused of raping and killing a white woman. At midnight John Wayne plays a Civil War veteran in search of his niece, who was captured by American Indians, in ''The Searchers'' (1956). At 2:15 a.m. ''She Wore a Yellow Ribbon'' (1949) follows a cavalry officer (John Wayne) as he tries to stymie an Indian uprising in the days before his retirement. In ''Stagecoach'' (1939), at 4:15 a.m., Wayne portrays a fugitive who hitches a ride on a stagecoach rambling through perilous Apache territory. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY A profile of Lincoln Electric, an arc-welding manufacturer that has not laid off an employee for economic reasons for 60 years. Also, an interview with the ''Mutts'' cartoonist Patrick McDonnell, and an exploration of the moral implications of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill with Paul Root Wolpe, director of the Emory Center for Ethics at Emory University.

headline: Seamen's Institute To Sell Its Building And Leave Manhattan
summary: In the early years of the Seamen's Church Institute, sailors arriving from the Atlantic would congregate for prayer in floating chapel barges anchored in Lower Manhattan. The institute replaced the chapels with a pair of hotels on South and State Streets, where in 1913 seamen paid 25 cents for a room. But after 176 years in the South Street Seaport area the institute, whose mission had gone well beyond its original incarnation as a maritime ministry, was leaving New York, officials said last week.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (AMC) TIN CUP (1996) This Ron Shelton film follows the down-and-out Roy (Kevin Costner, above), who runs a driving range in Texas, and his new client, a psychotherapist (Rene Russo) whose arrogant boyfriend (Don Johnson) is a golf star. In her review in The New York Times, Janet Maslin wrote: ''Hard as it may be to believe, Mr. Shelton's 'Tin Cup' is a flirty, funny comedy set right there on the links, with all the right raffish echoes of his earlier 'Bull Durham.' 'Tin Cup' has such unexpected flair that the game takes on new cachet, to the point where even golf clothes look good.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWJason Segel of the television show ''How I Met Your Mother'' is a guest; the hosts discuss saving money when eating at a restaurant.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES The Chinese figure skaters Shen Xue and Zhao Hongbo, who in November won the gold medal at the Cup of China in Beijing, and Zhang Dan and Zhang Hao, the runners-up, will face off against Caydee Denney and Jeremy Barrett, the American national champions, and Amanda Evora and Mark Ladwig, who placed second, as the pairs competition begins. Up first: the short program, in which skaters have to perform eight required elements over 2 minutes 50 seconds. (Above, David King of Britain and Stacey Kemp of Northern Ireland.) Other events today include women's speed skating, Nordic combined skiing and men's luge, at 1 p.m. on NBC; women's hockey, at 3 p.m. on the USA Network and 7:30 p.m. on CNBC; men's luge and men's freestyle skiing, at 7 p.m. on NBC; and the awards ceremonies on 11:35 p.m. on NBC. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Gen. James L. Jones, the White House national security adviser, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, discuss national security.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) THE COMEDY CENTRAL ROAST OF DAVID HASSELHOFF Where's a lifeguard when you need one? Mr. Hasselhoff, above, gets dunked by a few of his friends on topics like his drinking; the infamous cheeseburger video made by his daughters after he fell off the wagon; and his babes -- ''Baywatch'' and otherwise -- in this event taped on Aug. 1 in Los Angeles. Seth MacFarlane is the master of ceremonies; the roasters include Pamela Anderson, George Hamilton, Hulk Hogan (or, as Ms. Anderson put it, her fellow ''dumb blonde''), Gilbert Gottfried and Jerry Springer. Viewers can also sign on at comedycentral.com at 9:30 for a ''Roast Watch'' featuring Twitter updates from comedians in New York and Los Angeles. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Bret Baier, the guest host, will interview Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, and Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, about the midterm elections and events in Afghanistan.

headline: After 15 Months in Office, Policy vs. Politics for Obama
summary: Inside Washington, President Obama is savoring a springtime resurgence: signs of economic recovery, victory on health care, the upper hand in the financial regulation debate. Outside Washington, not so much. Polls show the president with job approval ratings of 50 percent or lower, as Democratic strategists brace for a thumping in the midterm elections.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 67TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDSRicky Gervais puts his comic sensibilities on display as host of this ceremony, sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, honoring achievement in film and television and seen by some as a forecast of the Academy Awards. Nominees in the drama category include ''Avatar,'' ''The Hurt Locker,'' ''Inglourious Basterds,'' ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire'' and ''Up in the Air'' for best motion picture; Emily Blunt, Sandra Bullock, Helen Mirren, Carey Mulligan and Gabourey Sidibe for best actress; and Jeff Bridges, George Clooney, Colin Firth, Morgan Freeman and Tobey Maguire for best actor. In the comedy or musical category, Meryl Streep competes against herself with best actress nominations for ''It's Complicated'' and ''Julie & Julia,'' which are both also up for best picture. Martin Scorsese will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award for outstanding contribution to the entertainment field. Mavis Spencer, the daughter of the actress Alfre Woodard and the writer and producer Roderick Spencer, is Miss Golden Globe. Billy Bush and Natalie Morales will stake out the red carpet at the Beverly Hills Hilton at 7; Nick Cannon will provide commentary from the wrap party at midnight. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Brit Hume will interview Lt. Gen. Ken Keen, head of the Haiti Task Force, and Rajiv Shah, administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, about relief efforts in Haiti after Tuesday's earthquake. General Keen and Mr. Shah will also appear on ''This Week'' at 10 on ABC and, at 10:30, ''Face the Nation'' on CBS and ''Meet the Press'' on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHENKEL, STEPHEN
summary: SCHENKEL--Stephen, 75, Emmy nominated television writer, producer and network executive died peacefully. Mr. Schenkel earned his reputation as a creative force and innovator by producing "All My Children," "Another World," and "Edge of Night." Co-Creator/Creative Consultant on "Ryan's Hope" and "ABC After School Specials." A Columbia University grad, Mr. Schenkel served as an executive at NBC, CBS, ABC and Benton & Bowles. He developed and produced a full spectrum of entertainment (variety, mini-series, game) programs and Discovery Channel documentaries. Stephen married his beloved Penny Bergman in 1990 after meeting her on the set of "All My Children." For both, it was a marriage made in soap opera heaven. Survivors include the families of Ellen and Cantor Tyrone Bauer, Bergman and Gottlieb in-laws. Donations: Parkinson's Disease Foundation or Trustees of Columbia Univ. c/o Dr. Leonard Stern/Chronic Kidney Disease Program.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (Nickelodeon) STICKS, STONES AND CYBERSLAMS As suicides in the wake of bullying increase, and with as many as 60 percent of middle-school students saying they have been tormented by their peers, ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee'' meets with victims and their aggressors to discuss the epidemic and what can be done to stop it. Among the cases examined by Ms. Ellerbee, center above, are those of Carl Walker Hoover, who hanged himself at age 11 after becoming the target of gay slurs, and Jon Carmichael, who hanged himself at 13 after being picked on because of his short stature. Other participants include Emma, a 17-year-old from South Hadley, Mass., where, in 2010, Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old transfer student from Ireland, committed suicide after being relentlessly taunted about her sexual history. And then there is Maria, 13, who was suspended for harassing a classmate and has since been part of an anti-bullying program in Atlanta. The program helps girls ''feel better about themselves,'' Maria says. ''I think it helped me a lot.'' She sighs. ''I wish I hadn't bullied that girl.'' 9 A.M. (BET) BOBBY JONES GOSPEL Mr. Jones raises the rafters on the 30th-season premiere, with performances by Jennifer Holiday, Kurt Carr, Pastor Shirley Caesar, Karen Clark Sheard and Byron Cage. ''Weekly With Ed Gordon,'' a news magazine with an African-American perspective, has its premiere at noon.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (Bloomberg) BLOOMBERG GAME CHANGERSJay-Z, above, has had more No. 1 albums on the Billboard 200 than Elvis Presley. As the head of a nearly billion-dollar enterprise, Jay-Z, born Shawn Carter, oversees interests in the record labels Def Jam and Roc-A-Fella, concert promotion, music publishing, Live Nation, artist management, clothing lines, real estate, sports bars and the New Jersey Nets. This program chronicles his life, from his early years in the public Marcy Houses in Brooklyn to drug dealing, to his career as a rapper and ascent as one of the music industry's biggest players, whose memoir, ''Decoded,'' was published on Tuesday. Among those interviewed are Russell Simmons, a co-founder of Def Jam; Lyor Cohen, chairman and chief executive of Warner Brothers Records; the music journalist Zack O'Malley Greenburg; the screenwriter Barry Michael Cooper; Jay-Z's childhood friends Jaz-O and Mr. Cee; and his grade-school teacher Renee Lowden. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Nigel Lythgoe, James Earl Jones and Vanessa Redgrave.

headline: Last Year Still Matters To 3-0 Chiefs
summary: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com. Is it safe to believe in the Chiefs?

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CAPSOUTO, ALBERT
summary: CAPSOUTO--Albert, died on January 19th in New York City at age 53. He is survived by his two older brothers, Jacques and Samuel. Albert was a pioneer/co-founder with his brothers of Capsouto Freres Restaurant. He was deeply involved with the downtown community; a member of CB1 for over 19 years. Albert graduated from Stuyvesant HS and Yale University. He was gift to his family from the day he was born.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 64TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Sean Hayes, left, who recently came out as gay in The Advocate and has been playing straight in the revival of ''Promises, Promises,'' has said he doesn't care if he's great or not as host of this awards show honoring excellence on Broadway. He just wants to have a good time (and maybe, as a nominee himself, walk away with a statuette). Green Day, Lea Michele and Matthew Morrison of ''Glee,'' and cast members of ''American Idiot,'' ''Fela!,'' ''Memphis,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''A Little Night Music'' and ''Ragtime'' are scheduled to perform. Presenters at this ceremony, broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall, include Antonio Banderas, Cate Blanchett, Viola Davis, Michael Douglas, Rosemary Harris, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson, Angela Lansbury, Laura Linney, Helen Mirren, Alfred Molina, Daniel Radcliffe, Stanley Tucci and Denzel Washington. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Susan E. Rice, the United States representative to the United Nations, discusses the Security Council's sanctions against Iran. Carly Fiorina, the Republican Senate nominee from California, talks about her primary victory here and on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: For Democrats, a Tea Party Target
summary: Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, has a vision of how the foreboding national political environment might evolve to his party's advantage. The old debate, in Mr. Emanuel's telling, pitted Big Government against Small Government. Republicans won it in 1980 when Ronald Reagan shattered the Democratic coalition that produced the New Deal and the Great Society.

headline: The Chatter
summary: ''The Internet is our friend, not our enemy.'' Leslie Moonves, C.E.O. of the CBS Corporation, which carried the Super Bowl and the Grammy Awards this year. Sites like Twitter enable online water-cooler conversations, encouraging people to split their time between their computers and big TV events.

headline: Nantz Active in Alzheimer's Research
summary: Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his son's busy life on the road. ''He'd tell me, 'Oh, son, you really don't need me,' '' Nantz said. But really, he wanted his gregarious father -- his first and best confidant and a former college football player -- with him as much as possible and to enjoy the Masters, the Super Bowl and the N.C.A.A. Final Four together. They were maybe a year from that goal.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER In this 78th-annual tree lighting ceremony, Mariah Carey, Sheryl Crow, Josh Groban, Jessica Simpson, Susan Boyle, Annie Lennox, Kylie Minogue and Boyz II Men will gather around a Norway spruce, above, that stands 74 feet tall and 40 feet in diameter. The tree, from Mahopac, N.Y., was donated by Peter Acton, a 12-year veteran of the New York Fire Department who works at Engine 79 in the Bronx. The Rockettes will put a little kick into the festivities, presided over by Natalie Morales and Al Roker of NBC's ''Today'' show. A preview show will begin at 7. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Patricia Cornwell discusses her new book, ''Port Mortuary,'' the 18th entry in the Kay Scarpetta series. Vincent Cassel talks about his role as the artistic director of a ballet company in Darren Aronofsky's latest film, ''Black Swan,'' starring Natalie Portman and opening on Friday.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL Ms. Winfrey steps out of the limelight as she assigns some Academy Award winners and nominees, past and present, to interview one another. The groupings include Halle Berry, who won the best actress award for ''Monster's Ball'' (2001), and Penélope Cruz, who landed the best supporting actress award last year for ''Vicky Cristina Barcelona'' and is nominated this year for ''Nine''; Ben Affleck, who with Matt Damon took home a statuette for best original screenplay for ''Good Will Hunting'' (1997), and Jeremy Renner, up for best actor in ''The Hurt Locker''; James Cameron, whose ''Avatar'' is nominated in nine categories, and members of the film's cast, Sam Worthington, Zoe Saldana and Sigourney Weaver; and Michael Douglas and Glenn Close, above, who reminisce about blood and a certain rabbit in ''Fatal Attraction'' (1987), which received six nominations. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The Top 10 male semifinalists perform.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '10 Prince will be honored for lifetime achievement and John Legend for his humanitarianism at this 10th annual ceremony honoring excellence by blacks and other minorities in entertainment and sports. Queen Latifah, left, hosts the event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Alicia Keys, Sean Combs (otherwise known as Diddy, of course), Drake, Trey Songz, Usher, Nicki Minaj, T. I., Kanye West and Eminem are scheduled to perform. Nominees include Rihanna, Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige and Melanie Fiona for best female R&B artist; Rasheeda, Trina, Lil' Kim and Ester Dean for best female hip-hop artist; Chris Brown, Maxwell and Raheem DeVaughn for best male R&B artist; Jay-Z, Ludacris, B. O. B. and Fabolous for best male hip-hop artist; and Justin Bieber, Young Money and Wale for best new artist. Alicia Renee and Nick Cannon will report from the red carpet starting at 6; a post-show follows at 11. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK The talk this morning is about the war in Afghanistan and the resignation of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, starting here with Leon E. Panetta, the director of central intelligence. The discussion continues with Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; Representative Barbara Lee, Democrat of California; the author Sebastian Junger; and retired Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC; and retired Maj. Gen. John R. Hawkins III on ''Washington Watch With Roland Martin,'' at 11 on TV One.

headline: Looking Ahead
summary: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data including personal income and spending for March, the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index and auto sales for April (Monday); factory orders for March (Tuesday); the Institute for Supply Management's service sector index for April (Wednesday); first-quarter productivity and retail sales results for April (Thursday); and employment and consumer credit figures (Friday). CORPORATE EARNINGS Companies reporting will include Anadarko Petroleum, GMAC Financial Services and Electronic Arts (Monday); Archer Daniels Midland, CVS Caremark, Duke Energy, Marathon Oil, Marsh & McLennan, MasterCard, Merck, Molson Coors Brewing, the News Corporation, NYSE Euronext, Pfizer, Thomson Reuters and YRC Worldwide (Tuesday); CBS, Prudential Financial, PulteGroup, Qwest Communications, Time Warner, Wynn Resorts (Wednesday); Cablevision Systems, Cigna, DirecTV Group, Kraft Foods, MGM Mirage and Sara Lee (Thursday); and Washington Post Company (Friday).

headline: Sports Quote
summary: 'After retirement, I'm coming after your job, Clark. I'm just letting you know. So you either have three more years or seven more years.' President Obama to the CBS announcer Clark Kellogg during Obama's stint as a commentator at the Georgetown-Duke game.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (SNY) BEER MONEY SportsNet New York, the television home of the Mets, continues to offer sports fans economic relief with a new season of trivia-for-cash games. Amber Wilson and Dan Schachner wander the city, with stops at stadiums, arenas, tailgate parties and even Central Park, to pepper those versed in all things athletic with questions. Correct answers equal money. Season 3 begins with a quiz starring the SNY personalities Keith Hernandez, above with Ms. Wilson; Ron Darling; Joe Klecko; and Ray Lucas, who will donate their winnings to charity. 8 P.M. (Fox News Channel) THE O'REILLY FACTORBill O'Reilly will talk with former President George W. Bush about his new memoir, ''Decision Points,'' as well as his views on the midterm elections and the state of politics. The interview will take place at the National Museum of the United States Air Force at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base outside Dayton, Ohio, where Mr. Bush is scheduled to speak as part of a Veterans Day tribute.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC) BREAKOUT Some of the most high-profile prison escapes in recent history are the subject of this new series. Each week it includes interviews with prisoners who made it over the wall and the law-enforcement teams that subsequently captured them. In this episode the subject is a convicted armed robber, George Rivas, above, who in 2000 escaped from a prison in Texas with six other inmates (they were called the Texas Seven), and ended up a few weeks later in southern Colorado, where he and two escapees were captured near the trailer park where they had been staying. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS President Felipe Calderón of Mexico is a guest.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BILL MOYERS JOURNAL At the time of his murder in Memphis, on April 4, 1968, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had expanded his campaign for racial equity to include the problem of economic inequality. In commemoration of the 42nd anniversary of Dr. King's death, Mr. Moyers discusses the plight of poor and working-class Americans who are falling behind economically and what the nation can do to help them realize the vision of Dr. King, above. The guests include Bryan A. Stevenson, a longtime advocate for social justice and a faculty member at the New York University School of Law, and Michelle Alexander, a legal scholar, civil rights advocate and the author of ''The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The chef Katie Lee prepares Easter dinner.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International IRAQI NEIGHBORHOOD

headline: Check Point: Santorum on Financing for Family Planning Programs
summary: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates in Wednesday night's debate. Romney and the Auto Bailout

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CMT) EMANCIPATED Lorin, above, a privileged 16-year-old from New Orleans who believes she doesn't need parental supervision, receives a reality check when she is given only 10 minutes to pack her bags and bid her family farewell before embarking on a three-week trial separation. That means trading her Range Rover, credit cards and luxurious surroundings for an unfurnished rental house without electricity and only a small amount of money for her basic needs. Stacy Kaiser, a licensed psychotherapist, offers guidance. This hourlong show falls between two episodes of ''World's Strictest Parents,'' at 8 and 10. 8 P.M. (HGTV) HOLIDAY BATTLE ON THE BLOCK Lights by the tens of thousands. Soldiers. Dancing snowflakes and a sugarplum fairy. In the third of four episodes, three neighboring families in Youngstown, N.Y., pull out the stops and then some to create the best holiday displays. Kim Myles, the show's host, offers each $5,000 and some free design advice. At 8:30 the competition concludes in Markham, Ontario, with a crèche of live animals, a re-creation of Santa's workshop and a Christmas sound-and-light extravaganza.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) WINDS OF WAR: GEORGE CLOONEY IN SUDAN In this ''Dateline NBC'' report, Ann Curry joins Mr. Clooney (above left, with Ms. Curry, center), the actor and human-rights advocate, on a fact-finding mission in southern Sudan. A referendum is planned there for Jan. 9 on whether the region should secede from the north and form its own country after decades of war and marginalization, threatening to throw the nation further into chaos. The two are joined in Sudan, and on a whistle-stop tour of the United States, by John Prendergast, who served as director of African affairs at the National Security Council during the Clinton administration and is a founder of the Enough Project, an antigenocide organization. Mr. Clooney also speaks about working with impoverished people who are struggling for peace. Ms. Curry interviews Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, about what a secession could mean, and how the Obama administration might react if unrest descends into genocide. 7 P.M. (National Geographic) CROCODILE KING With a typical adult male measuring 20 feet long and weighing 2,900 pounds, the salt-water crocodile is the world's largest reptile. This program uses high-speed cameras and infrared technology to travel into the Northern Territory of Australia, where the crocodile rules rivers and estuaries while battling the extremes of nature for its own kind of dominance. In ''Dog Whisperer,'' at 8, Cesar Millan comes to the rescue of Donna Kronenfeld and her Australian shepherd, Snickers, who was attacked by two off-leash boxers and now has the urge to bite dogs and humans.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10:30 P.M. (13) PROJECT KASHMIR In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Senain Kheshgi, above left, and Geeta V. Patel, right -- one Muslim, the other Hindu, both American -- hide their cameras as they travel to the disputed region of Kashmir to document the costs of war. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth and, with more than 500,000 armed Indian soldiers, one of the most militarized zones. Maggie Gyllenhaal is the host. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The journalists Laura and Lisa Ling discuss their new book, ''Somewhere Inside: One Sister's Captivity in North Korea and the Other's Fight to Bring Her Home.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES Billy Demong, right, the United States' first gold medalist in the Nordic combined, has been chosen to carry the flag for Team U.S.A. at this evening's closing ceremony at B.C. Place in Vancouver, British Columbia. Glimpses of post-Olympic revelry at the closing party will be shown at 11:35. The day's coverage begins with a prerecorded overview of the figure-skating medalists at 6 a.m. on MSNBC, followed by the men's curling bronze-medal match at 9 on Universal and the men's hockey gold-medal final and men's cross-country skiing at noon on NBC. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Talk of the health care summit makes the rounds, starting with Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, and Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee. The discussion continues with Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10 on Fox; Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, and Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 3:50 P.M. (Sundance) NO ONE KNOWS ABOUT PERSIAN CATS (2009) Negar (Negar Shaghaghi) and Ashkan (Ashkan Koshanejad) are young musicians with dreams of touring Europe and a need for backup players for their indie rock band -- in Tehran. ''Of course circumstances for iconoclastic, bohemian young people in Iran are not what they are elsewhere,'' A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times, adding that ''both the pathos and the buoyant energy'' of this ''bouncy, seething'' film by Bahman Ghobadi ''come from the sense that Negar, Ashkan and their friends are bravely laying claim to creativity, idealism and free expression in defiance of an authoritarian state that seeks to deny them those universal birthrights of modern youth.'' The film, above, which won a jury award in Cannes, is one of several movies that prompted the Iranian government to announce that it would punish filmmakers who do not obtain approval for their work. ''Productions in Iran are subject to review before being released there,'' The Times reported in December 2009, ''and directors are expected to submit screenplays for approval before beginning shooting, though some ignore the process.'' 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Sunita L. Williams and Leland Melvin met in a NASA astronaut class in 1998 and have each journeyed to the International Space Station. But back on Earth they spend a lot of time trying to manage their problem dogs. Ms. Williams's Jack Russell terrier, Gorby, likes to pick on dogs bigger than he is. Mr. Leland's Rhodesian Ridgeback mix Jake will try to bite anyone who gets near his owner. Cesar Millan comes to the rescue. In ''Squid vs. Whale,'' at 9, marine biologists attach a remote camera to a sperm whale, the largest toothed predator on the planet, as it journeys 1,000 feet below the ocean's surface in the Gulf of California in search of its favorite meal, the colossal squid.

headline: Georgi A. Arbatov, a Bridge Between Cold War Superpowers, Is Dead at 87
summary: MOSCOW -- Georgi A. Arbatov, who was the senior ''Amerikanist'' in the Soviet Communist Party in the final decades of the cold war and served as the Kremlin's voice for a generation of television viewers in the United States, died here on Friday. He was 87. Mr. Arbatov had cancer, according to his colleagues at the Institute for U.S.A. and Canada Studies in Moscow, which he founded and had directed.

headline: Many Eyes On Knoxville
summary: The news is being monitored from Kingsport to Memphis. Who is going to replace Lane Kiffin as Tennessee coach? Already the Texas defensive coordinator Will Muschamp and Air Force Coach Troy Calhoun have issued statements saying they will not leave their jobs. One name that has been mentioned is David Cutcliffe, a former offensive coordinator at Tennessee and former head coach at Mississippi. Cutcliffe was going to work with the offense at Notre Dame under Charlie Weis, then had a heart attack that took him out of coaching. He came back to Tennessee, then was hired by Duke, where he has made a drastic improvement in the program.

headline: High-Tech Treasure Hunt For Touring Italy
summary: Do you find walking tours too passive, like sitting through a boring lecture? Wish they were more like ''The Amazing Race,'' the popular CBS reality show? Then you might try Whaiwhai, a high-tech Italian touring game that is part ''Amazing Race'' and part treasure hunt, with a bit of DaVinci Code-style storytelling mixed in.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | FEB. 28--MARCH 6
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE Class is back in session at McKinley High, and the glee club, above, is upset after losing at the regional competition. Budget cuts force Mr. Schuester (Matthew Morrison) to get his students actively to recruit new members, which has Rachel (Lea Michele) and Finn (Cory Monteith) at odds. Chord Overstreet (''iCarly'') and Charice, a pop singer who got her break on ''Little Big Star,'' a talent show in the Philippines, guest star. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS Picking up where they left off last season, Jethro Gibbs (Mark Harmon) has to protect the team when Paloma Reynosa (Jacqueline Obradors), the head of the Reynosa drug cartel, retaliates against it. In ''NCIS: Los Angeles,'' at 9, the other Naval Crime Investigative Service team on prime time joins forces with the Los Angeles Police Department to take on money laundering, drugs and human trafficking. And at 10, the action continues in the City of Angels, as the NCIS team goes after a hit squad that eliminated an agent on assignment.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (13, 49) UNMISTAKEN CHILD (2009) In 2001 Geshe Lama Konchog, a revered Tibetan master, died at 84 after decades of isolated meditation in a mountain cave. Not long after, the Dalai Lama instructed Tenzin Zopa, a disciple of Konchog since the age of 7, to search for his reincarnation in the form of a young boy. For four years Mr. Zopa -- traveling the high country by foot, mule and helicopter, and guided by astrology, dreams and the direction of the smoke from the pyre at Lama Konchog's cremation -- looked for small children with special characteristics and performed ritualistic tests. He then made his determination, above, and awaited the Dalai Lama's decision. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this documentary from Nati Baratz ''inevitably leads you to consider the material world and to contemplate the balance in your own life between physical gratification and spirituality.'' He continued: ''The rugged landscape, in which mist filters through craggy cliffs, and wild flowers seem to dance in the mountain meadows, suggests that religion and geography are profoundly intertwined.'' The film, presented by ''Independent Lens,'' is in English, Tibetan, Nepalese and Hindi, with English subtitles. 8 P.M. (Fox) HUMAN TARGET Chance (Mark Valley) guards a British princess (Christina Cole) whose love for a commoner has made her the target of an assassination plot.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (TruTV) CONSPIRACY THEORY WITH JESSE VENTURAStirring up suspicions with the tag line ''You won't believe what you don't know,'' Mr. Ventura, above, the former professional wrestler and Minnesota governor, returns for a second season of investigating secrets, lies and cover-ups. 7:30 P.M. (CNBC) YOUR TAXES, YOUR VOTE: COUNTDOWN TO THE ELECTION In three reports shown on consecutive Fridays, John Harwood, CNBC's chief Washington correspondent and a reporter for The New York Times, will visit battleground states to discuss the election's biggest issues: taxes, jobs, the economy and the Tea Party.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (TV Land) THE 8TH ANNUAL TV LAND AWARDS Tom Hanks will hark back to his roots as just another struggling actor -- albeit one with a rather unusual work wardrobe -- when he reunites with Peter Scolari, above right with Mr. Hanks, to accept the Anniversary Award 30 years after the debut of their drag comedy, ''Bosom Buddies.'' Billy Crystal, Jane Leeves, Jay Leno, Wendie Malick, Bob Newhart and Betty White will bestow honors to some other blasts from the past, including giving the Impact Award to the cast of ''Everybody Loves Raymond''; the Fan Favorite Award to the crew of ''The Love Boat''; and the Legend Award to both Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner. Cheryl Ladd and Jaclyn Smith of ''Charlie's Angels'' will pay tribute to Farrah Fawcett, who died in June 2009. And Jane Lynch will accept the Future Classic Award on behalf of ''Glee.'' There is even a rendition of Journey's ''Don't Stop Believin' '' by a group of older choristers, including Shirley Jones and Marion Ross, with solos by David Hasselhoff and Marilu Henner. Tim Allen hosts. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace speaks with Alan K. Simpson, the retired Republican senator from Wyoming, and Erskine B. Bowles, former chief of staff in the Clinton White House, who serve as chairmen of the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform, President Obama's bipartisan effort to reduce the federal debt.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (The Hub) TAYLOR SWIFT'S JOURNEY TO FEARLESS From the childhood of Ms. Swift, above, in Pennsylvania to superstardom in Nashville, this three-part special uses home movies and personal photographs to chronicle her life as she embarks on her tour for ''Fearless.'' That 2008 album won four Grammy Awards, including album of the year -- making her the youngest artist and the first solo female country singer to earn that honor. Ms. Swift's new album, ''Speak Now,'' will be released on Monday. 8 P.M. (NBC) SCHOOL PRIDE A group of young idealists from Teach for America make over Lanier Elementary, a failing school in Baton Rouge, La., with the help of Tom Stroup, commander of a police SWAT team; Susie Castillo, an interior designer; Jacob Soboroff, a journalist; and the comedian Kym Whitley, who once worked as a substitute teacher.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (History) AMERICAN RESTORATION When members of the Harrison family of ''Pawn Stars'' want to return something like a rusty Sinclair gas pump or a decrepit Indian motorcycle to its original luster, they call Rick Dale, above, the owner of Rick's Restorations in Las Vegas. Now Mr. Dale is getting his own spinoff with this new series, which shows him and his team transforming seemingly worthless objects into valuable collectibles. Their first projects are a three-wheeled Marketeer golf cart from the 1960s and a Hopalong Cassidy bicycle from the '50s, followed, at 9:30, by a 1940s Hershey's dispenser and a 1950s Kelvinator refrigerator. ''Pawn Stars,'' at 10, finds Rick Harrison dealing in personal tapes from Sammy Davis Jr. and, at 10:30, a collection of fossils found along Mazon Creek in Illinois. 11 A.M. (Fox Business Network) THE WAR ON BUSINESS WEEK Liz MacDonald and Adam Shapiro explore the politics affecting job creation in the United States in this five-day programming block, shown from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. through Friday.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE Not even devious Sue (Jane Lynch) can prevent the choristers (above, Jenna Ushkowitz and Chris Colfer) from performing their own version of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' after Mr. Schuester (Matthew Morrison) learns that Emma (Jayma Mays) is a big fan. Barry Bostwick and Meat Loaf, who appeared in that 1975 cult classic, guest star. In ''Raising Hope,'' at 9, Jimmy (Lucas Neff) gets to act out his superhero fantasies when Sabrina (Shannon Woodward) asks him to stand in for her boyfriend at a Halloween party, and Maw Maw (Cloris Leachman) reveals her inner sex kitten when she goes trick-or-treating with Virginia (Martha Plimpton). Elsewhere, Jimmy ponders whether to unleash some demons and show his daughter the videos he received from the prison where her mother (Bijou Phillips) was executed. 8 P.M. (13, 49) EMERGENCY MINE RESCUE ''Nova'' travels to the San José Mine in Chile to chronicle the 69-day ordeal of the 33 miners as they struggled to survive 95-degree heat, almost total darkness and -- in the first 17 days of their entrapment, before they knew they were being searched for -- growing despair. The report features interviews with the families of some of the miners and footage at Camp Hope, the tent city where they kept vigil. Computer-generated imagery and additional interviews with mining engineers and rescue teams illustrate the race against time to reach the miners' chamber a half-mile below the surface.

headline: In Reducing a Conglomerate to Its Parts, a Test of Value
summary: ITT, Fortune Brands and Marathon Oil have all recently announced breakups, and Sara Lee is said to be contemplating one. Cargill announced on Tuesday that it would spin off its Mosaic unit. Market analysts contend that these businesses are too diverse and that separating them will allow the market to fully recognize each company's inherent value. The real question, though, is whether this will really create that extra value. Can one plus one equal more than two, or is this is yet another Wall Street fad?

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) PERLMAN, AX AND MA AT THE PENTHOUSE Above, from left, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the pianist Emanuel Ax and the violinist Itzhak Perlman will perform Mendelssohn's piano trios and a few other favorite works, including Schumann's ''Phantasiestücke'' (Op. 73 and Op. 12), at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse in this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' presentation. Alan Alda is the host. 3 P.M. (Fox Business Network) COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL Liz Claman celebrates her 500th episode. Guests include Steve Forbes, editor in chief of Forbes magazine.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KINGSLEY, WALTER
summary: KINGSLEY--Walter. Television executive and community leader, died of heart failure in Portland, Oregon, February 6th, at age 86. A New York native and graduate of Amherst College, he was involved in many humanitarian causes. Walter was the proud co-founder of Big-Brothers/Big-Sisters of Greater Los Angeles, board member BB/BS of America, and a big brother to two wonderful little brothers. Among other professional accomplishments, he was the founding President of TV firm ITC, where he brought the first British program to CBS with Patrick McGoohan as Danger Man. Walter is survived by his children Janis Scott of Los Angeles; Sam of New York; Tom of Portland; six grandchildren; and his beloved companion of five years, Donna Benson, of Portland. He was predeceased by his son Jim, and brothers Jerry and Len, both of San Francisco. Contributions appreciated at Big Brothers Big Sisters of America, 230 N 13th St., Philadelphia, PA 19107.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (AMC) THE WALKING DEAD Robert Kirkman's zombie comic-book series comes to life in this new drama about a Southern sheriff's deputy (Andrew Lincoln) who wakes up from a coma after a shootout to find his town overrun by the undead -- and his wife (Sarah Wayne Callies) and son (Chandler Riggs) missing. Now he's a man looking for his family, and anyone who gets in his way is going to lose. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said, ''The television adaptation is surprisingly scary and remarkably good, a show that visually echoes the stylized comic-book aesthetic of the original and combines elegant suspense with gratifyingly crude and gruesome slasher-film gore.'' She added that the series is ''not for everyone, obviously, but it is well made: a hard-core zombie story that even vampire lovers can watch.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The topic this morning is the midterm elections, discussed here by Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, and Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, appear on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC; Sarah Palin and Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, talk with Chris Wallace on ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10; Gov. Tim Pawlenty, Republican of Minnesota, and Gov. Edward G. Rendell, Democrat of Pennsylvania, are interviewed by Bob Schieffer on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi, a Republican, and former Gov. Tim Kaine, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, speak with David Gregory on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KINGSLEY, WALTER
summary: KINGSLEY--Walter. Television executive and community leader, died of heart failure in Portland, Oregon, February 6th, at age 86. A New York native and graduate of Amherst College, he was involved in many humanitarian causes. Walter was the proud co-founder of Big-Brothers/Big-Sisters of Greater Los Angeles, board member BB/BS of America, and a big brother to two wonderful little brothers. Among other professional accomplishments, he was the founding President of TV firm ITC, where he brought the first British program to CBS with Patrick McGoohan as Danger Man. Walter is survived by his children Janis Scott of Los Angeles; Sam of New York; Tom of Portland; six grandchildren; and his beloved companion of five years, Donna Benson, of Portland. He was predeceased by his son Jim, and brothers Jerry and Len, both of San Francisco. Contributions appreciated at Big Brothers Big Sisters of America, 230 N 13th St., Philadelphia, PA 19107.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LAMOTTA, RICHARD EDMUND
summary: LaMOTTA--Richard Edmund. Born in Brooklyn, New York on May 20th, 1942, Richard Edmund LaMotta was a larger-than-life unique man, and a true "social entrepreneur". He is best known as "Mr. Chipwich", the inventor of the original Chipwich, the ice cream cookie sandwich, of which he was so proud, and which came from a love of dunking cookies in milk. He worked hard his whole life, attending the prestigious Brooklyn Tech High School, and Brooklyn College and New York Law School at night over many years while working jobs at AT&T and CBS. Chipwich Chippoppity, a cookie candy, came out of the Chipwich brand and at its second release functioned in conjunction with MyStudentBiz, a business which allowed students to earn money, scholarships, and own a part of the company. His goal was to pass on the entrepreneurship skills he had learned, by mentoring students and helping anyone who asked for his advice. He loved helping people in any way he could, notorious for giving a helping hand to the homeless, and teaching his children to do the same. His generosity was outstanding, and a large part of his life. He created companies that would help people, like his current company, The MD System, an all-natural pain relief system, which will continue on. He loved reading and music, talking sports, car rides, having dinners with his older daughter, watching his younger daughter play sports, always an incredibly devoted family man. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Richard Edmund LaMotta Foundation at P.O. Box 309, Mount Kisco, NY 10549. Survived by his wife, son, two daughters, and a granddaughter. Pre-deceased by son and brother. The wake will be at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY on Saturday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm and Sunday from 2-4pm.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) THE DOORS: WHEN YOU'RE STRANGE From the formation of the Doors, above, in 1965 to the death of their lead singer, Jim Morrison, in 1971, the group -- including the drummer John Densmore, the guitarist Robby Krieger, the keyboardist Ray Manzarek and Morrison -- were one of the most influential, theatrical and even frightening American rock bands. Using only original footage, much of it previously unseen, this ''American Masters'' documentary from Tom DiCillo chronicles the creation of the band's six studio albums, starting at the U.C.L.A. film school, where Morrison and Mr. Manzarek met, and venturing onto concert stages. Johnny Depp narrates; Dick Wolf and Peter Jankowski (''Law & Order'') produced. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Geneen Roth talks about her new book, ''Women Food and God.''

headline: The 2.0 Report
summary: Williamsburg Is the New Williamsburg Should you find yourself wandering the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, these days, you might be reminded of another Williamsburg, the restored historic village in Virginia. With shops like the Brooklyn Kitchen, where you can learn how to pickle vegetables and butcher your own pig, and Rye, where you can sip an old-fashioned at the 100-year-old oak bar, the neighborhood hasn't quite returned to colonial times -- but chances are your server will have facial hair and woolens that would do an 18th-century blacksmith proud. There are glass blowers (Michael Anchin Glass Company), perfume makers (CB I Hate Perfume) and illegal urban beekeepers who've set up shop in East Williamsburg with that same can-do spirit that got us to the New World in the first place. While you might not hear the resounding fife and drums of our founding fathers, the bars on Bedford Avenue are jammed with Bunyan-bearded hipsters who look as if they moonlight in a fiddle band. And the spirit of Patrick Henry lives on in these Brooklynites, whose call to arms is ''Give me bike lanes or give me death!'' KATHLEEN EGAN

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) HAMMER HORROR FESTIVAL Turner Classic Movies salutes the heyday of Hammer Film Productions, a low-budget British studio that, from the mid-1950s through the 1970s, created lavish, Gothic fright films replete with striking direction, imaginative sets and a roster of stars willing to slum to campy effect. The tribute, to be shown each Friday in October, begins with a quartet of vampire flicks, starting with Peter Cushing as Van Helsing, the vampire hunter -- and the arch-enemy of Count Dracula, played by Christopher Lee (above) -- in ''Horror of Dracula'' (1958) and, at 9:30, ''The Brides of Dracula'' (1960). Mr. Lee is resurrected as the title bloodsucker at 11 in ''Dracula, Prince of Darkness'' (1966) and, at 12:45 a.m., in ''Dracula Has Risen From the Grave'' (1969). 7 P.M. (21); 9:30 P.M. (13) AT THE PALEY CENTER Pat Mitchell, president and chief executive of the Paley Center for Media, hosts this new six-part series focusing on people who have made significant contributions to television and film. First up: Ted Danson reminisces about his career, from Sam Malone, the ''Cheers'' character that made him a star, to his more recent roles in HBO's ''Curb Your Enthusiasm'' and ''Bored to Death'' and FX's ''Damages.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MARDEN, MICHAEL
summary: MARDEN--Michael, of New York City, age 75, died January 7, 2010. Husband of Leslie Macpherson, son of the late Nicholas B. and Kathryn Marden, he was born in New York City on September 27, 1934. He graduated from Briarcliff High School in 1951, Princeton University in 1955, and received his M.A. in American Studies from Columbia University in 1993. He served in the U.S. Army from 1955-1957. His career at CBS Television spanned from 1965 to 1989, working on the acquisition, scheduling and promotion of prime-time movies in New York, then becoming the Director of "Made for Television" movies in Los Angeles, and starting and supervising the CBS Late Movie in New York. In 1977 he became Director of Program Development, responsible for all aspects of developing comedy and dramatic series. After retiring, Mike continued with CBS News/New York Times conducting telephone interviews with members of Congress, delegates to various presidential conventions and the general public on timely subjects of local and national interest. He worked for the U.S. Census in New York and for Robert A. Becker Inc. where he recruited medical professionals for meetings and conferences on medical subjects. He also began working with Service Employees International Union ("SEIU") Communication Center in New York where he recruited union members to support political candidates and issues such as the presidential campaign of John Kerry in St. Louis, the New York State Budget campaign, union organizing in California, and the campaign for Senator Robert Menendez in New Jersey. In 2008 he led the SEIU team in Columbus, Ohio registering voters on behalf of Barack Obama. He went on to do similar work for then Senator Obama in Texas and Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife Leslie, sons Scott, David, Christopher, Michael and daughter Sarah Guidotti (all by his first wife Suzanne Jacobs), grandson Ellis Guidotti, brother Brice and sister Mary Carroll. A memorial celebrating his life will be held in February. Donations in his memory may be made to Public Television, Thirteen, 450 West 33rd Street, New York, NY, 10001-2605.

headline: THE BOSS; A Windbag, But He Was Our Windbag
summary: There was a day in spring training a dozen years ago, leaving the Yankees' clubhouse at what was then Legends Field, when I turned a corner and walked right into the puffed-out chest of George Steinbrenner. He grumped at me - could have been anybody, really - for being in his space and even let slip a profanity or two, before stepping back, composing himself and extending a hand.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International NORTH KOREA FACES

headline: Couch Camaraderie: Leno, Oprah and Letterman
summary: Jay and Dave together? Could it be true? It was, and there they were, Jay Leno and David Letterman sitting on a couch -- with Oprah Winfrey between them -- upstairs at the Ed Sullivan Theater, where Letterman tapes his show.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International CHINA'S HISTORIC DROUGHT

headline: Candy-Colored Bow-Tied Redemption
summary: THE Pied Piper was nowhere to be heard, and Santa Claus wouldn't be coming to town for a few more weeks, but something irresistible had drawn a small crowd to the West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village on a recent Thursday morning. Huddled in groups of two and three, a few dozen men and women in their 20s and 30s glanced at one another and at their smartphones, rereading the Twitter and Foursquare messages that directed them here, waiting for something to happen. Without fanfare a white van sailed up to the curb, and from it emerged a thin, 58-year-old man -- wearing a gray suit, a tiny red bow tie and white loafers -- who seemed as uncertain to meet his fans as they were excited to receive him. The gathering parted as he stepped onto the blacktop, picked up a basketball and made a few graceless attempts at hurling it at a hoop. ''Yeah, match that,'' he said snidely, to laughter.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) VENOM IN VEGAS The adventurer Donald Schultz (''Wild Recon''), above, spends 10 consecutive days with pythons, rattlesnakes, cobras and other deadly roommates in a 16-by-20-foot glass enclosure, outfitted with a bed and tiny bathroom, on the Las Vegas Strip. The danger increases every 24 hours as 5 snakes are added to an original 50 until a count of 100 is reached. What's worse, Mr. Schultz won't know which species he'll be living with until he opens each day's delivery. The purpose of this stunt: to extract venom for pharmaceutical research and perform tests to measure its potency, the depth of fang penetration and the strike range of some of the world's fastest snakes. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The golden ticket winners arrive in Hollywood, where they're met by Ellen DeGeneres at the judges' table.

headline: Ernie Harwell, Homespun Baseball Broadcaster for the Tigers, Dies at 92
summary: Ernie Harwell, the neighborly Georgian who delivered Margaret Mitchell's newspaper in the 1930s and then delivered the play-by-play of more than 8,500 major league baseball games over 55 years, died Tuesday at his home in Novi, Mich. He was 92. The Detroit Tigers, for whom he announced games for more than four decades, announced his death, which came eight months to the day after he learned he had cancer of the bile duct.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES Blades of glory: the American figure skater Evan Lysacek (right), the world champion, tries to overtake Yevgeny Plushenko of Russia, the defending Olympic gold medalist -- who enjoyed a 0.55-point lead after the short program -- in the men's free skate medal final. The day's coverage begins with women's curling, at 9 a.m. on Universal, followed by men's hockey and men's curling, at noon on the USA Network; women's halfpipe and women's 15-kilometer individual biathlon, at 3 p.m. on NBC; women's and men's curling and women's and men's hockey, at 5 on CNBC; women's hockey, at 5:30 on MSNBC; men's and women's skeleton and men's 20-kilometer biathlon, at 1 a.m. on CNBC; and women's curling (same-day tape), at 3 on MSNBC. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY The plus-size model Emme discusses clothes, curves and confidence; also, styles that look good at any size.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International AT A YEMENI UNIVERSITY,

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: A CELEBRATION OF MUSIC FROM THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT President and Mrs. Obama are hosts of this concert, taped on Tuesday in the East Room of the White House, in honor of Black History Month. Performers include Yolanda Adams, Joan Baez, Natalie Cole, Bob Dylan, Jennifer Hudson, John Legend, John Mellencamp, Seal, Smokey Robinson, the Blind Boys of Alabama, the Howard University Choir and the Freedom Singers. Robert De Niro and Morgan Freeman are the guest speakers. 6 P.M. (The Documentary Channel) VIVA NELSON MANDELA: A HERO FOR ALL SEASONS In honor of the 20th anniversary of Mr. Mandela's release from prison, Catherine Meyburgh explores the private side of the former president of South Africa through interviews with Archbishop Desmond Tutu; the anti-apartheid politicians Oliver Tambo, Ahmed Kathrada and Helen Suzman; the human-rights advocate George Bizos; the former South African foreign minister Pik Botha; the jazz singer Dorothy Masuka; the anti-apartheid activist Nthato Motlana; the trade union leader Cyril Ramaphosa; and Zolani Mkiva, a praise singer.

headline: What's on Today
summary: 10 P.M. (BET) THE MICHAEL VICK PROJECT This new documentary series chronicles the return of Michael Vick (above, second from left, with family members) to football as a backup quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles. A former first-stringer for the Atlanta Falcons, Mr. Vick lost his contract after pleading guilty to bankrolling a dog-fighting operation in 2007. After 18 months in prison, he was released to find his relationship with the N.F.L. and his family strained. This series investigates his life before prison as well as his experiences after. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews the children of Wanda E. Barzee, who in November pleaded guilty to federal charges of kidnapping and unlawful transportation of a minor in exchange for a 15-year prison term in the case of Elizabeth Smart. In 2002 Ms. Smart, then 14, was abducted from her Salt Lake City home by Ms. Barzee and her husband, Brian D. Mitchell, and held for nine months as a captive teenage wife.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International RIGHTS GROUPS FAULT INQUIRY IN RUSSIAN LAWYER'S DEATH

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOLLEY MADISON Hostess with the mostest. The beauty of President James Madison's wife, Dolley, may have attracted attention, but she used her position for serious purposes: to legitimize the country's new capital through weekly parties and bipartisan political gatherings, helping to forge a national identity. She also paved the way for first ladies to adopt social causes, choosing as her own the advocacy of children left orphaned by the War of 1812. ''American Experience'' portrays the Madisons' life and times through dramatic re-creations starring Eve Best, above, and Jefferson Mays. There are also interviews with the NPR news analyst Cokie Roberts and the historians Catherine Allgor and Richard Norton Smith. ''Morristown: Where America Survived,'' at 10:30, revisits the winter of 1779-80, when Gen. George Washington built a log-hut city in New Jersey for his troops and effectively saved the American revolution. 10 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FRONTIER MARKETS: INVESTING IN THE MIDDLE EAST Cheryl Casone reports from Syria, the Palestinian territories and Israel during this weeklong series on the pursuit of international market opportunities by the New York investors David Grayson, managing director of Auerbach Grayson & Company, and Jim Awad, managing director of Zephyr Management.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (SNY) GOING HOME WITH JOHAN SANTANA Mr. Santana, the ace pitcher of the New York Mets, wasn't always living the high life. In this premiere episode of ''Going Home,'' which follows several of the team's players back to their roots, Mr. Santana travels to his native Venezuela, where he reminisces about Little League games, breaking an aluminum bat on his first home run and the mountain he used to climb before each game. He also visits his mother, his childhood home and his first-grade classroom, where he sits, above, and where he met his future wife. He also hands out more than 10,000 toys and pieces of sports equipment at a pre-Christmas festival. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Tom Hanks, in the role of executive producer, continues on the talk-show circuit on behalf of ''The Pacific,'' the HBO mini-series, starting March 14, about the Pacific Theater during World War II. He moves to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC and the ''Late Show With David Letterman'' at 11:35 p.m. on CBS.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 11 P.M. (IFC) THE 25th FILM INDEPENDENT SPIRIT AWARDSEddie Izzard is host of what the IFC people are promising will be a boisterous celebration of movies by filmmakers who embody independence and originality, broadcast in real time from Los Angeles. (The ceremony is also popular with long-winded winners because they aren't booted from the stage by music cues.) Nominees include ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire,'' ''(500) Days of Summer'' (with Zooey Deschanel and Joseph Gordon-Levitt, above), ''Amreeka,'' ''Sin Nombre'' and ''The Last Station,'' for best feature; ''A Single Man,'' ''Crazy Heart,'' ''Easier With Practice,'' ''The Messenger'' and ''Paranormal Activity'' for best first feature; Maria Bello, Nisreen Faour, Helen Mirren, Gwyneth Paltrow and Gabourey Sidibe for best female lead; and Jeff Bridges, Colin Firth, Mr. Gordon-Levitt, Souleymane Sy Savane and Adam Scott for best male lead. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERERJennifer Love Hewitt directed and stars in the series's 100th episode, in which a ghost who knows the whereabouts of a hidden munitions dump with unexploded bombs confides in Melinda that someone will die. In ''Medium,'' at 9, Allison (Patricia Arquette) enrolls in self-defense classes after being mugged.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) TRUE CRIME WITH APHRODITE JONES A journalist and best-selling author, Ms. Jones (above with Norm Lapera, a retired law-enforcement officer) likes to say that the best way to understand a criminal mind is to get inside one. In this new series she conducts investigations into high-profile cases and tries to find what drove the criminals to violence. Her first subject: Scott Peterson, who murdered his wife, Laci, when she was eight months pregnant. The season will also include the Zodiac Killer, the Menendez brothers, O. J. Simpson, Phil Spector and the death of Michael Jackson. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLYJerry Seinfeld makes his debut in the guest host's chair, where he'll interview Peter Gros of ''Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom'' and a few of his critters as well as Donald Trump.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY In her 99th episode Jo Frost, above, tackles the case of Ashley McKinney, a full-time bank employee and accounting student. At home, though, Ms. McKinney assumes the role of referee as she runs interference between her son, who swears, breaks furniture and toys, and steals food from the refrigerator, and his defiant older sister. In the 100th episode, at 9, Ms. Frost revisits some of her most-improved subjects, like the Weinsteins, whose truck-driving ''raging bull'' patriarch has come to embrace his feminine side; Antoinette Lewis, a mother of two toddlers who was widowed just days before Ms. Frost first visited her; and Blythe Newsome, a single mother of six who has put the kibosh on unruly behavior. NOON (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Liz Claman interviews Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, live from the summit sponsored by the Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research.

headline: A.F.C. CHAMPIONSHIP MATCHUP
summary: Jets at Colts 3 p.m., CBS

headline: At Rikers, a Library for Those With Plenty of Time
summary: It seemed like ordinary book club conversation: The cheerful man with short-cropped graying hair stood gabbing with a ponytailed chap on the merits of novels by John Grisham and Jonathan Kellerman. But this was not your ordinary book club setting this recent weekday. The men were at a special ''standing library'' run by the New York Public Library at Rikers Island, and they both wore green jumpsuits with the letters ''DOC'' on the back, for New York City's Department of Correction.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) SOUTH PARK Some of the nation's top scientists band together to put a stop to a recent phenomenon in which rich, successful men suddenly want to have sex with enormous numbers of women. But when a test is administered in this Season 14 premiere, it turns out that some of the fourth-grade boys at South Park Elementary have a sex addiction problem as well. (Above right, Eric Cartman with an animated version of Tiger Woods.) In ''Ugly Americans,'' a new animated series at 10:30, Mark Lilly, a social worker at the Department of Integration, helps recent residents of New York, human and otherwise, adjust to city life. 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The contestants must grin and bare it -- all of it -- at their first photo shoot. André Leon Talley, the editor at large of Vogue, makes his debut at the judges' table.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) 2010 WINTER OLYMPIC GAMES On the games' penultimate evening, male and female figure skaters show off their footwork and artistry at the traditional champions gala. Snowboarding, skiing (above, Marie-Michele Gagnon of Canada competing in the giant slalom on Thursday) and bobsled round out the prime-time coverage. The day's events including the women's curling bronze-medal match at 9 a.m. on Universal; the men's curling bronze-medal match at noon on USA; women's cross-country skiing, snowboarding and bobsled at 1 p.m. on NBC; the men's curling gold-medal final at 6 on CNBC; the men's hockey bronze-medal game at 10 on MSNBC; and the men's curling gold-medal final (same-day tape) at 3 a.m. on MSNBC. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson travels to Seattle, where Spiritual Directors International, a nonprofit group that trains interfaith participants -- including this episode's subjects, a rabbi, a United Church of Christ minister and a Sufi sheikh -- in how to help congregants in their search for the experience of God's presence. Fred de Sam Lazaro journeys to Egypt, where Coptic Christians make up 10 percent of the population.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) I LOVE YOU, MAN (2009) Paul Rudd plays Peter Klaven, a girl's guy (code for wuss) without a male friend. Jason Segel, above center left with Mr. Rudd, who teamed up with him in ''Forgetting Sarah Marshall,'' is Sydney Fife, a guy's guy so secure in his maleness that he wears Ugg boots and shorts to walk his teeny dog. The two meet cute at an open house and, voilà!, Peter has a best man to stand by his side at his wedding to Zooey (Rashida Jones) -- if the wedding ends up happening. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''a fitfully funny comedy that owes much to Judd Apatow, the king of such sublimated man-on-man affairs,'' adding that the director, John Hamburg, ''doesn't do anything with the camera, but he sets a nice, easygoing tone for the actors.'' Andy Samberg plays Peter's masculine gay brother; J. K. Simmons and Jane Curtin are their parents; and Lou Ferrigno is himself. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton looks at the effect of the Haiti earthquake on religious people, and their efforts to send aid. Bob Abernethy talks with Jim Wallis, the author of ''Rediscovering Values: On Wall Street, Main Street and Your Street -- A Moral Compass for the New Economy,'' about the ethical implications of the lavish bonuses expected to be given to financial industry executives later this month.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) SUPER-MANNY SPECIAL: GRISWOLD FAMILY Climb back into your London taxi cab, Jo Frost. Mike Ruggles, above, a native Chicagoan and ''manny'' with more than 17 years of experience as a teacher and developmental therapist for children, goes up against a family of six from Colorado in this hourlong spinoff of ''Supernanny.'' And at times it seems that he has met his match. Allan Griswold, a working father with a short fuse, terrifies his brood by yelling and making threats. Roberta, a stay-at-home mother, feels like a failure and lets her four children run all over her. About those kids: Joe, 7, curses, makes obscene gestures and brutalizes his sister Lauren, 11. Brianna, 16, berates her mother and already drinks enough to have wound up in the hospital for alcohol poisoning. Even Alex, 2, hasn't escaped his brother's and father's wrath unscathed. 8 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER Detectives Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) and Bernard (Anthony Anderson) investigate the murder of a rich young woman found dead in her apartment. But why were suitcases filled with money and drugs left behind?

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) MAN ON WIRE (2008) As a young man, the aerialist Philippe Petit, above, was flipping through a magazine in a doctor's office when he saw an article about plans to build the two tallest skyscrapers in the world side by side in Lower Manhattan -- and he became obsessed with walking between them. This documentary from James Marsh reminisces about Mr. Petit's daredevil (and illegal) feat on Aug. 7, 1974, when for nearly 45 minutes he danced back and forth on a metal cable strung between the towers of the World Trade Center. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film, which won the Oscar for best feature documentary, ''thorough, understated and altogether enthralling.'' 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW Elisabeth Hasselbeck swaps jobs for the day with her husband, Tim. Mr. Hasselbeck will share hosting duties with Joy Behar, Whoopi Goldberg, Sherri Shepherd and Barbara Walters while his wife substitutes for him as an ESPN football analyst.

headline: The Insiders' Insider
summary: Before he goes to sleep, between 11 and midnight, Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, typically checks in by e-mail with the same reporter: Mike Allen of Politico, who is also the first reporter Pfeiffer corresponds with after he wakes up at 4:20. A hyperactive former Eagle Scout, Allen will have been up for hours, if he ever went to bed. Whether or not he did is one of the many little mysteries that surround him. The abiding certainty about Allen is that sometime between 5:30 and 8:30 a.m., seven days a week, he hits ''send'' on a mass e-mail newsletter that some of America's most influential people will read before they say a word to their spouses. Allen's e-mail tipsheet, Playbook, has become the principal early-morning document for an elite set of political and news-media thrivers and strivers. Playbook is an insider's hodgepodge of predawn news, talking-point previews, scooplets, birthday greetings to people you've never heard of, random sightings (''spotted'') around town and inside jokes. It is, in essence, Allen's morning distillation of the Nation's Business in the form of a summer-camp newsletter.

headline: Swing and Loathing
summary: THREE CHORDS FOR BEAUTY'S SAKE The Life of Artie Shaw

headline: B.C.S. Conference Outlook
summary: ACC CHRISTIAN PONDER FLORIDA STATE, QB The senior's experience and leadership will be particularly vital in Florida State's first season without Bobby Bowden as its coach since 1976.

headline: Ripped
summary: THESE are not just ''their stories.'' Many of the 456 episodes that made up the stunning 20-year run of ''Law & Order'' were based on real, recognizable news stories -- loosely based, at least. ''We take the headline, not the body copy,'' Dick Wolf, the show's creator, explained in 1997, ''because the first half of the show is a murder mystery and the second half is usually a moral mystery.''

headline: The Accidental Activist
summary: Related: Adventures in Humanitarian Tourism On a hot morning in January, at the Petionville Internally Displaced Person camp in suburban Port-au-Prince, Haiti, a four-wheel dirt bike pulled up outside the tent hospital, bearing an elderly woman with a deep gash in her cheek. While a group of medics assisted the patient inside, Sean Penn ambled over from under a tree where he had been having a meeting with one of his camp workers. He walked with a slightly bowlegged cowboy gait, a walkie-talkie crackling at his waistband, a cigarette dangling from his mouth. Having glanced into the tent and ascertained that the situation was in hand, he turned his rather dour gaze on a newly arrived reporter. Penn has never had conventional movie-star looks, but he does have the arguably superior gift of a magnificently interesting face. When he is in grooming mode, he tends to shellac his hair into a high, rather splendid, Little Richard-style pompadour, but today, as on most days in Haiti, the hair had been allowed to collapse into a dusty quiff. With his big, arrow-shaped nose and his heavy eyelids hanging at half-mast, he emanated the slightly sinister allure of a fairground carny. ''You ready to see the camp?'' he muttered.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International DUBAI POLICE SAY

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MANIATTY, CONNIE
summary: MANIATTY--Connie S., Wall Street Executive, lifelong philanthropist, beloved husband, father and brother, died peacefully at his home in Westport, CT on January 8, 2010 at the age of 90. His wife of 61 years, Betty, was at his side. Employed by Salomon Brothers in 1943, he became Partner in 1960 and was then Honorary Managing Director of Citigroup. "Connie was my first boss at Salomon Brothers back in 1966, and I was lucky to land under him - he was a great mentor and a true gentleman. Sitting right next to him, I learned the business of bond trading - and every day saw the importance of hard work and honest leadership." - Michael R. Bloomberg, Mayor, City of New York. "Connie Maniatty was responsible for a whole generation of Salomon Partners who went on to succeed and revolutionize the capital markets. He taught us to work hard and think outside the box, but most of all to do the right thing. We will miss him." - Lewis Ranieri, Former Vice Chairman, Salomon Brothers, Founder of Hyperion Funds, Chairman of Ranieri Partners. "As incredibly successful as he was professionally, he had such a passionate enthusiasm for his friends, his tennis game, his charities, his alma mater, and most importantly his family. He was as loyal a friend and as good an example of a true gentleman as you will ever find in this world...but God help you if you were up a game on him in the third set. It was then best to just get out of the way, as his fiery competitive streak was unleashed. Boy, he hated to lose, but he was always just as graceful in defeat, as he was in victory. I learned a lot of lessons from Mr. Maniatty, all of which I carry with me today, and I will miss him very much." - Sean McManus, President, CBS News and Sports. His love for Columbia University inspired him to work tirelessly raising money for the school and its athletic programs and led the fundraising campaign to build Wein Stadium. He personally funded every female and male athletic team at Columbia and Barnard for the past 40 years. "We have lost our true lion, a great man, friend, trustee and the best Columbia lion ever. I can never thank him enough for what he did for me when I was coaching Columbia football and how he helped me when I left. Without Connie there would be no football program and no Bill Campbell. I can honestly say that I have never known anyone that I respected more." - William "Bill" V. Campbell, Chairman of the Board and former CEO, Intuit. "Connie was Mr. Columbia University. He already is terribly missed by all the students who were there and those who have wanted to enter. I will never forget his kindness and generosity; it was a great honor to have known him. He will be in my prayers forever." Dr. Julius Maldutis, President and Chief Airline Analyst for Aviation Dynamics, Inc. Mr. Maniatty served on the Board of Trustee's of Columbia University in 1973 - 1985, chairing five committees. Columbia honored Mr. Maniatty with the Columbia Alumni Medal, the Columbia Varsity "C" Athletic Award, the John Jay Award in 1982, the Father Ford Award of Distinction in 1986 and was inducted into the InauguralColumbia Athletics Hall of Fame in recognition of his continued support of Columbia Athletics Mr. Maniatty served on the Board of Trustees of Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT for 18 years including being Chairman of the Board for an unprecedented nine consecutive terms. He founded the Norwalk Hospital Foundation and remained its Chairman until 2006. During his tenure more than $80,000,000 was raised which transformed the hospital into one of the most highly regarded hospitals in the state. In his hometown of Westport, CT he was on the Fairfield County Hunt Club Board of Trustees from 1977 - 2009, serving as President from 1980 - 1982. Mr. Maniatty created Scholarship Funds for Westport Police and Fire personal and their families, supported their Benevolent Foundation and launched the Defibrillator Program which has saved hundreds of lives. "Connie was a long time supporter of a great many of our programs. He did so much for the Westport Police and Fire Departments. We could never have done as much without supporters like him." - Alfred R. Fiore, Chief of Police, Westport, CT. Mr. Maniatty was one of the co-founders of the NYC Police and Firefighters Widows and Children's Benevolent Foundation. Mr. Maniatty is survived by his wife Betty Lasher Maniatty, their children, Margaret Fullington of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Anne Walker of Darien, CT and Philip Maniatty of New Canaan, CT, grandchildren, Christina and Garrett Fullington, Lindsay, Lilly and Stephen Walker and his brothers, Leo, Hermes, Arthur, Christopher and Perry Maniatty. Funeral Services will be held at 11am Saturday, January 16, Christ and Holy Trinity Church, 75 Church Lane, Westport, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 34 Maple Street, Norwalk, CT 06856, Columbia University Athletics, 3030 Broadway, Dodge Fitness Center, NY, NY 10027 or Christ & Holy Trinity Church, 75 Church Lane, Westport, CT 06880.
