headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER The series prepares to top itself in this Season 9 premiere, in which the heaviest contestants ever are subjected to cringe-inducing public weigh-ins in their hometowns. Then it's off to the weight-loss ranch, where each team of two must log 26.2 miles on stationary bicycles before a surprise twist raises the ante, and the first player is eliminated. Bob Harper, above right (with Darrell, a contestant), and Jillian Michaels return as the trainers without mercy; Alison Sweeney hosts. Ms. Michaels also appears alongside Kim Kardashian on ''The Jay Leno Show'' at 10. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Maggie Gyllenhaal about her latest film, ''Crazy Heart''; Mary J. Blige performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Everybody's favorite wardrobe wizards, Stacy London and Clinton Kelly, return for a seventh round of guiding the fashionably incompetent through the ABC's of savvy shopping. Their first victim: Courtney, who underwent gastric bypass surgery in 2006 and has since dropped a whopping 170 pounds -- but whose closet runs the gamut from extremely revealing to unflattering and oversize. The season's roster also includes a so-called Salem witch, above between Ms. London and Mr. Kelly; a woman who once earned the title of strongest in the world; an Episcopal priest with an aversion to feminine attire; and a cancer survivor struggling to realize her own beauty after a double mastectomy and an 80-pound weight loss. Ms. London and Mr. Kelly work their magic on the ''Worst Dressed American'' on the series's 250th episode on Jan. 29. 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW Dr. Mehmet Oz examines how stress in a relationship can make a person ill.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOLOn the road again: Simon Cowell, Randy Jackson and Kara DioGuardi fly to Boston for the inaugural audition of this two-night Season 9 premiere. The circuit continues in Atlanta on Wednesday, before moving on to Chicago; Orlando, Fla.; Dallas; Los Angeles; Denver; and ultimately Los Angeles. Guest judges like Victoria Beckham, Mary J. Blige, Kristin Chenoweth, Neil Patrick Harris, Joe Jonas, Avril Lavigne, Katy Perry and Shania Twain will join Mr. Cowell, Mr. Jackson and Ms. DioGuardi along the way. Ellen DeGeneres will step into Paula Abdul's shoes in Los Angeles. Ryan Seacrest hosts. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW The actress Rita Wilson helps viewers find their style.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) SAM COOKE: CROSSING OVER Sam Cooke instilled the spirit of gospel into pop music and in 1957, with ''You Send Me,'' became the first black singer to reach No. 1 on both the R&B and pop charts. Cooke, above, had a string of soaring hits like ''Soothe Me,'' ''Wonderful World'' and ''Cupid''; was a mentor to Aretha Franklin; and earned the support of Dick Clark in his fight against racism. But his career was cut short in 1964, when, at 32, he was gunned down while in the company of a prostitute. This ''American Masters'' presentation chronicles his life and career, from his early childhood singing at his father's First Baptist Church in Chicago to his involvement in the civil rights movement, and asks what might have been. Muhammad Ali, James Brown, Smokey Robinson, Lou Rawls and the producer Jerry Wexler are interviewed; Danny Glover narrates. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR: ON THE WINGS OF LOVE The high-flying Jake Pavelka, who hit turbulence while searching for romance with Jillian Harris on ''The Bachelorette'' last season, continues his quest for a partner. This week the 15 remaining women will move into a villa in Malibu, Calif., and start the dating process. Six of them will take part in a sexy photo shoot for InStyle magazine; five will visit Six Flags Magic Mountain; three won't have dates at all. And one will be piloted by Mr. Pavelka to a getaway in Palm Springs, where the twosome will be serenaded by the band Chicago. Then a bombshell is dropped.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) PASSING STRANGE In 2004 the singer-songwriter who goes by the name Stew, above, collaborating with Heidi Rodewald and Annie Dorsen, created this semiautobiographical rock musical about a young black man who leaves behind his middle-class, churchgoing upbringing in 1970s Los Angeles to travel to Europe in search of his identity, or what he calls ''the real.'' The result is a series of misadventures with sex, drugs, politics and art in Amsterdam and Berlin -- and the discovery that love is the most real thing of all. Initially presented at the Sundance Theater Lab in Utah, ''Passing Strange'' was performed at Berkeley Rep in California and the Public Theater in the East Village before opening at the Belasco Theater on Broadway in February 2008. The show earned seven Tony Award nominations, winning for best book of a musical. Writing in The New York Times, Charles Isherwood said: ''Call it a rock concert with a story to tell, trimmed with a lot of great jokes. Or call it a sprawling work of performance art, complete with angry rants and scary drag queens. Call it whatever you want, really. I'll just call it wonderful, and a welcome anomaly on Broadway, which can use all the vigorous new artistic blood it can get.'' Spike Lee directed this ''Great Performances'' presentation. 8 P.M. (NBC) MERCY Veronica (Taylor Schilling) finds her own love triangle drawing comparisons to three promiscuous college students who are admitted to the hospital with meningitis. Chloe (Michelle Trachtenberg) helps a bride-to-be (Eva Amurri) with her wedding plans when a bout of the flu turns out to be much more serious. Sonia (Jaime Lee Kirchner) takes charge of the case of a transplant recipient (Michael Imperioli) who wants his donor hand amputated after he discovers it belonged to a pedophile. And Dr. Sands (James Tupper) gets a surprise visit from his sister (Jill Flint).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (FX) ARCHER Subtitle this one ''The Spy Who Didn't Love Me.'' This new animated comedy from Adam Reed (Adult Swim's ''Sealab 2021'') follows the employees of the International Secret Intelligence Service (Isis), where espionage is merely a guise for any manner of undermining behavior. H. Jon Benjamin lends his voice to the master spy Sterling Archer (code name: Duchess); Jessica Walter is his mother and boss, Malory, above with Sterling Archer; Aisha Tyler is his ex-girlfriend, Agent Lana Kane; George Coe is his butler, Woodhouse; Chris Parnell is Cyril Figgis, the comptroller of Isis and Lana's new love interest; and Judy Greer is Malory's lovesick secretary, Cheryl. The action begins as Archer is assigned to train Cyril after he is promoted to agent. At 10:30 Archer must break into the Isis mainframe to neaten up a questionable expense account. 8 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSELJohn Stossel investigates ''crony capitalism,'' in which businesses benefit from political connections. Guests include Jonathan Blake and Annette Meeks of the Freedom Foundation of Minnesota and Dick Calabrese, chief of staff for Dick Armey, the former Republican House leader.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES The lab tightens security when Brennan (Emily Deschanel, right) and her team are ordered to work on a highly classified government case, leading Booth (David Boreanaz) and his boss (Diedrich Bader) to bend some rules to get at the reason for the investigation. Meanwhile Cam (Tamara Taylor) worries that her adopted daughter, Michelle (Tiffany Hines), is keeping a secret. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICAGeorge Stephanopoulos interviews President Obama at the White House; Billy Zane talks about his new series, ''The Deep End'' (see below); and the warning signs of Alzheimer's disease are examined.

headline: BITS
summary: Highlights from Bits, the technology blog updated all day at nytimes.com/bits.

headline: Wall St. Plunge Suggests Flaws In Fast Trading
summary: Investigators seeking an explanation for the brief stock market panic last week said Sunday that they were focusing increasingly on how a controlled slowdown in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, meant to bring about stability, instead set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges. It was an unintended consequence of a system built to place a circuit breaker on stocks in sharp decline. In theory, trades slow down so that sellers can find buyers the old-fashioned way, by hand, one by one. The electronic exchanges did not slow down in tandem, causing problems, according to two officials familiar with the investigation.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (HBO) 24/7 JIMMIE JOHNSON: RACE TO DAYTONA This sports reality franchise presents its first nonboxing edition as it tracks the fleet Mr. Johnson, the reigning four-time Nascar Sprint Cup Series champion -- and the Associated Press's 2009 Athlete of the Year -- as he and his No. 48 Hendrick Motorsports team prepare for the Super Bowl of car racing, the Daytona 500, on Feb. 14 in Daytona Beach, Fla. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Denise Richards discusses her divorce from Charlie Sheen and his most recent arrest.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC, BET, CBS, CNBC, CNN, C-Span, Fox, Fox Business Network, Fox News Channel, NBC, NY1, 13, 41, 47, 48) STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESSPresident Obama will address a joint session of Congress in the House chamber on issues expected to include the economy, job creation, health care reform and the 2010-11 budget. Gov. Robert F. McDonnell of Virginia will present the Republican response. 5 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Liz Claman reports live from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Among the chief executives interviewed are Duncan L. Niederauer of NYSE Euronext; Rich Gelfond of the Imax Corporation; James Turley of Ernst & Young; and Michael B. McCallister of Humana.

headline: High Schools in City Draw Big-Name Graduation Speakers
summary: In New York City, it is not just the colleges that can snag high-profile commencement speakers. High schools large and small are also celebrating their graduations with wit and wisdom from some major names. The best-known selective high schools, Stuyvesant and the Bronx High School of Science, each have about 800 graduates a year, helping them build up impressive back benches of well-known alumni. That gives them an advantage when it comes to bringing in the talent.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) 15TH ANNUAL CRITICS' CHOICE MOVIE AWARDS The Broadcast Film Critics Association honors the finest in cinematic achievement in 2009 at this ceremony broadcast live from the Hollywood Palladium in Los Angeles. Among the nominees for best picture are ''Avatar,'' ''An Education,'' ''The Hurt Locker'' (above), ''Precious,'' ''A Single Man'' and ''Up in the Air.'' George Clooney, Colin Firth and Morgan Freeman received nods for best actor, and Sandra Bullock, Carey Mulligan and Gabourey Sidibe are in the running for best actress. Adam Lambert and Sarah Silverman will present together; Meryl Streep will bestow a philanthropic award on Kevin Bacon; and John Krasinski, Amy Poehler and Death Cab for Cutie -- which will perform ''Don't You (Forget About Me)'' -- will pay tribute to the director John Hughes, who died in August. Nick Jonas & the Administration are the evening's house band; Kristin Chenoweth hosts. Red-carpet interviews begin at 8:30. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE MARTHA STEWART SHOWMichael Pollan talks about the importance of sustainable foods; Gary Lincoff provides a guide to wild mushrooms.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 11 P.M. (13) THE MEDIA: JOURNALISM IN CRISIS William F. Baker, president emeritus of WNET.org, narrates a documentary on the challenges and crises that print and broadcast journalism face in the digital age. Among those interviewed: Tom Curley, the president of The Associated Press; Bill Keller, the executive editor of The New York Times; Keith Olbermann, the MSNBC host, above; Sean Hannity, the Fox News Channel host; and Laura Ingraham, the syndicated radio host. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Guests include: Christina Romer, chairwoman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers; Michael Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security; Representative Jane Harman, Democrat of California; and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (DIY) GARAGE MAHALJay Leno's six-car, three-room Tudor-style garage, above, was a mess. So in this season premiere Bill Goldberg and his team toss out broken furniture, old clothing and useless artifacts to create his-and-her parking spaces for Mr. Leno and his wife, Mavis. The James Bondian touches include a 22-foot, in-floor turntable; mahogany doors operated by fingerprint access and a universal remote; and a subterranean storage unit cum library for his thousands of car magazines and books. The space includes extra-large cabinets to display Mr. Leno's memorabilia. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA In a show broadcast from St. Petersburg, Russia, George Stephanopoulos interviews President Obama about the signing of a nuclear arms control treaty with Russia.

headline: Little Beds, Big Personalities
summary: AROUND the time she began working as special projects editor for House & Garden in 2003, Susanna Salk noticed that children's rooms were being featured in shelter magazines, something that would have been almost unthinkable a decade earlier. ''Before, the priority was always a living room, a bedroom, a kitchen space, a garden and a portrait of the family,'' Ms. Salk said, explaining that she believes the shift took place in part because more adults with children had ''lots of disposable income.''

headline: Zelda Rubinstein, 76, 'Poltergeist' Actress
summary: Zelda Rubinstein, a 4-foot-3-inch character actress best known for playing the indomitable ghost-purging psychic in ''Poltergeist,'' died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 76 and lived in Los Angeles. The cause was complications of a heart attack she had two months ago, her agent, Eric Stevens, said. No immediate family members survive.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Planet Green) BIG CHEF TAKES ON LITTLE CHEF Little Chef may be something of a British institution, but this chain of old-fashioned roadside cafes has been on the brink of financial collapse for years. To the rescue: Heston Blumenthal, above, a three-Michelin-star English chef who experiments with low-temperature and sous-vide (under vacuum) cooking methods at his flagship restaurant, the Fat Duck, in the village of Bray in Berkshire. This series follows Mr. Blumenthal as he tries to revive Little Chef -- and classic English food -- in only six months. In ''Conviction Kitchen,'' at 10, the chef Marc Thuet and his wife and business partner, Biana Zorich, try to open a high-end restaurant in just three weeks. Their staff: 24 ex-convicts with no culinary experience. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDSMitt Romney, former governor of Massachusetts, discusses his political aspirations. His wife, Ann, chimes in.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MATTHAEI, GAY
summary: MATTHAEI--Gay Humphrey, Russian scholar, award winning author, independent film producer and interior designer, beloved wife of Konrad, twin sister of Jewel, mother of Marcella, Leslie and Konrad, grandmother of Konrad, Spencer and Sophie, passed away in her sleep on January 1, 2010. A Phi Beta Kappa, magna cum laude graduate of Mt. Holyoke College; she received her Masters Degree from Columbia University School of International Affairs, Russian Institute. Gay was one of the first four American students invited to visit the Soviet Union in 1954 by the undersecretary to Stalin, Nikita Kruschev. CBS and NBC equipped her with camera and film for this first peek behind the iron curtain. Her film was shown on NBC prime time and she lectured extensively throughout the country on her experiences in Russia. Gay co-authored, with her sister Jewel, three books about the coming of age of young Lakota Sioux in the 19th Century including the prize winning Ledgerbook of Thomas Blue Eagle and its accompanying award winning CD-ROM. Gay also produced and directed the educational film Where Time is a River, which won First Prize at the first Women's Film Festival and was subsequently acquired by the Museum of Modern Art Archive of Films. As President of Gay Matthaei Interiors, she specialized in residential and commercial interiors and historic restorations. She was a member of the Governor's Commission to Restore the State Capitol in Hartford. She also served as a Trustee of Mount Holyoke College for ten years, as a founder of the Addie Mae Collins Storefront School and as a Director of Young Audiences, Inc. Her literary awards include the International Reading Association Award, and Christopher Medal; her CD-ROM won the Emma Award, Best Visuals Educational Europe 1995; Intermedia Asia Best CD-ROM Title, 1995; Best CD-ROM Elementary School, Edinburgh Festival and the FNAC Prix. A celebration of Gay's life will be held at First Church of Round Hill, Greenwich, CT on Saturday, February 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Annual Fund of Mt. Holyoke College in memory of Gay Humphrey Matthaei, Class of '52. Mail to: The Annual Fund, Mount Holyoke College, Mary Wooley Hall, South Hadley, MA 01075 or to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, SD 57326.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) MILEY CYRUS IN LONDON: LIVE AT THE O2 My, how she's grown. Following on the heels of the furor caused by her music video ''Can't Be Tamed'' -- Fetish gear! Suggestive dance moves! Hints of Lady Gaga! -- this network television special, Ms. Cyrus's first, is said to reveal what ABC called in a news release ''her natural progression and sophistication.'' Filmed during her recent Wonder World tour, the 17-year-old Ms. Cyrus, above, performs ''7 Things,'' ''Party in the U.S.A.'' and ''The Climb'' and promotes her new, more adult CD, ''Can't Be Tamed,'' which will be released on Tuesday. She will talk about the performance on ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 a.m., and ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 a.m. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDS Toby Keith croons his song ''Trailerhood'' and discusses the Gulf of Mexico oil cleanup as part of the show's ''All American Concert Series.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) POIROT X: THE THIRD GIRL In the second of three new ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' productions, Hercule Poirot (David Suchet, right), Agatha Christie's debonair Belgian supersleuth, gets help from Ariadne Oliver (Zoë Wanamaker), an eccentric crime novelist, in cracking the case of Norma Restarick (Jemima Rooper), a tormented young heiress with a tragic past who is convinced that she murdered her childhood nanny, even though the death was ruled a suicide. Despite Norma's protestations, Poirot isn't so sure she's guilty. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. weighs in on how much impact the struggling economy will have on the midterm elections this fall, and discusses the timeline for the withdrawal of United States troops from Afghanistan. The midterm election debate continues with Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina, and Representative Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; and with Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, and Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) AGATHA CHRISTIE'S MISS MARPLE, SERIES V: THE SECRET OF CHIMNEYS This second of three new ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' productions finds Miss Marple (Julia McKenzie) accompanying Lady Virginia Revel (Charlotte Salt) to a weekend party at Chimneys, her family home where her father, Lord Caterham (Edward Fox), is playing host to Count Ludwig von Stainach (Anthony Higgins) of Austria. But when the count goes missing, the search reveals a decades-old murder and a mysterious diamond heist. Adam Godley is George Lomax, the politician who suggested the gathering and who has proposed marriage to Virginia. Jonas Armstrong is Anthony Cade, another, more adventurous suitor, who has captured Virginia's eye. And Stephen Dillane, above, is Finch, the chief inspector from Scotland Yard who is going to help Miss Marple make sense of the chaos. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates discusses military progress in the Middle East and diplomatic relations with Iran.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International SEOUL MULLS RESPONSE

headline: A.F.C. DIVISIONAL ROUND
summary: Ravens at Colts

headline: Bicycling on Camera, In New York and Beyond
summary: There is something cinematic about riding a bicycle through New York traffic with its speed, lights and danger. For the rider, street scenes can open up in flashes between stopped cars, creating a kind of stuttered approximation of film. No wonder, then, that many riders, like Luke Stiles and Chris Thormann, have tried to capture these scenes with a camera. From the backs of scooters and the tops of skateboards, Mr. Stiles, 36, a software developer and former racer, and Mr. Thormann, 25, a bicycle messenger and alleycat rider, have been shooting ''Empire,'' a film about everything that is ''fun, scary and exciting'' about bicycling in the city without brakes. ''It's in the sub-sub-subgenre that is fixed-gear action sports videos,'' Mr. Stiles explained. A profile in the latest issue of Cog magazine chronicles the project, which Mr. Stiles and Mr. Thormann hope to complete by this spring.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BROWN, HIMAN
summary: BROWN--Himan, 99, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Friday June 4th 2010 at 8:13pm. He was Father to Barry Kenneth Brown of California and Hilda Joan Brown of Arizona. Grandfather to Melina Celeste Brown and Barrie Kristen Brown. Beloved great-grandfather "Papa Hymie" to William Samuel Brown, Zoe Judith Mildred Sansted, Zachary Dakota Aloysius Sansted and Zia Eva Dora Sansted, all of Connecticut, he was also father-in-law to Judith Ann Brown of Manhattan. He was the Widow of Mildred Brown and Shirley Goodman. He was preceded in death by his parents Samuel Brown and Dora Arkis Brown who were immigrants from Odessa, Russia, His brothers Mende Brown and Nathan Brown. He also leaves behind his beloved caretaker Zulfiya Ziyakhodjaev, who gave structure, meaning, and love to his final years, his great friend and doctor Cameron Hernandez of Mt Sinai Visiting Doctors, who he admired as a doctor and loved as a friend, a neighborhood full of people who loved him, and a bustling building full of devoted staff who were more than just that to him; they looked out for him, listened to him and enabled him to remain the independent guy that he was until the very end. He was a member of the community of North Stamford, CT, where he spent every weekend and most summers for his entire life, and he leaves behind a group of friends there who have been a tremendous foundation, providing a retreat to a very intense and creative mind. He also leaves a wonderful, talented, and devoted group of actors who he has worked with for years and who have remained his loyal friends and creative inspiration throughout more years than any may want to admit. He surely joins those who left this earth before him at some heavenly table-reading, throwing a cue, joking with Zero, and listening to Mercy growl out a laugh. He grew up in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, fluent in Yiddish, and only learned English upon his entry into public school. Steeped in music and great classics, he played violin, and excelled intellectually, while attending Boy's High School with the likes of Bugsy Seigel and The Amboy Dukes. He attended Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School graduating as valedictorian with a law degree in 1931, but acting was his great passion, and he already was producing and performing in live theater, Catskills revues, and on the fast growing medium of radio. Legendary creator, producer, director of radio drama, beginning in 1927 with the Hi Brow Readings, he was a one man show, often seen riding a horse in Central Park or walking the country roads of his Stamford, CT retreat while editing scripts with a red pencil, he was a mysterious figure to many but a regular guy to those that knew him. Some of his notable series include The Rise of the Goldbergs, Dick Tracy, Adventures of the Thin Man, Inner Sanctum Mysteries, Grand central Station, and the Peabody Winning CBS Radio Mystery Theater. In the 1950s he bought Players Studios at 221 West 26th Street, now Chelsea Studios, to produce his shows. He was a Founding Member of the Director's Guild of America, proud AFTRA member, a philanthropist and founder of The Radio Drama Network to propagate the spoken word, and was devoted to health care causes and the issues facing people over 50. He was a proud liberal, intellectual, art collector, and legendarily frugal. A member of the Radio Hall of Fame, Brown is the recipient of the American Broadcast Pioneer and the Peabody Award. Brown has taught audio drama at Brooklyn College and the School of Visual Arts. He has lived at the same apartment on Central Park West since 1938. He was awarded a doctorate of Humane Letters by Brooklyn College in 2003. Services will be private, The family urges that in Lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Visiting Doctors of Mt Sinai, Attn: Dr Cameron Hernandez, 5 East 102nd Street, New York, NY 10029.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: TEEN MOVIES Turner Classic Movies extols the allure of sand and surf with an all-night festival that begins with ''Gidget'' (1959), starring Sandra Dee (above, with James Darren, center, and Cliff Robertson) as a small but mighty California girl who dreams of riding endless waves with a gang of surfers, including the very groovy Moondoggie, played by Mr. Darren. Mr. Robertson is the Big Kahoona, the older beach bum all the youngsters idolize. The lineup continues with a Frankie Avalon-Annette Funicello double bill, ''Beach Blanket Bingo'' (1965), at 10, and ''Bikini Beach'' (1964), at midnight. ''Where the Boys Are'' (1960), with Dolores Hart, Yvette Mimieux, Paula Prentiss, Connie Francis (who also crooned the theme song) and George Hamilton as college coeds looking for love during spring break in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., follows at 2 a.m. And ''Girl Happy'' (1965), starring Elvis Presley as a rock singer hired to chaperone a gangster's daughter (Shelley Fabares) on her first Florida holiday, wraps things up at 4 a.m. 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER The series begins a 12th season by introducing 13 new houseguests into a camera- and microphone-loaded Los Angeles home where the goal of one of the 13 is to wreak havoc on the other contestants. The last houseguest standing after weekly eliminations will pocket $500,000. Julie Chen hosts.

headline: A Parallel Universe To TV and Movies: Series on the Web
summary: HAS any art form -- or entertainment category or visual medium or whatever you want to call it -- grown so large so fast as the online serial, while remaining so consistently outside the mainstream cultural conversation? Quick, name a Web series. We'll wait. Did you come up with ''lonelygirl15''? Two years after that initial series ended, it's probably still the best known online serial -- not because of its quality, but because of the fuss when it was revealed to be fiction.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 52ND ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS ''Music's Biggest Night'' pulls out the stops with performances by Jamie Foxx and T-Pain with Slash and Doug E. Fresh, and Drake, Eminem and Lil Wayne with Travis Barker; a tribute to the guitar virtuoso Les Paul by Jeff Beck and Imelda May; a collaboration between the cast of the Broadway-bound musical ''American Idiot'' and Green Day, the band whose songs make up the show's score; a 3-D salute to Michael Jackson with Céline Dion, Jennifer Hudson, Smokey Robinson, Carrie Underwood and Usher; and a fund-raising segment on behalf of Haiti with Mary J. Blige and Andrea Bocelli. The acts whose records are the five album-of-the-year nominees -- Beyoncé, above, the Black Eyed Peas, Lady Gaga, the Dave Matthews Band and Taylor Swift -- will also take the stage at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. T-Pain and Keith Urban lead the nominations with four each, followed by Mr. Foxx and Eminem with three, and Drake with two. 10 A.M. (5) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Guests include Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, and Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (BBC America) THE GREAT FOOTBALL GIVEAWAY In 2000 Paul Clarke, an advertising executive, and his wife, Sarah, were visiting Malawi on a holiday when they noticed children playing with makeshift soccer balls made of layers of plastic bags bound together with string. The Clarkes vowed to return with real soccer balls. Since founding their charity, the Great Football Giveaway, in 2006, they have hand-delivered tens of thousands of soccer balls to impoverished children in Malawi, Uganda, Angola, Rwanda and Congo. This documentary tells the couple's story while celebrating the joy found in the simple act of kicking a ball around. ''I accepted that I'm not a doctor who can administer anti-retroviral drugs, I can't build wells and I'm not an engineer,'' Mr. Clarke has said of his endeavors. ''But I could find a way to help put smiles on kids' faces'' -- and perhaps save lives at the same time. With the help of the Clarkes' charity, a soccer program is being used to help rehabilitate child soldiers in Congo. 7 P.M. (National Geographic) NAT GEO AMAZING! Starting with ''Killer Swarms and Urban Penguins,'' this new series explores some of nature's surprising wonders.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: BOB HOPE Vaudevillian, U.S.O. Ambassador of Goodwill and all-out funny guy, Hope topped more than a few polls of the 20th century's greatest entertainers. This 14-film tribute begins with ''Bachelor in Paradise'' (1961), in which he plays an expert on love who causes trouble when assigned to write about sex in suburbia. In the middle of the retrospective, Bing Crosby and Dorothy Lamour join Hope in five of the seven ''Road'' films the three made: ''Road to Singapore'' (1940), at 1:15 p.m.; ''Road to Zanzibar'' (above, with Hope, left, and Crosby, from 1941), at 2:45; ''Road to Utopia'' (1946), at 4:30; ''Road to Bali'' (1952), at 6:15; and ''Road to Morocco'' (1942), at 8. The celebration ends with ''Call Me Bwana'' (1963), at 4:15 a.m. on Monday, in which Hope, as a famous anthropologist who is really a fraud, hunts and golfs his way across Africa as he searches for a lost moon capsule. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Governor Mitch Daniels of Indiana discusses the 2012 presidential election; Theodore B. Olson, one of the lawyers for the plaintiffs, talks about the ruling on Wednesday by a federal judge in San Francisco that struck down California's voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Groupon's Biggest Deal Could Transform City's Tech Start-Ups
summary: Chicago has been home to far bigger transactions than the one being discussed between Google and Groupon. But few, if any, have had as much riding on it for the city as this $6 billion deal does. Groupon, a Chicago company coveted for its ability to mobilize millions of people online to buy local products, offers steep daily discounts to consumers on an array of products and services. If the Google-Groupon deal is completed, Groupon will be one of the country's biggest start-up success stories and one likely to spur a frenzy of new investment in Internet-based companies, including more in sometimes-overlooked Chicago.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PAPES, THEODORE CONSTANTINE, JR.
summary: PAPES--Theodore Constantine, Jr.,81, died peacefully in his sleep on January 8, 2010. He will be forever known as a loving husband, father, grandfather, philanthropist, and executive. Mr. Papes was the founding President and CEO of Prodigy Services Company, which began as a joint venture of IBM, Sears, and CBS in 1988. He began his career as an IBM salesman in 1952, and ultimately became a Senior Vice-President and Group Executive, Director General of IBM Europe/Middle East/Africa, and President of Systems Product Development Division. Born in Gary, Indiana, "Ted" was the son of Theodore Constantine and Mary Di Paola Papes, immigrants from Greece and Italy, respectively. Ted served in the U.S. Navy as an aviation electronics technician after graduating from Horace Mann High School in Gary. He then enrolled in his alma mater, the University of Michigan, on the G.I. Bill where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1952 with a BA in economics. He was an avid member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity and became Sports Editor for the "Michigan Daily". His memory and legacy will be kept alive by his adored wife of 54 years, Centes Morrill Papes, his children Matthew (Deborah) Papes, Thaddeus (Valita) Papes, Daniel (Christina) Papes and Karin (Cyril) Cabral, ten grandchildren, and many dear friends. Ted will be remembered as a compassionate leader, mentor, and coach. His greatest loves were his wife Centes, his family, the Michigan Wolverines, his Catholic faith, photography, the Adirondack mountains, barbershop and choral singing, and fishing and skiing with his wife and children. Visitation will be at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral service will be held at the Church of St John and St. Mary, Chappaqua on Wednesday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to San Miguel Academy of Newburgh, 241 Liberty Street, Newburgh, NY 12550, The Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester, 351 Main Street, Mount Kisco, NY 10549 and The Northern Westchester Hospital Center, 400 East Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. Beecher Funeral Home, Inc., 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY 914-769-0001.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) DISTRICT 9 (2009) After a giant spacecraft stalls over Johannesburg, its inhabitants are placed in a squalid refugee camp, where they live for the next 20 years. Despite evidence that they are members of an advanced civilization, they are looked down upon by South Africans of all races and subjected to a heinous agenda of corporate greed in a program overseen by an executive played by Sharlto Copley, above. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said of this ''smart, swift'' film from Neill Blomkamp: ''Not that the metaphorical resonances of 'District 9' aren't rich and thought provoking. But the filmmakers don't draw them out with a heavy, didactic hand. Instead, in the best B-movie tradition, they embed their ideas in an ingenious, propulsive and suspenseful genre entertainment, one that respects your intelligence even as it makes your eyes pop (and, once in a while, your stomach turn).'' The film was nominated for four Oscars, including best picture. 8 P.M. (CBS) THREE RIVERS In this series about Pittsburgh transplant surgeons, which is returning from hiatus, Dr. Andy Yablonski (Alex O'Loughlin) tells a woman that she needs a new heart to save her unborn child and herself. But the donor's family has second thoughts.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS The Sea Shepherds, above, return with more ships -- including the Bob Barker, christened for the host of ''The Price Is Right,'' who donated the money for it -- larger crews and greater determination. Their Whale Defense Campaign takes them on a three-month journey to the South Ocean to stop whaling that the group asserts is illegal and exploits a loophole in international ocean law. At the heart of this series's third season is the imprisonment of Capt. Pete Bethune, whose ship, the Ady Gil, sank after colliding with the Shonan Maru 2 whaling vessel on Jan. 6. In February Captain Bethune was arrested after he boarded the Shonan Maru 2, tried to make a citizen's arrest of the captain and presented him with a $3 million bill for damages. Captain Bethune is now awaiting trial in Tokyo and could be sentenced to 15 years in prison. In the meantime, the Shepherds say that their 2010 Antarctic Defense Campaign has saved 528 whales. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 2010 SCRIPPS NATIONAL SPELLING BEE More than 270 champion spellers, ages 8 to 15, from the United States, as well as American territories and schools around the world, will converge in Washington to test their abilities. Chris Harrison hosts this two-hour final round. Semifinal rounds will be broadcast live on ESPN, starting at 10 a.m.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) JULIE & JULIA (2009) Meryl Streep, right, plays the chef Julia Child in yet another of her Oscar-nominated performances. Amy Adams is Julie Powell, an unhappy cubicle worker who tries to salvage her life by working her way through Child's ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking'' in a year and blogging about it. Nora Ephron wrote and directed this film, which is based on two memoirs: ''My Life in France'' by Child and Alex Prud'homme, and ''Julie & Julia'' by Ms. Powell. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said of Ms. Streep: ''By now this actress has exhausted every superlative that exists and to suggest that she has outdone herself is only to say that she's done it again. Her performance goes beyond physical imitation, though she has the rounded shoulders and the fluting voice down perfectly.'' Instead of overshadowing the original, she added, ''Ms. Streep's incarnation of Julia Child has the opposite effect, making the real Julia, who died in 2004, more vivid, more alive, than ever.'' And though Ms. Adams may have been outmatched by Ms. Streep, Ms. Dargis called Stanley Tucci, as Child's husband, Paul, impeccable. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Deborah Roberts reports on a program at Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Raleigh, N.C., where parishioners train to become Stephen Ministers, named for St. Stephen, who cared for the poor. In other segments Kim Lawton looks at the American financing of development projects in Sudan, and Bob Abernethy interviews the Rev. Richard Cizik about the role of religion in the push for nuclear arms reduction.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE IN THE 2000s: TIME AND AGAINTina Fey, Will Ferrell, Jimmy Fallon, Bill Hader, Chris Kattan, Seth Meyers, Tracy Morgan, Amy Poehler, Andy Samberg and Kristen Wiig reflect on the show's place in the 21st century in this retrospective of clips, backstage anecdotes and interviews. Alec Baldwin (second from right above with, from left, Mike Myers, Mr. Fallon and Horatio Sanz), who has hosted the show 14 times, and Christopher Walken, who tallies 7, weigh in. 8 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSELJohn Stossel examines federal income tax codes and tax forms, which have become complicated and costly to file. The guest panel includes the director Christopher Marshall and the screenwriter Vincent Vittorio of ''An Inconvenient Tax''; Mike Tomberlin of Tomberlin Electric Vehicles, whose golf carts qualify for ''green'' tax credits; Gary Milkwick, the vice president for accounting at the Tax Club; and Neal Boortz, a radio host and the author of ''The Fair Tax Book.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (TLC) THE WHAT NOT TO WEAR AWARDS And the statuette for finally accepting that it's not O.K. to dress as if you were 15 when you're 45 goes to ... ? Clinton Kelly, above at left, and Stacy London, center, with Miriam, sift through the ''What Not to Wear'' archives for the most dramatic transformations, weepiest breakdowns and heart-rending stories to rise from the ashes of fashion makeovers. Later, they rekindle romance by helping a couple change each other's wardrobe. 7 P.M. (MTV) GREEN DAY ROCKS BROADWAY This special peeks behind the scenes of the Broadway musical ''American Idiot,'' adapted from Green Day's 2004 album.

headline: NEW JERSEY
summary: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com. Comedy

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) FOUR CHRISTMASES (2008) Reese Witherspoon and Vince Vaughn, above, star as Kate and Brad, an unmarried San Francisco couple who each Christmas invent a charity project as an excuse to take a hedonistic vacation and avoid festivities with their dysfunctional families. But when a news reporter points a camera their way just as their trip to Fiji is canceled, they have no choice but to make the rounds. Robert Duvall and Sissy Spacek play Brad's divorced parents; Mary Steenburgen and Jon Voight are Kate's. The cast includes Tim McGraw and Jon Favreau as Brad's feral, cage-fighting brothers, and Kristin Chenoweth as Kate's relentlessly fertile sister. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that, in a break from holiday movie tradition, the film, ''briskly directed by Seth Gordon from a snappy, many-authored script, is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro interviews former President Jimmy Carter in Sudan, where for more than 20 years he has led a campaign to eradicate guinea worm, a painful tropical disease. In another segment Tim O'Brien reports on a case coming before the Supreme Court involving the University of California Hastings College of the Law and the Christian Legal Society, a campus group.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SMALL ISLAND Two couples -- one Jamaican, one English -- find their lives tragically intertwined in postwar Britain in this ''Masterpiece Classic'' adaptation of the 2004 novel by Andrea Levy, which won the Orange and Whitbread prizes for fiction. Naomie Harris and David Oyelowo, above, play Hortense and Gilbert Joseph, recent immigrants from the West Indies in a marriage of convenience. Ruth Wilson is their landlady, the working-class Queenie Bligh, whose husband, Bernard (Benedict Cumberbatch), has been mysteriously absent for a couple of years -- and whose offer of friendship exacts a great price. Part 2 will be shown on April 25. Laura Linney hosts. 5:30 P.M. (HBO) MASTERCLASS For more than 25 years, YoungArts, a program of the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts, has offered scholarships and mentoring to emerging high school artists. This new nine-part series follows several of these young musicians, dancers, writers, actors and visual artists as they meet with masters in their fields, starting with the tenor Plácido Domingo. Other luminaries are Edward Albee, Bill T. Jones, Liv Ullmann, Frank Gehry, Julian Schnabel, Michael Tilson Thomas, Jacques D'Amboise and Olafur Eliasson. Writing in The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger said, ''The program is must viewing for all those high school students with dreams of stardom of one sort or another, and for their teachers.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Bravo) CHRISTIAN SIRIANO: HAVING A MOMENT This one-hour program looks at the career of Christian Siriano, left, after he won the fourth season of ''Project Runway.'' The show finds him preparing for New York Fashion Week, overseeing his line while meeting with celebrities like Mena Suvari, Tori Spelling and Katrina Bowden. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Guests include Tori Spelling, Dean McDermott and Peter Krause; the musician David Gray performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL: IDOL GIVES BACK 2010 Alicia Keys, Carrie Underwood, the Black Eyed Peas, Annie Lennox, Jeff Beck and Elton John, as well as a few celebrities not yet revealed, use their star wattage to raise awareness and money for charities around the globe. The special, now in its third installment, has raised more than $140 million to date; this year's show is dedicated to programs like Feeding America, Malaria No More, the American branch of Save the Children and the United Nations Foundation. (Above, LaKisha Jones, left, a Season 6 ''Idol'' finalist, and Stacy Laster of the Houston Food Bank.) Ryan Seacrest will host from the ''American Idol'' stage in Los Angeles. Queen Latifah will hold court at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. 8 P.M. (13) THROUGH A DOG'S EYES For thousands of disabled Americans, dogs really are man's best friend. In this documentary, Jennifer Arnold, the founder of Canine Assistants, one of the nation's largest service-dog organizations, takes viewers through the process of being matched with, and becoming acclimated to, a dog, while inspirational stories show the transformation of seemingly ordinary dogs into full-blown heroes. Neil Patrick Harris narrates.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (National Geographic) AMERICAN SERENGETI ''Nature Untamed'' follows scientists at the American Prairie Foundation as they embark on a quest to rebuild three million acres of the Great Plains in Montana, where land and wildlife have been eroded by human settlement for more than 200 years. The mission, covering an area larger than Yellowstone, includes reintroducing species long associated with the West, like the bison, the pallid sturgeon and the prairie dog, and charting the resurgence of pronghorn antelope, cougars, rattlesnakes and big-horned sheep. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL A Season 3 contestant, Toccara Jones, right, surprises the women and quizzes them on the fashion industry. In this week's photo shoot the contestants dance and pose simultaneously, and one decides whether she wants to quit the competition. 7 A.M. (ABC) TODAYBen Stiller discusses his new film, ''Greenberg,'' and the former Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling and his wife, Shonda, discuss Mrs. Schilling's new memoir, ''The Best Kind of Different.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Planet Green) GREENSBURG: A FINAL LOOK On May 4, 2007, an enhanced F5 tornado -- one of the strongest in American history -- plowed through Greensburg, a small town in southwestern Kansas, leaving virtually nothing standing in its wake. For two years, Planet Green has been watching Greensburg rise like a phoenix on the Great Plains as residents rebuild their town as an oasis of environmental sustainability. This special looks back at highlights from previous episodes before the premiere of the third, and final, season at 9. Above, a scene from the show. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS This news program will make its debut in high definition, from a new set. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will weigh in on domestic and foreign policy; Charlie Crist, the Republican governor of Florida, will talk about his decision to run independently for the United States Senate; and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano and Interior Secretary Ken Salazar will discuss the environmental effects of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Ms. Napolitano and Mr. Salazar will also appear on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10, and on ''This Week,'' at 10 on ABC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (BBC America) TOP GEAR After buying used cars -- an FJ40 Toyota Land Cruiser, a Range Rover Classic, above, and a Suzuki Jimny -- over the Internet from dealers in Bolivia, James May, Jeremy Clarkson and Richard Hammond embark on a 1,000-mile drive from the middle of the Amazon rain forest to the Pacific coast of Chile through the treacherous terrain in the altiplano region, the Andes and the Atacama Desert. The ascent to La Paz along the steep North Yungas Road, popularly known as El Camino de la Muerte (''The Road of Death''), so terrifies the acrophobic Mr. May that he humorously threatens to cut off the head of anyone who bumps him. But he seems to be only half-kidding when he pulls a machete on Mr. Clarkson after a small accident. The two men leave their weapons behind when they appear on a special episode of ''Friday Night With Jonathan Ross'' at 9:40. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The guests include former President Bill Clinton and Jennifer Lopez. Here and on ''The View,'' at 11 a.m. on ABC, Alyssa Milano also promotes her new series, ''Romantically Challenged'' (Monday night at 9:30 on ABC), in which she plays a divorcée about to start dating for the first time since the Clinton administration.

headline: Newcomers Ride to Power With an Unclear Mandate
summary: The Tea Party movement set the agenda in its first midterms, its energy propelling the Republican sweep in the House and capturing the mood of a significant chunk of the electorate, with a remarkable 4 in 10 voters in exit polls expressing support for the movement. But in the Senate, the effect was exactly what establishment Republicans had feared: While Tea Party energy powered some victories, concerns about Tea Party extremism also cost them what could have been easy gains -- most notably in Nevada, where the Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid, survived a challenge from Sharron Angle, a Tea Party favorite.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE In this Season 6 finale, Cuddy (Lisa Edelstein) joins House (Hugh Laurie, above with Ms. Edelstein) and a rescue crew after a crane collapses on a building in Trenton, where a woman (China Jesusita Shavers) trapped in the rubble may lose her leg. All this on a day when House's world comes crashing down after he learns that Cuddy and Lucas (Michael Weston) are planning to move in together. With only three hours until the clock runs out in ''24,'' at 9, Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland) makes life difficult for President Taylor (Cherry Jones). 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW Dr. Mehmet Oz reveals his ultimate tips for summer dieting; also, five beauty bargains under $10.

headline: Auburn Is Seeing Crimson Over Questions and Rivalry
summary: The most anticipated day of every year in the state of Alabama has arrived with Auburn football devotees caught in a riptide of emotions. The Tigers have knocked down their previous 11 obstacles on the schedule and are a consensus No. 2 in the rankings. They can rest assured that Alabama, which hosts Friday's game in Tuscaloosa, will not add to its vast collection of national title trophies.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (LOGO) ''FREEHELD'' (2007) This 38-minute documentary, directed by Cynthia Wade, about Laurel Hester, a detective in Ocean County, N.J., with terminal lung cancer who fought a local ruling that prevented her from leaving her pension to her domestic partner, won an Academy Award for best documentary short subject. (Above left, Ms. Hester, who died in 2006, with her partner, Stacie Andree.) 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Discussion topics include the iPad; the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament Final Four; dyeing eggs and organizing an Easter egg hunt. The singer Amy Grant performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK At last! Liz (Tina Fey) meets the man of her dreams -- and questions fate -- while juggling the weddings of Floyd (Jason Sudeikis), Cerie (Katrina Bowden) and Grizz (Grizz Chapman). Meanwhile, Jack (Alec Baldwin, above with Ms. Fey) learns he can't love two women (Julianne Moore and Elizabeth Banks) at once. This season finale is one of five on NBC on Thursday night, starting, at 8, with ''Community,'' in which Britta (Gillian Jacobs) and Professor Slater (Lauren Stamile) battle for the affection of Jeff (Joel McHale), while Troy (Donald Glover) can't understand why his best friend, Abed (Danny Pudi), hasn't invited him to move into his dorm room. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 8:30, Leslie (Amy Poehler) handles things her own way after Ben (Adam Scott), the state auditor, bans her from holding a children's concert. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) tries to figure out who played whistle-blower and leaked the information that Sabre's printers catch on fire. And in ''The Marriage Ref,'' at 10, Demi Moore, Kelly Ripa and Jim Breuer offer advice -- not all of it good -- to sparring couples. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) must clean house in this Season 5 finale after the death of a hoarder forces them to sort through his mountains of belongings for clues. Meanwhile, Angela (Michaela Conlin) receives a surprise visit from her father (Billy F. Gibbons, as himself). In the Season 2 finale of ''Fringe,'' at 9, the journey of Olivia (Anna Torv) and Walter (John Noble) to the alternate universe leaves the existence of both worlds in question.

headline: AS BIG AS THE GAME
summary: I lived about half a mile from George in Bay Village [Ohio]. We really knew each other in the elementary years, fifth and sixth grade, in the 1930s. . . . In elementary school, he was the one with the white shirt and a tie. The rest of us were in knickers. -- IKE GANYARD (Childhood friend) George is directly responsible for my owning the Bulls. He was a minority owner of the team. We were having dinner in New York one night in the summer of '84. He was complaining about what a bad investment it was and about how he was tired of having to write checks every year to cover losses. I told him that his partners who were running the thing didn't know what they were doing and that I'd love to own the Bulls. A week later, I got a call from one of his partners asking me if I was serious and saying he wanted to get out. At that time, they had drafted [Michael] Jordan, but he hadn't played yet, so they really didn't know what they had. Whenever I was with George and a group of people after that, he'd say, ''This is the guy who screwed me out of the Bulls.'' -- JERRY REINSDORF (Owner, Chicago White Sox, 1981-present, and Chicago Bulls, 1985-present)

headline: A Crime-Plagued College That's Impossible to Get Into
summary: This is the week when millions of college applicants will find out whether they got into their first-choice schools, were put on the waiting list or were rejected. Anyone whose heart is set on Hudson University will be disappointed. Hudson University exists only on television -- mainly on the long-running ''Law & Order'' shows on NBC, and also briefly on ''Castle,'' an ABC series about a New York police detective and a best-selling author who shadows her.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Discovery, Animal Planet) LIFEOprah Winfrey narrates this 11-part nature series, which explores the adaptability and diversity of life on earth -- culling among the 30 million or so animal and plant species here -- from the spectacular to the downright bizarre. Images were captured in high definition using equipment like a ''yogi cam,'' which can track smoothly alongside migrating reindeer and elephants, and an intricate cable rigging that enabled crews to ''fly'' a camera through thousands of monarch butterflies. The survey begins with ''Challenges of Life,'' which explores survival strategies like those of the stalk-eyed fly, which inflates its head to impress females; Kenyan cheetahs who band together to hunt large prey; and monkeys in Brazil that use tools resembling a hammer and anvil to crack nuts. ''Reptiles and Amphibians,'' at 9, shows a pebble toad escaping a tarantula by bouncing down a rock face; a basilisk lizard running on water; a chameleon snatching its prey with its tongue; and the savage hunting techniques of the Komodo dragon. (Above, a sengi on the move.) 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE A discussion of the health care bill gets going with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin; Representative Deborah Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas. It continues with Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina; Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland; Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky; and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and with Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GLOVER, ERIKA DOMENICA LEOPOLDINA
summary: GLOVER--Erika Domenica Leopoldina, age 79, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, died on November 16, 2010, of heart failure and kidney failure at Nevis. Erika Glover was along with her late husband William a Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which they founded in 1964. She was born in the former Yugoslavia in 1931, left for Germany in 1954, and came to the United States, to Kentucky, in 1957. She settled in New York, where she worked for CBS and The New Yorker, marrying William Glover in 1962. She was a woman of courage, enthusiasm, and joy, a bonne vivante who loved her family very much. She is survived by daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu; a brother Luka, sister-in-law Vera, nephew Boris in Croatia; and cousins Marijan and Gregory in Toronto. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, www.doctorswithout borders.org

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MARDEN, MICHAEL
summary: MARDEN--Michael, of New York City, age 75, died January 7, 2010. Husband of Leslie Macpherson, son of the late Nicholas B. and Kathryn Marden, he was born in New York City on September 27, 1934. He graduated from Briarcliff High School in 1951, Princeton University in 1955, and received his M.A. in American Studies from Columbia University in 1993. He served in the U.S. Army from 1955-1957. His career at CBS Television spanned from 1965 to 1989, working on the acquisition, scheduling and promotion of prime-time movies in New York, then becoming the Director of "Made for Television" movies in Los Angeles, and starting and supervising the CBS Late Movie in New York. In 1977 he became Director of Program Development, responsible for all aspects of developing comedy and dramatic series. After retiring, Mike continued with CBS News/New York Times conducting telephone interviews with members of Congress, delegates to various presidential conventions and the general public on timely subjects of local and national interest. He worked for the U.S. Census in New York and for Robert A. Becker Inc. where he recruited medical professionals for meetings and conferences on medical subjects. He also began working with Service Employees International Union ("SEIU") Communication Center in New York where he recruited union members to support political candidates and issues such as the presidential campaign of John Kerry in St. Louis, the New York State Budget campaign, union organizing in California, and the campaign for Senator Robert Menendez in New Jersey. In 2008 he led the SEIU team in Columbus, Ohio registering voters on behalf of Barack Obama. He went on to do similar work for then Senator Obama in Texas and Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife Leslie, sons Scott, David, Christopher, Michael and daughter Sarah Guidotti (all by his first wife Suzanne Jacobs), grandson Ellis Guidotti, brother Brice and sister Mary Carroll. A memorial celebrating his life will be held in February. Donations in his memory may be made to Public Television, Thirteen, 450 West 33rd Street, New York, NY, 10001-2605.

headline: President, Rebounding, Gives Opponents Pause
summary: Suddenly, Republicans face an unanticipated problem: less than three months after their midterm triumphs, President Obama has regained political momentum. As Mr. Obama approaches the State of the Union address on Tuesday, various polls show him rising toward or beyond 50 percent approval of his job performance. Before his first 2011 clash with Republican adversaries who now share governing responsibility, those surveys also show that Americans credit Mr. Obama with greater commitment to finding common ground.

headline: Final Three for ''Idol''
summary: Ratings for Fox's ''American Idol'' recovered somewhat on Tuesday after falling to an eight-year low last week, but CBS won the night over all by a thin margin. According to Nielsen's estimates, a movie-theme episode of ''Idol,'' with guest-mentoring (and T-shirts) from Jamie Foxx, remained the night's top-rated show, earning 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., up from 17.5 million a week ago, but CBS's ''NCIS'' was close behind in the time slot with 16.9 million viewers. The CBS shows ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (15.9 million) at 9 p.m. and ''The Good Wife'' (12.9 million) at 10 won their time slots as well. ABC placed third on the night and NBC was fourth. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: In the Wings for Spring, A 'Born Yesterday' Revival
summary: A Broadway revival of Garson Kanin's play ''Born Yesterday'' is in the works for spring 2011, possibly with a relatively unknown actress in the lead role that Judy Holliday made famous more than 60 years ago, two theater executives familiar with the plans said on Tuesday. Nina Arianda, who received rave reviews last spring and several acting awards for her first major Off Broadway performance, as Vanda in the dark comedy ''Venus in Fur,'' is in discussions to play Billie Dawn, the showgirl mistress of the corrupt businessman Harry Brock, according to the two executives who spoke on condition of anonymity because the revival was still in unofficial planning stages.

summary: $25/SQUARE FOOT $240,000 approximate annual rent

headline: Investors Seek Change At Publisher
summary: 8:57 p.m. | Updated Activist investors are escalating their fight for change at some American companies.

headline: Al Morgan, 91, Author and TV Producer
summary: Al Morgan, a novelist, screenwriter, playwright and television producer who was probably best known for writing ''The Great Man,'' a 1955 novel that became the basis of a movie of the same name, died on March 3 at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 91. His daughter Joey Morgan confirmed his death.

headline: Gameday Guide
summary: Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups. 7 MISSOURI at 14 NEBRASKA 3:30 p.m., ABC/ESPN (4/5 stars) Missouri is a surprise contender but has a tough challenge on the road to stay unbeaten.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) MEDIUM Freaky Friday: Mayhem ensues in this Season 7 opener after Allison (Patricia Arquette) and her daughter Bridgette (Maria Lark, above left, with Jake Weber and Ms. Arquette) have the same dream about a dead con man (Tony Sirico) and wind up swapping personalities. At 9, ''CSI: NY'' introduces Jo Danville (Sela Ward), a former F.B.I. agent, who gets an unusual welcome when she stumbles over the body of a young woman who has been murdered in the building that houses the N.Y.P.D. crime lab. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Tom Selleck, Donnie Wahlberg and Bridget Moynahan discuss their new series, ''Blue Bloods,'' to have its premiere at 10 on CBS. Tom Jones performs.

headline: Risky Words With Insurers
summary: Updated: Fixed a typo in the second paragraph The next time you're talking with your insurer about filing a claim, you may want to watch what you say.

headline: Taco Bell Pulls Ads From 'Skins'
summary: Risque scenes on the hit MTV drama ''Skins'' have caused one company to remove its commercials from the program and have spurred a call by a TV watchdog group for a federal investigation. Taco Bell said Thursday that it had shifted its ads to other programs because ''Skins'' was ''not a fit for our brand.'' MTV did not respond to repeated requests for comment on Friday.

headline: Gameday Guide
summary: 12 ARKANSAS at 7 AUBURN 3:30 p.m., CBS Auburn is off to a 6-0 start, and a win here puts the Tigers in the national title conversation. TEXAS at 5 NEBRASKA 3:30 p.m., ABC Nebraska looks to be on the rise, while Texas seems headed in the other direction.

headline: John Strauss, 90, Composer; Wrote Theme for 'Car 54'
summary: There's a holdup in the Bronx, Brooklyn's broken out in fights.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Hallmark) THREE WISE WOMEN (2010) In this latest incarnation of the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future, Amy Huberman (above left, with Fionnula Flanagan) plays Liz, a successful doctor in her 30s who wonders if her pending marriage is really a dream come true, especially after an impulsive moment with an old friend under the mistletoe. Then her guardian angel, Tom (Hugh O'Connor), appears, just in time to take Liz on a time-traveling journey in search of true love. Ms. Flanagan plays the older Liz; Lauren Coe is Liz as a teenager. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Jeff Bridges discusses stepping into the boots of John Wayne in his role as Rooster Cogburn in the Coen brothers' remake of the 1969 western ''True Grit,'' to be released on Christmas Day. He moves to ''Live! With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GREENBERG, ALFRED N
summary: GREENBERG--Alfred N. May 16, 1919 September 12, 2010. An employee of Bache & Co., Playboy Magazine and CBS, Alfred was a music lover, an avid reader, and a contributor to the letters to the editor section of the New York Times. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army and was among those soldiers who were present at the liberation of Dachau. He was a devoted companion to the late Dr. Gertrude Ashur. He is survived by his sister, Miriam Lonsk, his nephew Donald (Marcia) Goodfriend and his niece Lois (Gary) Meyer. His brother "Buddy" Greenberg predeceased him. Services have already been held. Alfred's knowledge, intelligence and integrity will be missed by all who knew him.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '11 Patti LaBelle will be honored for lifetime achievement and Steve Harvey for his humanitarianism at this 11th-annual ceremony honoring excellence by blacks and other minorities in entertainment and sports. Kevin Hart hosts the event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Alicia Keys, Jill Scott, D J Khaled, Ace Hood, Kelly Rowland, Mary J. Blige, Mali Music, KimberlyNichole, Mary Mary, Donnie McClurkin, Shirley Caesar and Deitrick Haddon are scheduled to perform. Nominees include Marsha Ambrosius, Beyoncé (above), Keri Hilson, Jennifer Hudson and Rihanna for best female R&B artist; Chris Brown, Cee Lo Green, Bruno Mars, Trey Songz and Usher for best male R&B artist; Diamond, Cymphonique, Lola Monroe and Nicki Minaj for best female hip-hop artist; B.o.B., Drake, Lil Wayne, Rick Ross and Kanye West for best male hip-hop artist; and J. Cole, Bruno Mars, Miguel, Willow Smith and Wiz Khalifa for best new artist. Nick Cannon will join Terrence Jenkins and Rocsi from ''106 & Park'' on the red carpet starting at 6; a recap show follows at 11. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace will interview Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, who is to announce her candidacy for the 2012 Republican presidential race on Monday in Waterloo, Iowa. Mr. Wallace will also speak with Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, about his recent exit from budget talks led by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Bob Schieffer will interview Ms. Bachmann on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.
