headline: Champion's March to Greatness Appears Far From Done
summary: Day by day, climate after climate, Rafael Nadal keeps raising his game. On the 15th day of the United States Open, with afternoon turning into night, he willed himself into a career Grand Slam, making himself a master of all surfaces.

headline: On Social Networking Sites, Presidential Mystery Does Not Wait for the President
summary: The terse announcement came just after 9:45 p.m. Sunday from Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director. ''POTUS to address the nation tonight at 10:30 PM Eastern Time,'' he wrote on Twitter, sharing the same message that had just been transmitted to the White House press corps. According to Brian Williams, the ''NBC Nightly News'' anchor, some journalists received a three-word e-mail that simply read, ''Get to work.''

headline: Still Fighting Fire With Fire To Honor the Fallen of 9/11
summary: The 10th anniversary of 9/11 is near, summoning not only horrible memories of that cataclysm but also the anxiety of measuring up. Ten years on, there still aren't enough words, gestures, ceremonies or moments of silence to match the wound. Not paying attention is unthinkable, but it's even harder to think of an adequate tribute. ''Rescue Me,'' the FX show about firefighters who survived the attack on the World Trade Center, isn't a bad place to start. On Monday the drama begins its seventh and final season; it had its premiere in 2004, just as many Americans were moving on and getting over 9/11. And the series has stayed focused -- saltily, irreverently, but always passionately -- on a band of firehouse brothers and their loved ones. A lot has happened in that small world, though time hasn't healed much of anything.

headline: A Return, of Sorts, to NBC
summary: As always in the entertainment industry, business is business - and so, Ben Silverman is back in business with NBC. Mr. Silverman is best remembered for his brief reign as NBC's top programmer, one that did not result in hits or happiness for either party. In the aftermath of the departure, Jeff Zucker, then the network's chief executive, said hiring Mr. Silverman had been the biggest mistake he made.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International BENGHAZI CLASH EXPOSES

headline: Black Eyed Peas Land Super Bowl Halftime Show
summary: Seven years after Janet Jackson's ''wardrobe malfunction'' at the Super Bowl, is the National Football League finally ready to return to somewhat racy halftime shows by people under 40? The Black Eyed Peas will be the halftime band for Super Bowl XLV, scheduled for Feb. 6 at Cowboys Stadium in Arlington, Tex., the N.F.L. announced during the New Orleans Saints-Dallas Cowboys game on Thursday. It's a coup for the band: Last year's halftime show, featuring the Who, was seen by more than 153 million people, according to the league. It is good timing, too: the Black Eyed Peas will release a new album, ''The Beginning,'' on Tuesday.)

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER The five remaining contestants are made over at the hands of the fashion guru Tim Gunn, who arrives via a horse-drawn pumpkin carriage for the Cinderella-like transformations. On the to-do list: help the players choose outfits to flatter their hard-won, slimmer physiques; bestow oodles of gifts; and comment on hairstyles created by Ken Paves, above, with the contestants Hannah Curlee, center, and Olivia Ward. Finally, the competitors are taken to a castle, where they are reunited with loved ones. Meanwhile, in the weekly challenge, they'll search 50 car-shaped sand castles to find the keys to two new cars. 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE Sue (Jane Lynch) revives the school newspaper and publishes libelous articles. April (Kristin Chenoweth) returns to McKinley High and tries to persuade Mr. Schuester (Matthew Morrison) to run off with her. And Sam (Chord Overstreet) earns points from his classmates when details of his home life are exposed.

headline: Gameday Guide
summary: Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups. All times Eastern. 1 ALABAMA at 10 ARKANSAS 3:30 p.m., CBS The defending champions face a test on the road against an up-and-coming conference foe.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) SOUNDTRACK FOR A REVOLUTION ''American Experience'' chronicles the civil rights movement through the songs that protesters sang while fighting for justice and equality, from the bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., to the march on Washington. Archival footage is mixed with interviews with Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia; the singer Harry Belafonte; the social activist Julian Bond; and Andrew Young, the former mayor of Atlanta. John Legend, Joss Stone, Wyclef Jean, Anthony Hamilton and the Blind Boys of Alabama (above), Angie Stone, the Carlton Reese Memorial Unity Choir, Mary Mary, Richie Havens and the Roots perform songs like ''Eyes on the Prize,'' ''Wade in the Water'' and ''We Shall Overcome.'' The actor Danny Glover is an executive producer. 8:30 A.M. (CUNY) AFRICAN AMERICAN LEGENDS Roscoe C. Brown Jr. interviews Byron E. Lewis, chairman and chief executive of UniWorld, one of the largest African-American-owned advertising agencies, about the evolution of marketing to blacks since he founded the company in 1969.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (OWN) BECOMING CHAZ (2011) Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato (''The Eyes of Tammy Faye,'' ''RuPaul's Drag Race'') follow the sex change of Chastity Bono, the daughter of Sonny Bono and Cher, into a man named Chaz, above. This show traces the twists and turns of hormone injections, mood swings and breast removal. Providing support is Chastity's longtime girlfriend, Jennifer Elia. ''Mr. Bailey brings up a fascinating moment in the film: He asks Cher a question, and she just stares, motionless and unblinking as a cobra -- an excruciatingly long and pregnant pause,'' Cintra Wilson wrote in a profile about Chaz and the movie in The New York Times. ''Then her whole posture shifts. She says, 'If I woke up tomorrow in the body of a man, I couldn't get to the surgeon fast enough.' Right then and there it occurs to her how to relate to it.'' In ''The Doc Club With Rosie O'Donnell,'' at 10:30, Chaz discusses the extremes people will go to in realizing their authentic selves. 7:30 P.M. (BET) NOTORIOUS (2009) Jamal Woolard plays the Brooklyn rapper Christopher Wallace, a k a Biggie Smalls; Angela Bassett is his mother, Voletta Wallace; and Derek Luke is Sean Combs, known then as Puffy, in this drama about the larger-than-life Smalls, who was killed in 1997 at 24. A. O. Scott, writing in The Times, said, ''Biggie Smalls's best songs are so vivid -- and the circumstances of their making are so vividly reconstructed here -- that the usual nostalgic biopic haze never settles over 'Notorious.' '' He added: ''It's half pop fable, half naturalistic docudrama. Not a bad movie, but nowhere near as strong as its soundtrack.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Sundance) JAR CITY (2006) In this moody thriller from Baltasar Kormakur, a weary homicide detective named Erlendur (Ingvar E. Sigurdsson) investigates the murder of an old man and opens up a hornet's nest of long-ago crimes and buried secrets. ''The picture of Iceland that emerges'' in the film ''is vivid and powerful but not something the country's tourist board would be likely to endorse,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The landscape has its austere poetry to be sure -- mountains framing the apartment blocks of Reykjavik, spits of volcanic rock jutting into a churning sea -- but a fog of damp unhappiness seems to pervade every face and conversation. And yet by the end of this film, based on a popular mystery novel by Arnaldur Indridason, it is hard not to feel a certain affection for the place.'' Mr. Scott described the movie as ''intricate and pointed, conjuring a haunting, satisfying puzzle out of violence and chaos.'' In Icelandic, with English subtitles. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS

headline: The Sunday Story Line
summary: To the Sports Editor: Re ''Family Values Become a Focus,'' April 12, which held that the story was the difficulty CBS had in covering the Masters on Sunday.

headline: Favorite New Films From Some Familiar Names
summary: With time running out before Hollywood's big party, perhaps you're still struggling to complete that Oscar ballot. Who better to help than some famous movie buffs? Melena Ryzik, a k a the Carpetbagger, has spoken with figures from the media and entertainment worlds for their insights. Here are snippets of those chats, which appear in full at nytimes.com/carpetbagger. Then click over to oscars.nytimes.com/ballot to see other celebrity picks and to make your choices. Katie Couric

headline: Parsing Both Red and Blue In Late-Night TV Humor
summary: They might be funny, but the late-night TV hosts are just as partisan in their jokes as the politicians they make fun of. That's the conclusion of a study by the nonpartisan Center for Media and Public Affairs at George Mason University, which calculated the percentage of jokes that comedians aimed at Democrats and at Republicans this year.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE Jim (John Krasinski) begins the search for a manager to fill the shoes of the recently departed Michael Scott in this hourlong season finale. He interviews Andy (Ed Helms) and Darryl (Craig Robinson), leaving Dwight (Rainn Wilson) to fight his way back into the game. Also under consideration are characters played by the guest stars Jim Carrey, Will Arnett, Ricky Gervais, Catherine Tate, Warren Buffett (above) and James Spader. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 10, Chris (Rob Lowe) decides to make some big changes in the parks department. At 10:30, Leslie (Amy Poehler) and her crew put together the memorial service for a deceased friend, and Tom (Aziz Ansari) makes a life-altering decision. 6:50 P.M. (Sundance) THE U.S. VS. JOHN LENNON (2006) How did John Lennon go from beloved musician to antiwar activist and inspiration for peace? And why did the United States government want to deport him? This documentary from David Leaf and John Scheinfeld covers the years from 1966 to 1976 and argues that Lennon was a better person than President Richard M. Nixon. The filmmakers share unfettered access granted by Lennon's wife, Yoko Ono, to the couple's archives and vignettes featuring some of the period's more notable figures, including Angela Davis, Bobby Seale, Walter Cronkite, G. Gordon Liddy, John Dean, Ron Kovic, Gore Vidal, Mario M. Cuomo and George McGovern.

headline: N.F.L. Game Beats World Series Broadcast
summary: Football trounced baseball in the ratings on Sunday as NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' match-up between the New Orleans Saints and the Pittsburgh Steelers easily outperformed Game 4 of the World Series on Fox. Although final audience figures were not available on Monday, Nielsen's preliminary overnight estimates for the games show them leading the night over all. ''Sunday Night Football'' drew the highest ratings, although the audience for the broadcast was nowhere near last week's record-breaking game, which drew 25.6 million viewers. Fox's ratings for the San Francisco Giants' Game 4 victory over the Texas Rangers were up slightly, compared with Thursday's Game 2, which drew 14.1 million viewers when final ratings were released. Game 3 on Saturday attracted the lowest ratings for the series by a significant margin. The two networks led the night over all, with Fox's also getting a boost from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage well into the 7 o'clock hour. CBS placed third, garnering its most viewers at 7 with ''60 Minutes'' (10.7 million) followed by the reality shows ''The Amazing Race'' (9.2 million) and ''Undercover Boss'' (10.4 million) at 8 and 9. ABC was fourth. AMC said that the premiere of its new series ''The Walking Dead'' had been watched by 5.3 million, the largest audience for an original series on the channel. (By comparison, the season finale of the AMC drama ''Mad Men'' drew 2.44 million viewers.)

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS Will Bristol Palin live up to her nickname, Bulletproof? Or will Jennifer Grey and Kyle Massey pull some tricks out of their dancing shoes in this two-hour season finale? The three remaining couples will reprise their favorite performances and receive rankings from the judges before taking part in an ''instant dance'' round, in which they will be asked to master the cha cha cha to music they've only just heard. Christina Aguilera, above, will deliver her Grammy-winning single, ''Beautiful,'' and another from her new film, ''Burlesque.'' Afterward the winner can trip the light fantastic all the way home with a mirror-ball trophy. 8 P.M. (Fox News Channel) THE O'REILLY FACTORWhoopi Goldberg meets with Bill O'Reilly for the first time since his comments on ''The View'' last month prompted her to walk off the set.

headline: What's on Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) 50 CENT: THE ORIGIN OF ME This rapper, born Curtis Jackson, left, from Jamaica, Queens, traces his ancestry to Edgefield, S.C., where his great-great-great-grandmother Jane Jenkins was the slave of a prominent citizen. While in Edgefield (the birthplace of Senator Strom Thurmond, who died in 2003), 50 Cent confronts a museum docent about the racially charged symbolism of the Confederate flag. She, in turn, informs him that some of the slaves in the area were from Mongolia -- a statement that baffles 50 Cent. ''Black citizens of this country really needs to study the history, because it's just as much the black ancestry as it is the white ancestry,'' she tells him. Later, 50 Cent responds: ''She's offering her truth, what she's accepted as the truth based on information given to her. But I don't agree with it.'' In another segment, he talks about being adopted by his grandmother after his mother, a cocaine dealer who gave birth to him at 15, was killed when he was 12. 10 A.M. (Fox); MIDNIGHT (BET) THE WENDY WILLIAMS SHOW Chandra Wilson, who plays Dr. Miranda Bailey on ''Grey's Anatomy,'' talks about the show's season finale; Lynda Carter, a k a Wonder Woman, performs her single ''Crazy Little Things.''

headline: What's On Suday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) TINA FEY: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE A writer, producer, actress and comedian, Ms. Fey, right, knows from funny. In this tribute, taped on Tuesday at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, Ms. Fey is lauded by friends and colleagues from ''30 Rock'' and ''Saturday Night Live,'' including Fred Armisen, Alec Baldwin, Steve Carell, Jimmy Fallon, Jon Hamm, Jennifer Hudson, Jane Krakowski, Steve Martin, Seth Meyers, Lorne Michaels, Tracy Morgan, Amy Poehler and Betty White. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURMadeleine K. Albright, the former secretary of state, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, debate the Obama administration's foreign policy, the role of the United States in the world, the formation of a new Iraqi coalition and the chances for a bipartisan foreign policy in the new Congress.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE MIDDLE An evening of season finales begins as Frankie (Patricia Heaton) anticipates the end of the school year. That is, until she realizes that Brick (Atticus Shaffer, above, with Ms. Heaton) has three days to complete a big assignment he has put off for the year or risk being held back in the third grade by Ms. Rinsky (Doris Roberts). Meanwhile, Axl (Charlie McDermott) has failed to fulfill his required 30 days of community service. And Sue (Eden Sher) must prove that she never took a sick day from school to receive a perfect-attendance award at her graduation ceremony. In ''Modern Family,'' at 9, all that Jay (Ed O'Neill) wants for his birthday is a quiet day fishing on the lake. But everyone else insists on a big celebration. While planning the blowout, Claire (Julie Bowen) and Mitchell (Jesse Tyler Ferguson) end up trapped in the yard of their childhood home; Phil (Ty Burrell) runs into his college nemesis at the mall; and Cameron (Eric Stonestreet) finds his bakery expedition anything but a piece of cake. Now Jay's head won't stop throbbing. In ''Cougar Town,'' at 9:30, Jules (Courteney Cox) and the gang head to Hawaii for a vacation after Travis (Dan Byrd) makes a hasty decision to move there. And in ''Happy Endings,'' at 10:30, the group faces unexpected consequences after receiving a sudden invitation to the wedding of an old friend (T. J. Miller). 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW After 25 years of hosting this talk show, Ms. Winfrey, left, bids farewell.

headline: For Sale
summary: $6.9 MILLION 1500 Hempstead Turnpike (at the Meadowbrook State Parkway)

headline: Identity Theft And Copiers
summary: While it's common knowledge that leaving sensitive personal information in trash bins or on computers raises the risk of identity theft, many consumers may not be aware that copying sensitive information on certain copy machines could also put them at risk. Last month, CBS News highlighted the identity theft threat from copiers in an investigative report ''Copy Machines, a Security Risk?''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (BET, Centric) 2010 SOUL TRAIN AWARDS Anita Baker, above, and Ron Isley are honored as living legends by some of their peers, including Lalah Hathaway, Faith Evans, Rachelle Ferrell, Kem, Tamia, El DeBarge, Chrisette Michele, Freddie Jackson, Jeffrey Osborne and Peabo Bryson, at this event, taped on Nov. 10 at the Cobb Energy Performing Arts Center in Atlanta. Performers include Bilal, Bruno Mars, Cee Lo Green, Chanté Moore, Dionne Farris, Eric Benét, Erykah Badu, Goapele, Gyptian, Jazmine Sullivan, Keyshia Cole, Ne-Yo, R. Kelly and Tank. Also onstage: the CNN host Wolf Blitzer, who gets a lesson in dancing the Dougie from Doug E. Fresh himself. Terrence Howard and Taraji P. Henderson are the hosts. The stroll down the purple carpet for the festivities kicks off at 8, on BET. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses North Korea, ''don't ask, don't tell'' and the future of Congress. Also, new excerpts from a taped interview with former President George W. Bush and his brother Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor.

headline: Citadel Says It Is in Talks To Be Sold
summary: 7:22 p.m. | Updated Citadel Broadcasting said on Thursday it was in talks to sell itself to a smaller rival, Cumulus Media, for about $2.5 billion in cash and stock.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (Cooking) FROM SPAIN WITH LOVE Annie Sibonney, above, eats her way through Spain on an odyssey that takes her from the beaches of Mallorca to the rugged Pyrenees, with stops in the fishing villages of Galicia and cosmopolitan Madrid. Her journey begins in Basque country, a fiercely independent region with an inventive cuisine and, she says, more cooks per capita than anywhere else in the world. In this series premiere, Ms. Sibonney breaks through barriers at a men's-only gastronomic society; samples cod kokotxas, her favorite Basque dish; partakes in a ''tapas crawl''; and cooks alongside the chef Juan Mari Arzak, considered the godfather of modern Basque cuisine. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Dr. James M. Oleske, a pediatric infectious disease specialist in Newark, describes his mission to provide palliative and hospice care for young children.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Beyoncé and Brad Paisley will headline this 35th annual spectacle, in which 40,000 shells -- about 1,500 a minute -- are scheduled to explode from six barges on the Hudson River. Nick Lachey is host of the show, whose theme, ''Gift of Freedom,'' recognizes the 125th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty. 3 P.M. (Starz) PRINCE OF PERSIA: THE SANDS OF TIME (2010) The producer Jerry Bruckheimer helps transform a video game into a swords-sandals-and-sorcery spectacular starring Jake Gyllenhaal as the warrior of the title, an adopted son of an ancient king. Gemma Arterton is the pouty princess who joins forces with him to safeguard a supernatural dagger; Alfred Molina plays a wisecracking sheik; and Ben Kingsley is the king's suspicious brother. ''For the most part this is perfectly painless mush,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''If nothing else, it's entertaining to think about how this mash-up of ancient Persian heroics and headline news might sit with the Iranian powers that be. In March 2009 a spokesman for the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, demanded an apology from Hollywood for 'insults and accusations against the Iranian nation' over the last 30 years. Clearly they had no idea they were about to be Bruckheimer-ed.''

headline: Stumping for Others, As Her Own Support Dips
summary: With the Republican primary season in the books, and her field of endorsed candidates either heading off to the general election or going back to the drawing board, Sarah Palin is stepping up her presence on the campaign trail to help Republicans raise money. She appeared with Rand Paul on Thursday in Louisville, Ky., where he is locked in a competitive race for the United States Senate. She is scheduled to be the headliner at the Republican Party of Iowa's annual Reagan Dinner on Friday evening. Yet despite her increased visibility in the midterm election campaign, about half of voters surveyed in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll said an endorsement from Ms. Palin would not influence their decisions at the ballot box. Only one in 10 said her support would make them more likely to support a candidate.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) RACE AND HOLLYWOOD: ARAB IMAGES IN FILM Robert Osborne and Jack G. Shaheen, the author of ''Reel Bad Arabs: How Hollywood Vilifies a People,'' host this monthlong series focusing on depictions of Arabs on the screen. This installment begins with ''Adventure in Iraq'' (1943), in which an airplane carrying an estranged American couple (John Loder and Ruth Ford) during World War II is forced to land in the Iraqi desert, where its passengers are captured by a sect of Devil worshipers who plan to sacrifice them in exchange for three brothers about to be executed for espionage by the British. The evening continues with ''Action in Arabia'' (1944), in which an American newspaper correspondent (George Sanders) tangles with Nazis in Damascus, at 9:30; ''Sirocco'' (1951), starring Humphrey Bogart as a mysterious American who gets mixed up with gunrunners in Syria, at 11; ''Trunk to Cairo'' (1966), in which a secret agent (Audie Murphy) takes on neo-Nazis running a munitions factory in Egypt, at 1 a.m.; and ''Sinbad the Sailor'' (1947), with Douglas Fairbanks Jr. (above) as the Arabian Nights hero seeking the lost treasure of Alexander the Great, at 3:30. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) THE GREAT DINOSAUR ESCAPE Using recent scientific research and computer-generated effects, this two-hour special follows a herd of dinosaurs -- in particular, a young and vulnerable Edmontosaurus named Scar -- as it migrates from summering grounds at the North Pole across 1,000 miles of hostile terrain to escape the winter. ''Jurassic C.S.I.: In Living Color,'' at 10, watches as the ''dino detective'' Phil Manning uses highly focused X-ray beams to search for traces of color pigments in fossils like that of the Archaeopteryx, a magpie-size bird with teeth.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International ITALY MIGHT HAVE TO CUT ITS VACATION SHORT

headline: Streisand to Perform At the Grammys
summary: 12:10 p.m. | Updated The Grammy Awards on Sunday will feature lots and lots of youth, with performances by Justin Bieber, Katy Perry, Drake, Rihanna, Miranda Lambert, Lady Gaga, Bruno Mars, B.o.B. and Janelle Monae, none of whom are older than 27. And then there's Jaden Smith, age 12.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $47.50/SQUARE FOOT $530,147 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (NBC) THE ROAD BACK In this special edition of ''Dateline NBC,'' Tom Brokaw follows three families -- American, Iraqi and Iraqi-American -- through the war in Iraq, starting in 2002, before the United States invaded that country and removed Saddam Hussein from power, and up to the present, as the United States prepares to withdraw its military forces. In his report Mr. Brokaw reveals what happened to the families and asks whether the war was worth it. ''Nobody wants to go to war, nobody,'' says Staff Sgt. Charles Weaver (above with his wife, Dawn, and Mr. Brokaw) of the Second Brigade, Third Infantry Division, in Iraq. ''But if you have to do it, you do whatever you have to do.'' Dr. El Rabei, the patriarch of an Iraqi family, counters, ''I would rather be dead than see American troops in the streets of Iraq and Baghdad.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews Robert S. Ford, the American ambassador to Syria, about the uprising in the country and its effect on the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: NOON (Fox Movie) NIAGARA (1953) Marilyn Monroe and Niagara Falls are both shining stars of this dramatic thriller. Honeymooners Polly (Jean Peters) and Ray Cutler (Casey Adams) arrive at their cottage by the falls to find that Rose (Monroe) and George Loomis (Joseph Cotten, above with Monroe) have not yet checked out. The Cutlers take temporary accommodations, and the two couples' lives quickly become intertwined, making secrets harder to keep. Polly soon discovers that Rose is cheating on her husband and that his jealous rage is likely justified, although he does seem a bit unstable. And George's uneven personality is caused by Rose's openly lascivious behavior around other men, which is part of her plan. You see, Rose's lover, Patrick (Richard Allan), is to murder George, and it will appear to be the unsurprising suicide or disappearance of a temperamental man. Murder plots rarely go according to plan, however. At 1:30 is the whodunit film noir ''I Wake Up Screaming,'' (1941) starring Betty Grable, Victor Mature and Carole Landis. Frankie (Mature), a promoter, has been accused of murdering Vicky (Landis), a model and aspiring actress. Frankie and Vicky's sister, Jill (Grable), are interrogated for hours and their answers turned into flashbacks reveal the plot. A very eager cop played by Laird Cregar torments and pressures Frankie, and circumstantial evidence against the suspect starts to pile up. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Daniel Craig, Don Cheadle and Aretha Franklin are guests. A paralyzed bride gets married. And the New York Yankees gear up for their 2011 Hope Week, a five-day community service program. The team will recognize an individual, family or organization worthy of recognition and support, each day.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BEHRMAN, STANLEY J.
summary: BEHRMAN--Stanley J.,DMD., former professor of surgery and chief of dentistry, oral and maxillofacial surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center, and prominent New York surgeon, Dr. Stanley J. Behrman passed away comfortably on January 30th after a short battle with colon cancer. He is remembered by his former colleagues and residents for his 55 years of both clinical and academic excellence. During his tenure as Chief his abilities to teach, innovate upon, and improve jaw surgery led to significant advances in his specialty of Orthodontics. The generations of surgeons he trained, and patients he helped with his advanced and specialized techniques, are his legacy. A graduate of New York University and the University of Pittsburgh School of Dentistry, Dr. Behrman was one of the founders of the technique of intra-oral surgical manipulation of the upper and or lower jaw to correct deformities, improved the esthetic appearance, and improved the occlusion or, bite. Dr. Behrman was a practitioner and life long friend to many celebrated personalities. Amongst others this included the star, Betty Davis. He was able to preserve her mandible from a severe bone infection as she was performing on Broadway. He was acclaimed throughout the media, appearing on television numerous times and including the CBS special, The Body Human-The Body Beautiful. He is survived by his wife Marla, stepson Peter Grayson and his wife Josephine, grandsons Bradley and Eric, and brother Lawrence. He lived his life generously, intelligently, and faithfully and gave life a rich and purposeful meaning. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. For information please call: 917-596-7174. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach.

For information please call: 917-596-7174. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach.

headline: Mick Jagger to Perform Solo at the Grammys
summary: Mick Jagger will perform at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 13, his first-ever solo performance at the show. He will be paying tribute to his hero Solomon Burke, who died in October, as part of the ceremony's ''In Memoriam'' segment, the Recording Academy announced. Other performers already scheduled for the show, which will be broadcast live on CBS: Eminem, Lady Gaga, Arcade Fire, Justin Bieber and Usher, Katy Perry, and the very intriguing combination of Cee Lo Green with Gwyneth Paltrow and the Jim Henson Company Puppets. Mr. Jagger's appearance will likely stir further speculation about whether the Rolling Stones will go on tour later this year or next. The music industry has been abuzz for months with rumors about a possible tour, which have been stoked by a legal dispute between two potential promoters, Live Nation and Michael Cohl, the former Live Nation executive (and current lead producer of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'') who has been a longtime promoter of the band's tours. Late last year Live Nation sued Mr. Cohl over an agreement that allowed him to work with the Stones, and this week The Hollywood Reporter said that Mr. Cohl had countersued, asserting his rights for a tour timed to the band's 50th anniversary. (It was founded in 1962.)

headline: PRIME (AND NOT-SO-PRIME) TIME | SEPT. 19 - 25
summary: THE NEWSJennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, and Steven Tyler,the lead singer for Aerosmith, joined the panel of judges on ''American Idol,'' remaking the hit show on Fox. BEHIND THE NEWS The singing-competition show is being retooled for its 10th season after the departures of Ellen DeGeneres, Kara DioGuardi and the longtime house curmudgeon, Simon Cowell. Producers hope that the new judges will pump fresh energy into the show, which begins airing in January. Though ''Idol'' is still America's most-watched entertainment show, its ratings have flagged in recent years.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 7 P.M. (ABC) I.AM.FIRST: SCIENCE IS ROCK AND ROLL Will.i.am of the Black Eyed Peas, above with microphone, and Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway PT (for personal transporter), team up in this look at the 20th-annual First (as in ''For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology'') Championship, a worldwide K-through-12 competition promoting education, science and robotics. Filmed before an audience of 30,000 at the Edward Jones Dome in St. Louis, the program features performances by the Black Eyed Peas and Willow Smith, and appearances by other performers, including Justin Bieber, Jack Black, Bono, Miranda Cosgrove, Miley Cyrus, Josh Duhamel, Britney Spears, Snoop Dogg, Justin Timberlake and Steven Tyler, who speak on behalf of ''stem'' (science, technology, engineering and math) education. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota and a 2012 presidential candidate, makes the rounds of the morning news shows, starting with this report on the results of the Iowa Republican Party Ames Straw Poll. Herman Cain, another candidate, is also a guest. Ms. Bachmann and the candidate Tim Pawlenty, a former governor of Minnesota, speak with Jake Tapper on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC. Ms. Bachmann also talks with Chris Wallace on ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10; with Norah O'Donnell on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and with David Gregory on ''Meet the Press,'' also at 10:30, on NBC.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) THE USO PRESENTS: VH1 DIVAS SALUTE THE TROOPS Katy Perry, Nicki Minaj, Keri Hilson, Paramore, Sugarland and Grace Potter & the Nocturnals (above) serenade active-duty, reserve and retired Marines and their guests at the Marine Corps Air Station Miramar in San Diego. ''After having had the honor of performing for our troops in Iraq and Afghanistan, it gives me great pleasure to host an evening for them where they can really blow off some steam,'' said Kathy Griffin, the show's M.C., promising, '' I will not hold back.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, and Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas, about Congressional fiscal deliberations.

headline: Poll Shows Negative View of Tea Party Is on the Rise
summary: Little more than a year ago, most Americans did not know enough about the Tea Party to have an opinion. Now, more people have opinions, and they are hardly positive. The percentage of people with an unfavorable view of the Tea Party in a New York Times/CBS News Poll this week was higher than it has been since the first time the question was asked, in April 2010. Forty percent of those polled this week characterized their view as ''not favorable,'' compared with 18 percent in the first poll.

headline: A Poll of Ohio Voters
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that economic anxieties weigh heavy for Ohioans as they determine which political candidates will receive their votes in this year's midterm elections.

headline: GAME DAY GUIDE
summary: Also: Louisville at Rutgers, 11 a.m., ESPN2; Colorado at 16 Nebraska, 3:30 p.m., ABC

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (SNY) GOING HOME: DAVID WRIGHT Wright, above, the Mets' third baseman, travels to his hometown, Chesapeake, Va., with the field reporter Kevin Burkhardt, where the two visit Wright's high school. There he excelled as an athlete and aspired to become an engineer but ultimately turned down a scholarship to Georgia Tech to go pro -- making sure his contract stipulated that his college tuition would be paid for after he retires. The men also look at Wright's off-season hitting program and charitable endeavors and visit with his family, where his brother Daniel does a humorous imitation of David answering questions after a game. The Mets' spring training match-up against the Washington Nationals leads in at 7. 6:30 P.M. (ABC) ABC WORLD NEWS WITH DIANE SAWYER ''Made in America,'' a new segment, challenges viewers to remove products manufactured abroad from their homes and replace them with those made in the United States. It also asks: Is buying American products more expensive? What is no longer manufactured in the United States? And what difference would it make if everyone promised to buy more products made at home? David Muir and Sharyn Alfonsi report.

headline: 2010 Emmy Awards
summary: Here is a partial list of this year's winners. Comedy Series: ''Modern Family'' (ABC)

headline: Tennessee Senator Takes a Stand for Compromise
summary: WASHINGTON - Insiders could spot the constraints on Lamar Alexander in the Senate at least six years ago, as the two parties fought over judicial nominations. After a series of Democratic filibusters against the nominees of President George W. Bush, Senator Alexander helped start the bipartisan ''Gang of 14'' that worked to forestall the Republicans' ''nuclear option,'' which would have eliminated the use of filibusters to block judicial appointments. But he could not publicly join the group.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) ME FACING LIFE: CYNTOIA'S STORY In August 2004 Cyntoia Brown, 16, shot and killed Johnny Allen, a 43-year-old Tennessee real estate agent she said had picked her up for sex. Two years later Ms. Brown -- who had been born to a 16-year-old and adopted as a toddler -- was tried as an adult, found guilty of first-degree murder and especially aggravated robbery, and sentenced to life. In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Daniel H. Birman follows Ms. Brown, above, for six years, starting the week she was arrested, in the hope of exposing the reasons for violence among youth. What he discovered was a history, seemingly shaped by heredity and circumstance, that had repeated itself through each generation of Ms. Brown's biological family. 5:30 P.M. (Cinemax) FUNNY PEOPLE (2009) In this film from Judd Apatow, Adam Sandler plays George Simmons, a stand-up comedian turned Hollywood star and jerk, who discovers that he has a rare, potentially fatal blood disease. Seth Rogen is Ira, the fledgling comic George hires as an assistant, who for the time being seems only too content to accept scraps from his employer. Mr. Apatow's wife, Leslie Mann, plays Laura, the love who got away from George, and the one he wants back now that he's dying. (The Apatows' daughters play Laura's children.) Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said there was ''something irritatingly self-satisfied'' about the film, partly stemming from the autobiographical touches. ''Watching 'Funny People,' you get the sense that Mr. Apatow, one of the most successful filmmakers working in Hollywood, is very happy,'' she wrote. ''Bummer.''

headline: Vieira Is Said to Consider Leaving 'Today'
summary: Meredith Vieira, the co-host of NBC's ''Today'' show, is likely to leave the top-rated morning show this year, two people with knowledge of her deliberations said Tuesday. Ms. Vieira's contract ends in September, and she has made no secret that she dislikes the early morning wake-up calls and the stress of the position. She has not notified NBC of a decision, but is leaning toward leaving, according to the people, who insisted on anonymity to avoid affecting the outcome. If Ms. Vieira, 57, does leave, the news anchor on ''Today,'' Ann Curry, 54, would be a leading contender to replace her.

headline: Among Many Worthies, Who Should Win Emmys
summary: Outstanding Drama Series ''Breaking Bad'' (AMC); ''Dexter'' (Showtime); ''The Good Wife'' (CBS); ''Lost'' (ABC); ''Mad Men'' (AMC); ''True Blood'' (HBO)

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE She may be pushing 40, as the choristers are quick to point out, but Gwyneth Paltrow, foreground above, earns a little respect in her guest role as a substitute teacher who fills in for an indisposed Mr. Schuester (Matthew Morrison) and proves she can rock out with the best of them. Meanwhile, Sue (Jane Lynch) stands in for Principal Figgins (Iqbal Theba) and starts feeling extra powerful. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Emma Watson promotes ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1''; Rascal Flatts performs. Also, a look at some Thanksgiving Day parade floats.

headline: More Gay Characters On TV, Study Finds
summary: In a study released on Wednesday, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said that the number of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender characters on television had reached a new high in the new season. On the broadcast networks, there are 23 gay characters this season, representing 3.9 percent of all series regulars on scripted shows, the group said, up from 3 percent last year. The group, which has tabulated the number of gay characters for 15 years, said it was pleased by the progress but pointed to several areas where it felt the networks could improve. On scripted network television this season, it found, there are no gay characters who are black and no transgender characters.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE OLD CORRAL (1936) Gene Autry, right, was a man of many talents who wore many hats, most famously a Stetson, during his 91 years. He is the only entertainer to have been given five stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame -- one each for radio, recordings, film, television and live theatrical performance. He wrote and sang the holiday tune ''Here Comes Santa Claus,'' among others. From 1961 to 1997 he owned the Angels, the Major League Baseball team in Anaheim, Calif., that has gone through a few name changes through the years, and he served as the vice president of the American League from 1983 until his death in 1998. Here, Autry basks in the Turner Classic Movies spotlight of a monthlong celebration of singing cowboys. First up, he plays a sheriff who helps a blues singer (Hope Manning) after she witnesses the murder of a nightclub owner. At 9, Autry portrays a border inspector keeping livestock with hoof-and-mouth disease from entering the United States in ''Home on the Prairie.'' At 10:15, he plays a rancher who finds copper and is framed in a jailbreak with Tom Bennett (Edward Norris) in ''Back in the Saddle.'' At 11:45, he tries to stop a ring of lottery-ticket counterfeiters in ''Texans Never Cry.'' And at 1 a.m., he hunts for the payroll stolen from the Army in ''Wagon Team.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) FLASHPOINT Ed Lane (Hugh Dillon) goes to the hospital after being shot, and the Strategic Response Unit's Team One uncovers a trail of opium imported from Afghanistan while tracking down the shooter. Victor Garber reprises his guest role as the military psychologist who puts the team members through their paces.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (OWN) CARSON NATION Carson Kressley (above with Kelli, center, and Carmen), known for helping style-challenged men in ''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy,'' throws a dart at a map and goes to the town in America where it lands to help residents there discover what makes them look good on the outside and feel good on the inside. Tonight he travels to Scottsdale, Ariz., where a stay-at-home mom gets a makeover and a middle-age man battling shyness learns how to approach women. Also, Mr. Kressley helps a transgender woman who has lived as a man for 60 years. 8 P.M. (CBS) CHAOS The season's next-to-last episode of this series that follows the Clandestine Administration and Oversight Services group within the Central Intelligence Agency centers on undercover agents working to keep a ruthless son from succeeding his ailing father as a Middle Eastern dictator.

headline: The Lost Decade That Wasn't
summary: When people talk about being a buy-and-hold investor these days, they are often confronted by others who declare that the last 10 years were a ''lost decade.'' When I wrote about the power of compound interest a few weeks ago, many of the comments focused on this idea that the decade ending on Dec. 31, 2010 was the decade of lost money for most investors. Not surprisingly, people then take the next step and say that it could continue, and the United States could end up looking like Japan - 25 years of negative or flat stock market performance.

headline: Voters Want a Change Politicians Can't Deliver
summary: WASHINGTON - Here is the bad news forPresident Obama and incumbents in both parties: it can get worse - and stay that way for a long time. That might sound like catastrophic thinking after Mr. Obama's nerve-jangling birthday week, during which he got several gag gifts: a near default, a 500-point market drop and the first-ever downgrade of United States debt by a major credit ratings agency.

headline: Patricia Thompson, 63, TV Producer and Documentarian
summary: PARIS -- Patricia Thompson, a Paris-based American television producer and an Emmy-winning documentary filmmaker, died here on Monday. She was 63. The cause was a cerebral hemorrhage, her husband, Jim Bittermann, a CNN correspondent, said.

headline: David Nevin, 83, the Author Of Rousing Historical Novels
summary: David Nevin, an author of historical novels, including the best-seller ''Dream West,'' the epic tale of John Charles Frémont's role in the opening of the American West, died on Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, his wife, Luciana, said. Mr. Nevin lived in Greenwich and died at a nursing home there.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 68TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDSRicky Gervais returns as host of this ceremony -- considered a predictor of the Oscars -- sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles. Nominees include ''Black Swan,'' ''The Fighter,'' ''Inception,'' ''The King's Speech'' and ''The Social Network'' (best picture); Halle Berry, Nicole Kidman, Jennifer Lawrence, Natalie Portman and Michelle Williams (best actress in a motion picture -- drama); Jesse Eisenberg, Colin Firth, James Franco, Ryan Gosling and Mark Wahlberg (best actor in a motion picture -- drama); and ''Biutiful,'' ''The Concert,'' ''The Edge,'' ''I Am Love'' and ''In a Better World'' (best foreign language film). Robert De Niro will be honored with the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement. Gia Mantegna, the daughter of the actor Joe Mantegna, is Miss Golden Globe. Red carpet coverage begins at 7. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR In a special ''town hall'' edition, ''After the Tragedy: An American Conversation,'' survivors of the ''Congress on Your Corner'' event in Tucson, where a gunman opened fire, reunite to discuss what happened that day. (Jared L. Loughner has been charged in the shootings.) David Muir, an ABC News anchor, will lead an audience discussion about the current state of America and the difficult questions raised by the tragedy.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: CLARK GABLE IN COLOR Robert Osborne and Alec Baldwin explain why this lineup is required viewing, beginning with ''The Misfits'' (1961), which stars Marilyn Monroe (below, with Clark Gable) as Roslyn Taber, a freshly divorced showgirl, and Gable as Gay Langland, a ruggedly independent cowboy intent on joining an auto mechanic (Eli Wallach) and a rodeo performer (Montgomery Clift) in a plan to rope mustangs -- known as misfits, because they're too small for riding -- in the Nevada desert and sell them for dog food. Directed by John Huston and written by Arthur Miller, the film is considered a pioneer in the evolution of the American western, with its more contemporary, bleaker outlook. ''Westerns and the West have always been built on a morally balanced world where evil has a recognizable tab -- the black hats -- and evil always loses out in the end,'' Miller wrote. ''This is that same world, but it's been dragged out of the 19th century into today, when the good guy is also part of the problem.'' Among the movie's memorable lines: Gay's declaration that ''the man who's too afraid to die is too afraid to live.'' (Gable died just weeks after completing the film.) The evening continues into the wee hours with Gable as a big-game hunter in Kenya in ''Mogambo'' (1953), at 10:15; a slave owner in ''Band of Angels'' (1957), at 12:15 a.m.; a Dutch intelligence officer in ''Betrayed'' (1954), at 2:30; and a con man who seduces widows in ''The King and Four Queens'' (1956), at 4:30. NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Bill Moyers discusses his latest book, ''Bill Moyers Journal: The Conversation Continues,'' and opens up about President Lyndon B. Johnson, whom he served as press secretary.

headline: GAME DAY GUIDE
summary: INDIANA at 6 WISCONSIN - Noon, ESPN2; --- ; It is crowded at the top of the Big Ten, and the Badgers need to keep winning to stay in the mix. GEORGIA at 2 AUBURN- 3:30 p.m., CBS; ---- Will off-the-field distractions derail Auburn's national title hopes?

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLOMB, DORRIS GAINES
summary: GOLOMB--Dorris Gaines, died clear-minded, peacefully on September 22, 2010, her adoring husband Leon by her side. Staunch supporter of her beloved Fort Greene's art, business, and architecture. Ranking member of the Fort Greene Association, Historic Districts Council, CB2. Herbert Scott-Gibson Lifetime Achievement Award. A Southern belle, lavender hat engaging smile, loving "fun fun fun," Dorris' Grace will always be felt. In lieu of memorial donations can be sent to the Fort Greene Association.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLOMB, DORRIS
summary: GOLOMB--Dorris Gaines, died clear-minded, peacefully on September 22, 2010, her adoring husband Leon by her side. Staunch supporter of her beloved Fort Greene's art, business, and architecture. Ranking member of the Fort Greene Association, Historic Districts Council, CB2. Herbert Scott-Gibson Lifetime Achievement Award. A Southern belle, lavender hat engaging smile, loving "fun fun fun," Dorris' Grace will always be felt. In lieu of memorial donations can be sent to the Fort Greene Association.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MICHEL, WERNER
summary: MICHEL--Werner, Broadway writer/producer, television producer and long-time advertising agency program/media executive died peacefully a few weeks after celebrating his 100th birthday, on August 27th, 2010. He leaves his beloved wife of 41 years, Rosemary. Born in 1910 in Detmold, Germany, his early years were in Berlin. He earned his Ph.D. in musicology at the Sorbonne. He and his brother came to the United States just prior to the outbreak of WWII. After studying with Kurt Weill, he wrote and produced two musical reviews: "Reunion in New York" and "Reunion in Vienna." John Houseman brought him to Voice of America, where he was the Director. Later, he was Executive Producer at Dumont Television, and later worked on the Soap, Edge of Night at CBS, through Benton and Bowles. Various assignments at CBS including working on the Evening News with Walter Cronkite. He moved back to the Agency side working in programming at Reach, McClinton and SSC&B, where he supervised the Lucy Show for Lever Brothers. Fred Silverman brought him to ABC as a consultant. Later at MGM he was a producer of two successful television shows, "FAME" and "CHiPs". After retirement, he worked at Bozell & Jacobs. Werner was unique. He was passionate, but very critical. He always called it as he saw it, regardless of the political ramifications. He will be greatly missed.
