headline: GAME DAY GUIDE
summary: Also: Florida at 22 F.S.U., 3:30 p.m. ESPN; Northwestern at 5 Wis., 3:30, ABC; 18 S. Carolina at Clemson, 7 p.m., ESPN; Notre Dame at U.S.C., 8 p.m., ABC (*Regional) 11 MICHIGAN STATE at PENN STATE; NOON, ESPN2; --- ; There's a complicated three-way tie at the top of the Big Ten. Will this one help break it?

headline: Corrections
summary: A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about an agreement for CBS to continue televising the Tony Awards ceremony through 2013 erroneously included a Broadway trade association as a founder of the awards. While the Broadway League now presents them with the American Theater Wing, the league was not a founder. (The theater wing created the awards.)

headline: Site for '60 Minutes' to Take Viewers Into the Back Stories
summary: When a journalist recounts a just-completed interview to a friend or a colleague, ''you don't tell him the narrative of your story, you tell him what the person was like,'' said Bill Owens, the executive editor of ''60 Minutes,'' the CBS news magazine. ''60 Minutes'' is applying that insight to a new part of the CBSNews.com Web site, ''60 Minutes Overtime.'' It will feature behind-the-scenes segments about the stories told weekly on television. CBS has signed up a prominent sponsor, Pfizer, for the Web site, which started on Sunday, the day of the television program's 43rd season premiere.

headline: Debt Drama Overshadows The Big Picture
summary: 9:42 p.m. | Updated As Washington continues to debate a debt deal, the Obama administration has been preparing the country for the worst, with officials essentially saying the sky is about to fall.

headline: MTV Defends 'Skins' as Six Advertisers, Heeding an Outcry, Withdraw From Series
summary: The second episode of MTV's ''Skins'' suffered a dramatic drop in the ratings this week, to 1.6 million viewers from 3.3 million the prior week, as a half-dozen advertisers publicly distanced themselves from the provocative new drama series. Since the sexual content of the series came under scrutiny last week, General Motors, the Wm. Wrigley Jr. division of Mars, the Taco Bell division of Yum Brands, H&R Block, the Schick division of Energizer Holdings and Subway restaurants have all withdrawn from the series. Others that were in the debut episode on Jan. 17 were not back in the second episode on Monday, among them Foot Locker.

headline: Golf Commentary, No Whispering
summary: A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Feherty's half-interview, half-improv weekly show, ''Feherty,'' will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Feherty's 2002 novel, ''A Nasty Bit of Rough.'' Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.Q.How would you describe your new show? A.A televised nervous breakdown is the way it feels at the moment. I've been on TV for 15 years now, but it's never been anything I can be held completely responsible for. We're going to try various different things and see what the reaction is. Some of it will be serious. Some of it won't. There'll be an interview every week because I'm interested in other people's opinions. I just interviewedCharles Barkley, who was hysterical.Q.Is there anyone on TV you'd like to model yourself after?A.I'm a huge Billy Connolly fan, always have been. I like Ricky Gervais, Bob Newhart; people who are more observers. We've gotten to the stage today if you want comedy, you watch the news, and if you want news, you turn to the comedy channel. It's gotten turned upside down. Q.Whom do you like to win the United States Open next weekend?A.Steve Stricker has got to be one of the favorites. Although he shouldn't be able to win any tournaments. He's too nice. [Laughs.] He's a sweetheart.

headline: U.S. to Send Condolences After Suicides In War Zones
summary: For several administrations at least, the White House has declined to send letters of condolence to families of troops who committed suicide, even if those suicides occurred in combat zones. The policy was based on concerns within military circles that recognizing such deaths would encourage more suicides. But it infuriated many of those families, who felt they should have received the same kinds of letters sent to families of every service member killed in action.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MICHAEL JACKSON: A MOTHER'S STORY In her first televised interview since Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, his mother, Katherine, left, speaks with Sonia Lowe in this two-hour edition of ''Dateline NBC.'' On Ms. Jackson's mind: who she thinks is responsible for her son's death; his belief that people wanted him dead; how his three children are coping without their father, and her relationship with them; and how the Jackson family will be commemorating this day. She also responds to accusations that Mr. Jackson was a child molester and rumors that his former wife Debbie Rowe wants custody of the children. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE KING OF POP: ONE YEAR LATER This special installment of ''The Early Show'' features a performance of Michael Jackson's hit ''Man in the Mirror'' by James Morrison and remembrances from Christina Aguilera, Marc Anthony, L L Cool J, Smokey Robinson and John Landis, who directed the videos for ''Thriller'' and ''Black or White.'' ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 on ABC, also salutes Jackson; Alicia Keys performs.

headline: John Boehner? Who's That?
summary: Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, is in line to succeed Nancy Pelosi as House speaker if Republicans win control of the House in the midterm elections, making him one of the most powerful figures in government. Yet few voters in his own home state even have an opinion about him, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll in Ohio has found. About 7 in 10 Ohio voters expressed no opinion about Mr. Boehner, either favorable or unfavorable, including most Republican voters. Among the rest, there was a nearly even split, with 15 percent offering a positive view of Mr. Boehner, who has served in the House since 1991, and 16 percent a negative one.

headline: Sheen, Seeking More Than $100 Million, Sues His TV Show's Creator and Warner Brothers
summary: Charlie Sheen escalated his war with the creator of his hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men'' and the studio that produces it by filing a suit Thursday demanding more than $100 million in damages for first halting production on episodes planned for this season and then removing him from the show. The suit, which was obtained and posted by the celebrity gossip Web site TMZ, is in response to the decision this week by the studio, Warner Brothers, to fire Mr. Sheen from the comedy, citing both his behavior, which has included drug use and accusations of violence toward women, and his comments about the show's creator, Chuck Lorre, and studio executives.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) 31 DAYS OF OSCAR Day 2 of this tribute salutes Jack Nicholson (the most nominated actor: 12 nods and three wins) with four of his best-known films, starting with ''Five Easy Pieces'' (1970), in which he plays a classical pianist who returns to his upper-class family after dropping out of society to work in a California oil field, above. The evening continues with ''Terms of Endearment'' (1983), at 10, for which Mr. Nicholson won the best supporting actor award for his role as a womanizing astronaut who is not as bad as he seems. ''Easy Rider'' (1969) follows at 12:30 a.m., in which he portrays George Hanson, an alcoholic civil rights lawyer who shares a cell with Wyatt and Billy, the motorcyclists played by Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper. ''The Last Detail'' (1973) is broadcast at 2:15, in which he stars as Buddusky, a Navy lifer who, with his fellow escort (Otis Young), decides to show a young prisoner (Randy Quaid) a good time on his way to the brig. 9 A.M. (Fox News Channel) AMERICA'S NEWSROOM Martha MacCallum talks with David Axelrod, a former senior White House adviser, about the crisis in Egypt, his experience in the White House and his impressions of potential opponents President Obama may face in 2012. The interview will conclude on Thursday.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL VII Some of the cutest bruisers around, like the pair above, including ''spunky spaniels, pouncing pit bulls and bustling bassets,'' according to Animal Planet, go in for tackles, fumbles and ''Fido first downs'' (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy), at Animal Planet Stadium. Aerial coverage of the pups, plucked from shelters, will be provided by the Ice Breakers blimp and its hamster crew. Sloppier ground-level angles will be offered by the ever-popular water-bowl camera, joined this year by the Puppy Cam, to watch the action from the players' perspective, and the Kiss Cam, for some not-to-be-missed slobbers between man and his best friends. Chicken cheerleaders will lead the clucking from the sidelines. Not to be overlooked: the Kitty Halftime Show. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE In a live report from Cowboys Stadium in Arlington, Tex., Mr. Wallace interviews Roger Goodell, the National Football League commissioner; Lynn Swann, the former Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver; and Jerry Kramer, the former Green Bay Packers offensive lineman.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) POWER RANGERS: SAMURAI A new generation of Rangers must master the ancient samurai symbols of power, for control over fire, water, sky, forest and earth, in this newfangled adaptation of the popular children's series. Under the guidance of their mentor, Ji (Rene Naufahu), and with the help of their devoted animal zords, the Rangers battle to save Earth from the dark forces of the Netherworld ruled by the evil Master Xandred. Jayden (Alex Heartman) is the Red Ranger and the team's leader; Mia (Erika Fong) is the big-sisterish Pink Ranger; Kevin (Najee De-Tiege), the Blue Ranger, is an expert swordsman who adheres to a strict code of living; Emily (Brittany Pirtle) is the ever-optimistic Yellow Ranger; and Mike (Hector David Jr.), the Green Ranger, is a rebel who would rather be destroying video monsters than real ones. In this premiere episode Mike takes on a long-armed creature named Rofer. 7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIOColin Firth, the favorite to win the best actor Oscar for his portrayal of the stammering George VI in ''The King's Speech,'' traces his career in an interview with James Lipton.

headline: Corrections
summary: REAL ESTATE The ''In the Region'' article in Westchester and Connecticut copies on Dec. 12, about the improving market for high-end houses in northern Westchester, gave a broker's incorrect identification of the brokerage that held the listing on a home in Mount Kisco, N.Y., that sold for $3.2 million. It was Houlihan Lawrence, not Ginnel Real Estate. (Go to Article)

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International ISRAEL NAMES PANEL

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) WRONG TURN: THE KATI KIM STORY After spending Thanksgiving 2006 in Seattle the members of the Kim family -- James, Kati and their two daughters, 4 years and 7 months, above -- were on their way home to San Francisco on Nov. 25 when they took a wrong turn in a remote area of southwestern Oregon and became lost in a dense wilderness. Trapped in their car during a snowstorm, they rationed food while Ms. Kim breast fed the children, and kept warm by occasionally turning on the car's engine. When they ran out of fuel, they built fires of dried wood and magazines and, hoping to attract the attention of rescue helicopters, the car's tires. On Dec. 2 Mr. Kim set off on foot, believing the nearest town to be four miles away. He never returned. Rescuers found Ms. Kim and her children on Dec. 4. Mr. Kim's body was discovered on Dec. 6 in more than a foot of icy water -- and only a mile from a lodge that, while closed for the winter, was stocked with supplies. In this two-hour ''20/20'' report, Ms. Kim describes the family's ordeal for the first time on television. 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW In ''The Naked Hour,'' Dr. Mehmet Oz joins forces with Dr. Laura Berman, the sex therapist; Lisa Lynn, a weight-loss specialist; and Samantha Heller, a registered dietician, to help women improve their body images.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $24/SQUARE FOOT $319,584 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (CUNY) MORIN KHUUR: THE SOUL OF THE MONGOLIAN HORSEMAN ''Living Cultures'' is a series exploring customs and traditions around the world that are threatened with extinction. In the premiere the director Benoit Ségur travels to the Mongolian steppes, where four city children who join a family of horse herders are taught by Omba, a wise old musician, to play the morin khuur, above, a fiddlelike stringed instrument considered a symbol of Mongolia. The subjects of this 13-part documentary were chosen from a list of 166 Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity, identified by Unesco as deserving of promotion and protection, especially when the techniques can be passed down to children. 8 P.M. (USA) THE 135TH WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOW On Day 2 the sporting, working and terrier groups are judged, followed by best in show. David Frei and Mary Carillo are the hosts.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International KING OF JORDAN DISMISSES CABINET TO STYMIE PROTESTS

headline: In Club's Rift, Morley Safer Minced No Words
summary: At the height of a messy internal dispute a few weeks ago, members of the exclusive Century Association in Manhattan traded unusually tart and testy e-mail messages. But the words of a single member stood out for their harsh tone: those of Morley Safer, the longtime correspondent for CBS's ''60 Minutes.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION Langston (Laurence Fishburne) testifies against Nate Haskell (Bill Irwin, above right, with Mr. Fishburne), the ''Dick and Jane'' killer. Nick (George Eads) gets a call warning him that Jason McCann (Justin Bieber), the troubled teenager who in the season premiere had shot him, has returned to town. In ''The Mentalist,'' at 10, Patrick Jane (Simon Baker) is joined in the field by Agent Hightower (Aunjanue Ellis) after Lisbon (Robin Tunney) is injured while investigating the death of a modern-day prospector whose body was found near a mining site. 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY Pierce (Chevy Chase) ends up in the hospital after swallowing some mysterious pills and bequeaths a few final gifts after deciding he's dying. Meanwhile Jeff (Joel McHale) ponders the possibility of reconnecting with his long-absent father, and Troy (Donald Glover) meets his idol LeVar Burton (playing himself, above left, with Mr. Glover). In ''Perfect Couples,'' at 8:30, Julia (Christine Woods) tries to make Dave (Kyle Bornheimer) feel like more of a man, and Vance (David Walton) and Amy (Mary Elizabeth Ellis) argue about the role of Leigh (Olivia Munn) as a wedding planner after the shrimp rolls she serves at a ''Mad Men'' party cause food poisoning. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) finally presents ''Threat Level Midnight,'' the action movie he has been working on for 11 years. The stars: Michael, as Agent Michael Scarn; Dwight (Rainn Wilson), as Scarn's butler sidekick; and Jim (John Krasinski), as Scarn's archnemesis, Goldenface. ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 9:30, finds Leslie (Amy Poehler) stirring up a media frenzy as she promotes the harvest festival. In ''30 Rock,'' at 10, a sleep-deprived Jack (Alec Baldwin) loses his edge when negotiating the new nanny's salary, and Jenna (Jane Krakowski) tries to distract Liz (Tina Fey) from her breakup. And in ''Outsourced,'' at 10:30, Todd (Ben Rappaport) orders his staff to be on its best behavior when his American boss, Jerry (Matt Walsh), makes a surprise visit. But it turns out that Jerry only wants to party.

headline: Watching the Scenery, Not the Clock
summary: I walked into my office last Nov. 2, the day after the New York City Marathon, feeling pretty good about myself. Actually, I limped in, to be precise. But that didn't dull the glow even the slightest. A year and a half before, having wandered into the clichéd midlife morass of malaise and discontent, I'd set a goal of running the 26.2 miles as a personal reclamation project. Thirty pounds lighter, I crossed the finish line in 4 hours 30 minutes and a shade under 1 second, dragging my happier, more settled soul across with me.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) HARD TIME A new season begins with ''The Hustle,'' which explores the underground prison economy -- an illegal system of barter and trade -- inside the Ross Correctional Institution in Chillicothe, Ohio. There, inmates have concocted a variety of money-making strategies to buy items like potato chips and brand-name shampoo at the commissary. Some work as tailors or tattoo artists to earn extra money; others act as lawyers for fellow inmates. (Above, David Applegate, an inmate, displays his tattoos.) The currency of choice: instant coffee. ''Prison City,'' a second episode at 10, interviews inmates at Ross who are using their sentences to prepare for life on the outside. Then there is David Stonestreet, who was sentenced as a teenager to 20 years to life for complicity to aggravated murder. Mr. Stonestreet, who has no hope of parole, has acknowledged his homosexuality and transformed into an alter ego, Twiggy. 8 P.M. (13) PIONEERS OF TELEVISION From ''Dragnet'' and ''The Untouchables'' to ''Mannix'' and ''Mission: Impossible,'' this episode plumbs the underworlds of crime dramas and some of the groundbreakers behind them. The list includes Jack Webb, Desi Arnaz, Bruce Geller, Bill Cosby, Angie Dickinson, Stefanie Powers (above, in ''The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.''), Barbara Bain, Martin Landau, James Garner and Peter Falk.

headline: Signs of a Turnaround for Clemson, Georgia and U.S.C.
summary: National signing day culminates the yearlong recruiting process for coaches and the seemingly boundless obsession of fans who track prospects through online sites. It is also a time for observers to take stake of how each program, and by extension each coach, fared in a given recruiting cycle. On Wednesday, Tom Lemming, a longtime recruiting analyst now with CBS College Sports, assessed this year's class. Lemming, while taking a break at the network's television studio in Manhattan, provided his take on the three programs that had made the biggest impact on signing day and three that did not.

headline: Featured Matches
summary: Play at the U.S. Open begins on all courts at 11 a.m. Eastern. Seedings in parentheses. TV: CBS, 11 a.m.; Tennis Channel, 7 p.m. ASHE STADIUM

headline: Looking Ahead: The Men's Final Four
summary: Michigan St. vs. ButlerSaturday, 6:07 p.m.TV: CBS Cue the ''Hoosiers'' theme music. Butler, playing a few miles from campus and winner of 24 straight, will be the crowd favorite. Michigan State knows the feeling. Last year, the Spartans made it to the championship game as the de facto home team in Detroit. Can Tom Izzo get them back to the title game? A lot will depend on how Korie Lucious, playing for the injured Kalin Lucas, handles a tenacious Butler defense. Or will the Bulldogs, behind a baby-faced star (Gordon Hayward) and a baby-faced coach (33-year-old Brad Stevens) continue a run that would make Jimmy Chitwood and Norman Dale proud?

headline: Frances Buss, 92, Director and Early-Television Pioneer
summary: Frances Buss, who at the dawn of commercial television parlayed a job as a temporary receptionist into a pioneering career as a director whose work helped establish the talk show, the game show and the cooking show as television staples, died on Jan. 19 in Hendersonville, N.C. She was 92. She died a few days after having a stroke, said Mark Spencer, her great-nephew.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) JESSE STONE: NO REMORSE (2010) In this sixth installment of the franchise based on the books by Robert B. Parker, Tom Selleck (left, with Krista Allen) returns as Chief Stone, who, while suspended from his duties in Paradise, Mass., is moonlighting as an investigator for his friend Healy (Stephen McHattie), the state homicide commander. With Stone in Boston, that leaves Rose (Kathy Baker) and Suitcase (Kohl Sudduth) on their own to deal with a crime spree back home. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. discusses the attempted car bombing in Times Square, and the former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani explains why he believes that the suspect, Faisal Shahzad, should be declared an enemy combatant. Also at 10, John O. Brennan, President Obama's chief counterterrorism adviser; Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Independent of Connecticut; and Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York, lead the debate on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace.'' Mr. Brennan also appears on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and Mr. Holder on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: A Director of Classics, Focused on Conscience
summary: Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience -- ''12 Angry Men,'' ''Serpico,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''The Verdict,'' ''Network'' -- became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86. His stepdaughter, Leslie Gimbel, said the cause was lymphoma.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FEIN, HARRY N.
summary: FEIN--Harry N.,on March 17, 2010. Former Recording Engineer with CBS Records and Sony Entertainment. Beloved husband of Rita (Ricky), also survived by loving nieces, nephews, family and friends. Services Sunday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FEIN, HARRY N.
summary: FEIN--Harry N., on March 17, 2010. Former Recording Engineer with CBS Records and Sony Entertainment. Beloved husband of Rita (Ricky), also survived by loving nieces, nephews, family and friends. Services Sunday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

headline: Spare Times
summary: Around Town Museums and Sites

headline: Sony Chief Still in Search of a Turnaround
summary: TOKYO -- In Sony's 1993 comedy ''Groundhog Day,'' Bill Murray finds himself reliving the same dreary course of events, day after day. It is as good an analogy as any to Howard Stringer's stint as chief executive of Sony, the electronics and entertainment giant: upswing, stumble, repeat.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) TAKING WOODSTOCK (2009) The setting is what was officially known as the Woodstock Music & Art Fair in August 1969. But most of the concert takes place out of sight of the camera in this film from Ang Lee, which focuses instead on the transformative effects of that landmark event on an assortment of people. In the forefront is Elliot Tiber (Demetri Martin, above), an interior decorator living in Greenwich Village, on whose memoir the film is based. Elliot returns to the Catskills to help his parents (Henry Goodman and Imelda Staunton), Jews who immigrated from Russia, keep their failing motel afloat. He also paves the way for Max Yasgur (Eugene Levy), the owner of the dairy farm where the festival was held, and Michael Lang (Jonathan Groff), its primary creator, to strike a deal. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said: ''For all its sincerity, 'Taking Woodstock' lacks the passion of Mr. Lee's finest films, 'Brokeback Mountain,' 'Lust, Caution,' 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon' and 'The Ice Storm.' I would add, however, that given a subject that has become synonymous with overblown mythmaking, its modesty becomes it.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro interviews Desmond Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and retired Anglican archbishop, about South Africa since the end of apartheid.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S FOURTH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Justin Bieber, Enrique Iglesias and LeAnn Rimes will perform alongside cast members of the recently opened film ''The Twilight Saga: Eclipse'' in this 34th annual spectacle, in which 40,000 shells -- about 1,500 a minute -- are scheduled to explode from six barges on the Hudson River. (Above is the 2008 fireworks display.) Nick Cannon and Alison Sweeney are hosts of the special, broadcast live from aboard the 4,100-passenger Norwegian Epic cruise ship, which was christened on Friday. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses the transition of American military leadership in Afghanistan to Gen. David H. Petraeus. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Independent of Connecticut, continues the discussion on ''Fox News Sunday'' at 10; and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, is interviewed from Afghanistan on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) DON PASQUALE A new season of ''Great Performances at the Met'' begins with Otto Schenk's production of Donizetti's comic opera about an aging Don (John Del Carlo) who, frustrated that his nephew Ernesto (Matthew Polenzani) insists on marrying his beloved, the penniless Norina (Anna Netrebko, above), instead of taking a suitable wife, decides to cut off his inheritance by getting married himself. Mariusz Kwiecien plays the duplicitous Dr. Malatesta; James Levine conducts. Reviewing the production in The New York Times in November, Vivien Schweitzer wrote, ''Ms. Netrebko offered a vivid portrait of Norina, her fluid voice lustrous as she navigated the bel canto hurdles in a performance that was both physically energetic and vocally rich.'' Her transition to the vixen ''Sofronia,'' the Don's new wife, Ms. Schweitzer added, ''was complete as she flounced down the stairs in hot-pink tights, tiara and velvet gown, flustering the hapless Don by her sudden metamorphosis from timid to tyrannical.'' 1:30 P.M. (13) NEW YORK NOW SPECIAL EDITION: 2011 STATE OF THE STATE ADDRESS Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will detail his plans for the year, including spending cuts and modifications to government agencies.

headline: First It Was Diapers. Now Shop for Soap (and Similar) Online.
summary: ''A little bit of soap,'' the old song goes, ''will never wash away my tears.'' But what might a whole lot of soap do? Not to mention detergent, paper towels, sponges, disinfecting wipes and more than 25,000 other health, beauty and household products. The answer is of keen interest to Quidsi, the e-commerce company that operates Diapers.com. Quidsi is promoting its newest Web site, Soap.com, with a cheeky campaign that plays up convenience along with value.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL VI Some of the cutest bruisers around, according to Animal Planet, including ''spunky spaniels, fierce French bulldogs and bustling beagles,'' go in for tackles, fumbles and ''Fido first downs'' (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy), at Animal Planet Stadium, above. Aerial coverage of the pups, plucked from shelters, will be provided by the Twizzlers blimp and its hamster crew, and sloppier ground-level angles by the ever-popular water-bowl camera. The sideline will be hopping with bunny cheerleaders. Not to be overlooked: the Kitty Halftime Show, featuring the antics of a dozen kittens. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY In addition to the war on Al Qaeda, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton discusses Afghanistan, Iran, Haiti and health care reform.

headline: High Ratings For Jets' Win
summary: The Jets' 17-14 win over San Diego on CBS on Sunday generated a 23.1 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating, up 8 percent from the A.F.C. divisional playoff game between San Diego and Pittsburgh a year ago. In the New York market, the game's rating hit its peak at the end, from 7:45 to 8 p.m., when it registered a 35.3. Minnesota's rout of Dallas on Fox was the higher-rated Sunday game with a 23.9, up 14 percent from the Eagles-Giants N.F.C. divisional playoff game last year.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (OWN) SEASON 25: OPRAH BEHIND THE SCENES After two preview episodes, the series moves into its regular time slot as it goes backstage at Harpo Studios, where Ms. Winfrey and her team put the finishing touches on the final season of ''The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' In the premiere of ''Your OWN Show: Oprah's Search for the Next TV Star,'' at 9, Nancy O'Dell and Carson Kressley, above, guide 10 contestants, chosen from the more than 15,000 who auditioned, through various challenges to determine whether they have what it takes to be a television talk show host. Dr. Phil, Suze Orman and Gayle King will serve as mentors and judges. The winner will receive his or her own show, produced by Mark Burnett. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR In the premiere of a five-part series, Jeffrey Brown reports on the situation in Haiti a year after an earthquake devastated the capital, Port au Prince.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ELSA'S LEGACY: THE BORN FREE STORY In 1960 Joy Adamson published ''Born Free,'' the story of an orphaned lion cub in Kenya named Elsa, left, and her eventual release back into the wild after being taught by Ms. Adamson and her husband, George, to survive on her own. The book sold millions of copies and in 1966 was made into an Academy Award-winning film -- in the process changing public perceptions by treating animals as individuals. The reality behind the movie was far less romantic. This 50th-anniversary special, presented by ''Nature,'' uses George Adamson's journal entries, home movies and conversations with several of the couple's confidants to examine their roles as pioneering conservationists and their controversial views about wildlife. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURRepresentative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, and Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, debate federal spending.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Showtime) NINE (2009) Daniel Day-Lewis, above, plays Guido Contini, a director with a creative block and way too many women, in Rob Marshall's adaptation of the musical, first staged in 1982 and revived in 2003, with songs by Maury Yeston and a screenplay by Michael Tolkin and Anthony Minghella. ''Occasionally a flicker of genuine style emerges from all this busy, gaudy fuss,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Day-Lewis does not overdo the Italian-ness, and the sardonic smile playing around his mouth may be a sign of what he thinks of it all,'' while Marion Cotillard ''attains a measure of wounded dignity as Louisa, Guido's former leading lady and much-betrayed wife.'' He added: ''None of the rest of Guido's ladies are so lucky. It must be said that 'Nine' is an impressive feat of casting, with a shocking number of Oscar winners and nominees assembled in the service of its dubious and incoherent cause.'' Among them: Judi Dench as Guido's costume designer and confidante; Penélope Cruz as his married mistress; Nicole Kidman as a Nordic actress; Sophia Loren as Guido's mother; Kate Hudson as a Vogue reporter; and Stacy Ferguson, a k a Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas, as a prostitute. (Mr. Marshall's 2002 adaptation of the musical ''Chicago,'' starring Catherine Zeta-Jones and Renée Zellweger, will be shown on Starz at 6 p.m.) 6:30 P.M. (Cinemax) FOUR CHRISTMASES (2008) Reese Witherspoon and Vince Vaughn star as Kate and Brad, an unmarried San Francisco couple who each Christmas invent a charity project as an excuse to take a hedonistic vacation and avoid festivities with their dysfunctional families. But when a news reporter points a camera their way just as their trip to Fiji is canceled, they have no choice but to make the rounds. Robert Duvall and Sissy Spacek play Brad's divorced parents; Mary Steenburgen and Jon Voight are Kate's. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that, in a break from holiday movie tradition, the film, ''briskly directed by Seth Gordon from a snappy, many-authored script, is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) DEADLIEST EARTHQUAKES In an evening of programming devoted to Haiti on the eve of the one-year anniversary of the earthquake that killed more than 200,000 in the capital, Port-au-Prince, this ''Nova'' episode follows a team of American geologists as they enter the country in the earthquake's immediate aftermath to help determine what caused it, as well as the risks of a new one. A month later ''Nova'' also tags along as the geologists travel to Chile, where a quake 100 times more powerful generated a tsunami -- and where new data could help prevent future disasters. ''Battle for Haiti,'' a ''Frontline'' episode that examines gang leaders' efforts to reassert control in the ravaged capital, will be broadcast at 9 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 49; ''Children of Haiti,'' an ''Independent Lens'' installment that follows three teenage boys over three years, will be shown at 10 on Channel 13 and at 11 on Channel 49. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY Segments look at a quick face lift without surgery and how to minimize wrinkles and dark circles. Also, tips from Oprah Winfrey's makeup artist.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) HAPPY 101ST BIRTHDAY, LUISE RAINER Reared in Düsseldorf, Germany, and Vienna -- during a childhood she described as ''one of starvation, poverty and revolution'' -- Ms. Rainer distinguished herself on the Berlin stage in Max Reinhardt's company before heading in 1935 to Hollywood, where some imagined she might become the next Greta Garbo. Under contract to MGM, she had achieved fame by 1937 as the first back-to-back Oscar recipient in acting. ''Nothing worse could have happened to me,'' she said later of her subsequent inability to meet audience expectations in a succession of insignificant roles. After a failed marriage to the playwright Clifford Odets, she left MGM after only three and a half years and eight pictures, returning to film briefly in 1943 in ''Hostages'' for Paramount. Happily remarried to the British publisher Robert Knittel from 1945 until his death in 1989, Ms. Rainer appeared sporadically in television and onstage in London, where she lives, before making her 11-minute movie comeback at 86 in ''The Gambler'' (1997) as the wealthy grandmother of a family on the brink of ruin. This four-film tribute is introduced by ''Luise Rainer: Live From the TCM Film Festival'' (2011), featuring her April 2010 interview with Robert Osborne. ''The Good Earth'' (1937), Victor Fleming's adaptation of the Pearl Buck classic about Chinese farmers battling the elements, starring Ms. Rainer in her Oscar-winning role as the kitchen slave O-Lan, follows at 8:30. In ''The Great Ziegfeld'' (1936), at 11:30, Robert Z. Leonard's lavish biography of the starmaker Flo Ziegfeld (William Powell), she plays the French singer Anna Held, for which she earned her first Oscar. In ''The Great Waltz'' (1938), at 2:45 a.m., a film loosely based on the life of the composer Johann Strauss II (Fernand Gravet), she appears as the fictitious Poldi Vogelhuber, Strauss's wife. The night ends with ''Dramatic School'' (1938), at 4:30, with Ms. Rainer (above, proposing a toast), appearing alongside Lana Turner and Paulette Goddard, as a young actress struggling to find fame on the stage and success in her marriage to a titled Frenchman (Alan Marshal). 7:55 P.M. (Sundance) L'AUBERGE ESPAGNOLE (2002) Xavier Rousseau, an uptight Parisian student played by Romain Duris, moves into a communal apartment in Barcelona and soon learns the international language of love and friendship in this comedy from Cédric Klapisch. Audrey Tatou is Xavier's worried girlfriend. In ''Bob Le Flambeur'' (1956), the first entry in a double bill by Jean Pierre Melville, starting at 10, Roger Duchesne stars as Bob Montagné, a pompadoured middle-aged gambler who stakes everything on a daring plan to rob a casino. In ''Le Doulos'' (1962), at 11:45, a young Jean-Paul Belmondo, dressed in trench coat and fedora, stars as Silien, a stylishly sinister Parisian hood hired by a recent parolee (Serge Reggiani) for a safe-cracking job.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE 33RD ANNUAL KENNEDY CENTER HONORS The singer-songwriters Merle Haggard and Paul McCartney; the composer and lyricist Jerry Herman; the dancer, choreographer and director Bill T. Jones; and the television personality and producer Oprah Winfrey, above with Mr. McCartney, are honored for their contributions to American culture in this ceremony taped on Dec. 5, with President Obama and the first lady attending. Caroline Kennedy hosts for the eighth consecutive year. Performers and presenters include Edward Albee, Carol Channing, Sheryl Crow, Claire Danes, Vince Gill, Kelsey Grammer, Jennifer Hudson, Kris Kristofferson, Norah Jones, Angela Lansbury, Willie Nelson, Sidney Poitier, Chita Rivera, Julia Roberts, Chris Rock, James Taylor, John Travolta and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS BENEATH THE ICE Can Antarctica's past offer clues about what might happen to our planet? ''Nova'' explores that question by following a drilling probe deep into the ice, down through the water and three-quarters of a mile into the seafloor to recover rock cores from a time when Earth was a few degrees warmer than it is today. These cores offer clues not only about the past but also about the future.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) 16TH ANNUAL CRITICS' CHOICE MOVIE AWARDS The Broadcast Film Critics Association will bestow its honors at this ceremony broadcast live from the Hollywood Palladium. The show will feature appearances by Jon Hamm, Julianne Moore, Josh Brolin, Jesse Eisenberg, Sofía Vergara, Kevin Spacey, Emma Stone and former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California. Maroon 5 is the house band. Emily Blunt and Jimmy Kimmel will present Matt Damon (above) with the fourth Joel Siegel Award, which is named for the longtime ''Good Morning America'' film critic who died in 2007. Quentin Tarantino will receive the inaugural Critics' Choice Music+Film Award, presented by Tim Roth and created to recognize a filmmaker who heightens storytelling through the effective use of music. The show will also offer a preview of ''Single Ladies,'' a comedic drama starring Stacey Dash, LisaRaye McCoy and Charity Shea that explores what women want in a relationship. Tim Kash and La La Vazquez will report from the red carpet starting at 8 p.m. on VH1 and MTV. 8 P.M. (CBS) MEDIUM A desperate man seeks the help of Allison (Patricia Arquette) in finding his wife. Meanwhile she and Joe (Jake Weber) become concerned when Marie (Miranda Carabello) is overcome with anxiety during a spelling test. Miguel Sandoval, who plays District Attorney Devalos, directed the episode. In ''CSI: NY'' at 9, Mac (Gary Sinise) butts heads with the chief of Barcelona's crime lab after a Spanish club promoter is found dead.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DRUGS, INC. This four-part mini-series on drugs in America begins with an examination of how cocaine is produced and distributed -- from peasant farmers who make cocaine paste to a trafficker linked to Mexican cartels to a dealer in Miami. At 9 the series continues with a look at the stimulant methamphetamine, which is made from a common cold remedy. This episode documents a raid on a suspected meth lab and the physical damages caused by the drug. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Guests include George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, on his country's recent fiscal austerity; and Anjem Choudary, who was born in England and is a proponent of radical Islam.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (HBO) A PRESIDENT TO REMEMBER: IN THE COMPANY OF JOHN F. KENNEDY (2008) On the 50th anniversary of the inauguration of President Kennedy, Robert Drew combines film footage from four of his documentaries from the early 1960s (''Primary,'' ''Adventures on the New Frontier,'' ''Crisis: Behind a Presidential Commitment'' and ''Faces of November'') to create an overview of Kennedy's life, from his campaign as a young senator to his assassination in 1963. Using critical moments captured by Mr. Drew and his associates, Albert Maysles, D. A. Pennebaker, Richard Leacock, Hope Ryden and James Lipscomb, the film follows Kennedy as he meets with union workers as a fledgling candidate; watches approvingly as his wife, Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, gives a stump speech; strategizes with staffers about election tactics; deals with the Soviet Union and Nikita S. Khrushchev during the Cuban missile crisis; and works with his attorney general, his brother Robert F. Kennedy, during a showdown with Gov. George Wallace over the integration of the University of Alabama. The documentary, narrated by Alec Baldwin, ends with scenes of a grieving nation. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL In Part 2 of the Season 10 opener the judges Randy Jackson, Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler audition singers in New Orleans.

headline: The 'CSI' Treatment for the E.R.
summary: SOMETHING terrible is about to happen to the two beautiful people who are cruising down a street in South Beach in the first moments of ''Miami Medical.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) BIRDS OF THE GODS The depths of New Guinea's rainforest are inhabited by birds of unimaginable color and beauty, with plumes so fabulous that when Europeans first saw them in the 16th century, they believed the creatures were heaven-sent and called them birds of paradise (above, the Raggiana bird of paradise). The people of New Guinea say the birds possess supernatural powers. But to find these birds, and to witness their extraordinary mating displays, is next to impossible. In this ''Nature'' presentation, David Attenborough prepares a team of young scientists for a grueling expedition to uncover and film these fantastical birds, a quest considered the ultimate goal of wildlife filmmakers. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURThis morning's topic: President Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday, discussed here by Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota; Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas; and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut. The debate continues with Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, and Senator Dick Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: 'Dancing' Again
summary: The expressive footwork of Kate Gosselin -- and her expressionless mien -- continued to captivate and baffle viewers as ''Dancing With the Stars'' led the ratings on Monday night. That ABC reality competition averaged 20.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, followed by the premiere of the comedy ''Romantically Challenged'' (11.6 million), starring Alyssa Milano. CBS was runner-up on the night as a new episode of ''CSI: Miami'' (11.7 million) surpassed the rival crime series ''Castle'' (10.5 million) on ABC. Fox ranked third with ''House'' (10.6 million) and ''24'' (8.9 million). NBC placed fourth.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE All of the guests at the prewedding parties of Clark and Lois (Tom Welling and Erica Durance, above) lose their memories after drinking spiked Champagne from Zatanna (Serinda Swan). Meanwhile Lois is accused of theft by Fortune (James Kidnie), the casino owner, while searching for her lost engagement ring. In ''Supernatural,'' at 9, Sam (Jared Padalecki) and Dean (Jensen Ackles) are transported to an alternate universe where they are actors named Jared Padalecki and Jensen Ackles on a television series called ''Supernatural.'' 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICAJames Franco and Anne Hathaway talk about hosting the Academy Awards on Sunday.

headline: Former Mets Prospect Shuts Down The Yankees
summary: On a night when A. J. Burnett became the first Yankees starter to pitch eight complete innings, he was overshadowed by a failed Mets prospect playing for his fourth organization in 16 months. The Chicago White Sox edged the Yankees, 2-0, behind a sterling start by Phil Humber, who allowed his only hit with one out in the seventh inning.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (13) WO AI NI (I LOVE YOU) MOMMY The filmmaker Stephanie Wang-Breal chronicles 18 months in the life of Fang Sui Yong, an 8-year-old orphan, as she leaves behind her foster parents in China after being adopted by Donna and Jeff Sadowsky of Long Island. (Above, Donna Sadowsky with the child.) The documentary is the first installment in the three-part ''P.O.V. Adoption Stories,'' broadcast on Tuesdays through Sept. 14, which explores the challenges faced by adoptees as they forge new lives while holding onto their national and racial identities. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Training to be a ball boy at the United States Open tennis tournament. Also, tracking Internet use by children.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 83RD ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The young and the beautiful -- in this case, James Franco and Anne Hathaway -- make their debut as Oscar hosts at this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Colin Firth will take home the best-actor Oscar for his role as the stuttering George VI in ''The King's Speech'' and that Natalie Portman will win the best actress award for her turn as an increasingly demented ballerina in ''Black Swan.'' But there is still room for speculation in categories like best director, where David Fincher, for ''The Social Network,'' could trump Tom Hooper, for ''The King's Speech,'' the Oscar front-runner with 12 nominations and the favorite to win best film (''True Grit'' was second with 10 nominations). Robin Roberts, Tim Gunn, Krista Smith and Maria Menounos report from the red carpet starting at 7. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana, talks about his state's fiscal battles, as well as his possible White House run. Mr. Wallace analyzes the potential Republican field for the 2012 campaign with a 2008 candidate in the Republican presidential primaries, Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SHERLOCK: A STUDY IN PINK Benedict Cumberbatch (''Atonement''), right, plays a contemporary version of Arthur Conan Doyle's London sleuth, and Martin Freeman (BBC's ''Office'') is Dr. John Watson, his loyal sidekick and a veteran of the war in Afghanistan, in this three-part ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' production created by Steven Moffat and Mark Gatiss of ''Doctor Who'' fame. In this first episode, the flat mates tackle a case of serial suicide in which three people have disappeared under identical circumstances and later turned up dead, having taken the same self-administered poison. Then a fourth victim is discovered, dressed entirely in pink and found with the word ''Rache'' scratched into the floor where she died. Rupert Graves plays Detective Inspector Lestrade, who asks Sherlock to help him decipher what it all means. ''The appeal is elementary,'' Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, ''good, unpretentious fun, something that's in short supply around here.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley moderates a debate among the Senate candidates in Florida: Gov. Charlie Crist, an Independent; Representative Kendrick B. Meek, a Democrat; and Marco Rubio, a Republican.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Science) BUILD IT BIGGER The architect and professor Danny Forster, below, has risen to great heights and sunk to even greater depths to explain the design and construction challenges of some of the world's most celebrated structures, from the 1,356-foot Al Hamra Tower in Kuwait, the tallest twisting structure on Earth, to the Mponeng gold mine in South Africa, the deepest of its kind at more than 2.3 miles down. In this Season 5 opener, Mr. Forster travels 150 feet underneath New York City to examine the expansion of the subway system. Ruth Bernstein, his 95-year-old grandmother and an Upper East Side resident who apparently knows a thing or two about mass transit, makes a cameo appearance. 8 P.M. (NBC) WHO DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?Ashley Judd explores the branches of her family tree in this season finale, which finds her parsing the tales of her paternal great-grandmother, tracing the journey of an ancestor who confronted tragedy on the battlefield as a member of the Union Army, and discovering a link to the country's first settlers.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10:30 P.M. (Showtime) SECRET DIARY OF A CALL GIRL In the show's fourth and final season the high-class London escort Belle (Billie Piper, above), occupying a luxurious new town house, unexpectedly expands her skill set when her madam, Stephanie (Cherie Lunghi), lands in jail for a stint, saddling Belle with her appointment book and her stable of women, including the headstrong dominatrix Charlotte (Gemma Chan), as well as Stephanie's 19-year-old daughter, Poppy (Lily James), who has no idea what her mother does for a living. At the same time Belle's best pal, Ben (Iddo Goldberg), is eager to step into the role of beau, with the full knowledge of how his beloved earns her keep. ''Gigolos,'' a new series focusing on five real-life male escorts in Las Vegas and their female clientele, follows at 11. 8 P.M. (CW) THE VAMPIRE DIARIES The series returns from hiatus to find Jenna (Sara Canning) in anguish after an unexpected visit from Isobel (Mia Kirshner). Meanwhile Bonnie (Katerina Graham) uses a spell to harness the power of her ancestors, and Matt (Zach Roerig) tells the sheriff that his sister was killed by a vampire. ''Nikita'' also resumes, at 9, with Michael (Shane West) threatening to inform Percy (Xander Berkeley) that Alex (Lyndsy Fonseca) is the mole, unless Nikita (Maggie Q) tracks down, in less than 24 hours, the man who murdered Michael's family.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) UPSTAIRS DOWNSTAIRS ''Masterpiece Classic'' returns to 165 Eaton Place in London, almost 40 years after the premiere of the landmark series on PBS, with new characters and a couple of familiar faces (including Nico Mirallegro, above) in this three-part sequel, set in 1936. Jean Marsh reprises her Emmy-winning role as the parlor maid Rose Buck, rehired as the housekeeper by the new residents, Sir Hallam Holland (Ed Stoppard) and his wife, Lady Agnes (Keeley Hawes). Eileen Atkins, who created the original show with Ms. Marsh, takes on the role of Lady Maud Holland, Hallam's imperious and eccentric mother, whose return from India with a Sikh secretary and a monkey in tow interferes with her daughter-in-law's management of the house. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said Ms. Marsh and Ms. Atkins are ''exactly what this delightful and absorbing drama requires.'' The new ''Upstairs Downstairs'' ''sticks to the rules established by the original,'' she added, ''and defies the odds by being as good, and in some ways, even better.'' 7 P.M. (CBS) 60 MINUTES No one is allowed to borrow from the Vatican Library, except the pope. (Those who wish to view documents must apply.) And no wonder: the archive holds some of the world's most precious works of art and treasure, including the Codex Vaticanus Graecus 1209, the oldest-known nearly complete manuscript of the Bible; a copy of a letter from St. Peter, written by a disciple in 200 A.D.; and religious figures depicted in the Greek New Testament Bible, above. Morley Safer reports.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MORAN, WILLIAM
summary: MORAN--William, passed away peacefully after a brief illness on February 28, 2010 in Sarasota, FL. Bill Moran was a writer and producer at CBS News for twenty-five years. From 1974 to 1977 he was a principal writer for The CBS Evening News with Walter Cronkite. He was producer on the program for two years before joining CBS News Sunday Morning with Charles Kuralt, where he served as producer and senior producer for sixteen years, bringing him awards from the Writers Guild of America and an Emmy. Prior to joining CBS, Moran was a reporter for the Associated Press, covering New England, New York and Washington and was a producer and writer at Vermont Public Television. Prior to this, he was a correspondent for The New York Times, The Washington Post and Time. In 2002 his book, The Belles of New England, was published to excellent reviews. Moran was born February 5, 1934, in Portland, ME. He served for four years in the U.S. Navy and in 1961 graduated from Boston University. He resided in Old Greenwich, CT from 1971 to 1995 and most recently divided his time between Scarborough, ME and Sarasota, FL. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Small Moran, of Scarborough, ME and Sarasota, FL; two daughters, Lisa, of London, England and Beth, of Brooklyn, NY; a grandson, Henry Parker, of London; and a sister, Mary Flaherty of Portland, ME.

headline: Polls Predict and Hedge
summary: In sobering news for incumbents in Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that a majority of voters say their own representatives do not deserve to return to office. With less than a week before the midterm elections, about 6 in 10 voters say it is time to give someone new a chance to represent their district in Congress, the poll found. That figure is higher than it was in 1994, when Democrats last lost control of the House of Representatives.

headline: What's on Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN (2009) An unemployed, vacant-eyed young woman (Émilie Dequenne, above left, with Catherine Deneuve) who lives with her distant mother (Ms. Deneuve) near a train track in the Paris suburbs pretends to be the victim of an anti-Semitic attack after a relationship with a thuggish athlete (Nicolas Duvauchelle) sours. This seductive drama from André Téchiné was based on the real-life case involving Marie-Léonie Leblanc, a 23-year-old who claimed in 2004 that she had been the victim of an anti-Semitic attack by six men of North African and African origin on a train outside Paris. The French president at the time, Jacques Chirac, condemned the attack, and the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, urged French Jews to leave for Israel to ''escape the wildest anti-Semitism.'' Then the woman admitted that she had lied. ''I wanted my parents to take care of me,'' she explained, ''my boyfriend to take care of me.'' Manohla Dargis, reviewing the film in The New York Times, said: ''Mr. Téchiné isn't pretending that he understands what people do. But by showing us what they do, the flowers they pick and the people they love, he makes us notice them more intently.'' 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK In a two-part episode about baseball, repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m., Doug Muzzio interviews the journalist Jimmy Breslin about his new book, ''Branch Rickey,'' about the manager and executive who helped break the sport's color barrier by signing Jackie Robinson (above with Rickey) to the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. Though the biography breaks no factual ground, ''what Breslin has done, with his usual gritty perception, is revive a story of enormous consequence,'' David Oshinsky wrote in The New York Times Book Review. Rickey, ''a white man, is rarely mentioned when the great civil rights leaders are discussed. His politics were small-town Republican, his judgments often puritanical. He had numerous reasons for integrating baseball, Breslin reminds us, not all of them noble. But without his vision and persistence, civil rights may have taken an even slower, rougher path.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ECHO: AN ELEPHANT TO REMEMBER Echo, above, the matriarch of an extended clan in Amboseli National Park in Kenya, was the most studied elephant in the world. The subject of several books and documentaries, her life was also documented by Cynthia Moss, an expert in elephant behavior, and the filmmaker Martyn Colbeck across four decades. In May 2009 Echo died of natural causes at 65, leaving her family to face the worst drought ever recorded in Amboseli without her -- and leaving researchers to wonder whether Echo had taught her brood all they would need to know to survive. This ''Nature'' episode reflects on Echo's lingering legacy through archival footage of her maternal instincts at work and at play, as well as the recollections of those who watched over her. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour heads to Delaware to interview the Senate candidates Chris Coons, a Democrat, and Christine O'Donnell, a Republican supported by the Tea Party. Ms. Amanpour also talks with voters about what they think of the race. In another segment, Maria Shriver discusses ''A Woman's Nation Takes on Alzheimer's,'' part of a network-wide focus on the disease.

headline: Corrections
summary: An entry in the ''What's On Today'' television highlights on Tuesday about ''The Good Wife,'' on CBS, misstated the given name of the show's star. She is Julianna Margulies, not Joanna.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) GAME OF THRONES A cast of seemingly hundreds -- kings and queens, knights and renegades, liars and noblemen -- vie for power in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros in this adaptation of ''A Song of Ice and Fire,'' the fantasy book series by George R. R. Martin. Filmed in Northern Ireland and Malta, the story unfolds as King Robert Baratheon (Mark Addy) asks Lord Eddard Stark (Sean Bean, above) to help run his kingdom after the death of his right-hand man. Meanwhile, Princess Daenerys (Emilia Clarke) and her brother, Viserys (Harry Lloyd), whose family once ruled the kingdoms, are threatening the throne from the east. At the same time, in the north, Jon Snow (Kit Harington), Stark's illegitimate son, has joined the brotherhood of the Night's Watch, sworn protectors of the kingdoms. '' 'Game of Thrones' serves up a lot of confusion in the name of no larger or really relevant idea beyond sketchily fleshed-out notions that war is ugly, families are insidious and power is hot,'' Ginia Bellafante wrote in The New York Times, praising by comparison series like ''The Sopranos,'' ''The Wire'' and ''Deadwood.'' ''If you are not averse to the Dungeons & Dragons aesthetic, the series might be worth the effort. If you are nearly anyone else, you will hunger for HBO to get back to the business of languages for which we already have a dictionary.'' 10 A.M. (Fox ) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Secretary of Transportation Ray LaHood discusses recent suspensions of air traffic controllers who fell asleep on the job.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ESPN) THE BEST THAT NEVER WAS In 1981 the nature of college sports recruiting shifted as a dozen top-tier football programs waited for Marcus Dupree, a high school running back from Mississippi, to make his decision. After Mr. Dupree (left, in 1982) committed to the University of Oklahoma, his career faltered as conflict, injury and the burden of expectation took their toll. In this ''30 for 30'' documentary, Jonathan Hock explores why the star of Mr. Dupree, now a part-time truck driver, fell to earth and how he ultimately returned to football for redemption. 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE The series explores bullying, particularly when gay students are the victims. Kurt (Chris Colfer) finally stands up to his football team tormenters after meeting another gay student (Darren Criss) who sings for the competition.

headline: News Of The World
summary: Whether the scandal afflicting News Corp. represents the beginning of the fall of the House of Murdoch or just another thrilling episode in the career of the Teflon tycoon, I can't say. There is plenty enough spectacle without speculation. Nor is this the place to celebrate a rival's troubles. True, I did pull from my files and savor the indignant letters we received from News of the World's top editors last year as we prepared to publish an investigation of the paper's phone-hacking culture and Scotland Yard's timidity -- work that has been fully vindicated in recent weeks. But even if it is true, as online wags put it, that Murdoch's troubles threaten to deplete the world supply of schadenfreude, I don't plan to join the party.

headline: A Contrarian Out Looking For Trouble
summary: HERE COMES TROUBLE Stories From My Life

headline: America Wants Its 'Talent'
summary: ''America's Got Talent'' dominated the ratings on Tuesday as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to this NBC reality series, according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC led the night over all, outperforming CBS's lineup of crime show reruns. ABC was third with the season premiere of ''Wipeout'' (9.5 million). In fourth place, Fox broadcast a two-hour block of ''Hell's Kitchen'' (6.1 million).

headline: Fox Wins Monday
summary: Opposite mostly reruns on CBS, Fox eked out a victory on Monday as the top-rated network in prime time. According to Nielsen's estimates, the combination of ''House'' at 8 p.m., which drew 11.2 million viewers, and ''24'' at 9 (9 million), lifted Fox to No. 1, even as reruns of CBS's sitcoms in the 9 p.m. hour, ''Two and a Half Men'' (12.5 million) and ''The Big Bang Theory'' (11.5 million), earned slightly larger audiences. CBS drew lower ratings at 8 and 8:30 for a repeat of ''How I Met Your Mother'' (6.2 million) followed by a new episode of ''Rules of Engagement'' (7.8 million). CBS's rerun of ''CSI: Miami'' won the 10 p.m. hour with 9 million viewers, finishing ahead of NBC's ''Law & Order'' (6.9 million) and ABC's ''Castle'' repeat (6.6 million). ABC placed third, averaging 8 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a ''20/20'' special, ''Inside The Bachelor: Stories Behind the Rose,'' while NBC ranked fourth with ''Chuck'' at 8 (5.8 million) and ''Trauma'' at 9 (5.2 million).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (The Weather Channel) CHANGING PLANET In honor of Earth Day, Tom Brokaw moderates a town-hall-style symposium at Yale University to encourage student dialogue about climate change and its impact on health, economic opportunity, and moral and religious values, as well as to brainstorm about solutions. Sponsored by NBC Learn, the educational arm of NBC News; the National Science Foundation; and Discover magazine, the meeting brings together more than 100 students with Rajendra K. Pachauri, who heads the Yale Climate and Energy Institute; Billy Parish, a founder of the Energy Action Coalition, a youth advocacy organization working on climate change issues; Katharine Hayhoe, a research associate professor of geosciences at Texas Tech University; and Linda J. Fisher, vice president for safety, health and environment at DuPont. (Above, drought in the Southwest, among the topics addressed in the program.) 8:45 A.M. (Vme) ANIMALITOS EXPLORADORES Translated as ''Wild Animal Baby Explorers,'' this first Spanish-language children's television show from the National Wildlife Federation introduces five natural-science investigators -- Benita the Beaver, Skip the Rabbit, Izzy the Owl, Sammy the Skunk and Miss Sally the Salamander -- who will show youngsters that every backyard, playground and flower bed is worthy of exploration. Other Earth Day shows for children include ''Jake and the Never Land Pirates,'' at 8:30, and ''Handy Manny,'' at 9:30, on Disney Junior; and ''Sid the Science Kid,'' at 11 a.m., and ''Arthur,'' at 3 p.m., on Channel 13.

headline: Buff Cobb, 82, TV Host Of Early '50s Talk Show
summary: Buff Cobb, who with Mike Wallace, her husband at the time, hosted ''Mike and Buff,'' one of television's first talk shows, died on July 12 at a nursing home in Lebanon, N.H. She was 82. Her death was confirmed by her half brother, Thomas Cobb Brody.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $60/SQUARE FOOT $154,800 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (VH1) BRET MICHAELS: LIFE AS I KNOW IT In ''Rock of Love'' Mr. Michaels, left, the Poison frontman, searched for a girlfriend while he and Kristi Gibson took a break from their longstanding relationship. But sometimes home actually is where the heart is. In this new series Mr. Michaels -- who received a diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes at age 6 and who this year has had appendicitis, a brain hemorrhage and a ''warning stroke'' -- juggles life on the road with raising his two young daughters while trying to reconcile with their mother, Ms. Gibson. ''Rock of Love Girls: Where Are They Now?,'' which leads in at 9, provides updates on some of the unruly women who competed for, but ultimately didn't win, Mr. Michaels's affections. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews a 16-year-old boy who killed the person who molested him.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths VERONIS, PETER
summary: VERONIS--Peter, 87, died peacefully on August 20. He was married for 57 years to Dorothy (Babs) White, who died in 2004, and is survived by his daughter Judith Anne Rodgers, son-in-law Philip Rodgers, step-grandchildren Dina Weitz and Suellen Rodgers, and four siblings, Mary Thompson, George (Kim), John (Lauren) and Reverend Alexander (Pearl) Veronis. In 1941 he joined the U.S. Navy which he served for 10 years, during which time he became Chief Petty Officer on the battleship USS North Carolina and participated in major battles in the Pacific. After his honorable discharge he attended Columbia University from 1951-1954 while working in advertising for the Springfield Newspapers. Subsequently he became an advertising sales executive at Ridder Johns Co. and Look magazine before becoming Vice-President, Advertising Director of Psychology Today magazine and later Saturday Review. In 1973-1980 he served as Publisher of Book Digest magazine. Later, he created the CBS Magazine advertising network. Funeral services will be held 11am Wednesday, preceded by a 10am viewing at Archangels Greek Orthodox Church, 1527 Bedford Street, Stamford, CT. 06905 (1-203-348-4216). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Habitat for Humanity or Archangels Greek Orthodox Church.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY: THE MUSIC EVENT Callie -- played by Sara Ramirez, who trained at Juilliard and won a Tony Award for her role as the Lady of the Lake in ''Monty Python's 'Spamalot' '' -- bursts into song in this special episode, when her character confronts a life-altering moment with Arizona (Jessica Capshaw) after a car accident. The playlist features some of the music used as backdrop for the Seattle Grace doctors over the last seven seasons, including Snow Patrol's ''Chasing Cars,'' the Fray's ''How to Save a Life'' and ''The Story'' by Brandi Carlile, performed by cast members, including Ellen Pompeo, Patrick Dempsey, Kevin McKidd (above left, with Kim Raver), Chandra Wilson and Chyler Leigh. Kate Walsh of ''Private Practice'' also makes an appearance. Meanwhile, on ''Private Practice,'' which follows at 10, Peter (Tim Daly) discovers that the illness of his imprisoned mother, portrayed by Louise Fletcher (''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest''), may have been caused by his brother (Kyle Secor). 8 P.M. (13) SUNDAYARTS PRIMETIME SPECIALPhilippe de Montebello, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, hosts this special from the Morgan Library & Museum, which explores the 2010 restoration of the museum's McKim library building as well as three current exhibitions: ''Mannerism and Modernism: The Kasper Collection of Drawings and Photographs,'' ''The Diary: Three Centuries of Private Lives'' and ''The Changing Face of William Shakespeare.'' Other segments look at fashion week at Lincoln Center; ''Bye Bye Kitty!!! Between Heaven and Hell in Contemporary Japanese Art'' at Japan Society; ''Glenn Ligon: America'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art; the Stephen Petronio Dance Company at the Joyce Theater; and the Broadway revival of ''That Championship Season.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths VERONIS, PETER
summary: VERONIS--Peter, 87, died peacefully on August 20. He was married for 57 years to Dorothy (Babs) White, who died in 2004, and is survived by his daughter Judith Anne Rodgers, son-in-law Philip Rodgers, step-grandchildren Dina Weitz and Suellen Rodgers, and four siblings, Mary Thompson, George (Kim), John (Lauren) and Reverend Alexander (Pearl) Veronis. After his honorable discharge he attended Columbia University from 1951-1954 while working in advertising for the Springfield Newspapers. Subsequently he became an advertising sales executive at Ridder Johns Co. and Look magazine before becoming Vice-President, Advertising Director of Psychology Today magazine and later Saturday Review. In 1973-1980 he served as Publisher of Book Digest magazine. Later, he created the CBS Magazine advertising network. Funeral services will be held 11am Wednesday, preceded by a 10am viewing at Archangels Greek Orthodox Church, 1527 Bedford Street, Stamford, CT. 06905 (1-203-348-4216). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Habitat for Humanity or Archangels Greek Orthodox Church.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths EILER, JIM
summary: EILER--Jim, 83, Actor, writer, director, and founder of The Prince Street Players, Ltd. died on July 20th at his home in Boca Raton, FL. David Lile, his life-partner of 45 years, announced his death. Mr. Eiler created Broadway style musicals for young audiences. CBS-TV produced four National Emmy Winning Specials of his work starting in 1965 which are considered some of the finest ever created for children. Critics praised his songs and clever updating of the classic fairy tales "Pinocchio, "Jack and The Beanstalk," "Emperor's New Clothes" and "Aladdin," calling them "Sparkling and humorous", noting, "adults enjoyed them as much, or more, than the children." Born in Granite City, Illinois, Mr. Eiler's early career included the Nat. Companies of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," and "Kismet" (Omar Khayyam). He appeared in major stock productions playing comedy leads. His favorite was Og, the leprechaun, in "Finian's Rainbow." Performing aboard ship on a lengthy world tour, there was constant need for new material which he could quickly supply. On his return to NY this talent led to writing "special material" for many stars, and eventually to the founding of the Prince Street Players. He will be remembered by the many actors and directors who got their first break performing in a Prince Street show. All eleven of his scripts and scores are now leased throughout the world by Music Theatre International. His legacy is a joyous one of shared love and laughter through his words and music.

headline: Reality TV, Shaking Off Recession, Takes Entrepreneurial Turn
summary: If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, then perhaps the recovery is finally under way. Slowly. Two networks are betting on shows based on entrepreneurs competing for seed money for their business ideas. NBC's ''America's Next Great Restaurant'' features aspiring restaurateurs trying to impress a panel of judges to win financing for a new chain. And ABC has reintroduced ''Shark Tank,'' in which entrepreneurs try to get backing from a panel of venture capitalists who bet with their own money -- in exchange for a piece of the action.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths EILER, JIM
summary: EILER--Jim, 83, Actor, writer, director, and founder of The Prince Street Players, Ltd. died on July 20th at his home in Boca Raton, FL. David Lile, his life-partner of 45 years, announced his death. Mr. Eiler created Broadway style musicals for young audiences. CBS-TV produced four National Emmy Winning Specials of his work starting in 1965 which are considered some of the finest ever created for children. Critics praised his songs and clever updating of the classic fairy tales "Pinocchio, "Jack and The Beanstalk," "Emperor's New Clothes" and "Aladdin," calling them "Sparkling and humorous", noting, "adults enjoyed them as much, or more, than the children." He will be remembered by the many actors and directors who got their first break performing in a Prince Street show. All eleven of his scripts and scores are now leased throughout the world by Music Theatre International. His legacy is a joyous one of shared love and laughter through his words and music.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS Lisa, center, uncages her inner songbird when she goes to a performing arts camp in this 22nd-season premiere. The voices of the ''Glee'' choristers, from left, Lea Michele, Cory Monteith and Amber Riley, guest-star as Lisa's fellow musicians in training; Jemaine Clement and Bret McKenzie of ''Flight of the Conchords'' are her counselors. In the second-season opener of ''The Cleveland Show,'' at 8:30, Kanye West lends his voice to Kenny West, a struggling rapper with whom Cleveland writes a hit (''Be-Cleave in Yourself''). But there's only room in town for one star. And in the Season 8 premiere of ''Family Guy,'' at 9, James Woods plays a born-again version of himself, who invites residents of Quahog to meet his new companion (Ashley Tisdale). But then someone dies. And soon, so does another. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews John Boehner, the House minority leader, and Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, about the new Republican Party campaign blueprint, ''Commitment to America.''

headline: PAYOUTS | APRIL 18-24
summary: THE NEWS The five biggest banking companies in the United States reported a total of $17 billion in profits for the first quarter of 2010, by far their best showing ever. BEHIND THE NEWS Much of the gain came from proprietary trading, the risky business that got the big banks in trouble to begin with, and which they would have to spin off under President Obama's proposed regulatory overhaul. News of the profits was overshadowed by the government's charges that Goldman Sachs created securities that were secretly designed to fail, so that a favored customer could bet against them.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (A&E) BREAKOUT KINGS This new drama by Matt Olmstead and Nick Santora, the writers and producers of Fox's defunct ''Prison Break,'' is about two United States marshals (Domenick Lombardozzi, above left, and Laz Alonso) assigned to track down escaped felons. But, as the show's tagline puts it, ''It takes a con to catch a con.'' Or, in this case, three (Jimmi Simpson, Malcolm Goodwin and Serinda Swan), who receive upgraded accommodations and time shaved off their sentences in exchange for their efforts. ''Law & Order'' it's not. ''Matt and I really wanted to do a show where the heroes weren't earnest,'' Mr. Santora said, about the series's humor and verbal sparring, in an interview in The New York Times. ''Nothing is more boring than a procedural show where everyone is in lock step and acting as if it's the most important work in the world. I'd rather gouge my eyes out than watch one of them.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Margie Phelps, a lawyer for the Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan., and a daughter of its founder, the Rev. Fred Phelps, discusses the Supreme Court ruling in Snyder v. Phelps that found the church not liable for a $5 million jury award to Albert Snyder, the father of a Marine who was killed in Iraq. Church members appeared at the funeral with signs like ''America Is Doomed.'' The church contends that the deaths of soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan are God's way of punishing the United States for its tolerance of homosexuality.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) NOTHING PERSONAL Steven R. Schirripa, above, who played Bobby Baccalieri (until he was whacked) on ''The Sopranos,'' hosts this six-part series, which investigates the real-life world of murders for hire and the hit men behind them. This premiere episode tells the story of Larry Carrozza, known as Champagne, of the Colombo crime family. To prove his loyalty to the family, Mr. Carrozza accompanied Salvatore Miciotta, a notorious hit man called Big Sal, on what he thought would be an illicit yet routine errand in Brooklyn in 1983. It turned out to be a very different kind of illicit errand. Mr. Miciotta talks about what happened to Mr. Carrozza. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: REDEMPTION ISLAND Secrets are revealed on Redemption Island, and Matt and Russell duel to stay alive in the game. At 10 p.m., on ''Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior,'' a serial sniper taunts Mick (Matt Ryan) as he and the team try to track down the killer.

headline: Where to Point Your Browser
summary: ON THE SCREEN Blogs about trash have a wide-ranging, if filthy, pedigree. At one end are the fun and highly focused sites like Street Mattress (founded in 2001 and still posting pictures of discarded Posturepedics.) At the other are more academically minded ruminations on refuse, like Discard Studies, started in August. Last Night's Garbage occupies a space between these two poles. Photographs of trash dominate the blog and provide its author, Jed Tamarkin, with inspiration for writing short bits of fiction. The blog, which gets about 25,000 page views a month, has evolved since Mr. Tamarkin began shooting pictures outside his East Village apartment in the summer of 2007. Each photo was accompanied by text describing a fictional character with some relationship to whatever toy or commode or stroller happened to be lying on the street as Mr. Tamarkin passed by with his Canon point-and-shoot. (''There's a lot of baby strollers for some reason,'' he said.) Tags along the right side of the blog chronicle some of the recurring characters. There is Ross, a hard-drinking artist with relationship troubles; Stef, a chatty and celebrity-obsessed young woman; and Bobby, a drug-addled musician. There are also people who appeared only once, tossed off like so many old items of clothing.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) AMERICA CELEBRATES JULY 4TH AT FORD'S THEATERMichelle Obama is the honorary chairwoman of this annual celebration, taped on June 6, and President Obama will give the customary final address following performances by Kelly Clarkson, Dick Van Dyke, Renée Fleming, George Lopez, Lionel Richie and Robin Roberts, as well as cast members from the Broadway companies of ''Mary Poppins'' and ''Memphis'' and the Soldiers' Chorus of the United States Army Field Band. Gen. Colin L. Powell will pay tribute to five veterans who have received the Medal of Honor. Ty Burrell hosts. 7 A.M.
