(CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The morning shows are filled with the sound of music, starting here with Alicia Keys. Other performers are Maroon 5 on ''Today,'' at 7 on NBC; Mary J. Blige on ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 on ABC; and Pat Benatar on ''Rachael Ray,'' at 10 on ABC.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WALLANDER, SERIES II: THE MAN WHO SMILEDKenneth Branagh, left, continues his role as Inspector Kurt Wallander, Henning Mankell's scruffy Swedish sleuth, in this second of three new ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' productions. This episode finds Wallander reeling from having shot a man during his last case and on the verge of resigning from the force. But then his old friend Sten Torstensson (David Sibley) pleads with him to investigate the death of his father, who has just died in a suspicious car crash. Wallander refuses -- until Sten is found hanged. All signs point to murder after both father and son are revealed to have had the same unusual injury. Soon Wallander is back on the job and deep into a conspiracy involving postcards with death threats, a controversial philanthropist working in Africa and a former cop turned chief informant with some demons of his own. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY As Election Day approaches, Bret Baier tries to find out where things stand in the fight for the House. The guests include Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia; Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; and Karl Rove, former senior adviser to President George W. Bush.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International AFTER KYRGYZSTAN UPRISING,

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) CHUCK Chuck (Zachary Levi) and Sarah (Yvonne Strahovski), together above, go stylish -- and undercover -- in Milan during fashion week to retrieve a high-tech secret weapon. The model Karolina Kurkova and the actors Lou Ferrigno and Isaiah Mustafa guest star. In ''The Event,'' at 9, the staff of President Martinez (Blair Underwood) races to assess what happened to the plane that was barreling toward him last week until it disappeared into a fissure in the space-time continuum. And in ''Chase,'' at 10, Annie Frost (Kelli Giddish) and a team of United States marshals track a fugitive (Robert LaSardo) intent on killing for what he thinks is rightfully his. 3 P.M. (Fox Business Network) COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL Liz Claman broadcasts her 600th episode live from the Hercules Offshore oil rig H 201 in the Gulf of Mexico. Among the topics: the concerns and frustrations experienced by workers because of the moratorium against deep-water drilling imposed after the BP spill.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ESPN) INTO THE WIND In 1980, three years after receiving a diagnosis of osteosarcoma, a form of bone cancer, and having his right leg amputated six inches above the knee, Terry Fox decided to run across Canada. What began as one man's journey to raise money and awareness for cancer research has grown into the world's largest one-day fund-raiser for the cause. Though Mr. Fox, who was born in 1958, ran the equivalent of a marathon each day, he never finished his quest: starting in Newfoundland, he made it to Ontario before the cancer spread to his lungs. He died in 1981. In this latest entry in ESPN's ''30 for 30'' documentary series, the first-time filmmaker Steve Nash, a Canadian and a point guard for the Phoenix Suns, and the director Ezra Holland recount the story of Mr. Fox, one of Mr. Nash's childhood idols. ''I remember being a 6-year-old boy and waking up every morning and rushing to the TV to see where Terry was that day,'' Mr. Nash said. ''To see him running or hobbling across our country for the spirit of community and looking out for others was something that has stuck with me ever since. To see his face hiding the pain and to hear his words disguising the sacrifice was as motivating and as educational an experience as I've ever had.'' 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE First Sue Sylvester (Jane Lynch) and Olivia Newton-John got physical. Now Brittany (Heather Morris) and Britney Spears (as herself) are gyrating through the dreams of Will (Matthew Morrison), thanks to the anesthesia administered by Dr. Howell (John Stamos), a dentist and the new boyfriend of Emma (Jayma Mays).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 6:30 P.M. (FX) YOU DON'T MESS WITH THE ZOHAN (2008) Adam Sandler, above, stars in this comedy as Zohan, an Israeli special agent who wants out of the violent life. He fakes his death after an encounter with a Palestinian superterrorist (John Turturro) and heads to New York to become a hairstylist. A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the movie was ''the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen. That it is the only one I have ever seen -- and why is that? what cultural deficiency or ideological conspiracy has prevented this genre from flourishing? -- does not much detract from my judgment.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND David Owen, the former British foreign secretary and a physician, discusses the ''hubris syndrome'' in world leaders, past and present, and the theory that it might be an acquired personality disorder. He also recalls what Lord Acton famously wrote in an 1887 letter: ''Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths TINN, ARTHUR S.
summary: TINN--Arthur S.,age 83, recently of Brookfield, CT, died Wednesday. Born and resided in New York City for 72 years, veteran of WWII, graduate of CCNY, loving husband of the late Frances Tinn, Emmy Award winning director at CBS T.V. for 40 years. Survived by children; Jonathan, Eric and Elizabeth; son-in-law Tod and grandchildren Jenn, Zach, Charlie, Julia and Justin. Services 12 Noon, Sunday at Star Of David Chapel, West Babylon, NY.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths TINN, ARTHUR
summary: TINN--Arthur S., age 83, recently of Brookfield, CT, died Wednesday. Born and resided in New York City for 72 years, veteran of WWII, graduate of CCNY, loving husband of the late Frances Tinn, Emmy Award winning director at CBS T.V. for 40 years. Survived by children; Jonathan, Eric and Elizabeth; son-in-law Tod and grandchildren Jenn, Zach, Charlie, Julia and Justin. Services 12 Noon, Sunday at Star Of David Chapel, West Babylon, NY.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Showtime) NURSE JACKIE In this third-season premiere, Jackie (Edie Falco) and her marriage are feeling the strain of her prescription-drug problem, and after an intervention her relationship with Dr. O'Hara (Eve Best, above right, with Ms. Falco) is also at risk. Akalitus (Anna Deavere Smith) learns that some of the nearby hospitals could be closing, which would stretch her staff and resources to the limit. And Zoey (Merritt Wever) comes clean about her relationship with Lenny (Lenny Jacobson). 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE SECRET LIFE OF THE AMERICAN TEENAGER Amy (Shailene Woodley) wants her relationship with Ricky to progress, but Ricky (Daren Kagasoff) has a lot on his plate: his birth mother has unexpectedly re-entered his life. Ashly (India Eisley) tells her counselor that she wants to be home-schooled, and Ben (Kenny Baumann) and Adrian (Francia Raisa) learn the sex of their baby.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) MONEY AND MARCH MADNESS With the Final Four now set for this year's N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship, ''Frontline'' delves into the multibillion-dollar business of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and its brand of amateur sports. Lowell Bergman interviews Sonny Vaccaro, above, a former marketing executive at Nike, Adidas and Reebok who helped bring about the commercialization of college basketball, which last year resulted in a $10.8 billion, 14-year contract for the tournament with CBS and Turner Broadcasting. Now Mr. Vaccaro is leading a class-action suit aimed at getting college athletes, who traditionally have not been paid, a piece of the pie, and accusing the N.C.A.A. of preventing players from profiting from the use of their images and likenesses in licensed merchandise. Other ''Frontline'' segments include a portrait of Ai Weiwei, a global art star armed with a video camera and a growing Twitter following who is sometimes called China's Andy Warhol; and an interview with Brian Manning, the father of the imprisoned former military intelligence analyst Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, who maintains that his son did not hand over secret government documents to WikiLeaks. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS: THE STORY SO FAR Were Mike Catherwood and Lacey Schwimmer really told to tone down the sexual tension -- off the dance floor? Are Karina Smirnoff haters willing to ease up on their vitriol in support of the beloved Ralph Macchio, a k a the Karate Kid? And can Kirstie Alley continue to live up to her own hype? This special peels away the costumes and the spray tans on the 11 couples competing for the mirror-ball trophy before the first celebrity pairing is eliminated, at 9.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) CHAOSFreddy Rodriguez (''Six Feet Under'') stars as Rick Martinez, a C.I.A. spy whose dream job is eliminated on Day 1 but who is saved just in time by the agency's deputy director, H. J. Higgins (Kurtwood Smith). Higgins thinks the new guy would be a perfect addition -- as a mole -- to the roster of unruly agents in the Clandestine Administration and Oversight Services. Otherwise known as Chaos, the division is assigned to handle threats to national security, the biggest of which seem to be its own bureaucratic gridlock and incompetence. But when the agents dig up dirt on Rick, he finds himself playing their game. Eric Close portrays Michael Dorset, a psychologist turned operative motivated by paranoia; James Murray is Billy Collins, a Scot who was decommissioned from the British Secret Service and banished; Tim Blake Nelson (above right, with Mr. Close, center, and Mr. Rodriguez) is Casey Malick, whose understated demeanor serves to camouflage his ability to transform into a ''human weapon''; and Christina Cole is Adele Ferrer, who seems to have Rick's best interests at heart. But perhaps most dangerous is Fay Carson (Carmen Ejogo), an alluring agent with an uncanny ability for getting at the truth. 8 P.M. (Disney) PHINEAS AND FERB: PHINEAS'S BIRTHDAY CLIP-O-RAMA! As a birthday present to Phineas, Ferb puts together clips from previous episodes that show off the boys' best inventions. New animated segments tie it all together.

headline: Marshall Flaum, 85, Documentary Maker
summary: Marshall Flaum, an award-winning documentary filmmaker whose movies over a 55-year career examined show business, nature and historical subjects, died Oct. 1 in Los Angeles. He was 85. The cause was complications from hip surgery, his friend Mike Kaplan said.

headline: '60 Minutes' Plans to End Weekly Essay By Rooney
summary: Andy Rooney, whose folksy and often curmudgeonly essays have been a staple of ''60 Minutes'' for more than three decades, will end his regular weekly appearances on the program, CBS said Tuesday. Mr. Rooney, 92, has delivered 1,096 commentaries to the newsmagazine since becoming a regular contributor in 1978, according to CBS. He will formally announce his reduced role in essay No. 1,097 on Sunday night.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DRIBBEN, ELIZABETH L.
summary: DRIBBEN--Elizabeth L., New York City, passed away on January 20, 2011 after a long illness. Elizabeth was born in Buffalo, NY on August 20, 1937 and was the daughter of the late Louis Dribben and Clara Franklin. A graduate of Lafayette High School (Buffalo) and University of Buffalo, "Liz" enjoyed a four-decade career encompassing almost every aspect of broadcast news from writing to producing to on-air reporting, both locally on Buffalo's WKBW-TV and nationally for CBS News, in both radio and television. A pioneer among women in her field, Dribben continued to mentor younger reporters in her capacity as a member of the Adjunct Faculty of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University. At CBS from 1972-93, Dribben was principal writer-producer for Mike Wallace and Dan Rather, and produced her own program, One on One, eventually racking up some 2000 in-depth interviews with newsmakers in politics and the arts, from jurist Robert Bork to actress Helen Hayes. Her passion for theatre was legendary. She created and managed the network's (and the world's) first satellite radio unit. Ms. Dribben was a 2001 inductee of the Buffalo Broadcasting Hall of Fame, and a 2008 inductee to the Lafayette High School Hall of Fame. While she leaves no immediate family, she is survived by cousins in Albany, New York City and Israel, with her "family of friends" intertwined world-wide throughout the broadcasting and performance arts world. Elizabeth's generosity extends beyond her life, with the donation of her body to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Contributions in her memory may be made to the University at Buffalo (Attn: Cindy Johannes - E. Dribben Archives, P.O. Box 730, Buffalo, NY) or the Buffalo Broadcasters (Buffalo Broadcasters Association, 5672 Main Street, Williamsville, NY 14221) to help with the archiving of over 2,000 items from Elizabeth's vast portfolio - from personal correspondence to reel to reel tape interviews. Memorial services in Buffalo and New York City will be planned over the next few months. Toot-a-loo, Elizabeth - and spin that prayer wheel for us!

headline: CBS Tops Sunday
summary: In a rare instance of the Sunday night television schedule featuring no live sporting event or awards show, CBS managed to draw the most total viewers over all, thanks to the season premiere of ''The Amazing Race.'' According to preliminary Nielsen estimates the reality competition had 10.9 million total viewers, up slightly from the 10.4 million total viewers who tuned in to last year's premiere. The two-hour season premiere of ''Celebrity Apprentice'' on NBC did not fare as well, averaging 7.4 million total viewers.

headline: Political Sex Scandals Onstage in 'Tail! Spin!'
summary: When politics and sex meet it makes for great political theater. This summer they'll be theater when Mo Rocca (''CBS Sunday Morning''), Rachel Dratch (''Saturday Night Live'') and Sean Dugan (''Smash'') take the stage in ''Tail! Spin!'' -- a verbatim recitation of steamy e-mails, texts, interviews and Twitter messages that surfaced during recent political sex scandals. The show, created by the NPR contributor Mario Correa, is scheduled to play five performances, from Aug. 11-16, at the Kraine Theater as part of the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Directed by the Tony nominee Dan Knechtges (''Lysistrata Jones''), ''Tail! Spin!'' focuses on the sexual transgressions of four American politicians: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina who admitted to having an affair with a lover he had met while on vacation in Argentina; Larry E. Craig, a former Republican senator from Idaho who was caught in an undercover sex sting; and two former United States congressmen, Anthony Weiner of New York, who resigned over lewd online behavior, and Mark Foley of Florida, who resigned after he was caught sending sexually explicit texts to teenage Capitol Hill pages. The cast will portray some 30 different roles, including members of the media and the politicians' paramours and relatives.

headline: CBS Works to Revive Show Without Sheen
summary: It is not certain that CBS's hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men'' will return next season, but the show's studio, Warner Brothers, confirmed Thursday that it was trying to bring the show back without its original star, Charlie Sheen. A senior Warner Brothers executive, speaking on condition of anonymity because no deal has been set yet for the new version, confirmed Thursday that Chuck Lorre, the creator of the series, has set to work on a reconstruction of the show's format.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Hawaii Five-O’
summary: A scene in Monday’s episode of “Hawaii Five-O” doubled as an ad for Subway.

headline: Judge Says Aereo, a TV Streaming Service, May Continue
summary: Aereo, the service backed by Barry Diller, can keep streaming for now. A federal judge on Wednesday denied a temporary injunction sought by television broadcasters that would have shut down Aereo, a start-up that streams local TV stations' signals to customers over the Internet without the explicit permission of the stations.

headline: Excerpt: 'CSI'
summary: Ted Danson joined the CBS procedural this season.

headline: Preserving Music With Social Significance
summary: Recordings of Donna Summer's ''I Feel Love,'' Leonard Bernstein's first performance with the New York Philharmonic, ''Rapper's Delight'' by the Sugarhill Gang and a 1977 concert by the Grateful Dead are among the diverse entries that will be added to the National Recording Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday. Selected for preservation because they are ''culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant'' the library said in a news release, the 25 sound recordings chosen this year include a CBS radio broadcast of a Nov. 14, 1943, concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York and conducted by Bernstein, who filled in when both Artur Rodzinski and Bruno Walter were unavailable; as well as the Grateful Dead's May 8, 1977, performance at Cornell University's Barton Hall, which the library said ''has achieved almost mythic status among 'Deadhead' tape traders because of its excellent sound quality and early accessibility.'' Also chosen for induction were Bo Diddley's single ''Bo Diddley'' (and its B-side, ''I'm a Man''); the Booker T. & the M.G.'s single ''Green Onions''; the 1967 album ''Forever Changes'' by the psychedelic rock band Love; the soundtrack album of ''A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' performed by the Vince Guaraldi Trio; and ''Purple Rain,'' the 1984 soundtrack album performed by Prince and the Revolution.

headline: Split Decision in Ratings Battle
summary: In the battle for Thursday ratings supremacy, Fox and CBS split the spoils, as the former finished first in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic loved by advertisers and the latter reached the highest overall viewership. Fox's ''American Idol'' averaged 15.3 million total viewers and at least temporarily ended its slide in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic after a month of drops. NBC was also able to claim a small victory as ''Community'' held steady in the 18-to-49 category when compared to last week despite direct competition from a new episode of ''The Big Bang Theory'' on CBS at 8 p.m. ''Big Bang Theory'' on CBS was the No. 1 Thursday program with adults 18-to-49, but the show was down 12 percent in that category and dropped in total viewers (from 15 million to 13.6 million) when compared to the last new episode three weeks ago.

headline: 16th Time No Charm For ABC's 'Bachelor'
summary: Could the television broadcast audience be growing less susceptible to the charms of ''The Bachelor'' on ABC? The season premiere of the series averaged 7.7 million total viewers over a two-hour period on Monday night, according to Nielsen data, down from the 9 million viewers who watched the 15th-season premiere last January. There was also a 17 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last year. This placed ABC a distant second in the overall ratings among the broadcast networks, behind the CBS Monday comedy block. CBS finished No. 1 in all ratings categories in every prime-time half-hour. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: 'The Voice' Is Heard
summary: Riding its post Super Bowl send-off, NBC's singing competition ''The Voice'' exploded out of the gate in its first regular edition Monday night, squashing even the enormously popular CBS lineup of comedies. NBC got what might be called mixed results for its hugely anticipated new drama, ''Smash.'' The show dissipated a large portion of the ''Voice'' audience, but still managed to hit the best rating for any 10 p.m. drama on any network this season.

headline: Fierce '60 Minutes' Interrogator Who Didn't Blink
summary: Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of America's best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on ''60 Minutes,'' died on Saturday. He was 93. On its Web site, CBS said Mr. Wallace died at a care facility in New Canaan, Conn., where he had lived in recent years. Mr. Wallace, who received a pacemaker more than 20 years ago, had a long history of cardiac care and underwent triple bypass heart surgery in January 2008.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | THEATER
summary: MARY CHASE was wise about the comforting appeal that a divorce from reality offers. Her play ''HARVEY,'' about a man and his tall, invisible rabbit friend, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1944 and ran in its original Broadway production for more than four years. Now Roundabout Theater Company is reviving Chase's comedy in the first Broadway production of the 2012-13 season. When a show opens amid the feverish fuss about Tony Awards for the prior season, as ''Harvey'' is doing, its performances are often forgotten a year later. But the Roundabout has assembled a cast as likely to be memorable as any, led by Jim Parsons, the two-time Emmy Award winner for his portrayal of Sheldon Cooper, the charming nerd of a theoretical physicist on the CBS comedy ''The Big Bang Theory.'' He plays the rabbit-friendly Elwood P. Dowd, a role memorably played by James Stewart in the 1950 film version and the 1970 Broadway revival. Scott Ellis directs a cast that also includes Jessica Hecht, Charles Kimbrough, Larry Bryggman and Carol Kane. Previews begin Friday at Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org; $37 to $127.

headline: Excerpt: 'Chaos'
summary: The new CBS spy comedy stars Freddie Rodriguez.

headline: Amid Rumors She Is Leaving CBS, Couric Heads to Iraq
summary: As reports continue to swirl about an impending departure from her anchor position at CBS News, Katie Couric is to embark Tuesday morning on a long-planned trip to Iraq, where she will report on the military and political situation eight years after Baghdad fell to invading American forces. The trip, which CBS is expected to announce Tuesday, comes even as CBS and representatives of Ms. Couric repeat their recent denials of an imminent resolution of her current status at the network. Her contract with CBS ends June 4.

headline: Harold Dow, 62, Emmy-Winning CBS Reporter
summary: NEW YORK (AP) -- Harold Dow, the Emmy-winning CBS News correspondent who helped shape the documentary program ''48 Hours'' and covered the kidnapping of Patricia Hearst and the Sept. 11 attacks, died Saturday. He was 62. Mr. Dow died suddenly Saturday morning in New Jersey, a network spokeswoman, Louise Bashi, said. He lived in Upper Saddle River, N.J., but it wasn't immediately clear if he had been at home. The cause of death was not announced.

headline: CBS Explores Live Streaming With Web Show
summary: The live Web show ''What's Trending'' at cbsnews.com, an attempt to build a news-and-chat program driven by social networking -- sort of a digital ''Today'' -- is a self-consciously experimental project. That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: ''We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. It's what you need to know to be in the now.'' What's obviously different about ''What's Trending,'' which will webcast its second episode Tuesday at 1 p.m. Eastern time, is its approach to the news -- its content and format -- an area in which it's already been taken to task. It's probably unfair, or at least unrealistic, to criticize the show for a lack of seriousness or news judgment, given its premise and its Twitter-driven title. In the premiere episode the struggle by Ms. Lazar and her producers to find an intelligent way to discuss current events through the lenses of Facebook and Twitter (here, as in most discussions, the alpha and omega of social networking) was palpable and mostly unsuccessful.

headline: Glaad Grades Networks
summary: Most of the broadcast networks are satisfactorily portraying gays and lesbians on television, a leading media advocacy group said in a report released on Thursday. The Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, in its annual check-up of sorts on the networks, found that gay characters "are increasingly presented as matter-of-fact manner rather than a curiosity" and lauded the CW in particular. But it also labeled one broadcaster, CBS, as "failing" and called for more ethnic and cultural diversity in the portrayals of gay characters.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Good Wife'
summary: The CBS drama, starring Julianna Margulies, has lost viewers since moving to Sundays.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'BRIEN, G. FRANK
summary: O'BRIEN--G. Frank, of New York, NY, aged 73, passed away in Goshen, NY, April 25. Survived by brothers Edward Charles O'Brien and Daniel Rea O'Brien, several nieces and nephews. Frank was a retired File Clerk for CBS Law Dept. New York, NY. Funeral mass 10am Wednesday, May 2 at St. John The Evangelist Church, Goshen, NY. Donations to: www.hospiceoforange.com. Services by Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Monroe, NY.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (OWN) OPRAH'S NEXT CHAPTER Oprah Winfrey interviews Whitney Houston's daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown (above, with Ms. Winfrey); her sister-in-law and manager, Patricia Houston; and her brother, Gary Houston, about the speculation surrounding Ms. Houston's death on Feb. 11. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger discusses the political situations in Iran, Syria and other hot spots in the Middle East, as well as in China and Russia. Elliott Abrams, a senior fellow for Middle Eastern studies with the Council on Foreign Relations, and Rula Jebreal, a Palestinian journalist, talk about the visit of Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to the White House.

headline: Stuck in 3rd, CBS Upends 'Early Show'
summary: In a sweeping attempt to catch up to its rivals, CBS News will replace every member of the weekday anchor team on ''The Early Show,'' its perennially third-place morning program.

headline: John Miller to Join CBS, Bolstering 'The Early Show'
summary: Every week or so comes another signal that CBS is reshaping ''The Early Show,'' its low-rated morning newscast. On Monday will come another: the announcement that John Miller is joining the network as a senior correspondent with a special emphasis on the morning show. Mr. Miller, a fixture in media and law enforcement circles for decades, was most recently a deputy to the government's director of national intelligence. Once Mr. Miller ''put the word out'' about his decision to leave government, ''there was a lot of interest in him'' from television networks, said David Rhodes, the president of CBS News. At CBS, Mr. Miller will report and comment on homeland security, law enforcement and other matters.

headline: CBS Profit Sets Quarterly Record, Though TV Revenue Falls
summary: The CBS Corporation reported record operating income for the second quarter of 2012, even though overall revenue declined slightly from a year ago because of shifts in television programming schedules and a decline in digital sales. The company on Thursday reported $769 million in operating income for the three months ended June 30. That was a 5 percent increase over the same period last year and the highest second quarter for CBS since it was established as a separate entity from Viacom six years ago.

headline: Tonys Ceremony Is Set
summary: The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. (Off Broadway and regional shows are not eligible.) The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'BRIEN, G
summary: O'BRIEN--G. Frank, of New York, NY, aged 73, passed away in Goshen, NY, April 25. Survived by brothers Edward Charles O'Brien and Daniel Rea O'Brien, several nieces and nephews. Frank was a retired File Clerk for CBS Law Dept. New York, NY. Funeral mass 10am Wednesday, May 2 at St. John The Evangelist Church, Goshen, NY. Donations to: www.hospiceoforange.com. Services by Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Monroe, NY.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WRIGHT, WILLIAM
summary: WRIGHT--William. A former publishing executive who is credited with helping to revive the industry in the 1990s, died on February 26, 2012 surrounded by family at his home in Zionsville, Ind. He was 62 years old. The cause was complications from ocular melanoma, a rare cancer, his daughter Diana said. His strong and loving character, wisdom and generosity will be missed by all. Mr. Wright had a reputation in the publishing industry as a strong motivational leader. He left the Chief Operating Officer post at Random House Inc, to serve as President and CEO of the Hearst Book Group in 1995 after the publisher fell into tumult when many of its top authors and editors defected. Mr. Wright streamlined costs and grew the business by attracting new editorial talent. He published numerous bestselling books from authors as diverse as Pope John Paul II, President George H. W. Bush, Sidney Sheldon and Whoopi Goldberg. Mr. Wright was dedicated to promoting the publishing industry and serving his community. He was a past Chairman of New York is Book Country and was a board member of the Association of American Publishers from 1996 to 1998. While at the helm of Hearst Book Group he was a strong advocate for Literacy Volunteers, a statewide network of community-based volunteer services that exists to foster and strengthen literate communities throughout New York. His community service continued during his retirement. He served as a volunteer for Child Advocates of Indiana, an organization that intervenes on behalf of abused and neglected children. Prior to joining Random House in 1992, Wright was Senior Vice President of Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group. Before that he was Senior Vice President of CBS Educational and Professional Publishing. He joined CBS in 1980 as Director of Distribution and went on to hold several positions of increasing responsibility. Mr. Wright held a B.S. in Economics from Villanova University (1972) and an M.B.A from Temple University (1973). Bill received a scholorship to play basketball at Villanova but later relinquished his scholarship to focus on the arrival of his first child. "Despite his pressing job and community service responsibilities, Bill remained close to his children and remarked in his final hours that their success and happiness as adults was his proudest accomplishment," remarked Patricia Reber, his beloved longtime executive assistant. Mr. Wright is survived by his second wife Chandra of Zionsville, IN, his daughter Diana Wright Milkowski and her husband Matt Milkowski of Rumson, NJ and his son Jason Wright of Manhattan. He is also survived by grandchildren Kevin, Jake, Lyla and Mia and stepchildren Brittany, Charles and Corttany. There will be a memorial service at Assumption Church in Fairfield, CT on Friday, March 9, 2012 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Opportunity Network, 55 Exchange Place, Suite 503, New York, NY 10005 or online at opportunitynetwork.org.

headline: Television Schedule
summary: MONDAY -- FRIDAY 11 a.m.â7 p.m. Tennis Channel

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 54TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS ''Music's Biggest Night'' pulls out the stops with performances by Glen Campbell, this year's recipient of the Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Award, who will be joined by the Band Perry and Blake Shelton. The program also features Adele, who will sing live for the first time since her surgery five months ago; Paul McCartney, the 2012 MusiCares Person of the Year; Alicia Keys and Bonnie Raitt, in a tribute to Etta James; Chris Brown, Deadmaus, the Foo Fighters, David Guetta and Lil Wayne in a salute to electronica music; and the Beach Boys, who will reunite after more than two decades of not performing together live, backed up by Maroon 5 and Foster the People. Kanye West leads the nominations with seven, followed by Adele, the Foo Fighters and Bruno Mars with six, and Lil Wayne and Skrillex with five. L L Cool J, above with Taylor Swift, hosts this ceremony, broadcast from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' will be shown at 5 and ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6, both on E! 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum talks about his victories in Colorado, Minnesota and Missouri, and how he intends to maintain momentum. Jack Lew, the White House chief of staff, discusses the economic recovery, the White House budget and tension with Syria and Iran. Mr. Lew will also appear with Sarah Palin on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; with Mr. Santorum on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC; and with the Republican presidential candidate Representative Ron Paul of Texas on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WRIGHT, WILLIAM
summary: WRIGHT--William. A former publishing executive who is credited with helping to revive the industry in the 1990s, died on February 26, 2012 surrounded by family at his home in Zionsville, Ind. He was 62 years old. The cause was complications from ocular melanoma, a rare cancer, his daughter Diana said. His strong and loving character, wisdom and generosity will be missed by all. Mr. Wright had a reputation in the publishing industry as a strong motivational leader. He left the Chief Operating Officer post at Random House Inc, to serve as President and CEO of the Hearst Book Group in 1995 after the publisher fell into tumult when many of its top authors and editors defected. Mr. Wright streamlined costs and grew the business by attracting new editorial talent. He published numerous bestselling books from authors as diverse as Pope John Paul II, President George H. W. Bush, Sidney Sheldon and Whoopi Goldberg. Mr. Wright was dedicated to promoting the publishing industry and serving his community. He was a past Chairman of New York is Book Country and was a board member of the Association of American Publishers from 1996 to 1998. While at the helm of Hearst Book Group he was a strong advocate for Literacy Volunteers, a statewide network of community-based volunteer services that exists to foster and strengthen literate communities throughout New York. His community service continued during his retirement. He served as a volunteer for Child Advocates of Indiana, an organization that intervenes on behalf of abused and neglected children. Prior to joining Random House in 1992, Wright was Senior Vice President of Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group. Before that he was Senior Vice President of CBS Educational and Professional Publishing. He joined CBS in 1980 as Director of Distribution and went on to hold several positions of increasing responsibility. Mr. Wright held a B.S. in Economics from Villanova University (1972) and an M.B.A from Temple University (1973). Bill received a scholorship to play basketball at Villanova but later relinquished his scholarship to focus on the arrival of his first child. "Despite his pressing job and community service responsibilities, Bill remained close to his children and remarked in his final hours that their success and happiness as adults was his proudest accomplishment," remarked Patricia Reber, his beloved longtime executive assistant. Mr. Wright is survived by his second wife Chandra of Zionsville, IN, his daughter Diana Wright Milkowski and her husband Matt Milkowski of Rumson, NJ and his son Jason Wright of Manhattan. He is also survived by grandchildren Kevin, Jake, Lyla and Mia and stepchildren Brittany, Charles and Corttany. There will be a memorial service at Assumption Church in Fairfield, CT on Friday, March 9, 2012 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Opportunity Network, 55 Exchange Place, Suite 503, New York, NY 10005 or online at opportunitynetwork.org.

headline: On Night of Repeats, 'Big Bang' Stands Out
summary: A repeat of ''The Big Bang Theory'' was enough to give CBS an easy ratings victory (in total viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic) on Thursday, according to Nielsen data. All of the networks had a full slate of repeats, resulting in lower viewership totals across the broadcast board, but the audience for CBS's geeky comedy has proved to be very loyal, even for previously aired episodes. It still drew 10.2 million total viewers Thursday night, losing less than a third of its fall live audience average of 14.7 million for new episodes. Although its authenticity has been called into question, Discovery Channel's ''Moonshiners'' has frequently found itself to be among the top-rated cable shows on Wednesday nights. The most recent episode tied for the highest-rated cable program among adults 18-to-49 to go with a total of 2.6 million viewers.

headline: Polls Favor Two Democrats
summary: Democratic incumbents have an edge over their challengers in the Florida and Ohio Senate races, while in Wisconsin, fresh from winning the Republican primary, former Gov. Tommy Thompson has a six-point advantage over Representative Tammy Baldwin. New Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News polls of the three swing states offer a view of the competition for control of the Senate.

headline: CBS Adds 3 Gay Roles
summary: LOS ANGELES - For years CBS has lagged behind other television networks in its inclusion of gay, lesbian and transgender characters. In the season that starts in September, however, a gay character will join ''The Good Wife,'' a lesbian character will join ''Rules of Engagement'' and a gay character will appear in the new sitcom ''$#*! My Dad Says.'' Speaking last week to television reporters, Nina Tassler, CBS entertainment president, said the network was adding the characters to its prime-time programs ''because we're very disappointed in our track record so far.''

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Tuesday about Americans' sentiments regarding President Obama's decision to endorse same-sex marriage misstated the degree of support among racial groups when four New York Times/CBS News polls taken over the past year were aggregated. Sixty-one percent of self-identified Democrats who are white support legalizing marriage for gay couples, not 45 percent. Eighteen percent are opposed to any legal recognition, not 28 percent.

headline: On The Campaign Plane: Secret Service Gun Left Behind
summary: TAMPA, Fla. -- A Secret Service agent was pulled off Mitt Romney's campaign plane on Wednesday after accidentally leaving her loaded handgun in the bathroom. A CBS News producer found the gun in the lavatory as the Republican nominee flew from Tampa, Fla., to Indianapolis for a speech on Wednesday. An agent on the plane was alerted and retrieved the gun without incident.

headline: Ratings Decline Across the Board
summary: In what turned out to be a very rough night for the broadcast networks, almost all of Thursday's programming fell sharply no matter what category or time period is used for comparison. According to Nielsen, Fox's ''American Idol'' had another drop in total viewers, to 13.8 million this week from 15.9 million last week, and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic its new drama ''Touch'' fell to 7.5 million total viewers from 8.9 million. On CBS ''The Big Bang Theory'' hit a season low in the 18-to-49 category, and ''Person of Interest'' tumbled to its lowest viewership since February, at 13.5 million. ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC and ''Community'' and ''30 Rock'' on NBC dropped to season lows in adults 18-to-49 as well.

headline: On TV, Romney Doesn't Show Immigration Hand
summary: Responding to the challenge that President Obama posed in his order last week to stop deporting some illegal immigrants, Mitt Romney declined to say on Sunday whether he would reverse the president's decision if he takes up occupancy of the White House. Although Mr. Romney said during the Republican primary debates that he would veto the Dream Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants, he was more equivocal about Mr. Obama's order last week. It allows work permits and prevents deportation for as many as 1.4 million undocumented immigrants under the age of 30 who were brought to the United States as children.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MCMULLEN, JAY
summary: McMULLEN--Jay. He was a man of purpose, of integrity and achievement. His life was testimony to the conviction that the documentary film should embody the highest standards of journalism and that serious reporting had a place in television. His career was dedicated to upholding the Murrow tradition at CBS News, an era firm in its belief in the separation of news and entertainment, in non-partisan reporting independent of ratings, and in the nobility of its mission. He was a trusted colleague, a cherished friend and an inspiration. We join the McMullen family in mourning his passing and honoring his legacy. Xiaoyan and Irv Drasnin.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $30/SQUARE FOOT $63,120 approximate annual rent

headline: TV Ratings System Expected to Expand Online
summary: The black labels that tell families what to expect from network television shows will start to appear on the Internet streams of those shows, too. The expansion of the TV content ratings system is expected to be announced by the major broadcast networks on Monday morning. The ratings will be included in all episodic streams on Web sites like ABC.com and Fox.com by December, according to people with knowledge of the plan, who insisted on anonymity because it had not yet been made public.

headline: CBS and Comedy Central Get Gifts From Sheen
summary: The lambasting of Charlie Sheen's real and fictional personas proved to be a ratings gold mine for CBS and Comedy Central on Monday night. The season premiere of ''Two and a Half Men'' on CBS, which featured the funeral of Mr. Sheen's character, Charlie Harper, drew 27.8 million viewers. It was the highest-rated and most-watched season premiere of a scripted show since the second-season premiere of ''Desperate Housewives'' in September 2005. The show also lifted the rest of the CBS comedy slate, providing a big lead-in for its new comedy ''2 Broke Girls'' (19.1 million viewers) and helping ''How I Met Your Mother'' reach its highest premiere audience ever (11.3 million). Meanwhile, the roast of Mr. Sheen on Comedy Central was the second-most-watched telecast in the history of that cable channel, at 6.4 million total viewers, and the most-watched ever in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SHERLOCK, SERIES 2: A SCANDAL IN BELGRAVIA Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman (above from left) reprise their roles as Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson for the 21st century in this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' presentation. The sleuthing begins as they plunge into a case of blackmail involving the clever dominatrix Irene Adler (Lara Pulver), whose motto is ''know when you are beaten.'' It seems she has performed some ''recreational scolding'' on a British royal -- and she has the photographs to prove it. Now she's trying to trump Holmes at his own game. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS David Axelrod, the senior adviser to the Obama campaign, and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discuss the latest jobs report, the diplomatic crisis over the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng and whether the White House has taken too much credit for the killing of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MCMULLEN, JAY
summary: McMULLEN--Jay. He was a man of purpose, of integrity and achievement. His life was testimony to the conviction that the documentary film should embody the highest standards of journalism and that serious reporting had a place in television. His career was dedicated to upholding the Murrow tradition at CBS News, an era firm in its belief in the separation of news and entertainment, in non-partisan reporting independent of ratings, and in the nobility of its mission. He was a trusted colleague, a cherished friend and an inspiration. We join the McMullen family in mourning his passing and honoring his legacy. Xiaoyan and Irv Drasnin.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $36/SQUARE FOOT $144,432 approximate annual rent

headline: Revival Tour
summary: Long on the verge, Los Angeles's once-derelict downtown is the city's newest hot spot, where restaurants, galleries and boutiques are sprouting up almost overnight. By the time the Ace Hotel and the Diller Scofidio and Renfro-designed Broad Museum open next year, the neighborhood's transformation will be complete. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Shake-Up in Co-Hosts of CBS's Morning Show
summary: CBS on Thursday shuffled the deck of its six-month-old morning show, replacing Erica Hill with Norah O'Donnell, the network's chief White House correspondent. The casting change came as a surprise to staff members of ''CBS This Morning,'' the network's latest effort to create a competitive morning show. The CBS News executives who orchestrated the change said they felt that Ms. O'Donnell was a perfect fit for the co-host role, particularly given the current busy period of political news. She will join the other two co-hosts, Charlie Rose and Gayle King, in the early fall, they said.

headline: Excerpt: ‘How to Be a Gentleman’
summary: The new CBS sitcom updates the “Odd Couple.”

headline: Vice President Biden on CBS
summary: In an interview, Vice President Joe Biden offers a variety of critiques of Mr. Romney.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10:30 P.M. (HBO) GIRLS Four single women in their 20s navigate disappointing love lives and careers in New York -- and invite comparisons to Carrie, Samantha and the rest of the ''Sex and the City'' gang -- in this new comedy from Lena Dunham (''Tiny Furniture''). The show stars Ms. Dunham, Zosia Mamet and Jemima Kirke (above, from left) and Allison Williams. '' 'Girls' offers romantic failure wrapped in the trappings of failure,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. She added, ''The depiction of slacker life in New York, which includes tattoos, drugs, casual sex and abortions, is presented with wry humor, but it could easily be interpreted as a cautionary tale written by the religious right: the lifestyles of these modern women, untethered to responsibility, faith or morality, are parables that could scare Amish youth away from Rumspringa and wayward Mormons back into their temple garments.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Bill Cosby speaks about the Trayvon Martin case and civility within the 2012 presidential campaign. Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, discusses party unity.

headline: For 'CBS This Morning,' Showtime Has Arrived
summary: It is exceedingly rare for a new television newscast to be made almost entirely from scratch, as is the case with ''CBS This Morning,'' which will replace ''The Early Show'' on Monday morning. Many of the producers and talent bookers for ''CBS This Morning'' are new to the network, as are two of the three anchors, Charlie Rose and Gayle King.

headline: Plan to Split News Corp. Helps Stock
summary: On Wall Street, it's called the ''Murdoch discount.'' That's the view that the shares of News Corporation trade lower than the intrinsic value of its many media assets because of the control exerted by Rupert Murdoch. Because of his hold, the argument goes, the company takes on expensive ventures like the $5 billion purchase of Dow Jones in 2007, an acquisition whose value was heavily written down soon after closing.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (AMC) MAD MEN In last week's Season 5 premiere, Don Draper (Jon Hamm) was the man of the hour at a surprise birthday party engineered by his new wife, Megan (Jessica Paré, above), but he was embarrassed by her sexy performance of the French song ''Zou Bisou Bisou'' in front of his colleagues. In this week's episode, Don and Harry (Rich Sommer) try to make a client happy. Peggy Olson (Elisabeth Moss), fresh off the disappointment of having her Heinz pitch rejected, takes on new duties at the office. 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The program broadcasts an interview with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in which he expresses confidence that the Supreme Court will uphold the constitutionality of the health care law. Bob Schieffer speaks with Newt Gingrich and Ron Paul, both Republican presidential candidates, about the 2012 election. Other guests are Jan Crawford and John Dickerson, both of CBS News; Kevin Madden, a campaign adviser for Mitt Romney; and Gwen Ifill of PBS NewsHour.

headline: Country Music Awards Lift CBS in Ratings
summary: The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with ''60 Minutes.'' ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched ''Secret Millionaire'' at 8, followed by ''Desperate Housewives'' (8.8 million) and ''Body of Proof'' (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for ''The Celebrity Apprentice'' from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for ''Dateline'' at 7 (5.2 million) and ''America's Next Great Restaurant'' at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SILVER, BEN PEABODY
summary: SILVER--Ben Peabody. Award-winning CBS television news reporter and journalism professor, father to six and grandfather to eleven, died from complications of Parkinson's Disease May 2 at his home in St. Louis Park, MN. He was 85.

headline: Tight Senate Races Seen In Virginia and Wisconsin
summary: A new poll finds tight races for Senate seats in the presidential swing states of Virginia and Wisconsin.In Virginia, where the race pairs two former governors, 48 percent of likely voters support the Democratic candidate, Tim Kaine, and 46 percent back the Republican nominee, George Allen, a difference that is within the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

headline: Stand-Up Comedy Booker for 'Late Show' Loses Job
summary: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Eddie Brill, a longtime gatekeeper for rising stand-ups at ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' will no longer be the comedy booker at that CBS late-night series, ending the tenure of a respected and contentious figure in the stand-up comedy world.

headline: A Tinge of Workout Envy
summary: COLUMBUS, Ohio -- Mitt Romney is a man of steady and immutable habits. He drinks Cherry Coke Zero. He eats peanut butter and honey sandwiches. And he works out on an elliptical machine.Day, after day, after day.

headline: CBS Declares Next Week Is 'Tweet Week'
summary: If only CBS had thought of this when Charlie Sheen was still on one of its shows: taking a page from rival networks like ABC, CNN and Comedy Central, which have used Twitter to draw in and keep viewers watching shows like ''Piers Morgan Tonight'' and events like the Academy Awards or ''The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump,'' CBS announced on Thursday that it would have eight nights of programming emphasizing that platform. During that period some of its performers and personalities will post on Twitter in real time. #CBSTweetWeek, as the network is calling it, will run from Sunday through April 11 and spotlight events like Sunday's Academy of Country Music Awards (for which the musicians Dierks Bentley and Julianne Hough will post comments and answer questions on Twitter) and Monday's N.C.A.A. Division I men's basketball national championship game (during which the CBS Sports analysts Greg Anthony and Seth Davis will both be on call).

headline: A Good Night for CBS
summary: CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. ''Big Brother'' is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of ''Family Guy'' on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. ''60 minutes'' did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, ''The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special'' won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last season's edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Wednesday about the CBS executive Mike Aresco's being named the commissioner of the Big East Conference gave an outdated title for Sean McManus. He is the chairman, not president, of CBS Sports. (He was president from 1996 to 2011.)

headline: Revival of Murrow Show Sets Opening Lineup
summary: CBS News cameras were lined up inside the billionaire investor Warren Buffett's office on Wednesday for a new edition of ''Person to Person,'' a celebrity interview show that dates back to the 1950s, when Edward R. Murrow was the host. Newly revived by CBS, ''Person to Person'' will feature Mr. Buffett, the actor George Clooney and the singer Jon Bon Jovi on the episode that will be shown on Wednesday, Feb. 8. The network plans to announce the lineup on Thursday morning.

headline: 'NCIS,' New and Old, Lifts CBS in Ratings
summary: A new installment of ''NCIS'' topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results episode (15.6 million). ABC's new series ''Body of Proof'' won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming ''The Good Wife'' on CBS (10.6 million) and ''Parenthood'' on NBC (4.7 million). ABC's ''No Ordinary Family'' (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBC's ''Biggest Loser,'' which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: At Last, Couric Is Expected To Say She's Leaving CBS
summary: This week, Ms. Couric is planning to acknowledge one of the worst-kept secrets in television: that she is leaving the ''CBS Evening News'' after five years. Then, as soon as she returns from London, where she will be anchoring the network's coverage of the royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday, CBS will announce her successor during the first week of May. The meticulously arranged exit plan was described by four people with knowledge of it, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because it was not supposed to be revealed before the formal announcement.

headline: CBS Buys Clicker, a Web TV Guide
summary: The CBS Corporation said on Friday that it had acquired Clicker, a guide to online television, and installed its chief executive, Jim Lanzone, as the head of its digital media division. The Clicker acquisition strengthens CBS's position in an increasingly competitive area, television on the Web. The purchase price was not disclosed.

headline: Grammy Concert Moves to Nashville
summary: The televised concert to announce nominees for the Grammy Awards will be held in Nashville this year, in a nod to the power of country music within the music industry, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday.The show, entitled "The Grammy Nominations Concert Live!!!," will be broadcast from the Bridgestone Arena on CBS on Dec. 5 at 10 p.m.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Television network executives are in that anxious time of year just before they present the new season's shows to advertisers (the so-called upfronts). TV watching is down over all, as people, especially those in the lucrative 18- to 49-year-old market, turn to other media. CBS led all networks in average viewers from Sept. 19 through April 29, with hits like ''NCIS'' (above, with Mark Harmon, left, and Michael Weatherly) and ''The Good Wife.'' But Fox drew more viewers age 18 to 49. Cable networks with high numbers in that demographic include FX (882,000), A&E (773,000) and TNT (733,000). SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVITAN, GEORGE
summary: LEVITAN--George, on May 20, 2012. George was the core and spark of his wife's existence. He was so proud of his career at the United Nations and CBS and never forgot his most remarkable experiences. He shared them all with all of us, as he did his love for Frank Sinatra and French Silk Ice Cream. He will always be remembered by his many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and nephews and great-great-nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed. He had such pride for his deceased brother Paul and sister Belle. His adoring wife, Sydelle. Family and friends may gather today 11:15am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI. A graveside service to follow 12:30pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

headline: Tuning In: Fox Wins Convention Viewers
summary: TAMPA, Fla. - More than 20 million people tuned in to the Republican National Convention on Tuesday night, and more of them watched on Fox News than on any other channel by far. According to preliminary ratings, 6.9 million people tuned in to Fox News from 10 to 11 p.m., the hour that featured the evening's major speeches, by Ann Romney and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Million-Dollar Chorus For Obama Tax Plan
summary: Wednesday's installment of President Obama's running campaign to raise the taxes of millionaires featured a group of wealthy people who agree with him, standing at his side as he professed that the idea is popular among the gilded elite from Warren Buffett on down. ''The people who've joined me here today are extremely successful,'' Mr. Obama said during an appearance in the White House complex.

headline: Corrections
summary: A picture last Sunday with an article about the revival of downtown Los Angles was published in error. It was of ''Light Lab,'' by Amy Yoes, which appeared an an earlier exhibition at CB1 Gallery, one of many new businesses downtown; it did not show one of Daniel Aksten's colorful Tetris-like grids currently being exhibited.

headline: Letterman Anniversary Is Like a Low-Key Guest
summary: 5:12 p.m. | Updated David Letterman will celebrate 30 years as a late-night television host on Wednesday, though without much fanfare. There has been little media attention paid to the anniversary, and no prime-time special, or even a special celebration, planned by CBS.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Person of Interest’
summary: The CBS series stars Michael Emerson and Jim Caviezel.

headline: Netflix Attains the Rights To CW Network Shows
summary: 2:01 p.m. | Updated Once a Netflix skeptic, Time Warner has struck its biggest deal yet to allow the online service to license its television content. On Thursday, the Warner Brothers Television Group of Time Warner and the CBS Corporation announced a $1 billion deal that will give Netflix the rights to stream shows broadcast on the CW network for at least the next eight years.

headline: 'Tonight Show' Lays Off 20, And Leno Takes Salary Cut
summary: The NBC network on Friday instituted budget cuts at ''The Tonight Show,'' a television mainstay that has played home to Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and now Jay Leno.Between 20 and 25 ''Tonight'' staff members were laid off, according to a person with direct knowledge of the cuts, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the details of the restructuring are private. To stave off additional staff reductions, Mr. Leno took a sizable pay cut, said the person, who would not specify the amount. Some producers also agreed to salary reductions in order to keep their jobs, according to Deadline Hollywood, which earlier reported news of the cutbacks .

headline: ‘Good Wife’: Diane Is the Moral Center
summary: Part 9: The cast and creators of “The Good Wife” talk about how CBS has tried to change the show.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBAUM, MICHAEL
summary: ROSENBAUM--Michael, 64, on May 17. Family, friends, the journalism community and Cornell classmates mourn the loss of this award-winning CBS News producer. He rose from cub reporter at the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle to a distinguished 27-year career with CBS News, including as producer for the Evening News, Tel Aviv bureau chief and producer for 60 Minutes. He worked closely with Dan Rather and Bob Simon. Jeff Fager, chairman of CBS News, said Michael was skeptical of almost everything. His 1996 interview with Ethel Rosenberg's brother, who said he lied in testimony that helped send his sister to the electric chair, won Michael his fourth Emmy. He died peacefully at home in Manhattan after a brain tumor diagnosed in September. He is survived by his brother, David, of Los Angeles, sister, Judy Witt of Evanston, Ill., nephews Adam and Daniel Rosenbaum, niece Abby Witt and many loving friends. Services: 10:30am, Monday, Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83d St., NYC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBAUM, MICHAEL
summary: ROSENBAUM--Michael, 64, on May 17. Family, friends, the journalism community and Cornell classmates mourn the loss of this award-winning CBS News producer. He rose from cub reporter at the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle to a distinguished 27-year career with CBS News, including as producer for the Evening News, Tel Aviv bureau chief and producer for 60 Minutes. He worked closely with Dan Rather and Bob Simon. Jeff Fager, chairman of CBS News, said Michael was â€œskeptical of almost everything.â€ His 1996 interview with Ethel Rosenberg's brother, who said he lied in testimony that helped send his sister to the electric chair, won Michael his fourth Emmy. He died peacefully at home in Manhattan after a brain tumor diagnosed in September. He is survived by his brother, David, of Los Angeles, sister, Judy Witt of Evanston, Ill., nephews Adam and Daniel Rosenbaum, niece Abby Witt and many loving friends. Services: 10:30am, Monday, Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83d St., NYC.

headline: Univision and ABC to Start an English Channel to Reach Hispanics
summary: 10:30 a.m. | Updated The Walt Disney Company's ABC News division and Univision have tentatively agreed to create an English-language cable television channel for Hispanics in the United States. The companies, which will each own 50 percent of the joint venture, said Monday morning that the channel - which is, as yet, unnamed - would start sometime in the first half of 2013. Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, said it would be ''a 24/7 news, information and lifestyle network primarily in English that will serve the youngest and fastest-growing demographic in the country: U.S. Hispanics.''

headline: Never Too Late to Find His Brigadoon
summary: LOS ANGELES -- In his seven years as host of ''The Late Late Show'' on CBS, Craig Ferguson has had many an unusual broadcast, whether it was an episode partly lighted by flashlight when his studio lost power or an evening dedicated to the BBC science-fiction series ''Doctor Who.'' But until now Mr. Ferguson had never taken his show to Scotland, his home country. Following in the tradition of a series of ''Late Late Show'' episodes filmed in Paris last year, Mr. Ferguson traveled to Scotland in March, taking along his robot sidekick, Geoff Peterson, a team of celebrity pals like Mila Kunis, Rashida Jones, Michael Clarke Duncan and David Sedaris, and, wisest of all, some cameras to film his journeys there.

headline: Excerpt: 'Unforgettable'
summary: The CBS drama is about a police consultant who remembers almost everything.

headline: Excerpt: 'Hawaii Five-O'
summary: The new CBS series updates the 1970s police show.

headline: New Poll Finds Voters Dubious of Obama's Announcement on Same-Sex Marriage
summary: WASHINGTON -- Most Americans suspect that President Obama was motivated by politics, not policy, when he declared his support for same-sex marriage, according to a new poll released on Monday, suggesting that the unplanned way it was announced shaped public attitudes. Sixty-seven percent of those surveyed by The New York Times and CBS News since the announcement said they thought that Mr. Obama had made it ''mostly for political reasons,'' while 24 percent said it was ''mostly because he thinks it is right.'' Independents were more likely to attribute it to politics, with nearly half of Democrats agreeing.

headline: CBS Drops Hallmark Hall
summary: The Hallmark Hall of Fame franchise of made-for-television movies no longer has a home on network television. CBS has chosen not to extend its three-movie-a-year deal with Hallmark, so the franchise is now being shopped to others, Variety reported on Friday. CBS confirmed the decision in a statement that read: ''This is a partnership that has served CBS very well for many years. Hallmark Hall of Fame is a first-class organization, and we wish them nothing but success in their future.'' Hallmark Hall of Fame movies have been a television staple for 60 years and have been shown on NBC, PBS and ABC in the past. In recent years CBS has telecast the emotional, upbeat movies around holidays like Thanksgiving and Valentine's Day.

headline: TimesCast | May 15, 2012
summary: The race to define Mitt Romney's career at Bain Capital | President Obama courts female voters | Some surprising numbers in a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Excerpt: '2 Broke Girls'
summary: The CBS sitcom stars Beth Behrs and Kat Dennings.

headline: CBS Soap Opera Renewed
summary: CBS is not giving up on the daytime soap entirely. The network announced Monday that it had renewed ''The Young and the Restless'' for three more seasons, keeping the daily drama on the network through 2014. The 38-year-old series is the highest-rated soap opera on network television, so its renewal is not necessarily surprising on its own. But other soaps have not been so lucky lately: last year CBS canceled the soap opera ''Guiding Light,'' and this year it canceled ''As The World Turns.'' The former was effectively replaced by the game show ''Let's Make a Deal,'' and the latter by ''The Talk.''

headline: Fox's 'Idol' and CBS Are Leaders
summary: The ratings for ''American Idol'' reversed their course on Thursday night, growing slightly compared to last week, which provided Fox with a win for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. CBS drew the most viewers over all. An average of 17.9 million people watched ''Idol,'' barely beating last week's total of 17.4 million but the show was also up 4 percent in the 18-to-49 category. Again, not a large gain, but a change from the downward trend that followed earlier episodes. The CBS lineup continued its strong performance as ''The Big Bang Theory'' drew 16.1 million total viewers and beat ''Idol'' with adults 18-to-49 in the half-hour they went head to head, while ''The Mentalist'' had its largest audience of the season with 14.4 million viewers.

headline: Inside Today's New York Times/CBS Poll
summary: Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the findings of a New York Times/CBS News poll out today on the 2012 Republican presidential field.

headline: Jay McMullen, 90, Investigative Journalist
summary: Jay McMullen, whose career as an investigative journalist for CBS News included early uses of hidden cameras and undercover reporting, died Saturday at a hospice in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90. His death was confirmed by his family.

headline: Grammys to Be Held In Los Angeles Again
summary: The Grammy Awards will be held on Feb. 10 next year at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, its home for years, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has announced. The nominations will be revealed two months earlier, on Dec. 5, during a live prime-time concert. Both events will be broadcast on CBS. This year's broadcast was seen by almost 40 million viewers, making it the second-most-watched Grammy Awards ceremony in the event's 54-year history. (The highest was in 1984.) This year's highlights were a sweep of the major awards by Adele, the British soul singer, and a tribute to Whitney Houston, the pop diva who died the night before the broadcast. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Bridge'
summary: In this new series, a co-venture of CBS and the Canadian network CTV, a cop fights internal corruption as well as street crime.

headline: Wynton Marsalis on CBS
summary: Wynton Marsalis, the virtuoso jazz trumpet player and longtime artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, is adding another job to his resume: television commentator. CBS News announced on Thursday that Mr. Marsalis would begin appearing on its morning shows as a ''cultural correspondent'' in mid-January. Though his precise role is unclear, the announcement said the 50-year-old jazz artist from New Orleans would offer ''insight into a broad range of cultural and educational developments.''

headline: Hallmark Hall of Fame Needs a Get Well Card
summary: After proving to be a stable presence on broadcast television for more than 60 years, the Hallmark Hall of Fame is off to a rough start in its new home at ABC. That feel-good film franchise was dropped by CBS in May after a 16-year partnership, only to be picked up in July by ABC. But it seems that its audience forgot to change the channel. On Sunday ABC showed its first Hallmark movie, ''Mitch Albom's Have a Little Faith,'' which lost more than 50 percent of the total audience from last year's post-Thanksgiving Sunday presentation of ''November Christmas.'' That movie drew 13.5 million total viewers for CBS while ''Have a Little Faith'' managed only 6.5 million for ABC. Over all for the night, NBC dominated every ratings category with ''Sunday Night Football,'' as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Kansas City Chiefs, 13-9. Final numbers were not available Monday.

headline: Katie Couric to Fill In for Week On 'Good Morning America'
summary: Next week, Katie Couric will co-host the news on ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' It's a one-week role for the former co-host of ''Today,'' the main rival to ''Good Morning America'' in morning television. Ms. Couric will be filling in for Robin Roberts, who has the week off.

headline: Eugenio Derbez in 'Rob'
summary: The Mexican comedy star is starting to raise his profile in the United States.

headline: Competition Gets a Break From CBS Reruns
summary: A full slate of repeats on CBS allowed the other broadcast networks to gain some ground in the ratings on Thursday. Fox was by far the No. 1 network for the night, according to Nielsen data, as both ''American Idol'' and ''Touch'' received a bump in viewership from last week. They finished with 15.3 million total viewers and 8.2 million, respectively. ABC also benefited from the lack of competition. Not only did ''Grey's Anatomy'' bounce back from season lows, but the political drama ''Scandal'' also posted higher numbers, including 7.5 million total viewers, in its second week than its premiere. It's a rare feat for a new program.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth Recovering After Accident
summary: The actress Kristin Chenoweth was released from the hospital after she was injured Wednesday during the filming of the CBS series ''The Good Wife.'' In a statement on Thursday, Jill Fritzo, a publicist for Ms. Chenoweth, said: ''Kristin has been released from the hospital and is home recovering. She thanks everyone for their prayers and well wishes.''

headline: Excerpt: 'NYC-22'
summary: The new police drama, beginning on CBS on April 15, follows a group of rookie officers.

headline: CBS Reporter Attacked in Cairo
summary: 6:14 p.m. | Updated | Lara Logan, the CBS News correspondent, was attacked and sexually assaulted by a mob in Cairo on Feb. 11, the day that the Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was forced from power, the network said Tuesday. After the mob surrounded her, Ms. Logan ''suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers,'' the network said in a statement. Ms. Logan is recovering at a hospital in the United States.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 66TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, above, once again will sing and dance his way through the role of host for this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway, to be broadcast live from the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Performers include the casts of the nominees for best musical and musical revival -- ''Newsies,'' ''Nice Work if You Can Get It,'' ''Once,'' ''Evita,'' ''Follies,'' ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Leap of Faith'' -- as well as ''End of the Rainbow,'' ''One Man, Two Guvnors,'' ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' ''Ghost the Musical'' and ''Godspell.'' ''The Book of Mormon,'' last year's winner for best musical, will also be featured. Ellen Barkin, Candice Bergen, Jessica Chastain, Sheryl Crow, Nick Jonas, Angela Lansbury, James Marsden, Trey Parker, Jim Parsons, Mandy Patinkin, Tyler Perry, Bernadette Peters, Christopher Plummer, Paul Rudd, Amanda Seyfried and Matt Stone are among the presenters. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana; Dennis Van Roekel, president of the National Education Association; and Thea Lee, deputy chief of staff for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., about the effect of Wisconsin's recall election on the electoral map.

headline: In Debates, Two Women Will Moderate
summary: The moderating duties for the four presidential and vice- presidential debates this year will be evenly split between male and female journalists for the first time, the Commission on Presidential Debates said Monday, nearly two months before debate season begins.The moderators will be Jim Lehrer of PBS, Bob Schieffer of CBS, Candy Crowley of CNN and Martha Raddatz of ABC, the commission said after a long and mostly secret selection process.

headline: Voices From the Iowa Poll
summary: Jeff Zeleny reports on the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, focused on Iowa voters. In one month, the state’s caucuses will kick off the presidential election cycle.

headline: Historical Society Plans World War II Exhibition
summary: Helping to fill the seemingly endless appetite for information about World War II, the New-York Historical Society is planning a major exhibition on the conflict's effect on the homefront this fall.Titled "WWII & NYC," the exhibition is scheduled to open Oct. 5 and run through May 27. Among the documents scheduled for display is a rare copy of the original Instrument of Surrender , Japan's formal surrender to the Allies on Sept. 2, 1945, that will be exhibited starting on Sept. 21, before the rest of the exhibition opens. The document, one of 20 copies of the surrender agreement created at the time, has not been displayed in New York since 1945.

headline: TV Ratings
summary: In an odd twist, the time change due to Daylight Savings apparently continued to depress television ratings among the networks for the fourth night in a row on Wednesday. Overall viewership in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic was down by 9 percent compared to last week and almost every show experienced a drop in ratings of some kind. Fox was the No. 1 network for the night and ''American Idol'' had 17.9 million total viewers, but that was down from the 18.7 million who tuned in for last Wednesday's episode. On ABC, ''Modern Family'' finished with season lows in the 18-to-49 category and in total viewers (10.5 million). ''Criminal Minds'' on CBS hit a series low in viewers 18-to-49 and had 11.3 million total viewers.

headline: 'Chronicle' Leads on Slow Weekend for Movies
summary: Score one for 20th Century Fox, whose low-budget movie ''Chronicle'' turned out a bigger-than-expected crowd at theaters on what is typically one of Hollywood's slowest weekends of the year. ''Chronicle,'' about three teenage boys who learn they have superpowers, was No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $22 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The solid result for ''Chronicle,'' made in-house for a mere $12 million (not easy for a huge studio to do), validates Fox's decision to aggressively aim for elusive male moviegoers -- and on Super Bowl weekend, no less. Notably, Fox relied heavily on Twitter to create buzz, buying zero newspaper ads.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES The ladies who scheme and lunch wrap up loose ends as the series comes to a close. Bree's lawyer, Trip (Scott Bakula), begs her to tell him what really happened the night of Alejandro's murder when it looks as if she were about to be convicted. Gaby (Eva Longoria) tries to come up with a way to take the burden off Bree (Marcia Cross, above with Mr. Bakula). Susan (Teri Hatcher) works to conceal the sale of her house until she can break the news to her neighbors; Katherine Mayfair (Dana Delany) returns to Wisteria Lane with a job offer for Lynette (Felicity Huffman) -- one that could end her chances of reconciliation with Tom (Doug Savant). Renee (Vanessa Williams) reaches the end of her rope when Ben (Charles Mesure) is arrested before their wedding. And all the women agree to take care of Mrs. McCluskey (Kathryn Joosten) when she decides to die at home. 7 A.M. (Starz) EASY A (2010) Emma Stone plays Olive, a good girl who pretends to be bad to raise her social standing in high school, as well as that of some persecuted class virgins, in this satire directed by Will Gluck. But when her faked promiscuity generates an unexpected chain reaction, she sews a capital A on her clothes and parades around the school in suggestive outfits. Amanda Bynes is the leader of the Christian club, who denounces Olive as a slut. Penn Badgley is Olive's prince-in-waiting. ''Whatever else it accomplishes, the sassy high school comedy 'Easy A' commands attention for the irresistible presence'' of Ms. Stone, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times.
