headline: Public Opinion: Support for Cutting Back Mail
summary: An overwhelming majority of Americans support the Postal Service's plan to end Saturday mail delivery, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times/CBS News. The survey found that about 7 in 10 Americans say they would favor the change as a way to help the post office deal with billions of dollars in debt. The Postal Service continues to suffer losses of $36 million a day and is headed for projected losses of about $21 billion a year by 2016.

headline: ABC and CBS Split Prime-Time Monday
summary: ABC and CBS settled for a split ratings victory on Monday night as ''Dancing With the Stars'' averaged 17.5 million total viewers over a two-hour period and led ABC to the highest total audience. CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, though ''Two and a Half Men'' continued to fall from its lofty early-season perch to 14.9 million total viewers, down another million viewers from last week. One more drop of that size and the show will be in the same Charlie Sheen territory as last year. ''Terra Nova'' on Fox returned to its normal 8 p.m. time period with nearly 8 million viewers, down slightly compared to the last regularly scheduled episode two weeks ago.

headline: Marv Albert to Call N.F.L. Games for CBS
summary: Marv Albert will call N.F.L. games for CBS Sports starting this season, if there is one, but will give up announcing games for the Nets on the YES Network. Albert said the initial offer to call the games for CBS came during the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, which he was calling for CBS and Turner Sports, his primary employer for N.B.A. broadcasts on TNT.

headline: Network TV Viewers Keep Vanishing
summary: The case of the missing network viewers continued Wednesday night as more shows, including some of the biggest hits on television, recorded their lowest ratings of the year. That happened to ABC's ''Modern Family,'' considered the strongest comedy on television, which sank to a season-low 4 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old audience that drives most ad sales. The pattern continued with other ABC shows on the night. The comedy ''Suburgatory'' hit a low for that series, a 2 rating, and the much-talked about drama ''Revenge'' returned from a seven-week hiatus with its own season low, a 2.3 rating.

headline: Major Networks Shut Out of Best Drama Category in Emmy Nominations
summary: The winner of the Emmy Award for outstanding drama won't be announced until September. But the category's losers were all identified on Thursday: the big broadcast networks that televise the awards. The networks were completely shut out of the main drama series category for the first time, reflecting the gradual drift of top writers, producers and actors to cable.

headline: Rosemary Rice, 87, Daughter On Early TV's 'Mama' Series
summary: Rosemary Rice, an actress who found fame in the early days of television playing the perky oldest daughter, Katrin, on '' Mama ,'' a beloved family show broadcast live on CBS for many years, died on Aug. 14 at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 87. The cause was a heart attack, her son, John Merrell, said.

headline: Appellate Court Again Rules Against F.C.C. Fine in Janet Jackson Case
summary: WASHINGTON - A federal appeals court on Wednesday again threw out a $550,000 fine against CBS by the Federal Communications Commission forJanet Jackson's ''wardrobe malfunction'' during the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia had issued a similar ruling in July 2008. But that decision was sent back to the appeals court in May 2009 by the Supreme Court after it ruled in a separate case that the F.C.C. had the right to hold broadcasters accountable even for unscripted and isolated foul language.

headline: And More of the Same On the Networks, Too
summary: It was another low-key post-holiday night for television on Tuesday as the broadcast networks filled the schedule with more repeats. CBS was the No. 1 network over all in viewers and tied Univision for the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS's broadcast of the 34th annual Kennedy Center Honors attracted a sizable older audience with an average of 8.4 million total viewers, but the 18-to-49 crowd shied away. It tied the 2002 broadcast for the lowest-rated Kennedy Center Honors in viewers 18-to-49 and was down 27 percent in that advertiser-beloved category when compared to last year. A repeat of ''NCIS'' on CBS was the highest-rated program in every category for the night and drew 12.5 million total viewers.

headline: TimesCast | Santorum Catches Up
summary: February 14, 2012 - Rick Santorum catches up to Mitt Romney among Republican primary voters in the lastest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Monday about Representative Gabrielle Giffords's decision to resign from Congress in order to concentrate on recovering from her shooting injury, misidentified the television show on which she and her husband were interviewed in November when she demonstrated her improved ability to speak. It was ABC's ''20/20'' program, in an interview with Diane Sawyer -- not the CBS program ''60 Minutes.''

headline: Last Word: Mike Wallace
summary: Mike Wallace, the tough-guy interrogator of “60 Minutes,” was the personification of 20th-century television news. He made his name confronting the famous and infamous on camera.

headline: TV Executive Is Rebuked For Comments on Women
summary: 3:46 p.m. | Updated Even in the absence of Charlie Sheen, the CBS sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' is still finding ways to cause controversy. This time it's Lee Aronsohn, a co-creator and executive producer of that series, who incensed industry colleagues by suggesting that there were too many television comedies focusing on women.

headline: Mitt Romney on 'Face the Nation'
summary: Mitt Romney spoke on President Obama's most recent changes to immigration policy in an interview with Bob Schieffer.

headline: Lane Venardos, 67, Ex-CBS Vice President
summary: Lane Venardos, the executive producer of the ''CBS Evening News'' in the 1980s and later the network's vice president for hard news, overseeing its coverage of the protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and the Persian Gulf war a year later, died on Friday at his home in Maui, Hawaii. He was 67. The cause was a heart attack, his daughter Kelly Venardos-Ward said.

headline: Really, Really Short Workouts
summary: Think you’re too busy to work out? We have the workout for you. In minutes, high-intensity interval training (H.I.I.T.) will have you sweating, breathing hard and maximizing the health benefits of exercise without the time commitment. Best of all, it’s scientifically proven to work.

headline: David Axelrod on “Face the Nation”
summary: In an appearance on CBS, David Axelrod says that Mitt Romney "hasn't been able to make the sale to his own party."

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Thursday about Mitt Romney's declaring that the mandate in President Obama's health care program is a tax misstated the arrangements for an interview with CBS News in which Mr. Romney addressed the issue. The timing of the interview was set more than a week earlier. It was not ''hastily arranged.''

headline: Abortion and Akin Off-Limits
summary: It's the sort of statement that leaves journalists slack-jawed: ''The one stipulation to the interview was that I not ask him about abortion or Todd Akin.'' That's what Mitt Romney's campaign demanded, said Shaun Boyd, a reporter for the CBS-owned television station in Denver, when she interviewed the Republican presidential candidate on Thursday. Ms. Boyd was one of four Denver reporters to be granted five minutes with the candidate via satellite, and the only reporter to tell viewers about any preset restrictions.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS Bart persuades his family to go on a cruise, above, and even wrangles a luxury suite. Now if he can only figure out how to make the vacation last longer than a week. Treat Williams and Steve Coogan guest star. The soundtrack features an original song by Robert Lopez, a creator of ''The Book of Mormon.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY John O. Brennan, the chief counterterrorism adviser to President Obama, discusses the war on terror a year after the killing of Osama bin Laden. Mr. Brennan moves over to ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10, and ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' also at 10, on ABC.

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary on Monday about the television journalist Mike Wallace referred incorrectly to an interview he conducted for the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' with the chemist Jeffrey Wigand, who said tobacco executives had lied when they testified before Congress that they believed nicotine was not addictive. While CBS did not broadcast the interview in November 1995 as originally scheduled, it did indeed broadcast it three months later; it is not the case that ''the interview was not broadcast.'' The obituary also misstated the year when ''60 Minutes'' moved to its longtime time slot, Sunday nights at 7. It was 1975, not 1970.

headline: Another Chance For Arsenio Hall
summary: After an absence longer than many careers in show business, Arsenio Hall will be attempting a comeback in late-night television when a new syndicated show begins in over a year. Mr. Hall and partners that include CBS Television Distribution and stations owned by the Tribune Company announced on Monday that they had agreed to introduce a late-night show starring Mr. Hall in the fall of 2013.

headline: TimesCast | February 14, 2012
summary: Explosions in Bangkok | Santorum ties Romney in latest New York Times/CBS News poll | Underage models at New York Fashion Week.

headline: G.M. Won't Advertise In 2013 Super Bowl
summary: 5:59 p.m. | Updated For the second time in a week, General Motors is making news for advertising it will not be running rather than for advertising it is running. G.M. said it would not buy commercial time during Super Bowl XLVII, to be broadcast by CBS on Feb. 3, 2013. The company is not pulling out of the game, because it had not already agreed to buy any spots; rather, it has decided against a buy.

headline: ABC's 'Dancing' Is Strong, But CBS Leads the Pack
summary: Network television was a night of two Kurts on Tuesday as the retired N.F.L. quarterback Kurt Warner became the latest player eliminated on ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' and Kurt Hummel (Chris Colfer) on ''Glee'' stood up to a bully in an episode of the Fox series inspired by recent news reports. Both programs fared well in the ratings. The ABC dancing show attracted 16.8 million viewers to win the 9 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Glee'' drew a relatively modest 10.8 million viewers at 8 but led the night in the demographic prized by advertisers, adults 18 to 49. CBS averaged the most viewers over the course of the night with ''NCIS'' (19.8 million), ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (15.5 million) and ''The Good Wife'' (12.2 million). ABC placed second, with 7.8 million viewers for both ''No Ordinary Family'' at 8 and ''Detroit 1-8-7'' at 10. Fox ranked third, and NBC was fourth.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SILVER, BEN
summary: SILVER--Ben Peabody. Award-winning CBS television news reporter and journalism professor, father to six and grandfather to eleven, died from complications of Parkinson's Disease May 2 at his home in St. Louis Park, MN. He was 85.

headline: Cycling on Camera, in New York and Beyond
summary: There is something cinematic about riding a bicycle through New York traffic with its speed, lights and danger. For the rider, street scenes can open up in flashes between stopped cars, creating a kind of stuttered approximation of film. No wonder, then, that many riders, like Luke Stiles and Chris Thormann, have tried to capture these scenes with a camera.

headline: Messting
summary: Text messages that could mess up your life.

headline: Welcome Home, Wives
summary: ABC was grateful for the women of Wisteria Lane, as a new episode of that prime-time soap opera helped the network place second on Sunday night.

headline: 'Holidays in Hawaii'
summary: Monologue | Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Everyone's back from vacation today. In Washington, President Obama returned to the Oval Office after spending the holidays in Hawaii. And Joe Biden returned after spending the holidays on his home planet.

headline: Pitching a Product, Without Showing It
summary: Kellogg began an ad campaign on Monday that pitched the Special K Challenge to women but, in a twist, never showed the cereal in the spot.

headline: Pulling Out All the Stops to Rescue a TV Hero
summary: At times in the new season of “Chuck,” the NBC spy comedy beginning its new season on Sunday, the title wimp becomes a warrior.

headline: Dubai Opens a Tower to Beat All
summary: In the midst of a real estate crash, Dubai pulled out all the stops to celebrate the opening of the world’s tallest building.

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, a Mobile Ad Company
summary: Update | 11:24 a.m. Adding confirmation of deal.

headline: Secrets Kept Last Week May Lead to Victories This Week
summary: The Cardinals, Eagles and Bengals -- all three teams blowout losers in the final week of the season -- had something to preserve for the N.F.L. playoffs: the element of surprise.

headline: 'We Don't Need It'
summary: Monologue | Monday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: The global warming conference has been canceled. Right. We don't need it. You see, because it's so damn cold.

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
summary: Apple encroached upon Google's turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
summary: While Google introduced its first piece of hardware, the Nexus One cellphone, Apple began to take aim at advertising, Google’s bread and butter.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of Handling of Case
summary: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

headline: 'Exploding Underpants'
summary: Monologue | Tuesday night on "The Late Show With david Letterman" on CBS: Cold. Am I right? You know, Rush Limbaugh was ill. And he had to go to the hospital. He had chest pains but he's completely recovered. He'll be back on his job on Wednesday, which is great because the country really can use some hot air now.

headline: DirecTV Outlines 3-D Programming Push
summary: DirecTV announced Wednesday that it would debut several 3-D channel services later this year.

headline: Football Rolls Over ‘Conveyor Belt’
summary: A pair of reality shows, including one in which male contestants were delivered on a conveyor belt to prospective female mates, delivered decent ratings for ABC on Monday night.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday: Friends Forever?
summary: What to watch for Wednesday, Jan. 6.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Watch: New Media Drama
summary: The firm sues Duke Rosco, a monomaniacal talk show host whose reckless video vigilantism against the mother of a missing child drives the woman to suicide.

headline: NBC May Be Considering Reinstating Leno on 'Tonight Show'
summary: NBC executives held discussions with both Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien Thursday about the future of the network's late-night lineup. And while executives said that no final decision has been made, they did not deny that the network was considering moves that could include returning Mr. Leno to his old job as host of "The Tonight Show."

headline: The Pilot Navigates Fame
summary: Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III has adjusted to his fame since he landed US Airways Flight 1549 in the Hudson River last year. A new TLC documentary explores the event.

headline: Tennis Channel Takes Its Feud With Comcast to the F.C.C.
summary: The Tennis Channel claims cable operator Comcast is guilty of discrimination by making its own networks more widely available.

headline: Bloomberg — the Company — Helps Commercial Real Estate
summary: Bloomberg L.P. breathed a little life into the troubled commercial office market when it became the third largest renter of new office space.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: A Green Preview
summary: The auto industry is still in austerity mode when it comes to car shows. The North American International Auto Show in Detroit begins press previews on Monday, and according to Jim Henry, reporter for CBS Interactive, "The list of 19 brands holding a press conference is shorter than the list of 26 that aren't."

headline: Late-Night Hosts Joke About Latest Late-Night Chaos
summary: Once again, the lives of the late-night comedians provided them with plenty of fodder for their topical monologues — and for once, the focus wasn’t on David Letterman.

headline: Redstone Sells Russian Theaters to Daughter
summary: National Amusements, the holding company controlled by Sumner Redsone, is selling its Russian theater chain to Mr. Redstone's daughter and other investors in a further move to reduce its debt, The Associated Press reports.

headline: TV Calendar: New Shows in the New Year

headline: Sampler: Marriage Trial Goes Personal and Oakland Airport Is Most Punctual
summary: Personal Lives on the Stand | In the first day of the same-sex marriage trial in federal court in San Francisco, Theodore B. Olson asked his client, "What does it mean to be a lesbian?" Two gay couples testified about their lives and their reactions to the 2008 passage of Proposition 8, the state ballot initiative that changed the state's constitution so that gays and lesbians could not marry. Video coverage of the nonjury trial, which addresses the constitutionality of the gay-marriage ban, is not available on YouTube, as had been planned. Hours before the trial began, the United States Supreme halted, for a few days, the plan to show the court proceedings on YouTube until the justices could review the issue of cameras in the court room. [The New York Times]

headline: Jan. 14: Updates on the Rescue Effort in Haiti

On Tuesday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad told state television that the three Americans may be exchanged with Iranians jailed in the United States. "We're still at ground zero here, and nothing has happened," said Ms. Shourd, of Oakland, whose daughter, Sarah, has been imprisoned in Iran since she and two friends crossed the Iranian border from Iraq. "I can't even begin to tell you what this feels like to us." [The Oakland Tribune, Reuters]

Has the show canceled?" And the guy said, "No, just checking in on the elderly."

headline: Sampler: Asian Surnames Top Homebuyers and a Plan to Restore Bay Area Marshes
summary: Silicon Valley's Economy at Risk | A new study says that Silicon Valley lost 90,000 jobs in 2009, compared with the same period in 2008. The drop in the number of midlevel jobs, like engineers, has been the sharpest, as employers hire contractors instead of regular employees or hire people abroad, according to the annual report produced by the Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network and the Silicon Valley Community Foundation. But the report says the region's troubles go beyond the current job picture and the area could lose its competitive edge. "Let me give you a few snapshots in despair," wrote Chris O'Brien, in a column in The San Jose Mercury News. "The venture capital industry is collapsing. Our educational system is failing. State government is dysfunctional. Other regions are cleaning up on federal funding for green-tech jobs. And immigrants who have kept our innovation economy humming are feeling less and less welcome." [The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News].

headline: Crocidolite Acrostic

headline: Sampler: Drug Cases Dismissed in San Francisco and Can a Big House be Green?
summary: More Evidence Found in Santa Clara | Public defenders in Santa Clara County are waiting to see how the cases of accused sex offenders may be affected by the district attorney's office effort to gather new evidence from the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center. Some new material, known as intake forms, collected by the center's sexual assault response team were discovered this week. The discovery comes after last year's revelation that the center had 3,000 videotapes of medical exams of children who were alleged victims of assault. The videotapes have already led to the release of a man  convicted earlier and have put other convictions at risk. An appellate court ruled two years ago that hospital examiners were part of the "prosecution team" and that the district attorney's office was responsible for making sure evidence was turned over to defendants. "I'm sure they were dismayed at the discovery, and I'm glad to see they are jumping on it," said the public defender, Mary Greenwood. "We hope and believe the defense perspective will be solicited about the value of what else they find." [The San Jose Mercury News]

summary: It's Official: Gavin Newsom to Seek No. 2 Seat | "We are announcing formally today that I am jumping into the race for lieutenant governor," San Francisco's mayor, Gavin Newsom, told KCBS on Friday morning. This confirmed a report in The San Francisco Examiner that the mayor, after dropping from the race to become governor, planned to officially declare for office. "I really feel deeply that my responsibilities at home can be met in the context of this race," Mayor Newsom told KCBS, referring to his wife and baby daughter. In the June 8 primary, Mr. Newsom, 42, will face Janice Hahn, a Los Angeles councilwoman. On Thursday, Mr. Newsom reported his latest campaign contributions, which included $6,500 apiece from Mark and Susie Buell, who have been major contributors to Democratic candidates for national office, and $4,950 from Peter Ragone, his former press secretary. [KCBS, The San Francisco Examiner]

headline: Sampler: Pitching Marijuana for the Revenue, and the Last Day for Google Broadband Applications
summary: Marijuana Proposal Appeals to Need for Green | Proponents of the ballot measure to legalize marijuana in California won't dwell on the drug's safety or social acceptance. Instead, they will focus on money: They say that taxing its sales could raise $1.4 billion and ease the $20 billion state deficit. The measure, which qualified for the November ballot on Wednesday, would allow licensed retailers to sell up to one ounce at a time, a transaction that would be subject to tax. "We need the tax money," said Richard Lee, founder of Oaksterdam University, a trade school in Oakland for marijuana growers. Mr. Lee backed the ballot measure's successful petition drive. "Second, we need the tax savings on police and law enforcement, and have that law enforcement directed towards real crime." Some are not so sure. "We just don't think any good is going to come from this," said John Standish, president of the California Peace Officers Association. [The New York Times]

headline: Sampler: Confusion Over Medical Marijuana Rules, and Mall Parking Erased for Green Cars
summary: How Much Medical Marijuana Is Too Much? | Police, prosecutors and defense lawyers have struggled with the question of how much pot a medical marijuana patient may possess since the California Supreme Court threw out a conviction and struck down a state law that imposed an eight-ounce limit. Instead, patients are entitled to a "reasonable" amount of the drug for their ailments, the court said in its January ruling. The ruling has resulted in a number of marijuana cases being dismissed; other trials ended in acquittals. Law enforcement agencies around the state are struggling with the aftermath of the ruling. "Gray is not a good color for the law," said Gerald Benito, the Shasta County district attorney, who dismissed a case this month. "It makes it very difficult for us to enforce the law - I think everyone is crying out for a clear line." [The Associated Press]

headline: The Best Money Sites on the Web
summary: The annual Webby Awards were announced on Tuesday and there were two categories that caught our eye here at Bucks, Banking/Bill Paying and Financial Services.For the second year in a row, Mint won for Best Financial Services Web site, and for the third year in a row it won the People's Voice award. Mint, a personal finance Web site, beat CBS Moneywatch, which features video interviews with Jill Schlesinger; MicroPlace, a microfinance Web site; StockMapper, a site that specializes in stock heat maps; and wikinvest, an investment research portal.In the Banking/Bill Paying category, a money management site, moneyStrands, took the Webby, knocking last year's winner Xero out of the category. The London-based online lender Wonga won the People's Voice Award, which also went to Xero last year. The nominees in the category included The Morris Code, an interactive personal finance Web site sponsored by Bank of America and geared toward college students; Billeo, a bill paying site; and BillShrink.com, a Web site that scours the Internet for better deals on things like credit cards and cellphone plans.One additional note was in the Education category which nominated the Your Life, Your Money project. The project was produced by WNET-TV and Working Dog Productions and ran on the Public Broadcasting Service Web site.

headline: Sean Hayes to Host Tony Awards
summary: These have been some busy weeks for Sean Hayes, the Emmy Award-winning “Will & Grace” star: he’s been starring on Broadway in the revival of “Promises, Promises,” which netted him a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical. And – oh, yes – he recently came out publicly and was criticized by Newsweek in an article that said he and other gay actors were unconvincing as straight characters. And what better way to put that behind him than by hosting a nationally televised awards program? The much buzzed-about Mr. Hayes has been chosen to host the 64th Annual Tony Awards, its organizers said on Monday. The awards ceremony that honors Broadway’s best will be held on June 13 at Radio City Music Hall and will be broadcast live on CBS. The show’s longtime executive producers, Glenn Weiss and Ricky Kirshner of White Cherry Entertainment, will return and Mr. Weiss will once again direct the program. The 2010 Tonys team will come into the show with some momentum, or some big shoes to fill, depending on how you look at it: the 2009 awards ceremony, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew the show’s best ratings in three years.

headline: Leader of the Pack: ABC’s ‘Bachelorette’
Chair Lift | Give Your Table an Update
summary: A good friend inherited a Victorian circular oak dining table. The table has great sentimental value, but the matching oak and cane chairs - high-back and ornate - needed to go. He wanted something up to date but not hyper-modern (no plastic, no chrome). I suggested a bentwood chair like the ones that Thonet has been manufacturing for years, which would relate to the Victorian design of the table but still feel modern. He liked the idea but not the price tag (the chairs are about $400 a piece), and he was concerned about the sturdiness of the caned seats, an issue he had with the original chairs.

headline: Week 7 College Football Matchups
summary: The college football season is a grind. The clear goal for the top teams is to stay undefeated and that means you have to bring your best game every week. Alabama showed us last week that the top teams can't afford to come out flat. The Tide traveled to face a tough South Carolina team that had a great day and now it no longer controls its own destiny. This week Ohio State, which took over the top spot, goes on the road to Madison for one of the toughest games on its schedule. Auburn hosts Arkansas with the goal of remaining unbeaten headed into next week's game against L.S.U. (Would love to see both teams undefeated for that one.) Meanwhile, unbeaten Nebraska looks for some revenge as it hosts Texas in a rematch of last year's Big 12 championship game. Even some of the lower ranked unbeatens like Michigan State and Missouri have challenging games. Every week we learn a little bit more. This Sunday the B.C.S. rankings come out and the debate gets ratcheted up a notch. Things are happening people. Every Saturday is important.

headline: Week 8 College Football Matchups
summary: One of my favorite (and most delicious) things to compare the college football season to is a pint of Guinness. It takes some time to settle. You think you're ready for that first sip, but you're not. Patience, things are still settling. You stare at it. Still settling. Sometimes (often when you are thirstiest) it feels like it will never be ready to drink. (Anyone else getting thirsty?) That's how this season is going. It's taking forever to settle. The picture is still hazy. Just when it seemed like we knew what was going on the No. 1 team started losing every week. Now it seems we know even less. Will Oklahoma be the third straight No. 1 to go down? Don't sleep on Missouri and its nasty defense. Who will remain as the last unbeaten in the SEC after Auburn hosts L.S.U.? Will Cameron Newton's stock continue to rise? Or will he pull a Taylor Martinez/Denard Robinson when he faces a tough L.S.U. defense? Can Iowa take control of the Big Ten? Can Nebraska bounce back? Let's all get a pint of Guinness and wait to see what happens.

headline: Week 9 College Football Matchups
summary: Let's say this right now: It's hard to go undefeated in college football. After about the third or fourth week of the season, we all start to worry about what happens if all these teams go undefeated. Then teams start losing. That's the way it works. Suddenly, every week is like a playoff. Missouri and Michigan State are essentially playing playoff games on Saturday. Oregon as well. All those teams are on the road against ranked conference opponents with a lot to prove. A loss would knock any of them out of the national title conversation (some further out than others).  This is why I am not in favor of a playoff system. (Soapbox alert.) Not that I like the B.C.S., but I do not like the idea of a playoff.

headline: J'Accuse! Craig Ferguson Meets an Ardent French Admirer

You could write threatening letters in hopes that your doppelganger finds new material, or you could just grin and bear it. Or you could do what Craig Ferguson did and invite your copycat onto your show.

headline: Public Opinion on 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
summary: The Pentagon on Tuesday released its long-awaited report on "don't ask, don't tell," the policy that allows gay men and women to serve in the military as long as they keep their sexual orientation quiet. The report, the result of a nine-month study, said that repealing the law would present a low risk to military effectiveness. It also found that 70 percent of service members believe that the impact of repealing the law would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

headline: One Man's Trash Is Grist for Another Man's Blog

At the other are more academically minded ruminations on refuse, like Discard Studies, started in August. Last Night's Garbage occupies a space between these two poles. Photographs of trash dominate the blog and provide its author, Jed Tamarkin, with inspiration for writing short bits of fiction.

Once Summerall became a Giant in 1958, he sat in on the offensive and defensive meetings. It was the season when the Giants lost to the Baltimore Colts, 23-17, in overtime, in the N.F.L. championship game.

headline: SILENT PARTNERS
summary: THEY MET BACKSTAGE at a 1972 Renaissance-themed Sid and Marty Krofft television special (Ricky Nelson as a betighted troubadour; Mickey Rooney as head torturer; Howard Cosell, Cyd Charisse, Ann Sothern, Yma Sumac, Billy Barty and plenty of nightmarish puppets). Lorene Yarnell was a dancer in the wimpled chorus line, Robert Shields the silent jester who opened the program. She was seven years older than he was and divorced, and she had been dancing on television variety shows for years, had been in the films ''Sweet Charity'' and ''Bye-Bye Birdie.'' He was a street performer who had begun as Robbie the Mechanical Man in a traveling sideshow in Canada before being invited to study with Marcel Marceau. She taught him to dance; he taught her to mime. ''It was destiny,'' she would say later. The nonmime woman who falls in love with a mime man may be forgiven for a hesitancy to convert, but she did. She followed him to San Francisco, where they worked separately, she in Ghirardelli Square and he in Union, before performing together. They were married the same year, in the way of his people: a pantomimed ceremony in Union Square. The bride wore whiteface and a bandleader's uniform. So did the groom.

headline: At 19th Hole, Recalling an Innovator
summary: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. -- Frank Chirkinian lifted his game for one final performance. Close friends of Chirkinian, a longtime CBS producer, gathered Feb. 22 at Emerald Hills Golf Clu in West Palm Beach, Fla., called together by John Haas, who was, until the club's recent sale, its co-owner with Chirkinian. It had become clear to Haas and others that Chirkinian, who was dying of cancer, would not live long enough to attend his World Golf Hall of Fame induction May 9 in St. Augustine, Fla. They agreed that if Chirkinian felt up to it, he would tape an acceptance speech for the ceremony.

"NCIS: Los Angeles" was close behind at 9 p.m. with 16.5 million viewers, while "The Good Wife," at 10, delivered 11.6 million to win its time slot ahead of its network competitors. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place over all, with ABC broadcasting a two-hour special, "Best in Film: The Greatest Movies of Our Time" (7.1 million). Fox ranked fourth with mostly repeats.

headline: 'Idol' Tops Ratings (Again)
summary: "American Idol" remained dominant in the ratings on Wednesday as 23.5 million viewers tuned in for two hours of performances from the remaining competitors on the Fox reality show, according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS ranked a distant runner-up for the night, earning decent results opposite "Idol" with "Survivor: Redemption Island" at 8 (10.8 million) and a rerun of "Criminal Minds" at 9 (8.7 million). CBS's "Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior" led the 10 p.m. time slot with 8.9 million viewers, edging past NBC's "Law & Order: SVU" (8.7 million) and easily beating ABC's "Off the Map" (4.5 million) in the hour. ABC and its comedy line-up finished in third place over all, benefiting largely from solid ratings for "Modern Family" at 9 (10.8 million). NBC was fourth with "Minute to Win It" at 8 (4.2 million) and a repeat of "Law & Order: SVU" at 9 (4 million).

headline: Fox Leads Ratings
summary: The judges on "American Idol" intervened to save Casey Abrams from elimination on Thursday as 20.7 million viewers tuned in to the results show on Fox, according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox led the prime-time ratings over all, despite broadcasting a repeat of "Bones" at 9 p.m. (8.8 million). ABC placed second for the night, earning its best ratings at 9 for "Grey's Anatomy" (10.1 million). At 8, ABC's "Wipeout" garnered 7.5 million viewers, while at 10, ABC's "Private Practice" drew eight million. CBS ranked third over all, averaging 7.2 million viewers for its live coverage of college basketball. NBC finished a distant fourth place as its comedy lineup continued to struggle.

headline: CBS Takes Sunday Night

The rest of the CBS lineup drew slightly smaller audiences: "The Amazing Race" (roughly 10.9 million), "Undercover Boss" (11.8 million) and "CSI: Miami" (10.6 million). ABC ranked second with solid results for "Secret Millionaire" at 8 p.m. (10.5 million) but low ratings at 9 and 10 for reruns of "Desperate Housewives" (4.7 million) and "Brothers & Sisters" (2.7 million). NBC was close behind in third, and Fox was fourth.

headline: Among Independents, Poll Favors Obama Over Congress
summary: Independent voters make up an influential voting bloc that frequently decides elections, but they are an unpredictable bunch. In 2008, just over half of independent voters threw their support behind Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats, yet by the election of 2010, they had swung back to supporting Republicans for Congress. Now, just a few months into the new Congress's term, more than twice as many independents approve of the job the president is doing than they do of the job Congress is doing, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: 'Dancing With the Stars' Delivers Again for ABC
summary: "Dancing With the Stars" dominated the ratings on Monday as 22.3 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour installment of the ABC reality show, according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC led the night by a wide margin, including the 10 p.m. hour after the dancing competition: "Castle" (12.8 million) outperformed "Harry's Law" on NBC (8.2 million) and a rerun of "Hawaii Five-0" on CBS (5.8 million). CBS ranked second for the night with mostly sitcom repeats from 8 to 10, while NBC was third, averaging 4.2 million for its 8 p.m. special "All Together Now: A Celebration of Service," followed by 4.4 million for "The Event" at 9. Fox was fourth with reruns of "House" (4.8 million) and "The Chicago Code" (4 million).

summary: "Body of Proof," a new drama with Dana Delany playing a medical examiner, delivered promising ratings for ABC in its 10 p.m. debut on Tuesday, helping the network draw the most viewers on average for the night. According to Nielsen's estimates, 13.9 million viewers watched the premiere -- a smaller audience than the one for ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" at 9 (18.8 million) but large enough to top "The Good Wife" on CBS (10 million) and "Parenthood" on NBC (4.8 million). CBS ranked a solid second place on the night, with 18.3 million for "NCIS" at 8 and 15.2 million for "NCIS: Los Angeles" at 9, while NBC finished third with "The Biggest Loser" from 8 to 10 (7.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth with mostly repeats.

headline: CBS Declares Next Week Is 'Tweet Week'
summary: If only they'd thought of this while Charlie Sheen was still on one of their shows: taking a page from rival networks like ABC, CNN and Comedy Central that have used Twitter to draw in and keep viewers watching shows like "Piers Morgan Tonight" and events like the Academy Awards or "The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump," CBS announced on Thursday that it would have eight nights of programming emphasizing that platform, during which some of its performers and personalities will post on Twitter in real time. #CBSTweetWeek, as the network is calling it (with a friendly Twitter hashtag), will run from Sunday through April 11 and spotlight events like Sunday's Academy of Country Music Awards (for which the musicians Dierks Bentley and Julianne Hough will post comments and answer questions on Twitter) and Monday's N.C.A.A. Division I men's basketball national championship game (during which the CBS Sports analysts Greg Anthony and Seth Davis will both be on call). On Tuesday, Pauley Perrette will entertain your inquiries about the various stains and improvised killing implements seen on "N.C.I.S.", and on Wednesday the "Survivor" host Jeff Probst will surely fend off thousands of questions about how contestants relieve themselves.

headline: Peabody Awards Go to 'Justified,' 'The Good Wife' and 'Sherlock'
summary: The gun-toting federal marshal Raylan Givens, the litigator Alicia Florrick and the consulting detective Sherlock Holmes may not share much when it comes to righting wrong-doings, but television series featuring those characters were all named winners of the 70th annual George Foster Peabody Awards on Thursday. Peabody Awards, bestowed by the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication and recognizing excellence in electronic media, were given to the FX series "Justified" and the CBS drama "The Good Wife," as well as "Sherlock: A Study in Pink," a 21st-century spin on Sherlock Holmes seen on the PBS series "Masterpiece/Mystery!" Other winners included the HBO movie "Temple Grandin," about that autism advocate, as well as the World War II mini-series "The Pacific" and the Spike Lee documentary "If God Is Willing and Da Creek Don't Rise," about life in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, both shown on that cable network. C-Span was named the winner of an award for its searchable video library and CNN for its coverage of the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico; Peabodys also went to the arts series "American Masters" for "LennonNYC," about John Lennon, and "Elia Kazan: A Letter to Elia," directed by Kent Jones and Martin Scorsese.

headline: Fox Tops the TV Ratings Again
summary: With the "American Idol" judges having saved Casey Abrams from elimination a week ago, the same slate of 11 competitors faced off again on Wednesday with two hours of musical trials, this time performing the songs of Elton John and Bernie Taupin. The performances attracted an average audience of 23.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. for Fox, according to Nielsen's estimates, producing far higher ratings than any other program on that night. Fox easily won the night over all with CBS in second place, NBC in third, followed by ABC in fourth. CBS earned its best ratings at 9 p.m. with "Criminal Minds" (12.9 million), but drew a solid 10.6 million at 8 for "Survivor: Redemption Island." CBS's spinoff "Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior" (9.3 million) led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of "Law & Order: SVU" on NBC (8.3 million) and "Off the Map" on ABC (4.2 million). NBC garnered 4.2 million at 8 for "Minute to Win It" followed by a rerun of "SVU" at 9 (3.6 million), while ABC broadcast sitcom repeats from 8 to 9:30 prior to "Mr. Sunshine" at 9:30 (4.1 million).

headline: U.S. Isn’t the Only Country With March Madness
summary: Perhaps the closest equivalent is in Japan, with its national high school baseball tournaments.

headline: 'Idol' Attracts 22 Million Viewers
summary: Two finalists were eliminated from "American Idol" on Thursday, Naima Adedapo and Thia Megia, as a results episode of the Fox reality show attracted an impressive 22 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The audience for "Idol" lifted Fox far ahead of its network rivals on the night and provided a boost to Fox's hidden-camera special with Howie Mandel, "Mobbed," which delivered a solid 10.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. following "Idol." ABC's "Grey's Anatomy" (12.7 million) edged past CBS's "CSI" (12.5 million) to lead that time slot, but CBS ranked second for the night over all, earning its best ratings at 10 with "The Mentalist" (13.9 million) and strong results at 8 and 8:30 for the sitcoms "The Big Bang Theory" (11.7 million) and "Rules of Engagement" (8.2 million). ABC was third as 6.3 million tuned in to "Wipeout" at 8 and 7.6 million at 10 for "Private Practice." NBC placed a very distant fourth with mostly repeats of its comedy line-up. On Bravo on Wednesday, the eighth season finale of "Top Chef" delivered 2.8 million viewers, slightly more than the audience who watched the series' prior season conclusion (2.7 million).

headline: UConn Beats Butler to Win N.C.A.A. Title

headline: When Katie Couric Met Andrew Goldman
summary: Apparently, it’s official: Katie Couric will no longer anchor the “CBS Evening News.” It’s hardly a surprise. She has been hinting at a move for ages, and speculation that she wouldn’t last has been gurgling pretty much since her first day in the anchor’s chair five years ago. But rarely was she ever so open with her ambivalence about the job as she was in an interview with Andrew Goldman, which appears in the April 10 issue of the magazine but which we’re publishing online now. Goldman conducted it on Friday, March 25, the day before Couric took off for a pre-big-news vacation to Turks and Caicos. Although she wouldn’t confirm that she was leaving the show — she was more interested in discussing her new book, “The Best Advice I Ever Got: Lessons From Extraordinary Lives” — she expressed some regrets about trying to push the nightly-news genre too far too fast and she floated a theory (though she wouldn’t put her name behind it) that CBS’s local news lead-ins might have kept her mired in third place.

headline: With Stakes High, N.F.L. Relies on a Star Lawyer

headline: Country Music Awards Lift CBS in Ratings
summary: The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with “60 Minutes.” ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched “Secret Millionaire” at 8, followed by “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million) and “Body of Proof” (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million) and “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

headline: The Day the Bear Roared
summary: It has been 25 years since Jack Nicklaus clinched his sixth, and last, Masters title with a birdie putt few will ever forget.

headline: ‘NCIS,’ New and Old, Lifts CBS in Ratings
summary: A new installment of “NCIS” topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of “NCIS: Los Angeles” (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.6 million). ABC’s new series “Body of Proof” won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.6 million) and “Parenthood” on NBC (4.7 million). ABC’s “No Ordinary Family” (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBC’s “Biggest Loser,” which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Boosts CBS on Tuesday

According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for “NCIS” on CBS; during the 9 p.m. hour, that network’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.3 million) finished just slightly behind ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.5 million). At 10,“Body of Proof” (11.3 million) on ABC edged “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.9 million). ABC placed second for the night, lagging behind at 8 with the second season premiere of “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” (5.3 million). NBC ranked third, averaging 7.2 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10, followed by “Parenthood” (5.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth among the networks with mostly reruns.

headline: ABC Cancels ‘All My Children’ and ‘One Life to Live’

ABC said it would replace “All My Children” and “One Life to Live” with less expensive, unscripted programs. Read more on Media Decoder…

headline: ABC Cancels ‘All My Children’ and ‘One Life to Live’

headline: Viewers Not So Mad About Paul Reiser’s Return
summary: Twelve years after “Mad About You,” Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBC’s comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of “The Paul Reiser Show” at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBC’s similarly ratings-starved sitcom “Community” (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by “American Idol” on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for “The Office” (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of “Idol” and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for “Bones.” CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of “Wipeout” at 8 (6.2 million).

summary: A CBS News report questioned several facts in Greg Mortenson’s memoir, which has fed a charity he runs.

headline: ’60 Minutes’ Leads CBS to Sunday Night Ratings Win
summary: The newsmagazine “60 Minutes” delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as CBS won the night’s ratings over its network competitors. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.6 million viewers tuned in at 7 p.m. for an edition that featured an investigation into the accuracy of Greg Mortenson’s book “Three Cups of Tea.” CBS then also won the 8 p.m. hour with its reality show “The Amazing Race” (8.7 million). ABC ranked close behind CBS in second place for the night, leading during the 9 p.m. hour with “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million). NBC placed third over all, garnering an average of 7.4 million viewers for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11. Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup, although “Family Guy” (6 million) earned the night’s highest ratings in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

headline: Publisher of ‘Three Cups of Tea’ to Conduct Review
summary: Viking, the publisher of “Three Cups of Tea,” said in a statement on Monday that it would review the book and its contents with the author, Greg Mortenson, after a CBS News report that called into question the accuracy of part of the book.

summary: The ripples created by an explosive television report challenging the veracity of “Three Cups of Tea,” a bestselling memoir dealing with Afghanistan and Pakistan, have reached Queens.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Dominates Ratings for ABC
summary: A 90-minute edition of “Dancing With the Stars” dominated the ratings on Monday as 19.6 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC easily led the night over all despite a diminished audience after the dancing competition for its sitcom “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (8.5 million). CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” led at 10 p.m., drawing 10.9 million viewers and outperforming ABC’s “20/20” special (7.6 million). CBS ranked second, earning modest ratings for its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including “How I Met Your Mother” (6.4 million), “Mad Love” (5.6 million) and “Mike & Molly” (9.7 million), while a repeat of “Two and a Half Men” attracted 7.3 million viewers at 9. Fox was third with “House” at 8 (8.6 million) and “The Chicago Code” at 9 (6.4 million). NBC struggled in fourth place with “Chuck” (4.2 million) and “The Event” (3.7 million) followed by the recently rebooted version of “Law & Order: Los Angeles” (4.9 million).

headline: Pentagon Is Quiet on ‘Three Cups of Tea’ Questions
summary: Pentagon officials continued their silence on Tuesday about allegations against Greg Mortenson, the co-author of the best-selling “Three Cups of Tea,” after a fellow best-selling author and mountaineer, Jon Krakauer, released an article on byliner.com raising his own questions about the accuracy of Mr. Mortenson’s book and the management of his charity.

headline: Audience Up, ‘Idol’ Defies TV Gravity
summary: A slight uptick in the ratings for “American Idol” reverses a trend and makes the show look increasingly like a cultural fixture.

headline: The Danger of Donald Trump
summary: It’s easy to see why people think Donald Trump has become the Charlie Sheen of the Republican Party. Gluttons for attention, the two share a rare talent at self-promotion, self-delusion and self-immolation. And Sheen now proclaims himself a birther, in league with Trump’s crusade to promote a lie about President Obama that is also believed by nearly half of G.O.P voters.

headline: Seven ‘Idol’ Aspirants, 21.8 Million Viewers
summary: Fox’s “American Idol” attracted 21.8 million viewers on Wednesday as the seven remaining aspiring pop stars performed songs written in the last 10 years. Although the reality show’s 90-minute episode easily outperformed all other programs on the night, “Breaking In,” Fox’s new sitcom that follows “Idol” at 9:30 p.m., struggled. It drew a much more modest 7.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS earned a second place finish for the night, garnering 10.5 million at 8 p.m. for “Survivor: Redemption Island,” followed by reruns of “Criminal Minds” (8.8 million) and “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” (7.2 million). ABC was third with new episodes of its comedy lineup, including “Modern Family” (9.8 million) at 9 p.m., and back-to-back installments of “Happy Endings” at 10 p.m. (4.6 million) and 10:30 (3.8 million). NBC placed a distant fourth with mostly reruns.

headline: Madelyn Pugh Davis, 90, 'I Love Lucy' Writer
summary: Madelyn Pugh Davis, who with her writing partners for the classic sitcom ''I Love Lucy'' concocted zany scenes in which the harebrained Lucy dangles from a hotel balcony, poses as a sculpture or stomps and wrestles in a vat full of grapes, died Wednesday at her home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. She was 90. Her death was confirmed by her son, Michael Quinn Martin.

headline: Sol Saks, Writer of ‘Bewitched’ Pilot, Dies at 100
summary: Mr. Saks was behind the first episode of the popular sitcom about a suburban housewife skilled in the uses of enchantment.

headline: A Clash Over the Airwaves
summary: The government wants TV broadcasters to give up some of their airwaves to allow for expanded use by cellphones and other mobile applications.

headline: Despite the Evidence, 'Birther' Bills Advance
summary: OKLAHOMA CITY -- Investigations have concluded that President Obama was, in fact, born in Hawaii in 1961, as he has always said. Just this week, on the news program ''Good Morning America'' on ABC, George Stephanopoulosproduced a copy of the president's Certification of Live Birth, causing a potential presidential aspirant, Michele Bachmann, the Republican congresswoman from Minnesota, to say that the issue appeared settled. In 2008, the Supreme Court declined to hear a case challenging that proof.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 15-20 with 1,224 adults throughout the United States, of whom 1,116 were registered voters. The sample of land-line telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 69,000 active residential exchanges across the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to ensure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its share of all telephone numbers.

headline: Poll Finds Lack of Passion for Republican Candidates
summary: Republican voters have yet to form strong opinions about most of their potential candidates for president in 2012, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Early Word: Resignation

headline: NEW POLL SHOWS DARKENING MOOD ACROSS AMERICA
summary: Americans are more pessimistic about the nation's economic outlook and overall direction than they have been at any time since President Obama's first two months in office, when the country was still officially ensnared in the Great Recession, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Amid rising gas prices, stubborn unemployment and a cacophonous debate in Washington over the federal government's ability to meet its future obligations, the poll presents stark evidence that the slow, if unsteady, gains in public confidence earlier this year that a recovery was under way are now all but gone.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll: 2012 Republicans, Obama and the Economy
summary: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on the early Republican field for the 2012 presidential race and the nation’s economic outlook.

headline: In Media’s Wedding Frenzy, Hints of Viewer Fatigue

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, appears live from Cairo on CNN’s “State of the Union” and NBC’s “Meet the Press” to discuss his meeting with rebel leaders in Benghazi, Libya. headline: Why Do Doubts Persist About Where President Obama Was Born?

headline: Couric Is Expected to Say She’s Leaving CBS

Then, as soon as she returns from London, where she will be anchoring the network’s coverage of the royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday, CBS will announce her successor during the first week of May.

headline: Few Americans Familiar With Title IX, Though Most Approve of It

headline: Couric Confirms Departure From CBS
summary: 7:46 p.m. | Updated | Katie Couric confirmed on Tuesday what has been widely reported for weeks: that she will leave her job as the anchor of the “CBS Evening News.”

headline: Dancing Past the Reruns
summary: With mostly reruns on CBS and Fox, “Dancing With the Stars” dominated Monday night in the ratings, attracting 21.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That ABC reality competition easily led its 90-minute time slot from 8 to 9:30 p.m. while boosting ABC’s sitcom “Better With You” at 9:30 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night with repeats of its sitcoms, including “How I Met Your Mother” at 8 (5.3 million), “The Big Bang Theory” at 9 (7.7 million), and “Mike & Molly” at 9:30 (7.8 million). A new installment of “Mad Love” garnered 5.6 million viewers at 8:30. Fox edged past NBC for third place, earning 4.8 million for a rerun of “House” at 8 followed by a repeat of “The Chicago Code” (4.1 million). NBC finished in fourth despite broadcasting new episodes of “The Event” at 9 (4.4 million) and “Law & Order: Los Angeles” at 10 (5.8 million), which trailed behind repeats of CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (7 million) and ABC’s “Castle” (7.6 million) in its time slot.

headline: Get Your Royal Wedding Fix on TV

headline: Obama's Approval Rating Jumps After Raid

The president's approval rating now stands at 57 percent, up from 46 percent in the most recent survey. Will it last? After Saddam Hussein, the former ruler of Iraq, was captured during the presidency of George W. Bush, Mr. Bush got an 8-point bump. But it only lasted a month.

Many more Americans now approve of the job he is doing as president and of the way he is handling foreign policy, the war in Afghanistan and the threat of terrorism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Early Word: No Bin Laden Photos, but Thousands of Words
summary: In Today’s Times:— In deciding not to release photographs of Osama bin Laden’s corpse, President Obama concluded that the images could incite violence against Americans and would do little to persuade skeptics that Al Qaeda’s founder had been killed in the raid on his Pakistan compound, Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti write. There is still a risk that a photo will be leaked, they say, noting that fakes are already circulating on the Internet. Today, Mr. Obama is scheduled to take part in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Sept. 11 memorial in lower Manhattan before meeting with relatives of the victims. On Friday, he will travel to Fort Campbell, Ky., to speak to troops returning from combat duty in Afghanistan.

headline: Ten Ideas for 'Two and a Half Men'
summary: I'm imagining the "Two and a Half Men" writers these days thusly: four days without sleep, living off Ho Ho's and Coke (that's the cake and the drink, people), clumps of hair strewn on the ground. As Bill Carter reported in The Times in late April, the writers have been given less than three weeks to come up with a newish version of their hit comedy. They are no doubt under just a teensy bit of pressure to produce something with the same award-winning, ratings-generating, money-raking-in qualities as the original, while also having to abruptly write out a major character, Charlie Harper, the jingle-writing cad brother played by Charlie Sheen until he was fired by Warner Brothers in March.

headline: Els, With Hope for More, Is Hall of Famer

After three previous tries, Rob Mariano, a k a Boston Rob, was finally victorious, winning this season’s $1 million prize. CBS ranked No. 1 for the night, leading at 7 p.m. with “60 Minutes” (12 million) as well as at 10, following the “Survivor” finale with a reunion special (11.3 million). ABC placed second for the night, garnering 10 million viewers from 9 to 11 for the season finale of “Desperate Housewives.” NBC was third with “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million), “Minute to Win It” at 8 (3.5 million) and “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). Fox and its animated comedy lineup finished fourth.

headline: Watchlist: A Self-Conscious Web Experiment From CBS News

That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: “We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. It’s what you need to know to be in the now.”

headline: Reality TV Carries NBC in Tuesday Ratings
summary: The return of “America’s Got Talent” catapulted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 15 million viewers watched the two-hour sixth-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Up by more than 2.6 million over last year’s premiere (12.4 million), “America’s Got Talent” also lifted NBC’s ratings at 10 p.m., during which the network’s new reality competition “The Voice” attracted its largest audience to date, 14.4 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night, though reliable audience figures for its coverage of the N.B.A. finals were not immediately available. Preliminary overnight estimates were the highest for a Game 1 broadcast since 2004, slightly outperforming last year’s first game, which drew 14.1 million viewers. CBS was third with reruns of “NCIS” (11.1 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (9.9 million) and “The Good Wife” (6.2 million). Fox was fourth with a new episode of “Traffic Light” at 9:30 (2.2 million) after repeats of “Glee” and “Raising Hope.”

headline: NBC Hires Hartman for Brian Williams Show

headline: Another Hundred (or So) People: ‘Company’ Cast Plans a Tonys Reunion
summary: If you missed the New York Philharmonic‘s star-studded production of “Company” at Avery Fisher Hall in April, then you aren’t Woody Allen or Alec Baldwin (whom we’re pretty sure we spotted in the crowd on opening night), but you’re still entitled to see this A-list team reunite for the Tony Awards. Organizers for the Tonys said on Thursday that this “Company” cast will perform at the awards telecast on June 12. Neil Patrick Harris, who played the lonely bachelor Robert in that production, wasn’t hard to pin down, since he’s hosting the Tonys; he’ll be joined in this performance by Stephen Colbert, Jon Cryer, Christina Hendricks, Patti LuPone and Martha Plimpton, as well as Jill Paice, Anika Noni Rose, Jennifer Laura Thompson, Jim Walton, Chryssie Whitehead, Katie Finneran and Aaron Lazar. A statement from the Tony organizers did not indicate which number(s) the “Company” cast will perform (so can we put our thumb on the scale now for “Side by Side by Side/What Would We Do Without You?”). The Tonys will be held this year at the Beacon Theater and broadcast on CBS. An HD film version of the Philharmonic’s “Company” will also be shown in movie theaters starting June 15.

headline: Fox Dances to No. 1 Again

headline: Just How Much Is a Tony Worth?

But just how valuable is winning a prestigious Tony? And how much does the publicity — and the broadcast television showcase for the musical numbers on CBS — help the runners-up? FiveThirtyEight, a blog devoted to helping readers of The New York Times cut through the clutter of this data-rich world, decided to find out.

headline: 30 Seconds With David Feherty
summary: A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Feherty’s half-interview, half-improv weekly show, “Feherty,” will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Feherty’s 2002 novel, “A Nasty Bit of Rough.” Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.

headline: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Immokalee, Fla.
summary: Fifty years after Edward R. Murrow concluded his tenure at CBS with “Harvest of Shame,” an arresting expose of migrant field workers in rural Florida, CBS News correspondent Byron Pitts returned to Florida’s tomato, bean and sugarcane fields for an update. In Harvest of Shame: 50 Years Later, Mr. Pitts found that, while wages have improved, the work — when it could be found — is just as backbreaking as it was in 1960. Juan Lopez, a 62-year-old tomato picker in Immokalee, said he gets up before dawn hoping to find work; in 2009 he said he earned “$7,800 for a full year of work.”

summary: The couple are to be married in Garrison, N.Y.

headline: Returning to Bronx, 3 Losses Forgiven
summary: George Frazier was the first pitcher in major league history to lose three games in a best-of-seven World Series. On Sunday, he will make his first appearance at Old-Timers’ Day in the Bronx.

headline: CBS Plans Talk Show for ‘Survivor’ Host Jeff Probst
summary: The CBS Corporation, the longtime distributor of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” is conceiving a new daytime talk show starring Jeff Probst, the host of the reality show “Survivor,” the company said Monday.

headline: CBS Leads a Lackluster Sunday Night
summary: On a low-rated Sunday night of network television, CBS’s line-up of “60 Minutes” and reruns delivered the most viewers in prime time, while NBC’s second season premiere of “The Marriage Ref” struggled, garnering just 4.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “60 Minutes” attracted the night’s largest audience with 7 million viewers at 7 p.m.; after that CBS broadcast repeats of “Hawaii Five-0” (4.9 million), “Undercover Boss” (4.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (5.2 million) until 11 p.m. NBC ranked second for the night despite the modest showing for “The Marriage Ref” at 10. NBC broadcast an encore of last week’s “America’s Got Talent” and it averaged 5.4 million viewers an hour from 8 to 10. ABC was third over all with repeats of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (3.9 million), “Castle” (4.2 million), and “Body of Proof” (4 million). Fox ranked a distant fourth with reruns of its regular Sunday night comedies.

headline: A Demographic Gray (or Graying) Lures TV Industry
summary: “My Generation,” which was nominated for a daytime Emmy, is bringing attention to the age group that watches more TV than any other.

headline: For the Producer of ‘Survivor’ and ‘The Voice,’ There’s No Sitting Still
summary: For Mark Burnett, the reality television producer who has five prime-time series on the air in America, being busy is one of the keys to his success.

headline: ‘Bachelorette,’ Seeking Love, Wins Eyes
summary: ABC’s reality competition “The Bachelorette” posted its best ratings in three weeks on Monday, delivering the night’s largest audience with eight million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The solid ratings helped ABC extended its winning streak to 16 weeks as the top-rated network on Monday night. NBC ranked second as “Law & Order: LA” finished in a tie with ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” at 10 p.m., each attracting 6.4 million viewers. Earlier, NBC’s rerun of “America’s Got Talent,” at 8 p.m., garnered 5.8 million viewers and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” drew 4.8 million at 9, less than the five million viewers who watched a new episode of Fox’s “MasterChef” in the same time slot. For the night, however, Fox lagged behind CBS, which placed third with reruns of its sitcom line-up followed by a “Hawaii Five-0” repeat at 10 p.m. (5.8 million).

headline: Thursday: Surfer’s Handle
summary: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You say po-TAY-to, I say po-TAH-to. I actually don’t; that’s the kind of thing that would have gotten me keelhauled in the Bronx where I grew up. But I had to warn you somehow, didn’t I, because I’m pretty sure we’re going to have a rousing discussion after you all do this puzzle about the difference between ACRONYMs and initialisms.

headline: Republican Voters Lack Enthusiasm for Presidential Contenders, Poll Shows
summary: Republican voters are not satisfied with the candidates running for the Republican nomination and wish they had more choices, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. None of the candidates currently hoping to challenge President Obama in 2012 has earned enthusiastic support from more than 7 percent of Republican voters.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: A sample of landline telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a list of more than 69,000 active residential exchanges across the country.

headline: Latin Musicians Threaten to Sue the Grammys
summary: The increasingly bitter dispute that erupted early in April when the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced it was eliminating 31 categories from the Grammy Awards notched up yet another step on Thursday when a New York law firm announced plans to sue the academy on behalf of musicians who play Latin jazz, one of the categories that is being dropped.

headline: Wildfire Continues to Burn Near Nuclear Facility in New Mexico
summary: Updated | 7:50 p.m. The Las Conchas wildfire in northern New Mexico has blazed through nearly 93,000 acres since Sunday and stands poised to become the largest in the state’s history, according to officials.

headline: Despite Fears, Owning Home Retains Allure, Poll Shows
summary: About nine in 10 Americans see owning a home as part of the American dream, even as many doubt their home is a good investment, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Full Results From The New York Times and CBS News Poll
summary: Full results from a poll on President Obama’s job performance, the nation’s status, problems facing the country, Congress and more.

headline: C.W. Whalen Jr., 90, Dies; Led Vietnam War Dissent
summary: Mr. Whalen was a six-term Republican congressman from Ohio who espoused a variety of liberal causes.

headline: Sarkozy Is Assaulted as He Meets Voters
summary: An assailant grabbed President Nicolas Sarkozy of France by the shoulder on Thursday as he met local residents in the southwestern French town of Brax.

headline: AMC Shares Tumble on Debut
summary: Shares of AMC Networks — the media company spun off from Cablevision that is home to “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad” — fell on their full trading debut on the Nasdaq market on Friday.

headline: Seen It Before: CBS Wins the Night With Repeats
summary: For CBS, an all-repeat lineup eked out a first-place finish for the network in the ratings on Thursday as “CSI” and “The Mentalist” delivered the night’s largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in for a rerun of “The Mentalist” at 10 p.m.. while “CSI” attracted 6.8 million at 9. “Wipeout” on ABC led the 8 p.m. hour with 6.5 million viewers, outperforming CBS’s combination of “The Big Bang Theory” (6.6 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (4.9 million). ABC earned a second-place finish, drawing 6.1 million at 9 p.m. for “Expedition Impossible” and 5.4 million at 10 for a new installment of “Rookie Blue.” Fox was third, averaging 5 million for “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 p.m. followed by a rerun of “Glee” (2.9 million) at 9. NBC trailed in fourth with sitcom repeats and a new episode of “Love Bites” (1.8 million) at 10.

headline: July 3 — 9
summary: A listing of cultural events this week.

headline: Monday: Next-to-Last Greek Letter
summary: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you are a movie lover like I am, this will be a fun puzzle for you, even though it’s not the Independence Day theme you might have been expecting. It’s nothing brain-breaking either, but then again it’s Monday, and we’re just easing our way back into the groove.

headline: We Knew They Got Raises. But This?
summary: Updated figures show that median pay surged 23 percent last year for top executives at 200 big companies.

headline: How We Picked Our Presidents, 1960s Style

headline: Winning? Comedy Central Plans Roast of Charlie Sheen

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Gets Plenty of Viewers
summary: “America’s Got Talent” attracted its third-largest audience ever on Tuesday as the latest two-hour installment of the NBC reality competition drew 15.5 million viewers and dominated the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Only the show’s two previous season finales, in 2010 and 2009, garnered more viewers.

headline: Times curbs Pogue’s P.R. appearances
summary: Journalists are accustomed to seeing public relations pitches in their inbox. I was surprised, though, when I recently got one on June 8 touting tech columnist David Pogue’s speech to P.R. professionals in which he credits P.R. with providing most of his ideas.

headline: White House Changes Policy on Condolence Letters for Military Suicides
summary: For several administrations at least, the White House has declined to send letters of condolence to families of troops who committed suicide, even if those suicides occurred in combat zones.

headline: Rock Star’s Lawsuit Against Tony Awards Is Moved to New York
summary: Bret Michaels will probably have a return engagement with the Tony Awards in New York – not to perform or present any trophies, but to pursue a lawsuit against the organizers of that show and CBS, which broadcast the program and the accident in which, Mr. Michaels said, he was nearly killed.

headline: Death on the Battlefield
summary: President Obama has made the enlightened decision to begin sending letters of condolence to the families of combat troops who commit suicide.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Keeps Viewers Transfixed
summary: “America’s Got Talent” had another night on top of the ratings as 12.5 million viewers tuned in to NBC’s reality competition on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The hourlong episode at 9 p.m. far exceeded the ratings for any other program on the night, lifting NBC to No. 1 in prime time, even as the rest of the network’s programs lagged behind in their respective time slots.

headline: Big Start for ‘Big Brother’
summary: The debut of the 13th edition of “Big Brother” lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday as 7.7 million viewers tuned in to the 9 p.m. premiere episode, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality show delivered the night’s largest audience, outperforming ABC’s “Wipeout” in the 8 p.m. hour (6.6 million) as well as Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” in the same time slot (5.4 million).

headline: Josef Suk, Czech Violinist, Dies at 81
summary: Mr. Suk was a great-grandson of Dvorak and a grandson of the turn-of-the-century violinist and composer also named Josef Suk.

headline: At the Ed Sullivan Theater, a Stupid Human Trick

headline: Sawyer’s Jaycee Dugard Interview Boosts ABC
summary: ABC’s special edition of “Primetime” on Sunday featuring Diane Sawyer’s interview with kidnapping victim Jaycee Dugard delivered the highest ratings on the night by a wide margin and, excluding sports broadcasts, that network’s largest audience of the summer. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 14.8 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour broadcast from 9 to 11 p.m., easily outperforming the second most watched program, “60 Minutes” on CBS at 7 p.m. (8.1 million).

headline: Obama Leans on G.O.P. for a Deal on Debt Ceiling

headline: McConnell Proposal Gives Obama Power to Increase Debt Limit
summary: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, said Tuesday that a bipartisan budget deal with President Obama was probably out of reach, and he proposed a plan under which the president could increase the federal debt limit without Congressional approval for offsetting spending cuts.

headline: Danson to Star in ‘C.S.I.’
summary: The Media Decoder blog has word that Ted Danson will be starring in “C.S.I.” as CBS tries to keep that franchise going.

headline: In Debt Ceiling Fight, Obama Has the Edge
summary: Last year, President Obama and House Republicans managed to reach a last-minute accord on preserving the Bush tax cuts, and then in April they just barely averted a government shutdown. But now, in this debate over the debt ceiling, each side seems ready to make a stand at last and find out whom the voters really trust when it comes to righting the nation’s finances.

headline: Still Fighting Fire With Fire to Honor the Fallen of 9/11
summary: The final season of “Rescue Me,” the FX series about firefighters, makes for a passionate tribute to the suffering and heroism of 9/11.

headline: Greg Cosell, Unheralded Maestro of N.F.L. ‘Matchup’
summary: It’s a February afternoon in Indianapolis. The former Auburn quarterback and Heisman winner Cam Newton is under his first N.F.L. microscope. On live national television, in front of some 200 reporters at Podium C in the N.F.L. scouting combine media center, Newton is fielding (fending off) rapid-fire questions about expectations for the N.F.L., his character, his level of “football focus,” his baggage.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Bests America’s Pastime
summary: Broadcast at the same time as Major League Baseball’s All-Star Game on Fox, “America’s Got Talent” still managed to deliver Tuesday night’s most viewers, as 13.8 million tuned in to the show’s latest two-hour installment, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Parties Can’t Agree on the Consequences of Default
summary: The fact that politicians in Washington can’t agree on how to raise the debt ceiling is hardly surprising. The fact that they can’t agree on what happens if they don’t may be more significant.

headline: Despite Benefit Disparities, Middle Class Supports Mortgage Deduction
summary: A couple of weeks ago, David Streitfeld and Megan Thee-Brenan of The New York Times reported on the results of a Times/CBS News poll on homeownership in the United States. The poll found continued support for government subsidies for homeownership, including the mortgage interest deduction. Noting broad, bipartisan support for the deduction, Mr. Streitfeld and Ms. Thee-Brenan acknowledged that “… almost no one favors discontinuing the mortgage tax deduction, a prized middle-class benefit that has been featured on some budget-cutting proposals.”

headline: Why Taxes Will Rise in the End
summary: Economists have a name for a budget that covers soaring medical costs and pays for the world’s largest military with some of the world’s lowest taxes: a free lunch.
