summary: A list of the 2011 prime time Emmy Award winners and nominees.

headline: Marketa Kimbrell, Who Brought Theater to the Forgotten, Is Dead at 82
summary: For more than 25 years, the New York Street Theater Caravan, founded by Ms. Kimbrell and Richard Levy, performed in New York and beyond.

headline: The Tax Increases We’ll Get
summary: Continuing this week’s series on what Republicans are risking if they punt on a deficit deal, I recommend reading David Leonhardt’s column on tax increases from yesterday’s Times — and particularly the conclusion, in which he points out that however much wonks may love the idea of a comprehensive tax reform that eliminates credits, loopholes and deductions, it’s just as likely that taxes will go up the old-fashioned way:

headline: Photo Finish for NBC and CBS
summary: A game show, a talent show and a dating show lifted NBC into a virtual tie for first place with CBS in the ratings on Wednesday night as NBC drew about as many viewers on average as CBS’s lineup of “Big Brother” and crime show reruns. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC’s reality competition “America’s Got Talent” earned the night’s largest audience with 11 million viewers at 9 p.m., but the network lagged behind CBS the rest of the night as “Minute to Win It” garnered just 4.8 million at 8 and “Love in the Wild” drew 5.1 million at 10.

headline: ‘Late Show’ Theater’s Entry Is Smashed Again
summary: Four days after an intoxicated man broke through the glass doors of the Ed Sullivan Theater, home to David Letterman’s “Late Show,” another man has tried the same thing.

headline: Spare Times for Children, for July 15 -21
summary: A selected listing of events for, by and about children, teenagers and families.

headline: CBS Edges Rivals
summary: CBS eked out a victory as the top-rated network on Thursday night as 6.5 million viewers tuned in to “Big Brother” at 9 p.m.

headline: Fallback Plan Moving to Fore as Budget Talks Stall
summary: Congressional leaders are negotiating a fallback plan as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 17
summary: The looming debt deadline continues to cast shadows over the Sunday talk shows, but this time the discussion is spreading to include the outlook on the state and local levels. A few presidential candidates are also dropping in to share their opinions on how the nation can get out of its budget fix.

headline: Held in Document Theft, ‘America’s Presidential Historian’ Faces New Scrutiny
summary: Historical societies are checking their records for visits by Barry H. Landau, who is accused of stealing documents signed by Abraham Lincoln from the Maryland Historical Society.

summary: A quick, informal selection of voices from across the country this weekend found cynicism about the state of negotiations in Washington and resignation about the partisan jousting.

headline: Charlie Sheen Signs TV Deal for ‘Anger Management’
summary: Charlie Sheen has made a deal that will — possibly — bring him back to television in a new situation comedy.

headline: President of HBO Sports Leaving After 33 Years
summary: Ross Greenburg, who has run the division since 2000, denied reports that he was fired for losing Manny Pacquiao to Showtime.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad’ Cooks Up Record Numbers
summary: Despite a 13-month absence after an excruciatingly tense Season 3 cliffhanger, “Breaking Bad” set a ratings record in its return to AMC on Sunday night. According to Nielsen, an estimated 2.6 million people tuned in to witness the further misadventures of the meth dealers Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and to learn whether Jesse actually killed a fellow meth cooker. That number was 32 percent greater than the viewership for last season’s premiere, and was the highest total in the series’ history.

headline: Both Sides Confident on Debt Talks Despite Impasse
summary: Lawmakers continued to squabble over the details of competing proposals and offered little evidence that a deal was at hand.

headline: Public Gives Obama the Edge on Debt Talks
summary: While Americans are closely divided over whether the debt ceiling should be raised, the public gives President Obama higher marks than Congressional Republicans for his handling of the negotiations, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: For Three Same-Sex Couples, Together Many Years, the Wait Is About Over
summary: In brief sketches, three pairs of longtime partners discuss how they met, difficulties they endured and their joy at New York’s enactment of a law allowing same-sex marriage.

headline: After Quake, Japanese Choose Peace of Mind Over Great View
summary: In Tokyo, unit sales at apartment buildings more than 20 stories tall were down nearly 40 percent from the year before.

headline: Wendi Deng Murdoch Refuses to Pull a Punch
summary: The Murdoch who may have emerged best from the question-and-answer session in the British parliament was not Rupert Murdoch or his son James, but his wife, Wendi Deng Murdoch.

headline: At Comic-Con, Some Shows Draw Double Takes
summary: SAN DIEGO— Comic-Con International, founded in 1970 as a gathering for comic book geeks, long ago grew into a multi-tentacled beast. Now the genres it showcases include animation, manga, horror, fantasy and science fiction.

headline: The Spirit of the Spacesuit
summary: Don’t mourn the passing of the space shuttle program. Spaceflight will flourish without it.

headline: A Cool Debut for ‘Awkward’
summary: Teen drama, both real and fictional, continues to be a winning formula for MTV. The network’s new scripted comedy series “Awkward” made its debut to strong ratings Tuesday night, following the hit show “Teen Mom,” a reality series whose title needs no explanation. Currently on its third season, “Teen Mom” drew 3.2 million viewers and was the most-watched cable show in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic for the night, a prize it has claimed each week since its season premiere on July 7, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers. “Awkward,” which focuses on the teenage life of one Jenna Hamilton (Ashley Rickards), who wants nothing more than to fit in at her high school, picked up slightly more than 1.7 million viewers.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings July 22 — 28
summary: A selection of rock and pop listings.

headline: The Lesser Depression
summary: Even if Washington and Brussels succeed in avoiding immediate financial catastrophe, the deals being made will surely make the broader economic slump worse.

headline: ‘Hair’ Encore: Three Same-Sex Marriages
summary: Three gay couples who have ties to theater will wed on the Broadway stage of the St. James Theater on Monday night after the performance of the musical “Hair,” a day after New York State’s new marriage law takes effect. Among them is the Broadway actress Terri White, who received strong reviews in the 2009 Broadway revival of “Finian’s Rainbow” and will appear in the revival of “Follies” that begins next month.

headline: Univision Triumphs on a Barren Night of Broadcast TV
summary: A relatively barren television landscape on Thursday night — with the big four networks running either comedy repeats or reality shows — allowed the Spanish-language Univision to score a ratings victory in the category advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds with its 8th Annual Youth Awards show, “Premios Juventud.” The three-hour ceremony, which featured performances from Ricky Martin and Pitbull, averaged 4.1 million total viewers. The winners were determined by online vote at univision.com. CBS had the most total viewers on the night thanks to a live eviction episode of “Big Brother” (6.7 million viewers). “Love Bites,” the sole NBC series not in repeats, fell to just under 1.8 million viewers for its (unplanned) final episode. The show was canceled earlier this week.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 24
summary: With time running out for a deficit reduction compromise to avert a federal government default, all eyes are on President Obama and Congressional leadership. The Sunday talk shows are no exception.

headline: Debt Drama Blocks Out Big Picture on Credit

headline: CBS Wins Sunday Night With Familiar Shows
summary: CBS once again held the top ratings spot for Sunday in both total viewers and adults 18-49 with two mainstays, “60 minutes” (8.2 million viewers) and “Big Brother” (6.9 million). They were followed by the debut of the network’s latest reality show, “Same Name,” in which a celebrity lives the life of an ordinary person who shares the same name; 5.3 million viewers watched the episode on Sunday featuring the actor David Hasselhoff. Future guests are to include Kathy Griffin, Mike Tyson and Reggie Bush of the New Orleans Saints. On AMC, “Breaking Bad” retained a large portion of its season-premiere audience with a total of 2 million viewers for the second episode. It was the second-most-watched episode in series history. “Breaking Bad” is ahead of last season’s viewership total by 30 percent.

headline: With Washington at Impasse, Worry Over Investor Reaction

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Delivers
summary: CBS once again held the top ratings spot for Sunday.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Makes Another Splash in the Ratings
summary: Buoyed by the record-setting performance of Professor Splash, a professional diver who belly-flopped into a 12-inch kiddie pool from 3 stories up, “America’s Got Talent” on NBC was once again the most watched show on Tuesday with 11.2 million viewers overall, and it was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen data.

summary: Among the criteria brokers use to classify office buildings are age, location, curb appeal, tenancy, building infrastructure and ownership.

headline: Heidi Klum and Tim Gunn Make It Work on ‘Runway’
summary: The fashion guru Tim Gunn and the model Heidi Klum made a not quite triumphant but still satisfactory return to New York City as “Project Runway” had its Season 9 premiere on Lifetime on Thursday night.  The fashion designer competition averaged 2.7 million total viewers according to Nielsen, making small gains over the premiere from last season.  It was certainly an eventful episode, as four of the twenty contestants were eliminated by the 20-minute mark.

summary: “The Shrinks Are Away!” features a free night of readings from several fiction authors and a poet.

headline: New York Is Ready for Its Close-Up
summary: More and more television shows are filming in the city thanks to an accommodating tax credit policy, large soundstages in Queens and a variety of locations.

summary: With an ominous deadline to raise the debt ceiling looming on Tuesday, the White House and Congressional lawmakers are still far from reaching a deal. The impasse raises the central question of this Sunday’s talk shows: Will America default?

headline: Why Tyrants Love the Murdoch Scandal

headline: A Good Night for CBS in the Ratings
summary: CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. “Big Brother” is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of “Family Guy” on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. “60 minutes” did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, “The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special” won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last season’s edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday).

headline: Maddow Agrees to a New Contract With MSNBC
summary: 4:57 p.m. | Updated | LOS ANGELES– MSNBC said Tuesday that it had signed its top star, Rachel Maddow, to a new multi-year contract, cementing her position at the cable news channel for several years.

headline: Out of the Ruins: Where Directors Landed

headline: Kutcher to Play a Billionaire on ‘Two and a Half Men’
summary: This much CBS will say about the revised version of its hit comedy “Two and a Half Men”: Ashton Kutcher plays an “Internet billionaire with a broken heart.” And his character’s name is Walden Schmidt.

headline: CBS Reports Quarterly Profit More Than Doubled to $395 Million
summary: Analysts predict that the strong showing by CBS is likely to be repeated by the other major media companies that will report second-quarter earnings this week and next.

headline: Giffords Race Lacks Only the Candidate

headline: Glaad Report Likes ABC Family Values
summary: An annual report by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation commended the ABC Family cable channel for its representation of gay, lesbian and bisexual characters in its programming and for the racial diversity of those characters. In its fifth annual Network Responsibility Index, which Glaad issued on Wednesday, the organization gave a rating of “Excellent” to ABC Family, whose shows include “Pretty Little Liars,” “The Secret Life of the American Teenager,” “Greek” and “Switched at Birth,” and said that 55 percent of that channel’s 103 hours of original programming from June 2010 through May 2011 included “LGBT-inclusive images.” Herndon Graddick, the senior director of programs at Glaad, said in a statement, “Viewers expect to see television environments that accurately reflect what it’s like to be a young adult, and today that includes young adults who happen to be gay.”

headline: CBS Invites Viewers to Help Fill ‘Big Brother’ Vacancies
summary: “Big Brother” on CBS claimed the top spot for total viewers in prime time among programs on the broadcast networks Thursday night, and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million viewers tuning in according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the “Big Brother” household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows’ long-in-the-tooth format.  Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted resident, and the person with the most votes will get the chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, averaging around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers thanks to its reality competitions, “Wipeout” (6.6 million viewers) and “Expedition Impossible.” (4.8 million).

According to Nielsen data, 1.8 million total viewers watched the episode — a 9 percent increase over the same point from last season. That continues an overall trend for the year that suggests a slowly growing audience. But how will viewers (and potential viewers) approach the show now that the end for Walter White is officially in sight?

headline: A Ratings Victory for Fox Football
summary: Another nationally televised preseason National Football League game, another victory in the ratings. The nastiness caused by the owners' lockout does not appear to have dimmed football fans' ardor for the game, even for preseason games. The Fox telecast of the the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles exhibition game drew an estimated average of 8.7 million viewers in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. hour and 9.1 million during the the rest of prime time. The broadcast was up 45 percent compared to a game last year at this time, and helped Fox win a night when its stiffest competition was "Big Brother" on CBS (8 million total viewers) and both NBC and the CW were in repeats.

headline: N.F.L. Season Opener Kicks Off NBC’s Ratings

headline: N.F.L. Season Opener Kicks Off NBC's Ratings
summary: While the final outcome of the National Football League season opener on Thursday between the Green Bay Packers and the New Orleans Saints was in doubt until the end, what was never in doubt was the ratings dominance the N.F.L. would give NBC. (The Packers ultimately won the game, 42-34.) According to Nielsen estimates, an average of 27.2 million total viewers tuned in for the game. It was the second-most-watched N.F.L. opener of all time, trailing only last season's Brett Favre-enhanced contest between the Minnesota Vikings and The Saints.  CBS, which was led by "Big Brother" at 9 p.m. with 6.5 million viewers, came in far behind NBC for second place among the broadcast networks.

headline: Women's Scheduling Draws Criticism
summary: Vocal complaints lodged by several top men's players about scheduling at the 2011 U.S. Open resulted in dramatic schedule changes, giving the men more rest between matches that might have otherwise been closer together due to rain interruption earlier in the week. But while the men were appeased, the four women who had advanced to the semifinals were done few favors by the revised schedule.

headline: Repeal Day: The End of 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
summary: Which new TV shows are worth a try? Which returning ones deserve a second look? The New York Times critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger were discussing all things television Thursday afternoon with Times readers. Mr. Genzlinger, wondering if he needs a therapist, or perhaps a priest, or maybe a neurosurgeon, reported that two of his favorite new shows so far this season were aimed at demographics that he is decidedly not in: "The Secret Circle" on CW, and "2 Broke Girls" on CBS. But to Mr. Hale those choices were perfectly understandable.

headline: 'X Factor' Holds Steady in the Ratings
summary: The ratings for "The X Factor" premiere on Wednesday may not have met expectations, but the second episode last night at least held steady. With 12.5 million viewers, the overall ratings matched the debut episode, while the 18-to-49-year-old audience dropped off by just 2 percent. It was enough to give Fox a victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49 demographic for the night, representing Fox's first ratings win ever for a Thursday during premiere week. CBS once again finished first in total viewers, led by two episodes of "Big Bang Theory" (averaging 14.4 million viewers) and its new drama "Person of Interest" (13.2 million), according to Nielsen data. However, "Person of Interest" fell in its second half-hour and was fourth in the 18-to-49 category for its 9 p.m. time slot, behind "X-Factor," "Grey's Anatomy" on ABC and "Whitney" on NBC.

headline: Scripted Drama Can't Touch Football's Supremacy

Among scripted entertainment shows, the series premiere of "Pan Am" on ABC took off with 10.9 million total viewers, a higher total audience than its lead in, "Desperate Housewives" (9.8 million viewers). A new timeslot and an Emmy win for Julianna Margulies (not to mention a dynamite new haircut, with bangs) did not translate to a ratings increase for "The Good Wife" on CBS. That legal drama attracted 10.5 million viewers, down from 12.9 million for last season's premiere episode.

That was enough to earn Zooey Deschanel, who plays the “adorkable” Jess, and her colleagues the embrace of the network, as Bill Carter reported on Media Decoder: “The network ordered 11 more episodes, for a total 24 for the year, a signal that it wants as much ‘New Girl’ as it can possibly get.”

headline: N.F.L. Carries NBC in Sunday Night Ratings
summary: For one night of the week at least, NBC has little to worry about regarding its broadcast schedule: the National Football League continues to save the network from what has so far been a dismal fall season. The Baltimore Ravens defeated the Jets, 34-17, on "Sunday Night Football" to give NBC a ratings win in all viewership categories. Final audience numbers were not available on Monday afternoon. CBS finished second over all with new episodes of "The Amazing Race" and "The Good Wife," though the numbers were skewed higher because of N.F.L. coverage overruns across the country. On ABC, "Pan Am" quickly lost altitude; it averaged 7.75 million total viewers in its second week, down more than 3 million from the series premiere.

headline: The Price of Running Late, Part 1

headline: Exit the Curmudgeon
summary: Have you ever wondered what Sundays would be like without Andy Rooney on "60 Minutes," inveighing against all manner of injustices and irritants, from the near-cosmic to the barely worth mentioning? If you have, and even if you haven't, you are about to find out. On Sunday night, Mr. Rooney delivered his last philippic after 33 years as a regular contributor to the CBS newsmagazine.

headline: No Sheen, No Problem for 'Two and a Half Men'
summary: While the initial curiosity behind a Charlie Sheen-less "Two and a Half Men" seems to be fading, the CBS comedy was still able to reach 17.3 million viewers on Monday night, narrowly beating ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" (16.5 million) as the most-watched program. On Fox, "Terra Nova" retained 100 percent of its premiere 18-to-49-year-old audience, a fantastic sign for the expensive sci-fi program. Meanwhile, the fall season had its first network casualty on Tuesday when NBC announced that it had canceled "The Playboy Club" after its third episode fell to just 3.4 million viewers.

And 12.3 percent of the participating readers correctly predicted that show would last only three episodes.

headline: Polls Reveal Americans’ Doubts About Afghan War

headline: 'New Girl' on Fox Keeps Drawing Viewers
summary: It may be just the third week of the fall TV season, but the Tuesday night programming slate has already settled into a ratings groove. Once a wild card, "New Girl" on Fox is now a mainstay thanks to a full-season pickup last week and its continued perch atop the 18-to-49-year-old demographic ratings. The comedy, which stars Zooey Deschanel, lifted Fox to another overall Tuesday night win in that category. "NCIS," meanwhile, fulfilled the same role it has for the last nine seasons on CBS, gathering the largest possible audience (18.9 million total viewers) while posting respectable numbers in the 18-to-49 category. The one question mark: Sarah Michelle Gellar may have to go back to vampire-slaying: her new show "Ringer" on CW dropped another 33 percent in what was already a dismal 18-to-49 rating. It averaged 1.5 million viewers.

headline: ‘New Girl’ on Fox Keeps Drawing Viewers
summary: That sitcom is leading the way in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic among broadcast networks on Tuesday nights.

headline: Going Retro to Catch Phillies Fever; Granderson’s Catches Worth a Replay

headline: Polls Reveal Americans' Doubts About Afghan War
summary: As the war in Afghanistan reaches its 10th anniversary, two national surveys reveal an American public that thinks the United States should not be fighting in Afghanistan and the war has not been worth it. And a survey of military veterans examines the attitudes of those who have served both before and since Sept. 11, finding high levels of pride in their service with less certainty about American military efforts in Afghanistan.

headline: Viewers Not Scared to Watch 'American Horror Story'
summary: Coming a mere 48 hours after the cancellation of "The Playboy Club," NBC announced on Thursday that another freshman entry, "Free Agents," will get the axe after only four episodes. The comedy could only muster 3.3 million total viewers on Wednesday. No replacement has been announced to occupy its 8:30 timeslot. Elsewhere, "The X Factor" transitioned nicely to the "Boot Camp" portion of its competition, roping in 11.5 million total viewers and winning the night for Fox in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic by retaining 100 percent of that demographic when compared to the 90-minute episode that aired last Thursday. CBS was once again the most-watched network with "Criminal Minds" (13.3 million viewers) leading the way.

It was the most-watched League Division Series game in cable history and the most-watched Division Series game on either network TV or cable since 2005.

headline: CBS Is Top Network Standing
summary: So far, CBS has done pretty well for itself over the course of this still-young fall season. How well? According to Nielsen ratings data from Sept. 19 through Oct. 9, CBS has 20 of the top 30 shows among the broadcast networks in total viewership, making CBS the first network to accomplish such a feat. It was also the number one network in average viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Stalwarts "NCIS" and "NCIS: LA" certainly helped the network's cause on Tuesday, garnering 18.7 million viewers and 15.4 million respectively, although the two dramas hit season lows in the 18-to-49 demo. If it can hold steady, ABC will have a new entry in the top 30 with the new Tim Allen comedy "Last Man Standing." The two-episode series premiere was sampled by nearly 13 million total viewers.

headline: CBS Is Top Network Standing
summary: CBS has 20 of the top 30 shows among the broadcast networks in total viewership.

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
summary: Now that viewers have gotten a look at most of the new shows this season, the fall television picture is becoming clearer: sitcoms like "New Girl" (with Zooey Deschanel) and "2 Broke Girls" (with Kat Dennings) have gotten votes of confidence, Tim Allen's "Last Man Standing" earned a spot in the Top 30, while "H8R," "Free Agents" and "How to Be a Gentleman" are out or on their way. Did these shows deserve their fates, for better or worse? Speaking of comedies, HBO unveiled "Enlightened" and came back with a new season of "Bored to Death" and a male breast-feeding scene. Has HBO finally gone too far? The television critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger have posted answers to your questions and comments.

headline: Thank You, Supercommittee
summary: Whenever people worry that the American electorate has become hopelessly divided, I like to point out that we're remarkably united on at least one issue: Everyone dislikes Congress. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that only 9 percent of Americans approve of the way lawmakers are handling their jobs. And more than four out of five Republicans, Democrats, and Independents actively disapprove. (President Obama's 46 percent approval rating looks like massive support by comparison.)

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 14
summary: Steven Levy of Wired magazine profiles Jeff Bezos as Amazon ships its first Kindle Fire tablets today. The piece sets up Amazon vs. Apple. "Apple is fundamentally a hardware company - 91 percent of its revenue comes from sales of its coveted machines, compared to just 6 percent from iTunes," he writes. "Amazon, on the other hand, is a content-focused company - almost half of its revenue comes from sales of media like books, music, TV shows, and movies - and the fire-sale-priced Fire is designed to be primarily a passport to the large amount of that content that's available digitally." [Wired]

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 16
summary: The day after the nighttime raid that cleared protesters from Zuccotti Park, the New York Police Department was criticized by local politicians and news organizations for its treatment of reporters and the restrictions it placed on how they do their work. The Associated Press reported that at least half a dozen reporters were arrested in and around the park, home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, including a reporter and photographer from the agency. Michael Oreskes, senior managing editor for The A.P., said: "Journalists should not be restricted from access to news events or detained for attempting to do their jobs. We were unhappy that two of our staff members were swept up in the police operation, but we appreciate the N.Y.P.D.'s decision to release them."

With its range of TV and radio stations, CBS could collect as much as $250 million of the estimated $2.4 billion that is expected to be generated by political campaigns across the country, The Times wrote. Such sums have only grown larger because of a 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions.

A new episode of "Modern Family" led the way, with 12.6 million total viewers, followed by "The Middle," at 9.1 million, according to Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, a special Wednesday live results episode of "The X Factor" drew 8.5 million total viewers and put Fox in second place for the night in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS was in third place with a slate of repeats and a recap episode of "Survivor: South Pacific."

New episodes of "Terra Nova" and "House" on Fox made only slight gains compared to last week against the weakened competition, with 7.2 million total viewers and 7.3 million respectively. ABC's presentation of "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" drew 7.7 million viewers.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 1
summary: The rapper Kanye West received the most nominations for the 54th Annual Grammy Awards during a ceremony broadcast on Wednesday night on CBS, but it was the pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars who dominated the Song of the Year, Record of the Year and Album of the Year nominations, The ArtsBeat blog reported. Adele, the British soul singer, received six nominations for her album "21," which included the hit "Rolling in the Deep." (Her singing voice has been temporarily silenced by vocal cord surgery, and it is not clear, The Los Angeles Times reported, whether Adele will have recovered sufficiently to perform when the awards are handed out on Feb. 12.) Mr. Mars also received six nominations, three for "Grenade," his song about unrequited love, and three for the album "Doowops and Hooligans." Mr. West was nominated seven times based on two albums - his complex solo set "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" and his collaboration with Jay-Z, "Watch the Throne." Both were left off the Album of the Year list, but were nominated for Rap Album of the Year. (The snub of MBDTF, as Mr. West's album is known, was certainly the hot topic on Twitter.)

headline: Andrew Kazdin, Record Producer, Dies at 77

headline: European Inquiry Focuses On Setting of E-Book Prices
summary: BRUSSELS -- The European antitrust authority said Tuesday that it was investigating possible collusion between Apple and five large publishing houses in the growing market for electronic books. The European Commission said that Apple might have helped imprints like Penguin, owned by Pearson of Britain, and HarperCollins, owned by News Corporation of the United States, engage in ''anticompetitive practices affecting the sale of e-books.''

headline: Gingrich Gains Favor in Iowa, New Poll Finds
summary: DES MOINES -- Newt Gingrich enters the final four weeks of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses with Republican voters in the state viewing him as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, more attuned to their concerns and just as capable of defeating President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Mr. Gingrich is rated more favorably than any of the other six remaining candidates in the race among voters who say they are likely to attend the Republican caucuses in Iowa. He would be supported enthusiastically as his party's presidential nominee by more voters than any of his rivals, the poll found, and is leading in the head-to-head competition as the campaign here builds.

headline: Christie Stumps for Romney at Iowa Event
summary: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa - Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey brought his national popularity and political clout to a small rally in a business park here on Wednesday to pitch a message for Mitt Romney, calling him "the most qualified person to be president" and "the only Republican who can win."

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted with 642 likely Republican caucusgoers throughout Iowa from Nov. 30 to Dec. 5. The sample of telephone numbers called consisted mostly of those selected randomly by a computer from a complete list of registered voters. Registered Republicans who voted in the 2010 general election were selected at a slightly higher rate. Registered Democrats and registered voters classified as ''inactive'' were excluded.

headline: A Good Night for Fox Despite Little Joy From 'Glee'

"Glee" drew 7.1 million total viewers, a far cry from the 11.1 million that tuned in to a comparable episode a year ago, while "New Girl" fell to 6.8 million viewers, a series low. CBS finished first in total viewers, with repeats from its "NCIS" franchise.

Based on the talks there, "marketers remain keen on buying commercial time during video programming despite the uncertain outlook for the economy." Spending on TV ads around the world next year will increase 6.7 percent from 2011, said one forecaster, Vincent Létang, as compared with a predicted overall 5 percent increase in advertising. (Online ads will have the greatest growth, he predicted, 11.2 percent.)

headline: A Year-End Candidate for a 10 Worst List

It wasn't the dumbest thing I've ever done, not by a long shot. But there are good reasons why, slightly more than a decade or two later, I haven't repeated the experience. New Year's Eve can be tough enough. Why make matters worse by standing for hours in the cold, packed together with thousands upon thousands of strangers?

headline: Univision Finds Ratings Success

headline: Explaining Tonight's Polls
summary: Within an hour or so, we'll be getting results about Iowa voters' preferences from interviews that are known as "entrance polls" -- similar to the exit polls conducted for primaries in other states. Edison Research of Somerville, N.J. stations interviewers at a random number of caucus sites, and they ask voters before they head inside to fill out questionnaires about their choices for a presidential candidate, and their positions on other issues.

headline: Fewer Viewers Check Out 'The Bachelor' on ABC
summary: Could the television broadcast audience be growing less susceptible to the charms of "The Bachelor" on ABC? The season premiere of the series averaged 7.7 million total viewers over a two-hour period on Monday night, according to Nielsen data, down from the 9 million viewers who watched the 15th-season premiere last January. There was also a 17 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last year. This placed ABC a distant second in the overall ratings among the broadcast networks, behind the CBS Monday comedy block. CBS finished No. 1 in all ratings categories in every prime-time half-hour.

headline: A Date for the Tony Awards

The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30.

Fox was first in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, as "New Girl" was the highest-rated program of the night in that category. headline: Pro Bowl Helps NBC in Ratings
summary: NBC's coverage of the 2012 N.F.L. Pro Bowl drew a decent number of fans on Sunday as the American Football Conference defeated the National Football Conference 59-41, though not nearly enough to dominate the overall broadcast network ratings. NBC was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates, and it finished second in total viewers with 10.7 million, just behind CBS (11.4 million). Those two networks were close enough in total viewers that NBC might yet squeak by when the final numbers are released. "Undercover Boss" had the largest audience for CBS, at 13.1 million total viewers. On ABC, "Once Upon a Time" continued to perform well - especially for a freshman drama - with its highest audience total since November (10.8 million).

Seems like a perfectly nice fella. If Gingrich hates him, I think I'll vote for Mitt."

headline: The Empire Strikes Back

Davis's faux concern about "privacy laws at work here" is, of course, designed to make it appear that the N.C.A.A. actually cares about an athlete's privacy. As is Emmert's line at the end about how "you have to respect the privacy of others." What a joke.

headline: 'Big Bang' on CBS Holds On Despite Fox's 'Idol' Comeback
summary: The broadcast networks took an all-hands-on-deck approach to the first night of February sweeps on Thursday and gave television viewers a full slate of new content. Based on preliminary Nielsen ratings, the top choice was once again "The Big Bang Theory" on CBS as it finished with a higher rating than "American Idol" in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the third week in a row.  The good news for Fox was that "Idol" at least momentarily put a stop to its recent ratings slide, down only slightly among adults 18-to-49, and even gained back total viewers when compared to last week with an average of 17.1 million. It was still down 28 percent in the 18-to-49 category from the same Thursday episode last year.

headline: The Grammys: Does Anyone Stand a Chance Against Adele?

This British belter, a critical favorite and seller of more than 7.5 million records (hard copies and digital) in the United States alone last year, will surprise almost no one if she sweeps the big awards on Sunday, including Album, Record, Song and Artist of the Year. She is also doubling as perhaps the most anticipated young performer at the Feb. 12 Grammy ceremony, to be broadcast on CBS. That is, depending on how you feel about Chris Brown.

headline: CBS Threatens ABC Over Reality Show
summary: Lawsuits over copycatting in reality television have gone nowhere in the past, but CBS has suggested to ABC that it may consider one over a summer show called ''Glass House.'' The format is similar to CBS's long-running summer series ''Big Brother,'' and ABC has hired many former production members from that show. On Friday CBS sent a sternly worded letter to ABC about it. The letter implies, without directly saying so, that CBS will sue ABC over copyright infringement. The letter said that CBS was ''putting ABC on notice that its continued development and production of 'Glass House' exposes ABC to liability.'' The letter said the elements of the new show are ''substantially and strikingly'' similar to ''Big Brother.'' In ''Glass House,'' which has its debut on June 18, 14 people are chosen to live in a house all summer with cameras on them in pursuit of a cash prize -- the essence of ''Big Brother'' competition. In the past copyright cases have proved nearly impossible for reality-show plaintiffs to win because, in simple terms, everybody's reality is inherently different. The total number of former staff members on ''Glass House'' is at least 18, according to the CBS letter, all of whom signed nondisclosure agreements when they worked for ''Big Brother.'' The CBS letter argued that it would be impossible for anyone who signed such a letter to help produce a similar show without breaching the agreement. ABC had yet to respond to the CBS letter or requests for comment by Sunday afternoon.
